title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
In the realm of experimental design and statistical analysis, Nested Models are indispensable for handling data with hierarchical or grouped structures. These models are particularly useful when the levels of one factor are only meaningful within the levels of another factor. Understanding nested models allows researchers to account for variability at different levels, ensuring more accurate and generalizable inferences.
Intuitive Analogy:
Consider a university conducting a study on student performance across different courses. Here, courses can be nested within departments, meaning each course belongs to only one department. This hierarchical structure necessitates a nested model to appropriately account for the variability both within and between departments.


By the end of this lecture, you will be able to:

Recognize and model nested factors.
Differentiate between nested and crossed factors.
Formulate fixed and random nested models.
Apply variance components and hypothesis tests to nested designs.
Implement nested models using R.
Engage with advanced mathematical concepts through proofs and derivations.
Enhance your understanding through practical R examples and exercises.

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
In the realm of experimental design and statistical analysis, Nested Models are indispensable for handling data with hierarchical or grouped structures. These models are particularly useful when the levels of one factor are only meaningful within the levels of another factor. Understanding nested models allows researchers to account for variability at different levels, ensuring more accurate and generalizable inferences.
Intuitive Analogy:
Consider a university conducting a study on student performance across different courses. Here, courses can be nested within departments, meaning each course belongs to only one department. This hierarchical structure necessitates a nested model to appropriately account for the variability both within and between departments.


By the end of this lecture, you will be able to:

Recognize and model nested factors.
Differentiate between nested and crossed factors.
Formulate fixed and random nested models.
Apply variance components and hypothesis tests to nested designs.
Implement nested models using R.
Engage with advanced mathematical concepts through proofs and derivations.
Enhance your understanding through practical R examples and exercises.

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
Nested vs.Â Crossed Factors

Nested Factors
Definition:
Nested factors occur when the levels of one factor are exclusively contained within the levels of another factor. Each level of the nested factor appears only within one level of the parent factor.
Examples:

Cores within Bales: In wool experiments, multiple cores are sampled from each bale. Here, cores are nested within bales.
Heads within Machines: When evaluating machine performance, different heads are used within each machine, and each head is specific to a machine.

Visual Representation:
Machine 1
â”œâ”€â”€ Head 1
â”œâ”€â”€ Head 2
Machine 2
â”œâ”€â”€ Head 1
â”œâ”€â”€ Head 2
â”œâ”€â”€ Head 3
â€¦


Crossed Factors
Definition:
Crossed factors are those where every level of one factor appears with every level of another factor. There is no hierarchical containment, and levels are fully crossed.
Examples:

Treatments across Blocks: Applying multiple treatments across all blocks in an experiment.
Students and Teachers: If every teacher instructs every student, factors are crossed.

Visual Representation:
Teacher 1
â”œâ”€â”€ Student 1
â”œâ”€â”€ Student 2
Teacher 2
â”œâ”€â”€ Student 1
â”œâ”€â”€ Student 2
â€¦


Applications of Nested Models

Manufacturing: Assessing variability of machine components within different machines.
Biological Studies: Measuring responses of plants within different plots.
Educational Research: Evaluating student performance within classrooms and schools.

Reference:
Dean, A., Voss, D., & DraguljiÄ‡, D. (2017). Design and Analysis of Experiments. Springer.

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
Fixed-Effects Nested Model
A Fixed-Effects Nested Model is used when both the parent and nested factors are of primary interest and their effects are fixed.

Model Specification
\[
Y_{ijt} = \mu + \alpha_i + \beta_j(i) + \epsilon_{ijt}, \quad \epsilon_{ijt} \sim N(0, \sigma^2)
\]
Where:

\(Y_{ijt}\): Response for the \(t\)-th observation in the \(j\)-th nested factor within the \(i\)-th parent factor.
\(\mu\): Overall mean.
\(\alpha_i\): Fixed effect of the \(i\)-th level of Factor \(A\) (parent factor).
\(\beta_j(i)\): Fixed effect of the \(j\)-th level of Factor \(B\) nested within Factor \(A\).
\(\epsilon_{ijt}\): Random error.

Intuitive Example:
Evaluating the performance of different machine heads within specific machines, where both machines and heads are of fixed interest.

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
Random-Effects Nested Model
A Random-Effects Nested Model treats the nested factors as random effects, assuming they are randomly sampled from a larger population.

Model Specification
\[
Y_{ijt} = \mu + \alpha_i + B_j(i) + \epsilon_{ijt}, \quad B_j(i) \sim N(0, \sigma^2_B), \quad \epsilon_{ijt} \sim N(0, \sigma^2)
\]
Where:

\(B_j(i)\): Random effect for the \(j\)-th level of Factor \(B\) nested within Factor \(A\).
\(\sigma^2_B\): Variance component for the nested random effect.
\(\sigma^2\): Residual error variance.

Intuitive Example:
Assessing the variability of machine heads across randomly selected machines from a factory population.
Reference:
Montgomery, D. C., & Runger, G. C. (2010). Applied Statistics and Probability for Engineers. Wiley.

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
Expected Mean Squares
In random-effects nested models, the Expected Mean Squares (EMS) are pivotal for estimating variance components. EMS are derived based on the modelâ€™s structure and assumptions.

EMS for Fixed-Effects Nested Model
Given the model:
\[
Y_{ijt} = \mu + \alpha_i + \beta_j(i) + \epsilon_{ijt}
\]
Expected Mean Squares:
\[
EMS_A = \sigma^2 + r \sigma^2_B + r b Q(\alpha_i)
\]
\[
EMS_B(A) = \sigma^2 + r \sigma^2_B
\]
\[
EMS_E = \sigma^2
\]
Where:

\(r\): Number of replicates per nested factor.
\(b\): Number of levels of Factor \(B\) within each level of Factor \(A\).
\(Q(\alpha_i)\): Sum of squares of fixed effects.

Reference:
Christensen, R. (2018). Analysis of Variance, Design, and Regression. Chapman and Hall/CRC.


Estimation of Variance Components
Using the EMS, variance components are estimated as follows:
\[
\hat{\sigma}^2_B = \frac{MS_B(A) - MS_E}{r}
\]
\[
\hat{\sigma}^2 = MS_E
\]
Where:

\(MS_B(A)\): Mean Square for the nested factor.
\(MS_E\): Mean Square for the error term.

Step-by-Step Example:
Suppose we have:

\(a = 5\) levels of Factor \(A\).
\(b = 4\) levels of Factor \(B\) nested within each \(A\).
\(r = 3\) replicates per \(B\).

An ANOVA table would provide \(MS_A\), \(MS_B(A)\), and \(MS_E\), from which variance components are estimated.

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
section: Example 1: Machine Heads Nested in Machines
text:
Example 1: Machine Heads Nested in Machines
Scenario:
Assessing the performance of machine heads nested within machines to understand variability attributable to different machines.

Step-by-Step R Implementation

# Load necessary library
library(lme4)
# Simulated Data
set.seed(123)
machines <- factor(rep(1:5, each = 20))
heads <- factor(rep(rep(1:4, each = 5), 5))
response <- rnorm(100, mean = as.numeric(machines) + as.numeric(heads) / 2, sd = 1)
data <- data.frame(response, machines, heads) # Fit Random-Effects Nested Model
model <- lmer(response ~ (1 | machines / heads), data = data)
summary(model)

# Extract Variance Components
VarCorr(model)

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
Interpretation

Model Fitting:

The lmer function fits a random-intercept model where heads are nested within machines.

Summary Output:

Provides estimates for the fixed effect (overall mean) and random effects (variance components for machines and heads).

Variance Components:


machines: Variability attributable to different machines.
heads within machines: Variability attributable to different heads within the same machine.
Residual: Unexplained variability.

Reference:
Kempthorne, O. (1977). Design and Analysis of Experiments. Robert E. Krieger Publishing Company.

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
Example 2: Nested Design ANOVA

Scenario
Analyzing a nested design using traditional ANOVA methods.
Step-by-Step R Implementation

# Nested ANOVA with aov
model_aov <- aov(response ~ machines + Error(machines / heads), data = data)
summary(model_aov)

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
Interpretation

Model Fitting:

The aov function specifies heads nested within machines using the Error term.

ANOVA Summary:

Displays sources of variation, degrees of freedom, sum of squares, mean squares, and F-values for both machines and heads within machines.

Hypothesis Testing:


Machines: Tests if there is significant variability between different machines.
Heads within Machines: Tests if there is significant variability between different heads within the same machine.

Reference:
ScheffÃ©, H. (1959). The Analysis of Variance. Wiley.

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
Degrees of Freedom
In nested designs, allocating degrees of freedom correctly is crucial for accurate hypothesis testing.
Calculation for Nested Effects
For a nested effect \(B(A)\):
\[
\nu_{B(A)} = (b - 1) \times a
\]
Where:

\(b\): Number of levels of Factor (B) within each level of Factor (A).
\(a\): Number of levels of Factor (A).

Example:
If there are 5 machines (\(a = 5\)) and 4 heads within each machine (\(b = 4\)), then:
\[
\nu_{B(A)} = (4 - 1) \times 5 = 15
\]
Reference:
Dean, A., Voss, D., & DraguljiÄ‡, D. (2017). Design and Analysis of Experiments. Springer.

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
Estimable Contrasts
In nested models, contrasts within nested factors are restricted to comparisons within each level of the parent factor.

Constructing Contrasts

Within-Machine Contrasts: Compare different heads within the same machine.
Between-Machine Contrasts: Compare different machines, irrespective of heads.



Example
Comparing the performance of Head 1 vs.Â Head 2 within Machine 3.
Reference:
Christensen, R. (2018). Analysis of Variance, Design, and Regression. Chapman and Hall/CRC.

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
Summary

Nested Models are essential for analyzing data with hierarchical or grouped structures.
Fixed-Effects Nested Models focus on specific levels of factors, providing detailed insights into those particular levels.
Random-Effects Nested Models generalize findings to larger populations by treating nested factors as random samples.
Variance Components quantify the variability at different hierarchical levels, facilitating a deeper understanding of data structure.
R Implementation using packages like lme4 and functions like aov allows for flexible modeling of nested designs.
Advanced Topics such as degrees of freedom allocation and estimable contrasts ensure rigorous statistical analysis.
Mathematical Derivations in the appendix provide a theoretical foundation, enhancing comprehension of underlying principles.

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
Key Takeaways

Properly modeling nested structures is crucial for accurate inference.
Differentiating between fixed and random effects guides appropriate model selection.
Understanding variance components aids in dissecting sources of variability.
Practical R examples bridge the gap between theory and application, fostering hands-on learning.

Reference:
Montgomery, D. C., & Runger, G. C. (2010). Applied Statistics and Probability for Engineers. Wiley.

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
Variance Component Estimation

Deriving Expected Mean Squares for Nested Models
Consider the Fixed-Effects Nested Model:
\[
Y_{ijt} = \mu + \alpha_i + \beta_j(i) + \epsilon_{ijt}, \quad \epsilon_{ijt} \sim N(0, \sigma^2)
\]


Expected Mean Squares

For Factor (A):

\[
EMS_A = \sigma^2 + r \sigma^2_B + r b Q(\alpha_i)
\]
Where \(Q(\alpha_i)\) is the sum of squares due to Factor (A).

For Factor (B(A)):

\[
EMS_B(A) = \sigma^2 + r \sigma^2_B
\]

For Error:

\[
EMS_E = \sigma^2
\]

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
Derivation Steps

Assumptions:


\(\alpha_i\) and \(\beta_j(i)\) are fixed effects.
Errors are independent and normally distributed.


Variance Components:


Between (A) Groups: Variance due to Factor (A) is zero since (A) is fixed.
Between (B(A)) Groups: Variance due to Factor (B) nested within (A) is \(\sigma^2_B\).
Within (B(A)) Groups: Residual variance is \(\sigma^2\).


Estimation:


Using the ANOVA table, mean squares are equated to expected mean squares to solve for variance components.

\[
MS_A = \sigma^2 + r \sigma^2_B
\]
\[
MS_B(A) = \sigma^2 + r \sigma^2_B
\]
\[
MS_E = \sigma^2
\]
Solving for \(\sigma^2_B\):
\[
\hat{\sigma}^2_B = \frac{MS_A - MS_E}{r}
\]
\[
\hat{\sigma}^2 = MS_E
\]

Conclusion
The derivation showcases how ANOVA decomposes total variability into components attributable to nested factors and residual error, facilitating the estimation of variance components.
Reference:
Montgomery, D. C., & Runger, G. C. (2010). Applied Statistics and Probability for Engineers. Wiley.

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
Satterthwaite Approximation
The Satterthwaite Approximation is employed to estimate the degrees of freedom for variance components, enabling the construction of confidence intervals.

Steps

Estimate Variance Components:

Using REML or other estimation methods, obtain estimates for \(\sigma^2_B\) and \(\sigma^2\).

Calculate Degrees of Freedom:

Approximated based on the variance component estimates.

Construct Confidence Intervals:

\[
CI = \hat{\sigma}^2 \pm t_{\alpha/2, df} \times SE(\hat{\sigma}^2)
\]
Where:

\(\hat{\sigma}^2\): Estimated variance component.
\(t_{\alpha/2, df}\): Critical value from the t-distribution.
\(SE(\hat{\sigma}^2)\): Standard error of the variance component estimate.

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
Example in R

# Fit the Model

model <- lmer(response ~ (1 | machines / heads), data = data)
# Extract variance Components
var_components <- VarCorr(model)
sigma_B_sq <- as.numeric(var_components$machines:heads)
sigma_sq <- attr(var_components, "sc")^2
# Confidence Intervals Using Wald Method
confint(model, parm = "sigma_B_sq", method = "Wald")
confint(model, parm = "sigma_sq", method = "Wald")


Interpretation
The confint function provides confidence intervals for the variance components, allowing for inference about population variability.
Reference:
Christensen, R. (2018). Analysis of Variance, Design, and Regression. Chapman and Hall/CRC.

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text: Medium Difficulty

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
1. Two-Way ANCOVA with Interaction
Dataset: Simulate a dataset with three treatments and one covariate.
Tasks:

Generate data for treatments A, B, C with a covariate (X).
Fit an ANCOVA model adjusting for (X).
Test the significance of treatment effects and the covariate.
Generate diagnostic plots and interpret them.

R Code Example:

set.seed(123)
# Define Factors and Covariate
Treatment <- factor(rep(c("A", "B", "C"), each = 30))
X <- rnorm(90, mean = 50, sd = 10)
# Simulate Responses with Treatment Effects and Covariate EffectY <- 5 + ifelse(Treatment == "A", 0, ifelse(Treatment == "B", 2, 4)) + 0.5 * (X - mean(X)) + rnorm(90, mean=0, sd=3)

data_sim <- data.frame(Treatment, X, Y)
# Fit ANCOVA Model
model_sim <- lm(Y ~ Treatment + X, data = data_sim)

summary(model_sim)

# Diagnostic Plots
par(mfrow = c(2, 2))
plot(model_sim)

# Estimated Marginal means
library(emmeans)
emm_sim <- emmeans(model_sim, ~Treatment)
pairwise_sim <- contrast(emm_sim, method = "pairwise")
summary(pairwise_sim)

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
Questions

Main Effects:


Treatment: What are the estimated effects of treatments A, B, and C?
Covariate (X): How does (X) influence the response variable (Y)?


Significance Testing:


Are the treatment effects statistically significant after adjusting for (X)?
Is the covariate (X) a significant predictor of (Y)?


Diagnostic Plots:


Do the residual plots indicate any violations of ANCOVA assumptions such as non-linearity, heteroscedasticity, or non-normality?
Are there any influential observations that may affect the modelâ€™s validity?


Interpretation of Pairwise Comparisons:


Which treatments significantly differ from each other after adjusting for (X)?
How do the adjusted means compare across treatments?

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
Expected Answers

Main Effects:


Treatment: Treatments B and C have positive effects relative to Treatment A, indicating higher response values.
Covariate (X): The covariate (X) has a positive influence on (Y), suggesting that as (X) increases, (Y) tends to increase.


Significance Testing:


Treatment Effects: If the p-values for Treatment are below the significance level (e.g., 0.05), treatments have significant effects.
Covariate (X): If the p-value for (X) is below the significance level, (X) is a significant predictor.


Diagnostic Plots:


Residuals vs.Â Fitted: Random scatter suggests homoscedasticity and linearity.
Q-Q Plot: Points close to the diagonal indicate normality of residuals.
Influential Observations: Absence of points with high leverage or large residuals indicates no influential observations.


Interpretation of Pairwise Comparisons:


Significant Differences: Significant pairwise differences indicate which specific treatments differ after adjusting for (X).
Adjusted Means: Provide a clearer comparison by accounting for the covariateâ€™s effect, highlighting the true treatment effects.

Reference:
Christensen, R. (2018). Analysis of Variance, Design, and Regression. Chapman and Hall/CRC.

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
1. Unbalanced Two-Factor ANCOVA Analysis
Dataset: Utilize a dataset with unequal numbers of replicates across treatment combinations.
Tasks:

Simulate an unbalanced dataset with two factors and one covariate.
Fit an ANCOVA model using both Type II and Type III sums of squares.
Compare the results and discuss how imbalance affects the interpretation of main and interaction effects.

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
R Code Example

library(car)
set.seed(456)

# Simulate Unbalanced Data

FactorA <- factor(rep(c("A1", "A2", "A3"), times = c(4, 6, 5)))FactorB <- factor(rep(c("B1", "B2"), each = 7, times = 2))
X <- rnorm(15, mean = 50, sd = 10)
# Simulate Responses with Treatment and Covariate EffectsY <- 5 + ifelse(FactorA == "A1", 0, ifelse(FactorA == "A2", 2, 4)) + ifelse(FactorB == "B1", 0, 3) + 0.5 * (X - mean(X)) + rnorm(15, mean=0, sd=3)

data_unbalanced <- data.frame(FactorA, FactorB, X, Y)

# Fit ANCOVA Model

fit_unbalanced <- lm(Y ~ FactorA * FactorB + X, data = data_unbalanced)
# Type II Sum of Squares

typeII <- Anova(fit_unbalanced, type = "II")

print(typeII)
# Type III Sum of Squares
typeIII <- Anova(fit_unbalanced, type = "III")
print(typeIII)

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
Discussion Points

Type II vs.Â Type III SS:


Type II: Tests main effects after accounting for other main effects but ignores interactions.
Type III: Tests main effects after accounting for all other factors, including interactions.


Impact of Imbalance:


Type II SS: Provides unbiased estimates of main effects under the assumption of no interaction.
Type III SS: Necessary when interactions are present or when the design is unbalanced, as it accounts for all factors simultaneously.


Significance of Effects:


Type II SS: May show significant main effects if thereâ€™s true variability not explained by interactions.
Type III SS: May adjust significance levels based on interactions, leading to different conclusions.


Implications for Experimental Conclusions:


Choosing SS Type: Critical for accurate inference; Type I SS is inappropriate due to dependency on factor order.
Misinterpretation Risks: Incorrect SS type can lead to misleading conclusions about factor significance and interactions.

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
Expected Insights

Type II SS: Suitable when interactions are not of primary interest, providing clear main effect interpretations.
Type III SS: Essential in unbalanced designs or when interactions are present, ensuring main effects are evaluated conditionally.
Imbalance Effects: Can distort Type I SS results, making Type II and III SS more robust alternatives in such scenarios.

Reference:
Christensen, R. (2018). Analysis of Variance, Design, and Regression. Chapman and Hall/CRC.

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
2. Three-Factor Interaction Interpretation
Dataset: Use a simulated dataset with three factors exhibiting a significant three-way interaction.
Tasks:

Simulate data with three factors and one covariate.
Fit a three-way ANCOVA model.
Visualize the three-way interaction.
Use emmeans to estimate marginal means and perform pairwise comparisons.
Explain how the three-way interaction affects the interpretation of main and two-way interactions.

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
R Code Example

library(emmeans)

library(ggplot2)

set.seed(789)# Simulate Data


FactorA <- factor(rep(c("A1", "A2", "A3"), each = 24))

FactorB <- factor(rep(c("B1", "B2"), each = 12, times = 3))

FactorC <- factor(rep(c("C1", "C2", "C3"), times = 8))

X <- rnorm(72, mean = 50, sd = 10)

# Simulate Responses with Three-way Interaction

Y <- 5 + ifelse(FactorA == "A1", 0, ifelse(FactorA == "A2", 2, 4)) + ifelse(FactorB == "B1", 0, 3) + ifelse(FactorC == "C1", 0, ifelse(FactorC == "C2", 1.5, 3)) + 0.5 * (X - mean(X)) + ifelse(FactorA == "A1" & FactorB == "B1", 0,1) +

ifelse(FactorA == "A2" & FactorB == "B2", 1, 2)) + rnorm(72, mean=0, sd=3)data_three <- data.frame(FactorA, FactorB, FactorC, X, Y)

# Fit Three-way ANCOVA Model

fit_three <- lm(Y ~ FactorA * FactorB * FactorC + X, data = data_three)

summary(fit_three)

# Plot Three-way Interaction

ggplot(data_three, aes(x=FactorA, y=Y, color=FactorB, group=FactorB)) + geom_point() + geom_line() + facet_wrap(~ FactorC) + labs(title="Three-Way Interaction Plot", x="Factor A", y="Response") + theme_minimal()# Estimated Marginal means

emm_three <- emmeans(fit_three, ~ FactorA * FactorB * FactorC)

contrast_results <- contrast(emm_three, method = "pairwise", adjust = "none")

summary(contrast_results)

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
Interpretation

Three-Way Interaction:


Visualization: Non-parallel lines across different levels of Factor C indicate a significant three-way interaction.
Statistical Significance: Significant three-way interaction in the model summary confirms that the combined effect of Factors A, B, and C deviates from additivity.


Impact on Main and Two-Way Interactions:


Main Effects: Cannot be interpreted independently as their effects depend on the levels of other factors.
Two-Way Interactions: The presence of a significant three-way interaction implies that two-way interactions also vary across the third factor.


Practical Implications:


Complex Relationships: Understanding how multiple factors interact provides deeper insights into the data.
Decision Making: Facilitates more informed decisions by recognizing nuanced effect patterns.

Reference:
Dean, Voss & DraguljiÄ‡ (2017). Design and Analysis of Experiments. Springer.

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
3. Mathematical Proof of Interaction Contrasts
Task: Derive formulas for interaction contrasts in a three-factor design and prove that they measure deviations from additivity.
Requirements:

Show how to construct interaction contrasts.
Prove that if all interaction contrasts are zero, the model is additive.

Hints:

Utilize the definitions of main effects and interaction terms.
Employ properties of linear algebra to demonstrate the relationship between interaction contrasts and additivity.
Reference Dean et al.Â (2017) and Christensen (2018) for theoretical foundations.

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
Proof Outline

Define the Three-Factor Model:

\[
Y_{ijk} = \mu + \alpha_i + \beta_j + \gamma_k + (\alpha\beta){ij} + (\alpha\gamma){ik} + (\beta\gamma){jk} + (\alpha\beta\gamma){ijk} + \epsilon_{ijk}
\]
Where \(\sum \alpha_i = \sum \beta_j = \sum \gamma_k = 0\).

Construct Interaction Contrasts:


Two-Way Interactions:
\((\alpha\beta)*{ij}\): Measures the interaction between Factors A and B.
Similarly for \((\alpha\gamma){ik}\) and \((\beta\gamma){jk}\).
Three-Way Interaction:
\((\alpha\beta\gamma)*{ijk}\): Measures the deviation from additivity among all three factors.


Prove Deviations from Additivity:


Additive Model:

If all interaction terms are zero (\((\alpha\beta){ij} = (\alpha\gamma){ik} = (\beta\gamma){jk} = (\alpha\beta\gamma){ijk} = 0\)), the model simplifies to:
\[
Y_{ijk} = \mu + \alpha_i + \beta_j + \gamma_k + \epsilon_{ijk}
\]
This represents a purely additive model where the combined effect of factors is the sum of their individual effects.

Non-Additive Model:

If any of the interaction terms are non-zero, the model deviates from additivity, indicating that the effect of one factor depends on the levels of other factors.

Conclusion:

Interaction contrasts (\((\alpha\beta){ij}\), \((\alpha\gamma){ik}\), \((\beta\gamma){jk}\), and \((\alpha\beta\gamma){ijk}\)) measure the extent to which the observed responses deviate from an additive model. Non-zero contrasts signify the presence of interactions, emphasizing the importance of considering these higher-order effects in experimental analysis.
Reference:
Dean, Voss & DraguljiÄ‡ (2017). Design and Analysis of Experiments. Springer.

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
Adjusted Treatment Means
The Adjusted Mean for treatment (i) accounts for the influence of blocking factors, providing a more accurate estimate of the treatment effect.
\[
\mu + \tau_i = \bar{Y}_i - \beta (\bar{X}_i - \bar{X})
\]
Where:

\(\mu\): Overall mean.
\(\tau_i\): Treatment effect for treatment (i).
\(\bar{Y}_i\): Mean response for treatment (i).
\(\beta\): Regression coefficient for the covariate.
\(\bar{X}_i\): Mean covariate value for treatment (i).
\(\bar{X}\): Overall mean of the covariate.

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
Derivation

Model Equation:

\[
Y_{ij} = \mu + \tau_i + \beta (X_{ij} - \bar{X}) + \epsilon_{ij}
\]

Taking the Mean for Treatment (i):

\[
\bar{Y}_i = \mu + \tau_i + \beta (\bar{X}_i - \bar{X}) + \bar{\epsilon}_i
\]
Since \(\bar{\epsilon}_i = 0\) (assuming errors have mean zero),
\[
\bar{Y}_i = \mu + \tau_i + \beta (\bar{X}_i - \bar{X})
\]

Solving for Adjusted Mean:

\[
\mu + \tau_i = \bar{Y}_i - \beta (\bar{X}_i - \bar{X})
\]
This equation represents the adjusted treatment mean, accounting for differences in the covariate.
Reference:
Montgomery, D. C., & Runger, G. C. (2010). Applied Statistics and Probability for Engineers. Wiley.

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
F-Test for Homogeneity of Slopes
Testing the assumption of homogeneity of regression slopes ensures that the relationship between the covariate and the response is consistent across all treatment groups.
Model Comparison

Model Without Interaction (Assuming Homogeneous Slopes):

\[
Y_{hi} = \mu + \theta_h + \tau_i + \beta X_{hi} + \epsilon_{hi}
\]

Model With Interaction (Allowing Slopes to Vary):

\[
Y_{hi} = \mu + \theta_h + \tau_i + \beta X_{hi} + (\theta \tau){hi} + \epsilon{hi}
\]
Where \((\theta \tau)_{hi}\) allows the slope of the covariate to vary with treatments.

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
Hypothesis Testing

Null Hypothesis ((H_0)): Homogeneity of slopes (\(\beta\) is the same across treatments).
Alternative Hypothesis ((H_A)): Slopes vary across treatments (\(\beta_i \neq \beta_j\) for some (i, j)).

Test Procedure

Fit Both Models:


Reduced Model: Without interaction.
Full Model: With interaction.


Compare Models Using ANOVA:


# Fit Reduced Model
model_reduced <- lm(Time ~ fColor + x, data = balloon.data)

# Fit Full Model with Interaction
model_full <- lm(Time ~ fColor * x, data = balloon.data)

# Compare Models

anova(model_reduced, model_full)


Decision Rule:


If the interaction term is significant (\(p < \alpha\)), reject (H_0) and conclude that slopes are not homogeneous.
If not significant, accept (H_0) and proceed with the reduced model.

Conclusion:
A significant interaction term indicates that the effect of the covariate varies across treatments, violating the homogeneity of slopes assumption and necessitating a more complex model.
Reference:
ScheffÃ©, H. (1959). The Analysis of Variance. Wiley.

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
Confidence Intervals for Higher-Order Contrasts
For higher-order interactions involving multiple factors, confidence intervals for contrasts provide insights into the magnitude and significance of these interactions.
Formula:
\[
CI = \hat{L} \pm t_{\alpha/2, df} \sqrt{\text{Var}(\hat{L})}
\]
Where:

\(\hat{L}\): Estimated contrast.
\(t_{\alpha/2, df}\): Critical value from the t-distribution.
\(\text{Var}(\hat{L})\): Variance of the contrast estimate.

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
Steps in R

Estimate the Contrast:

Using the emmeans package to define and estimate contrasts.

Calculate the Confidence Interval:

The emmeans package automatically provides confidence intervals when performing contrasts.

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
Example

library(emmeans)

# Fit the ANCOVA Model

model <- lm(Y ~ Treatment + X, data = data_sim)

# Define Estimated Marginal means

emm <- emmeans(model, ~ Treatment)

# Define a Contrast (e.g., Treatment B vs. Treatment A)

contrast_AB <- contrast(emm, method = "pairwise")

summary(contrast_AB, infer = TRUE)

Interpretation:
The output provides the estimated difference, standard error, t-value, and confidence interval for the contrast. If the confidence interval does not include zero, the contrast is statistically significant.
Reference:
Christensen, R. (2018). Analysis of Variance, Design, and Regression. Chapman and Hall/CRC.

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
Medium Difficulty

Two-Way ANCOVA with Interaction

Dataset: Simulate a dataset with three treatments and one covariate.
Tasks:

Generate data for treatments A, B, C with a covariate (X).
Fit an ANCOVA model adjusting for (X).
Test the significance of treatment effects and the covariate.
Generate diagnostic plots and interpret them.

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
R Code Example

set.seed(123)

# Define Factors and Covariate

Treatment <- factor(rep(c("A", "B", "C"), each=30))

X <- rnorm(90, mean=50, sd=10)

# Simulate Responses with Treatment Effects and Covariate Effect

Y <- 5 +

ifelse(Treatment == "A", 0, ifelse(Treatment == "B", 2, 4)) +

0.5 * (X - mean(X)) +

rnorm(90, mean=0, sd=3)

data_sim <- data.frame(Treatment, X, Y)

# Fit ANCOVA Model

model_sim <- lm(Y ~ Treatment + X, data = data_sim)

summary(model_sim)

# Diagnostic Plots

par(mfrow = c(2, 2))

plot(model_sim)

# Estimated Marginal means

library(emmeans)

emm_sim <- emmeans(model_sim, ~ Treatment)

pairwise_sim <- contrast(emm_sim, method = "pairwise")

summary(pairwise_sim)

text:
2. Three-Factor Interaction Interpretation
Dataset: Use a simulated dataset with three factors exhibiting a significant three-way interaction.
Tasks:

Simulate data with three factors and one covariate.

Visualize the three-way interaction.
Use emmeans to estimate marginal means and perform pairwise comparisons.
Explain how the three-way interaction affects the interpretation of main and two-way interactions.

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
R Code Example

library(emmeans)

library(ggplot2)

set.seed(789)

# Simulate Data

FactorA <- factor(rep(c("A1", "A2", "A3"), each = 24))

FactorB <- factor(rep(c("B1", "B2"), each = 12, times = 3))

FactorC <- factor(rep(c("C1", "C2", "C3"), times = 8))

X <- rnorm(72, mean = 50, sd = 10)

# Simulate Responses with Three-way Interaction

Y <- 5 +

ifelse(FactorA == "A1", 0, ifelse(FactorA == "A2", 2, 4)) +

ifelse(FactorB == "B1", 0, 3) +

ifelse(FactorC == "C1", 0, ifelse(FactorC == "C2", 1.5, 3)) +

0.5 * (X - mean(X)) +

ifelse(FactorA == "A1" & FactorB == "B1", 0,

ifelse(FactorA == "A2" & FactorB == "B2", 1, 2)) +

rnorm(72, mean=0, sd=3)

data_three <- data.frame(FactorA, FactorB, FactorC, X, Y)

# Fit Three-way ANCOVA Model

summary(fit_three)

# Plot Three-way Interaction

ggplot(data_three, aes(x=FactorA, y=Y, color=FactorB, group=FactorB)) +

geom_point() +

geom_line() +

facet_wrap(~ FactorC) +

labs(title="Three-Way Interaction Plot", x="Factor A", y="Response") +

theme_minimal()

# Estimated Marginal means

emm_three <- emmeans(fit_three, ~ FactorA * FactorB * FactorC)

contrast_results <- contrast(emm_three, method = "pairwise", adjust = "none")

summary(contrast_results)

text:

Three-Way Interaction:


Visualization: The interaction plot shows non-parallel lines across different levels of Factor C, indicating a significant three-way interaction.
Statistical Significance: The model summary reveals a significant three-way interaction, confirming that the combined effect of Factors A, B, and C is not purely additive.


Impact on Main and Two-Way Interactions:


Main Effects: Cannot be interpreted independently as their effects depend on the levels of other factors.

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
3. Mathematical Proof of Interaction Contrasts
Task: Derive formulas for interaction contrasts in a three-factor design and prove that they measure deviations from additivity.
Requirements:

Show how to construct interaction contrasts.
Prove that if all interaction contrasts are zero, the model is additive.

Hints:

Utilize the definitions of main effects and interaction terms.
Employ properties of linear algebra to demonstrate the relationship between interaction contrasts and additivity.
Reference Dean et al.Â (2017) and Christensen (2018) for theoretical foundations.

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
Proof Outline

Define the Three-Factor Model:

\[
Y_{ijk} = \mu + \alpha_i + \beta_j + \gamma_k + (\alpha\beta){ij} + (\alpha\gamma){ik} + (\beta\gamma){jk} + (\alpha\beta\gamma){ijk} + \epsilon_{ijk}
\]
Where \(\sum \alpha_i = \sum \beta_j = \sum \gamma_k = 0\).

Construct Interaction Contrasts:


Two-Way Interactions:
\((\alpha\beta)*{ij}\): Measures the interaction between Factors A and B.
Similarly for \((\alpha\gamma){ik}\) and \((\beta\gamma){jk}\).
Three-Way Interaction:
\((\alpha\beta\gamma)*{ijk}\): Measures the deviation from additivity among all three factors.


Prove Deviations from Additivity:


Additive Model:

If all interaction terms are zero (\((\alpha\beta){ij} = (\alpha\gamma){ik} = (\beta\gamma){jk} = (\alpha\beta\gamma){ijk} = 0\)), the model simplifies to:
\[
Y_{ijk} = \mu + \alpha_i + \beta_j + \gamma_k + \epsilon_{ijk}
\]
This represents a purely additive model where the combined effect of factors is the sum of their individual effects.

Non-Additive Model:

If any of the interaction terms are non-zero, the model deviates from additivity, indicating that the effect of one factor depends on the levels of other factors.

Conclusion:

Interaction contrasts (\((\alpha\beta){ij}\), \((\alpha\gamma){ik}\), \((\beta\gamma){jk}\), and \((\alpha\beta\gamma){ijk}\)) measure the extent to which the observed responses deviate from an additive model. Non-zero contrasts signify the presence of interactions, emphasizing the importance of considering these higher-order effects in experimental analysis.
Reference:
Dean, Voss & DraguljiÄ‡ (2017). Design and Analysis of Experiments. Springer.

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
section: Expected Mean Squares for Nested Models
text:
Expected Mean Squares for Nested Models
For the model \(Y_{ijt} = \mu + \alpha_i + \beta_j(i) + \epsilon_{ijt}\), the Expected Mean Squares (EMS) are:
\[
EMS_A = \sigma^2 + r \sigma^2_B + r b Q(\alpha_i)
\]
\[
EMS_B(A) = \sigma^2 + r \sigma^2_B
\]
\[
EMS_E = \sigma^2
\]

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
Derivation Steps

Assumptions:


Fixed Effects: \(\alpha_i\) and \(\beta_j(i)\) are fixed.
Random Error: \(\epsilon_{ijt} \sim N(0, \sigma^2)\).
Replicates: \(r\) replicates per nested factor.


Variance Components:


Between (A) Groups: Variance due to Factor (A) is captured by \(\alpha_i\).
Between (B(A)) Groups: Variance due to Factor (B) nested within (A) is \(\sigma^2_B\).
Within (B(A)) Groups: Residual variance is \(\sigma^2\).


Calculation of EMS:


EMS for Factor (A):

\[
EMS_A = Var(\alpha_i) + Var(\beta_j(i)) + Var(\epsilon_{ijt}) = \sigma^2 + r \sigma^2_B + r b Q(\alpha_i)
\]

EMS for Factor (B(A)):

\[
EMS_B(A) = Var(\beta_j(i)) + Var(\epsilon_{ijt}) = \sigma^2 + r \sigma^2_B
\]

EMS for Error:

\[
EMS_E = Var(\epsilon_{ijt}) = \sigma^2
\]

Estimation of Variance Components:

Using the ANOVA table, mean squares are equated to EMS to solve for \(\sigma^2_B\) and \(\sigma^2\):
\[
\hat{\sigma}^2_B = \frac{MS_A - MS_E}{r}
\]
\[
\hat{\sigma}^2 = MS_E
\]
Where:

\(MS_A\): Mean Square for Factor (A).
\(MS_E\): Mean Square for Error.

Conclusion:
The derivation demonstrates how ANOVA decomposes total variability into components attributable to nested factors and residual error, enabling the estimation of variance components.
Reference:
Montgomery, D. C., & Runger, G. C. (2010). Applied Statistics and Probability for Engineers. Wiley.

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
section: Interaction Contrasts Measure Deviations from Additivity
text:
Interaction Contrasts Measure Deviations from Additivity
Definition:
In a three-factor design, interaction contrasts quantify how the combined effect of three factors deviates from the additive effects of each factor individually and their two-way interactions.

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
Proof Steps

Define the Three-Factor Model:

\[
Y_{ijk} = \mu + \alpha_i + \beta_j + \gamma_k + (\alpha\beta){ij} + (\alpha\gamma){ik} + (\beta\gamma){jk} + (\alpha\beta\gamma){ijk} + \epsilon_{ijk}
\]
Where \(\sum \alpha_i = \sum \beta_j = \sum \gamma_k = 0\).

Construct Interaction Contrasts:


Two-Way Interactions:
\((\alpha\beta)*{ij}\): Measures the interaction between Factors A and B.
Similarly for \((\alpha\gamma){ik}\) and \((\beta\gamma){jk}\).
Three-Way Interaction:
\((\alpha\beta\gamma)*{ijk}\): Measures the deviation from additivity among all three factors.


Prove Deviations from Additivity:


Additive Model:

If all interaction terms are zero (\((\alpha\beta){ij} = (\alpha\gamma){ik} = (\beta\gamma){jk} = (\alpha\beta\gamma){ijk} = 0\)), the model simplifies to:
\[
Y_{ijk} = \mu + \alpha_i + \beta_j + \gamma_k + \epsilon_{ijk}
\]
This represents a purely additive model where the combined effect of factors is the sum of their individual effects.

Non-Additive Model:

If any of the interaction terms are non-zero, the model deviates from additivity, indicating that the effect of one factor depends on the levels of other factors.

Conclusion:

Interaction contrasts (\((\alpha\beta){ij}\), \((\alpha\gamma){ik}\), \((\beta\gamma){jk}\), and \((\alpha\beta\gamma){ijk}\)) measure the extent to which the observed responses deviate from an additive model. Non-zero contrasts signify the presence of interactions, emphasizing the importance of considering these higher-order effects in experimental analysis.
Reference:
Dean, Voss & DraguljiÄ‡ (2017). Design and Analysis of Experiments. Springer.

title: Nested Models in Statistical Design
text:
References

Dean, A., Voss, D., & DraguljiÄ‡, D. (2017). Design and Analysis of Experiments. Springer.
Montgomery, D. C., & Runger, G. C. (2010). Applied Statistics and Probability for Engineers. Wiley.
Christensen, R. (2018). Analysis of Variance, Design, and Regression. Chapman and Hall/CRC.
Kempthorne, O. (1977). Design and Analysis of Experiments. Robert E. Krieger Publishing Company.
ScheffÃ©, H. (1959). The Analysis of Variance. Wiley.

title: Row and Column Designs
text:
In the realm of experimental design, Rowâ€“Column Designs serve as an extension of traditional blocking techniques by incorporating two independent blocking factors: rows and columns. These designs are instrumental in controlling multiple sources of variability, thereby enhancing the precision and efficiency of treatment comparisons. By organizing experimental units into a matrix of rows and columns, Rowâ€“Column Designs mitigate the influence of two distinct nuisance factors, enabling clearer insights into the effects of the primary treatments under investigation.
Intuitive Example: Imagine conducting an agricultural experiment to test different crop varieties. The field is naturally divided into rows and columns due to varying sunlight and soil moisture gradients. By applying each variety once per row and column, you control for these environmental gradients, ensuring that differences in crop performance are attributable to the varieties themselves rather than external factors.
This lecture delves into the structure, analysis, and practical applications of Rowâ€“Column Designs, with a focus on specific examples like Latin Square Designs and Youden Designs. We will explore theoretical foundations, implement analyses using R, and engage with advanced topics to provide a comprehensive understanding suitable for graduate-level studies.



Understand the principles and utility of Rowâ€“Column Designs.
Explore specific examples such as Latin Square and Youden Designs.
Analyze data using ANOVA tailored for Rowâ€“Column Designs.
Extend designs to accommodate factorial experiments.
Implement Rowâ€“Column Designs in R with step-by-step guidance.
Reinforce concepts through exercises covering numerical examples, conceptual understanding, and mathematical proofs.
Explore advanced mathematical derivations and proofs in the Appendix.

title: Row and Column Designs
text:
Rowâ€“Column Design Structure
A Rowâ€“Column Design arranges experimental units in a two-dimensional grid comprising rows and columns. Each cell in the grid represents an experimental unit to which a treatment is applied. This design incorporates two independent blocking factors:

Rows: Control for variability along the horizontal dimension.
Columns: Control for variability along the vertical dimension.

title: Row and Column Designs
text:
Blocking Factors

Row Blocks: Address systematic variability across rows, such as gradients in environmental conditions.
Column Blocks: Address systematic variability across columns, such as variations in soil composition.

Intuitive Explanation: Consider a greenhouse experiment where temperature gradients run horizontally and light intensity gradients run vertically. By arranging treatments in a rowâ€“column grid, you control for these two sources of environmental variability, ensuring that treatment effects are not confounded with spatial gradients.

title: Row and Column Designs
text:
Advantages

Reduced Variability: By controlling two sources of variability, Rowâ€“Column Designs offer greater precision in estimating treatment effects.
Efficiency: These designs make efficient use of experimental units, especially in small-scale experiments with inherent multidimensional variability.
Flexibility: They can be extended to accommodate factorial experiments and multiple interactions.
Enhanced Analytical Power: ANOVA tailored for Rowâ€“Column Designs can effectively isolate treatment effects from block effects.

Reference: Montgomery, D. C., Peck, E. A., & Vining, G. G. (2020). Introduction to Linear Regression Analysis. Wiley.

title: Row and Column Designs
text:
Definition
A Latin Square Design is a specialized type of Rowâ€“Column Design where:

Each treatment appears exactly once in each row.
Each treatment appears exactly once in each column.

This ensures that the design is balanced and controls for both row and column effects effectively.

title: Row and Column Designs
text:
Construction

Standard Latin Squares:
For \(v = 3\) treatments, a Latin Square can be constructed as follows:

\[
\begin{array}{|c|c|c|}
   \hline
   A & B & C \\
   \hline
   B & C & A \\
   \hline
   C & A & B \\
   \hline
   \end{array}
\]

Rows and Columns: Each treatment \(A\), \(B\), and \(C\) appears once per row and column.


Randomization:
To prevent systematic bias, randomize the order of treatments within rows and columns. This can be achieved by randomly permuting the treatment labels for rows and columns.

title: Row and Column Designs
text:
Model
For a Rowâ€“Column Design with \(b\) rows, \(c\) columns, and \(v\) treatments, the ANOVA model is defined as:
\[
Y_{hqi} = \mu + \theta_h + \phi_q + \tau_i + \epsilon_{hqi},
\]
where:

\(Y_{hqi}\): Response for treatment \(i\) in row \(h\) and column \(q\).
\(\mu\): Overall mean.
\(\theta_h\): Effect of row \(h\).
\(\phi_q\): Effect of column \(q\).
\(\tau_i\): Effect of treatment \(i\).
\(\epsilon_{hqi} \sim N(0, \sigma^2)\): Random error term.


Key Assumptions

Normality: The residuals (\(\epsilon_{hqi}\)) are normally distributed.
Homogeneity of Variance (Homoscedasticity): The variance of residuals is constant across all treatments, rows, and columns.
Independence: Observations are independent of each other.
No Interaction: There is no interaction between rows and treatments or columns and treatments, i.e., the effects of treatments are consistent across rows and columns.



ANOVA Table

\(SS_{\text{Columns}}\)
\(MS_{\text{Columns}} = \frac{SS_{\text{Columns}}}{c - 1}\)
\(F = \frac{MS_{\text{Columns}}}{MS_{\text{Error}}}\)

\(v - 1\)
\(SS_{\text{Trt adj}}\)
\(MS_{\text{Trt adj}} = \frac{SS_{\text{Trt adj}}}{v - 1}\)
\(F = \frac{MS_{\text{Treatments}}}{MS_{\text{Error}}}\)


Error
\(bc - b - c - v + 2\)
\(SS_{\text{Error}}\)

title: Row and Column Designs
text:
Hypothesis Testing

Null Hypothesis (\(H_0\)): All treatment means are equal (\(\tau_i = 0\) for all \(i\)).
Alternative Hypothesis (\(H_A\)): At least one treatment mean differs.

Decision Rule: Reject \(H_0\) if the F-ratio for treatments exceeds the critical value from the F-distribution with degrees of freedom \((v - 1, bc - b - c - v + 2)\) at the chosen significance level (\(\alpha\)).

title: Row and Column Designs
text:
Example Interpretation

Rows and Columns: Assess the significance of row and column effects. Significant row or column effects indicate that these blocking factors explain a substantial portion of the variability in the response.
Treatments: Determine if treatments have a significant impact on the response variable after accounting for row and column effects.
Error: Represents unexplained variability, serving as the denominator for F-ratios.

title: Row and Column Designs
text:
Computational Formula
These formulas typically apply to the Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) for experimental designs involving treatments laid out in a structure with rows and columns, aiming to control for variability from these two sources (e.g., Latin Squares, Youden Squares, Row-Column Designs).

\(b\): Number of rows
\(c\): Number of columns
\(v\): Number of treatments
\(y_{hq}\): Observation in rowÂ \(h\)Â and columnÂ \(q\)
\(t(h,q)\): Treatment applied in cellÂ \((h,q)\)
\(N = bc\): Total number of observations (assuming a complete layout)
\(B_h = \sum_{q=1}^{c} y_{hq}\): Total for rowÂ \(h\)Â (sum ofÂ \(c\)Â observations)
\(C_q = \sum_{h=1}^{b} y_{hq}\): Total for columnÂ \(q\)Â (sum ofÂ \(b\)Â observations)
\(T_i = \sum_{(h,q): t(h,q)=i} y_{hq}\): Total for treatmentÂ \(i\)
\(G = \sum_{h=1}^{b} \sum_{q=1}^{c} y_{hq}\): Grand total (sum ofÂ \(N=bc\)Â observations)
\(r\): Number of replications per treatment (assumed constant in some provided formulas, but could beÂ \(r_i\))
\(n_{h.i}\): Number of times treatmentÂ \(i\)Â appears in rowÂ \(h\)
\(n_{.qi}\): Number of times treatmentÂ \(i\)Â appears in columnÂ \(q\)
\(CF = \frac{G^2}{N} = \frac{G^2}{bc}\): Correction Factor

Note. We have \(r\) replications per treatment in a complete design, but in some cases, \(r_i\) may vary. The formulas provided assume a complete layout with equal replication. ## Unadjusted Row Effect Sum of Squares (\(SS_\theta\))
\[
SS_{Rows} = \frac{1}{c} \sum_{h=1}^{b} B_h^2 - \frac{2 G^2}{bc} + \frac{b G^2}{bc} = \frac{1}{c} \sum_{h=1}^{b} B_h^2 - \frac{G^2}{bc}
\]

title: Row and Column Designs
section: Derivation of Row Effect Sum of Squares
text:
Derivation of Row Effect Sum of Squares
The unadjusted sum of squares for rows measures the variability between row means.

Row meanÂ \(h\):Â \(\bar{y}_{h.} = B_h / c\)
Grand mean:Â \(\bar{y}_{..} = G / N = G / (bc)\)
The sum of squares is the sum of squared deviations from the grand mean, weighted by the number of observations per row:

\[
SS_{Rows} = \sum_{h=1}^{b} \sum_{q=1}^{c} (\bar{y}_{h.} - \bar{y}_{..})^2 = \sum_{h=1}^{b} c (\bar{y}_{h.} - \bar{y}_{..})^2
\]

Substitute the means:

\[
SS_{Rows} = \sum_{h=1}^{b} c \left(\frac{B_h}{c} - \frac{G}{bc}\right)^2 = \sum_{h=1}^{b} c \left[\frac{B_h^2}{c^2} - \frac{2 B_h G}{bc^2} + \frac{G^2}{(bc)^2}\right]
\]

Distribute the sum and simplify:

\[
SS_{Rows} = \sum_{h=1}^{b} \left[\frac{B_h^2}{c} - \frac{2 B_h G}{bc} + \frac{c G^2}{b^2 c^2}\right]
\]
\[
SS_{Rows} = \left(\frac{1}{c} \sum_{h=1}^{b} B_h^2\right) - \frac{2 G}{bc} \left(\sum_{h=1}^{b} B_h\right) + \sum_{h=1}^{b} \frac{G^2}{bc}
\]

SinceÂ \(\sum B_h = G\)Â and the last term sumsÂ \(b\)Â times:

\[
SS_{Rows} = \frac{1}{c} \sum_{h=1}^{b} B_h^2 - \frac{2 G^2}{bc} + \frac{b G^2}{bc} = \frac{1}{c} \sum_{h=1}^{b} B_h^2 - \frac{G^2}{bc}
\]

The formulaâ€™sÂ \(1/c\)Â factor arises naturally because eachÂ \(B_h\)Â is the sum ofÂ \(c\)Â observations. Dividing the squared totalÂ \(B_h^2\)Â byÂ \(c\)Â scales it appropriately for the sum of squares calculation based on means.

title: Row and Column Designs
section: Unadjusted Column Effect Sum of Squares (\(ss_\phi\))
text:
Unadjusted Column Effect Sum of Squares (\(ss_\phi\))
\[
SS_{Cols} = \frac{1}{b} \sum_{q=1}^{c} C_q^2 - \frac{G^2}{bc}
\]

Derivation of Standard Formula:

The derivation is analogous to the Row SS derivation, swapping roles of rows and columns.

Column meanÂ \(q\):Â \(\bar{y}_{.q} = C_q / b\)
Grand mean:Â \(\bar{y}_{..} = G / (bc)\)
Sum of squares:

\[
SS_{Cols} = \sum_{q=1}^{c} \sum_{h=1}^{b} (\bar{y}_{.q} - \bar{y}_{..})^2 = \sum_{q=1}^{c} b (\bar{y}_{.q} - \bar{y}_{..})^2
\]

Following similar algebraic steps as forÂ \(SS_{Rows}\)Â leads to:

\[
SS_{Cols} = \frac{1}{b} \sum_{q=1}^{c} C_q^2 - \frac{G^2}{bc}
\]

Treatment Effect (Adjusted for Rows and Columns)
Adjustment is needed because treatments are generally not orthogonal to rows and columns. We first find adjusted treatment totals (\(Q_i\)) and then use them to calculate the adjusted treatment sum of squares (\(SS_\text{Trt adju}\)).

Adjusted Treatment Totals (\(Q_i\))
\[
Q_i = T_i - \frac{1}{c} \sum_{h=1}^{b} n_{h.i} B_h - \frac{1}{b} \sum_{q=1}^{c} n_{.qi} C_q + \frac{b}{c} r_i G
\]
where

\(T_i\): Total for treatment \(i\)
\(B_h\): Total for row \(h\)
\(C_q\): Total for column \(q\)
\(G\): Grand total
\(h\): Row index
\(q\): Column index
\(n_{h.i}\): Number of times treatment \(i\) appears in row \(h\)
\(n_{.qi}\): Number of times treatment \(i\) appears in column \(q\)

Note. This uses potentially variable replication \(r_i\). If \(r\) is constant, \(r_i\) becomes \(r\). This formula assumes \(r_i\) replications per treatment.

title: Row and Column Designs
text:
Explanation of Standard Formula:

The adjusted total \(Q_i\) is the raw treatment total$ T_i$ corrected for the effects of the specific rows and columns where treatment \(i\) appeared.
The adjustment subtracts the estimated contribution of row means (\(B_h/c\)) and column means (\(C_q/b\)) for the units receiving treatment i and adds back the overall mean effect (\(G/bc\)) scaled by the number of replications (\(r_i\)).
This quantity arises naturally from the normal equations for estimating treatment effects (\(\tau_i\)) in the linear model \(y_{hq(i)} = \mu + \theta_h + \phi_q + \tau_i + \epsilon_{hq(i)}\) after eliminating row and column parameters. The \(Q_i\) form the right-hand side of the reduced normal equations for the treatment effects.

title: Row and Column Designs
section: Adjusted Treatment Sum of Squares (\(SS_\text{Trt adj}\))
text:
Adjusted Treatment Sum of Squares (\(SS_\text{Trt adj}\))
\[
SS_\text{Trt adj} = \sum_{i=1}^{v} Q_i \hat{\tau}_i
\]
where:

\(ss_{Tadj}\): Adjusted treatment sum of squares
\(Q_i\): Adjusted treatment total for treatment \(i\)
\(\hat{\tau}_i\): Estimated treatment effect for treatment \(i\)
\(v\): Number of treatments
\(\hat{\tau}_i\): Estimated treatment effect (solution to the reduced normal equations)

title: Row and Column Designs
text:
Explanation of Standard Formula:

This formula arises directly from the theory of linear models.
The adjusted sum of squares for a factor (here, treatments) can be expressed as the quadratic form \(\hat{\tau}' Q\), where \(\hat{\tau}\) is the vector of estimated treatment effects (solutions to the reduced normal equations \(C \hat{\tau} = Q\)) and \(Q\) is the vector of adjusted totals.
Expanding \(\hat{\tau}' Q\) gives the summation \(\sum Q_i \hat{\tau}_i\).

title: Row and Column Designs
text:
Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)
For a Latin Square Design with \(v\) treatments, the ANOVA model includes:
\[
Y_{hqi} = \mu + \theta_h + \phi_q + \tau_i + \epsilon_{hqi},
\]
where:

\(Y_{hqi}\): Response for treatment \(i\) in row \(h\) and column \(q\).
\(\mu\): Overall mean.
\(\theta_h\): Effect of row \(h\).
\(\phi_q\): Effect of column \(q\).
\(\tau_i\): Effect of treatment \(i\).
\(\epsilon_{hqi} \sim N(0, \sigma^2)\): Random error term.

In a classical (fully balanced) Latin Square, the treatment sum of squares is the same whether you view it as â€œadjustedâ€ (after removing row and column effects) or â€œunadjustedâ€ (looking at treatments alone). In other words, they do not differ.

title: Row and Column Designs
text:
Why They Are the Same

Orthogonality
In a Latin Square, the design is constructed so that treatments are orthogonal (statistically independent) to the row and column factors. Orthogonality means that when you estimate the effect of treatments, you are not â€œborrowingâ€ or â€œconfoundingâ€ variation that belongs to the row or column blocks.
Balanced Cells
Each treatment occurs exactly once in every row and once in every column, so there is no overlap in the sum of squares partition:
\[
\text{SSTotal} \;=\; \text{SSRows} \;+\; \text{SSColumns} \;+\; \text{SSTreatments} \;+\; \text{SSError}.
\] Because of this strict balance, the decomposition of sums of squares is clean and unique.
Adjusted = Unadjusted for Orthogonal Designs
When factors are orthogonal, â€œpartialâ€ or â€œadjustedâ€ sum of squares for a given factor (e.g.Â treatments) equals the â€œunadjustedâ€ sum of squares you would get if you calculated it before removing the other factors. No matter the sequence in which you enter factors into the model, the SS for each orthogonal factor is unchanged.

title: Row and Column Designs
text:
When They Might Differ

Missing Data or Unbalanced Layout
If some runs are missing or the design is not balanced, the orthogonality breaks. Then the â€œadjustedâ€ (Type III or partial) sum of squares for treatments can differ from the â€œunadjustedâ€ (Type I or sequential) sum of squares.
Non-orthogonal Blocks/Treatments
If blocking factors and treatments are not arranged in an orthogonal way (as in some incomplete-block or more complex designs), you can again see discrepancies.

In the standard (complete, balanced) Latin Square, however, there is perfect orthogonality among row blocks, column blocks, and treatmentsâ€”so the treatment SS is invariant to whether you consider it â€œadjustedâ€ or â€œunadjusted.â€

Hypothesis Testing:

Null Hypothesis (\(H_0\)): All treatment means are equal (\(\tau_k = 0\) for all \(k\)).
Alternative Hypothesis (\(H_A\)): At least one treatment mean differs.

Decision Rule: Reject \(H_0\) if the F-ratio for treatments exceeds the critical value from the F-distribution with degrees of freedom \((v - 1, (v-2)(v-1))\) at the chosen significance level (\(\alpha\)).

title: Row and Column Designs
text:
Example in R

# Simulated Data for Latin Square Design
set.seed(123)
data <- data.frame(
    row = factor(rep(1:3, each = 3)),
    column = factor(rep(1:3, times = 3)),
    treatment = factor(c("A", "B", "C", "B", "C", "A", "C", "A", "B")),
    response = c(10.2, 15.3, 20.1, 14.8, 19.5, 9.7, 19.0, 9.9, 14.2)
)

# Fit ANOVA Model
fit <- lm(response ~ row + column + treatment, data = data)
anova(fit)

Because the Latin Square is fully balanced, the treatment SS is invariant to whether you consider it â€œadjustedâ€ or â€œunadjusted.â€

title: ANCOVA: Statistical Analysis of Covariance
text:
In statistical analysis, Analysis of Covariance (ANCOVA) serves as a powerful tool that combines the principles of ANOVA (Analysis of Variance) and regression. ANCOVA allows researchers to adjust the response variable for one or more covariates (also known as nuisance variables) that are related to the response but are not influenced by the treatments. This adjustment enhances the precision of treatment effect estimates and controls for potential confounding factors.
Intuition: Imagine you are a teacher assessing the effectiveness of different teaching methods (treatments) on studentsâ€™ final exam scores (response). However, students come with varying levels of prior knowledge (covariate). By using ANCOVA, you can adjust the final scores based on their initial knowledge, providing a clearer picture of how each teaching method truly affects performance.
This lecture delves into the theoretical foundations, assumptions, and applications of ANCOVA. We will explore practical implementations using R, ensuring a balance between theoretical depth and applied understanding. References to classical texts will support and deepen the content, providing a rigorous academic framework.



Understand the purpose and application of ANCOVA.
Explore the mathematical model and assumptions underlying ANCOVA.
Learn methods to test and interpret treatment effects adjusted for covariates.
Use R to perform ANCOVA and evaluate its assumptions.
Extend the model to unbalanced data and multiple covariates.
Reinforce concepts with exercises covering numerical examples, conceptual understanding, and mathematical proofs.
Explore advanced mathematical derivations and proofs in the Appendix.





pacman::p_load(
    car, # Companion to Applied Regression
    emmeans, # Estimated Marginal Means
    lmtest, # Tests for Linear Models
    ggplot2, # Data visualization
    dplyr, # Data manipulation
    ggpubr, # Publication-ready plots
    easystats, # Easy statistical analysis
    here # File path management
)
# Set theme for ggplot2
theme_set(see::theme_modern())


# Load the balloon data
balloon_df <- read.table(
    here("data", "dean2017", "balloon.txt"),
    header = TRUE
)
# Prepare the data: center the covariate and convert treatment to factor

balloon_df <- balloon_df |>
    mutate(
        Order_c = Order - mean(Order), # Center the covariate
        fColor = factor(Color, labels = c("pink", "yellow", "orange", "blue")) # Convert treatment to factor
    )

# Display the first few rows of the dataset

title: ANCOVA: Statistical Analysis of Covariance
text:
Why ANCOVA?
ANCOVA addresses several key scenarios in experimental and observational studies:

Adjusting for Covariates: It accounts for variability due to covariates, improving the precision of estimating treatment effects.
Controlling for Confounding Variables: By adjusting for variables related to the response but not influenced by treatments, ANCOVA enhances causal interpretations.
Increasing Statistical Power: Reducing error variance by accounting for covariates can lead to more powerful tests of treatment effects.

Example: Consider comparing the effects of three different fertilizers (A, B, C) on crop yield. Soil quality before treatment is a covariate that affects yield but is not influenced by the fertilizer used. ANCOVA can adjust yield differences based on initial soil quality, providing a clearer assessment of fertilizer effectiveness.
Reference: Dean, Voss & DraguljiÄ‡ (2017) discuss the integration of covariates in experimental designs, highlighting the benefits of ANCOVA in Design and Analysis of Experiments.

title: ANCOVA: Statistical Analysis of Covariance
section: The ANCOVA Model: Centered Form of the Model
text:
The ANCOVA Model: Centered Form of the Model
For \(v\) treatments and \(n\) total observations, the ANCOVA model is defined as:
\[
Y_{ij} = \mu + \tau_i + \beta (X_{ij} - \bar{X}_{\cdot\cdot}) + \epsilon_{ij},
\qquad(1)\]
where:

\(Y_{ij}\): Response variable for the \(j\)-th unit under treatment \(i\).
\(X_{ij}\): Covariate value for the \(j\)-th unit under treatment \(i\).
\(\bar{X}_{\cdot\cdot}\): Overall mean of the covariate.
\(\epsilon_{ij} \sim N(0, \sigma^2)\): Error term.
\(\mu\) (overall mean): This is the grand mean of the response variable when the covariate \(X_{ij}\) is at its overall mean \(\bar{X}_{\cdot\cdot}\).
\(\tau_i\) (treatment effect): This represents the deviation of the \(i\)-th treatment from the overall mean adjusted for the covariate. That is, it estimates the effect of treatment \(i\) at the covariate value \(\bar{X}_{\cdot\cdot}\). These are not raw group means; they are adjusted treatment means.
\(\beta\) (regression coefficient): This is the common slope that quantifies the effect of the covariate \(X_{ij}\) on the response \(Y_{ij}\), assumed constant across treatments.

Intuition: Centering the covariate reduces multicollinearity between the intercept and the covariate, enhancing the interpretability of the model parameters.

title: ANCOVA: Statistical Analysis of Covariance
text:
Adjusted Treatment Means
The adjusted mean for treatment \(i\) is given by:
\[
\mu_{i}^\text{adj} = \mu + \tau_i = \bar{Y}_{i \cdot} - \beta (\bar{X}_{i \cdot} - \bar{X}_{\cdot\cdot}),
\qquad(2)\]
\[
\tau_i = \bar{Y}_{i \cdot} - \mu - \beta (\bar{X}_{i \cdot} - \bar{X}_{\cdot\cdot}),
\]
Derivation:

Model Equation:

\[
Y_{ij} = \mu + \tau_i + \beta (X_{ij} - \bar{X}_{\cdot\cdot}) + \epsilon_{ij}
\]

Taking the Mean for Treatment \(i\):

\[
\bar{Y}_{i\cdot} = \mu + \tau_i + \beta (\bar{X}_{i \cdot} - \bar{X}_{\cdot\cdot}) + \bar{\epsilon}_i
\]
Since \(\bar{\epsilon}_i = 0\) (assuming errors have mean zero),
\[
\bar{Y}_{i\cdot} = \mu + \tau_i + \beta (\bar{X}_{i \cdot}  - \bar{X}_{\cdot\cdot})
\]

Solving for Adjusted Mean:

\[
\mu + \tau_i = \bar{Y}_{i \cdot} - \beta (\bar{X}_{i \cdot}  - \bar{X}_{\cdot\cdot})
\]
This equation represents the adjusted treatment mean, accounting for differences in the covariate.

title: ANCOVA: Statistical Analysis of Covariance
text:
Why Adjustment is Necessary
If the covariate differs across treatment groups (i.e., \(\bar{X}_{i\cdot} \ne \bar{X}_{\cdot\cdot}\)), then the unadjusted means \(\bar{Y}_{i\cdot}\) reflect not only the treatment effects but also differences in the covariate distributions. To isolate the treatment effect, we use:
\[
\hat{\mu} + \hat{\tau}_i = \bar{Y}_{i\cdot} - \hat{\beta}(\bar{X}_{i\cdot} - \bar{X}_{\cdot\cdot}),
\]
which adjusts each treatment mean to the same covariate level, thus removing confounding due to the covariate.

title: ANCOVA: Statistical Analysis of Covariance
text:
Parameter Estimation via Least Squares
The estimation of model parameters (\(\tau_i\) and \(\beta\)) typically employs the Least Squares estimation approach:

The estimation of the covariate slope coefficient is expressed as:

\[
\hat{\beta} = \frac{S_{xy}}{S_{xx}}
\qquad(3)\]
where:
\[
SP_{xy} = \sum_{i=1}^{a}\sum_{j=1}^{n_i}(x_{ij} - \bar{x}_{i.})(y_{ij} - \bar{y}_{i.})
\qquad(4)\]
and
\[
SS_{xx} = \sum_{i=1}^{a}\sum_{j=1}^{n_i}(x_{ij} - \bar{x}_{i.})^2
\qquad(5)\]

title: ANCOVA: Statistical Analysis of Covariance
text:
Partitioning of Variation
ANCOVA decomposes the total observed variability into components associated with treatments, covariates, and residual errors:

Total Sum of Squares (SS Total):

\[
SS_\text{Total} = \sum_{i=1}^{a}\sum_{j=1}^{n_i}(y_{ij} - \bar{y}_{..})^2
\]

Treatment Sum of Squares adjusted for covariates (SS Treatment):

\[
SS_{\text{Treatment}|x} = \sum_{i=1}^{a}n_i(\hat{\mu}_i^{adj} - \bar{y}_{..})^2
\]

Covariate Sum of Squares (SS Covariate):

\[
SS_\text{Covariate} = \hat{\beta}^2 SS_{xx}
\]

Residual Sum of Squares (SS Error):

\[
SS_\text{Error} = SS_\text{Total} - SS_{\text{Treatment}|x} - SS_\text{Covariate}
\]

The ANCOVA F-test evaluates the statistical significance of treatment effects after adjusting for the covariate.

title: ANCOVA: Statistical Analysis of Covariance
text:
Hypothesis Testing
Objective: Test the null hypothesis using the F-statistic.
\[
H_0: \tau_1 = \tau_2 = \cdots = \tau_a = 0
\]
\[
H_a: \text{At least one } \tau_i \text{ is different from the others}
\]
Test Statistic: \[
F = \frac{MS_{\text{Treatment}\mid x}}{MS_\text{Error}} \sim F_{a-1, N-a-1}
\]
Decision Rule: Reject \(H_0\) if \(F > F_{\alpha; a-1, N-a-1}\), where \(\alpha\) is the significance level. Interpretation: A significant F-statistic indicates that at least one treatment mean is different after adjusting for the covariate.

title: ANCOVA: Statistical Analysis of Covariance
text:

balloon_fit <- lm(

title: ANCOVA: Statistical Analysis of Covariance
section: Explanation: Adjusted vs.Â Unadjusted Means in ANCOVA
text:
Explanation: Adjusted vs.Â Unadjusted Means in ANCOVA
In ANCOVA, unadjusted means are simple group averages of the response variable \(Y\) , ignoring the covariate \(X\) . These can be biased if \(X\) is associated with both the treatment and the outcome. Adjusted means account for the covariate by estimating the group means at a common value of \(X\) (e.g., the grand mean \(\bar{X}_{\cdot\cdot}\) ), removing confounding effects.

title: ANCOVA: Statistical Analysis of Covariance
text:
Bias in Unadjusted Means (Fig. 9.2)

Scenario: Suppose two groups ( \(i=1, 2\) ) have different covariate distributions (e.g., Group 1 has lower \(X\) , Group 2 has higher \(X\) ).
Issue: If \(Y\) increases with \(X\) , comparing unadjusted means \(\bar{Y}_1\) and \(\bar{Y}_2\) (horizontal lines) ignores the covariate effect, leading to biased treatment comparisons.
Solution: Adjust means by modeling the relationship between \(Y\) and \(X\) within each group.

title: ANCOVA: Statistical Analysis of Covariance
section: R Code to Replicate Fig. 9.2 (Unadjusted Means)

title: ANCOVA: Statistical Analysis of Covariance
text:
Comparison of Plots








Aspect
Unadjusted Plot
Adjusted Plot




Means
Horizontal lines at \(\bar{Y}_i\)
Horizontal lines at \(Y_i\) adjusted to \(\bar{X}_{\cdot\cdot}\)


Bias
Biased if \(X\) differs between groups
Unbiased by accounting for \(X\)


Interpretation
Misleading treatment effect due to \(X\)
True treatment effect isolated from \(X\)


Reference Line
None
Dotted line at \(\bar{X}_{\cdot\cdot}\)




Key Insight

In the unadjusted plot, Group 2â€™s higher mean \(Y\) might be due to its higher \(X\) values, not the treatment.
In the adjusted plot, both groups are compared at the same \(X\) ( \(\bar{X}_{\cdot\cdot}\) ), isolating the true treatment effect. The vertical dotted line emphasizes the adjustment point.

title: ANCOVA: Statistical Analysis of Covariance
text:
Checking Model Assumptions
Objective: Verify ANCOVA assumptions using diagnostics.
Content:

Tools:

Residual Plot: Plot residuals (\(y_{ij} - \hat{y}_{ij}\)) vs.Â covariate or time order (e.g., Figure 9.3 for balloon experiment, residuals -2 to 2, time order 1 to 29).
Tests: Interaction test for homogeneity of slopes.

Checks:

No patterns (linearity).
Constant spread (homoscedasticity).
Random scatter (independence).


Rationale: Violations like non-linear trends or unequal slopes invalidate ANCOVA results. Residual plots ensure the model fits the data appropriately.

title: ANCOVA: Statistical Analysis of Covariance
text:
1. Linearity
Definition:
The relationship between the response variable \(Y\) and the covariate \(X\) must be linear within each treatment group.
Mathematically:
For treatment \(i\), we assume: \[
E[Y_{ij} \mid X_{ij}] = \mu + \tau_i + \beta X_{ij}
\]
Linearity Check (Graphical):

ggplot(balloon_df, aes(x = Order, y = Time, color = fColor)) +
    geom_point(aes(shape = fColor)) +
    geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE, formula = y ~ x) +
    labs(title = "Linearity Check: Response vs. Covariate by Treatment") +
    scale_color_manual(values = c("pink", "yellow", "orange", "blue"))







FigureÂ 4: Linearity Check: Response vs.Â Covariate by Treatment





Interpretation:
If the regression lines appear approximately straight within each group, the assumption is likely satisfied.

title: ANCOVA: Statistical Analysis of Covariance
text:
2. Homogeneity of Regression Slopes
Definition:
The effect of the covariate (\(\beta\)) is assumed to be the same across all treatment groups.
Mathematically:
\[
\text{Test } H_0: \beta_1 = \beta_2 = \cdots = \beta_v
\]
This is equivalent to testing for no interaction between treatment and covariate.

title: ANCOVA: Statistical Analysis of Covariance
text:
Homogeneity Check (Statistical)

# Full model allowing interaction
model_full <- lm(Time ~ fColor * Order_c, data = balloon_df)

# Reduced model assuming common slope
model_reduced <- lm(Time ~ fColor + Order_c, data = balloon_df)

# Compare models
anova(model_reduced, model_full)

title: ANCOVA: Statistical Analysis of Covariance
text:
3. Independence of Covariate and Treatment
Definition:
The covariate should be independent of treatment assignment, i.e., covariate values should not systematically differ across treatment groups.
Random assignment of treatments is crucial to ensure this independence.

title: ANCOVA: Statistical Analysis of Covariance
text:
4. Normality of Residuals
Definition:
Residuals from the model should follow a normal distribution.
Diagnostic Check (Graphical & Statistical):

# Residual plots
par(mfrow = c(1, 2))
qqnorm(resid(model_reduced))
qqline(resid(model_reduced))
hist(resid(model_reduced), breaks = 10, main = "Histogram of Residuals")







FigureÂ 5: Normality Check: Q-Q Plot and Histogram of Residuals








# Shapiro-Wilk test
shapiro.test(resid(model_reduced))


    Shapiro-Wilk normality test

data:  resid(model_reduced)
W = 0.96374, p-value = 0.3465



TableÂ 7: Shapiro-Wilk Test for Normality of Residuals




Q-Q plot should lie along the reference line.
Histogram should resemble a bell curve.
Shapiro-Wilk p-value > 0.05 indicates normality.

title: ANCOVA: Statistical Analysis of Covariance
text:
5. Homoscedasticity (Equal Variances)
Definition:
The variance of residuals should be constant across levels of the covariate and treatments.
Diagnostic Check (Graphical & Statistical):

plot(
    model_reduced$fitted.values,
    resid(model_reduced),
    xlab = "Fitted values",
    ylab = "Residuals",
    main = "Homoscedasticity Check"
)
abline(h = 0, col = "red")







FigureÂ 6: Homoscedasticity Check: Residuals vs.Â Fitted Values








# Breusch-Pagan Test
lmtest::bptest(model_reduced)


    studentized Breusch-Pagan test

data:  model_reduced
BP = 3.9212, df = 4, p-value = 0.4168



TableÂ 8: Breusch-Pagan Test for Homoscedasticity




Random scatter around zero with no funneling supports homoscedasticity.
Breusch-Pagan p-value > 0.05 suggests equal variances.

Each assumption plays a critical role in ensuring valid inference from ANCOVA. Always assess assumptions before interpreting model results.
Analogy: Think of ANCOVA as leveling the playing field. Just as a referee ensures that all players are subject to the same rules regardless of their backgrounds, ANCOVA adjusts the response variable based on covariates, ensuring that treatment comparisons are fair and unbiased.

title: ANCOVA: Statistical Analysis of Covariance
text:
7. Treatment Contrasts and Confidence Intervals
Objective: Make inferences about specific treatment differences.

Contrast: Linear combination \(\sum c_i \tau_i\), where \(\sum c_i = 0\) (e.g., \(\tau_1 - \tau_2\)).
Estimator: \(\sum c_i \hat{\tau}_i = \sum c_i (\bar{y}_{i.} - \hat{\beta}_1 \bar{x}_{i.})\).
Variance:

\[
\text{Var}(\sum c_i \hat{\tau}_i) = \sigma^2 \left( \sum \frac{c_i^2}{n_i} + \frac{(\sum c_i \bar{x}_{i.})^2}{SS_{xx}} \right)
\]
\[
\widehat{\text{Var}(\sum c_i \hat{\tau}_i)} = MS_\text{Error} \left( \sum \frac{c_i^2}{n_i} + \frac{(\sum c_i \bar{x}_{i.})^2}{SS_{xx}} \right)
\]

Confidence Interval:

\[
\sum c_i \tau_i \in \sum c_i \hat{\tau}_i \pm t_{\alpha/2; n-a-1} \sqrt{\widehat{\text{Var}(\sum c_i \hat{\tau}_i)}}
\]

Rationale: Confidence intervals pinpoint which treatment differences are significant, adjusted for the covariate, aiding targeted conclusions.

title: ANCOVA: Statistical Analysis of Covariance
text:
Pairwise Comparisons of Adjusted Means
Objective: Adjust for multiple tests to control error rates.

Contrast Formula
For pairwise comparison \(\tau_i - \tau_j\) (e.g., \(\tau_1 - \tau_3\)):
\[
\text{Estimate: } \hat{\tau}_i - \hat{\tau}_j = (\bar{y}_i - \hat{\beta}_1 \bar{x}_i) - (\bar{y}_j - \hat{\beta}_1 \bar{x}_j)
\]


Variance Calculation
From ANCOVA theory:
\[
\widehat{\text{Var}}(\hat\tau_i - \hat\tau_j) = MS_{\text{Error}} \left[ \frac{1}{n_i} + \frac{1}{n_j} + \frac{(\bar{x}_i - \bar{x}_j)^2}{SS_{xx}} \right]
\]

\(SS_{xx} = \sum_{i=1}^a \sum_{k=1}^{n_i} (x_{ik} - \bar{x}_{\cdot\cdot})^2\) (total covariate SS)
Balloon data parameters: \(n_i = 8\), \(\hat{\beta}_1 = -0.211\), \(MS_{\text{Error}} = 6.731\), \(SS_{xx}\) (unreported but embedded in SEs)



Confidence Interval Calculation
\[
\text{CI: } \hat{\tau}_i - \hat{\tau}_j \pm  (\text{Critical Value}) \sqrt{\widehat{\text{Var}}(\hat\tau_i - \hat\tau_j)}
\]

CI Critical Values:

Bonferroni: Critical value \(t_{\alpha/(2m); sn-a-1}\), where \(m\) is the number of comparisons.
ScheffÃ©: Critical value \(\sqrt{(a-1) F_{\alpha; a-1, n-a-1}}\).

When multiple treatments are involved, pairwise comparisons of adjusted means can be performed to identify specific differences.
Use the emmeans package to perform pairwise comparisons of adjusted means.







Warning



Because the adjusted means are not independent unless the covariate is balanced across treatments (i.e., treatment means are equal), the ScheffÃ© method is preferred for multiple comparisons. The Bonferroni method is conservative and may not be appropriate for all situations. The ScheffÃ© method is more powerful and flexible, allowing for a wider range of contrasts to be tested.

title: ANCOVA: Statistical Analysis of Covariance
