title: ANCOVA: Statistical Analysis of Covariance
text:
Handling Unbalanced Data in R
# Fit ANCOVA model with unbalanced data
# Assume 'data_unbalanced' is loaded with unequal replicates
fit_unbalanced <- lm(Response ~ FactorA * FactorB, data = data_unbalanced)

# Type II Sum of Squares
Anova(fit_unbalanced, type = "II")

# Type III Sum of Squares
Anova(fit_unbalanced, type = "III")
Considerations:

Type II SS: Suitable when interactions are not of primary interest.
Type III SS: Appropriate when interactions are present or main effects need to be tested conditionally.

title: ANCOVA: Statistical Analysis of Covariance
text:
Model with Multiple Covariates
\[
Y_{ij} = \mu + \tau_i + \beta_1 X_{1ij} + \beta_2 X_{2ij} + \ldots + \epsilon_{ij}
\]
R Implementation:
# Fit ANCOVA model with multiple covariates
model_multi_cov <- lm(Response ~ FactorA + FactorB + Covariate1 + Covariate2, data = data)
summary(model_multi_cov)
Interpretation: Assess the effect of each covariate and treatment while controlling for other covariates.

title: ANCOVA: Statistical Analysis of Covariance
text:
Nonlinear Relationships
If the relationship between the response and covariate is not linear, polynomial terms can be included in the model.

Model with Polynomial Terms
\[
Y_{ij} = \mu + \tau_i + \beta_1 X_{ij} + \beta_2 X_{ij}^2 + \epsilon_{ij}
\]
R Implementation:
# Fit ANCOVA model with quadratic term
model_poly <- lm(Response ~ FactorA + FactorB + x + I(x^2), data = data)
summary(model_poly)
Interpretation: Determine if adding a quadratic term improves model fit and captures the nonlinear relationship.

title: ANCOVA: Statistical Analysis of Covariance
text:
Adjusted Treatment Means
The adjusted mean for treatment \(i\) is given by:
\[
\mu^\text{adj} = \mu + \tau_i = \bar{Y}_{i \cdot} - \beta (\bar{X}_{i \cdot} - \bar{X}_{\cdot\cdot}),
\]
where:

\(\mu\): Overall mean.
\(\tau_i\): Treatment effect for treatment \(i\).
\(\bar{Y}_{i\cdot}\): Mean response for treatment \(i\).
\(\beta\): Regression coefficient for the covariate.
\(\bar{X}_{i \cdot}\): Mean covariate value for treatment \(i\).
\(\bar{X}_{\cdot\cdot}\): Overall mean of the covariate.

Derivation:

Model Equation:

\[
Y_{ij} = \mu + \tau_i + \beta (X_{ij} - \bar{X}_{\cdot\cdot}) + \epsilon_{ij}
\]

Taking the Mean for Treatment \(i\):

\[
\bar{Y}_{i\cdot} = \mu + \tau_i + \beta (\bar{X}_{i \cdot} - \bar{X}_{\cdot\cdot}) + \bar{\epsilon}_i
\]
Since \(\bar{\epsilon}_i = 0\) (assuming errors have mean zero),
\[
\bar{Y}_{i\cdot} = \mu + \tau_i + \beta (\bar{X}_{i \cdot}  - \bar{X}_{\cdot\cdot})
\]

Solving for Adjusted Mean:

\[
\mu + \tau_i = \bar{Y}_{i \cdot} - \beta (\bar{X}_{i \cdot}  - \bar{X}_{\cdot\cdot})
\]
This equation represents the adjusted treatment mean, accounting for differences in the covariate.
Reference: Montgomery (2019) and ScheffÃ© (1959) provide detailed derivations of adjusted means in ANCOVA.

title: ANCOVA: Statistical Analysis of Covariance
text:
F-Test for Homogeneity of Slopes
To test the assumption of homogeneity of regression slopes (i.e., that \(\beta\) is consistent across treatments), an F-test can be conducted by comparing two models:

Model Without Interaction (Assuming Homogeneous Slopes):

\[
Y_{ij} = \mu + \tau_i + \beta X_{ij} + \epsilon_{ij}
\]

Model With Interaction (Allowing Slopes to Vary):

\[
Y_{ij} = \mu + \tau_i + \beta_i X_{ij} + \epsilon_{ij}
\]
Where \(\beta_i = \beta + (\alpha\beta)_i\) allows for different slopes across treatments.
Test Procedure:

Null Hypothesis (\(H_0\)): Homogeneity of slopes (\(\beta_i = \beta\) for all \(i\)).
Alternative Hypothesis (\(H_A\)): Slopes vary across treatments (\(\beta_i \neq \beta\) for at least one \(i\)).

F-Statistic Calculation:
\[
F = \frac{\text{SSR}_{\text{Interaction}} / \text{DF}_{\text{Interaction}}}{\text{SSE} / \text{DF}_{\text{Error}}}
\]
Where:

\(\text{SSR}_{\text{Interaction}}\): Sum of squares for the interaction term.
\(\text{DF}_{\text{Interaction}}\): Degrees of freedom for the interaction.
\(\text{SSE}\): Sum of squares for error.
\(\text{DF}_{\text{Error}}\): Degrees of freedom for error.

Decision Rule:

Compare the calculated F-statistic to the critical value from the F-distribution.
Reject \(H_0\) if \(F\) exceeds the critical value, indicating heterogeneous slopes.

Reference: ScheffÃ© (1959) elaborates on hypothesis testing for interaction terms in ANCOVA.

title: ANCOVA: Statistical Analysis of Covariance
text:
Confidence Intervals for Higher-Order Contrasts
For higher-order interactions involving multiple factors, confidence intervals for contrasts can provide insights into the magnitude and significance of these interactions.

Formula
\[
\text{CI} = \hat{L} \pm t_{\alpha/2, df} \sqrt{\text{Var}(\hat{L})}
\]
Where:

\(\hat{L}\): Estimated contrast.
\(t_{\alpha/2, df}\): Critical value from the t-distribution.
\(\text{Var}(\hat{L})\): Variance of the contrast estimate.



Steps in R

Estimate the Contrast:
Using the emmeans package to define and estimate contrasts.
Calculate the Confidence Interval:
The emmeans package automatically provides confidence intervals when performing contrasts.

Example:
library(emmeans)

# Fit the ANCOVA model
model <- lm(Y ~ Treatment + X, data = data_sim)

# Define estimated marginal means
emm <- emmeans(model, ~ Treatment)

# Define a contrast (e.g., Treatment B vs. Treatment A)
contrast_AB <- contrast(emm, method = "pairwise")
summary(contrast_AB, infer = TRUE)
Interpretation: The output provides the estimated difference, standard error, t-value, and confidence interval for the contrast. If the confidence interval does not include zero, the contrast is statistically significant.

title: ANCOVA: Statistical Analysis of Covariance
text:
Conclusion
Analysis of Covariance (ANCOVA) is a versatile statistical technique that enhances the power and precision of experiments by adjusting for covariates. By combining the strengths of ANOVA and regression, ANCOVA controls for extraneous variability, enabling more accurate assessment of treatment effects. Mastery of ANCOVA empowers graduate students to conduct robust experimental analyses, interpret complex interactions, and draw meaningful causal inferences.
Key Takeaways:

Purpose of ANCOVA: Adjusts for covariates to isolate treatment effects.
Assumptions: Linearity, homogeneity of regression slopes, independence of covariate and treatment, normality, and homoscedasticity.
Model Fitting: Involves testing treatment effects while accounting for covariates.
Extensions: ANCOVA can handle unbalanced designs, multiple covariates, and nonlinear relationships.
Practical Implementation: R provides comprehensive tools for performing ANCOVA and diagnostic assessments.
Advanced Topics: Understanding higher-order interactions and mathematical derivations enhances analytical rigor.

Future Directions: Further exploration into advanced experimental designs, mixed-effects models, and nonparametric ANCOVA methods will provide a deeper understanding of complex data structures and enhance analytical capabilities.

title: ANCOVA: Statistical Analysis of Covariance
text: References

title: Power Analysis in One-Way and Two-Way ANOVA
text:
One-way ANOVA tests whether the means of three or more groups differ significantly. For example, imagine comparing the average test scores of students taught using three teaching methods (Method A, Method B, Method C).




Power (1 - Î²): The probability of correctly rejecting a false null hypothesis (typically targeted at 0.80 or higher).
Significance Level (Î±): The probability of a Type I error (rejecting a true null hypothesis), often set at 0.05.
Effect Size: A measure of the magnitude of differences between group means, quantified in ANOVA using Cohenâ€™s f.
Sample Size (r): The number of observations per group, which we often solve for in power analysis.
Noncentrality Parameter (Î»): A parameter that shifts the F-distribution under the alternative hypothesis, used to compute power.




Cohenâ€™s f measures the standardized difference between group means relative to within-group variability. The formula is:
\[
f = \sqrt{\frac{\sum_{i=1}^k (\mu_i - \mu)^2 / k}{\sigma^2}}
\]
Where:

\(k\): Number of groupsâ€“ In the textbook, \(\nu\) is used instead of \(k\).
\(\mu_i\): Mean of group \(i\).
\(\mu\): Overall mean across all groups.
\(\sigma^2\): Within-group variance (assumed equal across groups).

Interpretation (Cohenâ€™s benchmarks):

Small: \(f = 0.1\)
Medium: \(f = 0.25\)
Large: \(f = 0.4\)




Suppose we have three groups (\(k = 3\)) with means \(\mu_1 = 10\), \(\mu_2 = 12\), \(\mu_3 = 14\), and within-group variance \(\sigma^2 = 16\). The overall mean is:
\[
\mu = \frac{10 + 12 + 14}{3} = 12
\]
Numerator of \(f^2\):
\[
\frac{\sum (\mu_i - \mu)^2}{k} = \frac{(10 - 12)^2 + (12 - 12)^2 + (14 - 12)^2}{3} = \frac{4 + 0 + 4}{3} = \frac{8}{3} \approx 2.667
\]
\[
f = \sqrt{\frac{2.667}{16}} = \sqrt{0.1667} \approx 0.408
\]
This is a large effect size, close to Cohenâ€™s \(f = 0.4\).



The noncentrality parameter quantifies the shift in the F-distribution under the alternative hypothesis:
\[
\lambda = \frac{r \sum_{i=1}^k (\mu_i - \mu)^2}{\sigma^2}
\]
Where \(r\) is the sample size per group (assuming balanced design). Using Cohenâ€™s f:
\[
\lambda = r k f^2
\]



Using the above means and \(\sigma^2 = 16\), with \(r = 10\) per group:
\[
\sum (\mu_i - \mu)^2 = 4 + 0 + 4 = 8
\]
\[
\lambda = \frac{10 \times 8}{16} = 5
\]
Or via \(f\):
\[
\lambda = 10 \times 3 \times (0.408)^2 = 30 \times 0.1665 \approx 5
\]



Power is calculated using the noncentral F-distribution:

Numerator degrees of freedom: \(df_1 = k - 1\)
Denominator degrees of freedom: \(df_2 = N - k\), where \(N = r k\)
Critical F-value: \(F_{\text{crit}}\) at \(\alpha\), found from the F-distribution.
Power: \(1 - P(F <  F_{\text{crit}} | \lambda)\), where \(F\) follows a noncentral F-distribution.




Goal: Determine the sample size per group (\(r\)) for \(k = 3\) groups, medium effect size (\(f = 0.25\)), \(\alpha = 0.05\), and power = 0.80.




library(pwr)

k <- 3
f <- 0.25
alpha <- 0.05
power <- 0.80

result <- pwr.anova.test(k = k, f = f, sig.level = alpha, power = power)
print(result)


     Balanced one-way analysis of variance power calculation 

              k = 3
              n = 52.3966
              f = 0.25
      sig.level = 0.05
          power = 0.8

NOTE: n is number in each group


Output:
     Balanced one-way analysis of variance power calculation 

              k = 3
              n = 52.39771
              f = 0.25
      sig.level = 0.05
          power = 0.8

NOTE: n is number in each group
We need approximately \(r = 53\) subjects per group, so total \(N = 3 \times 53 = 159\).




Degrees of Freedom:

\(df_1 = k - 1 = 2\)
\(df_2 = N - k = 3 \times 53 - 3 = 156\)

Noncentrality Parameter:

\[
\lambda = r k f^2 = 53 \times 3 \times 0.25^2 = 159 \times 0.0625 = 9.9375
\]

Critical F-value:

\[
F_{\text{crit}} = qf(0.95, 2, 156) \approx 3.05
\]

Power:

\[
\text{Power} = 1 - pf(3.05, 2, 156, ncp = 9.9375)
\]

power_manual <- 1 - pf(qf(0.95, 2, 156), 2, 156, ncp = 9.9375)
print(power_manual)

[1] 0.8048873


Output: Approximately 0.803, confirming the power is close to 0.80, validating the pwr result.

title: Power Analysis in One-Way and Two-Way ANOVA
text: Goal: Determine the sample size per group (\(r\)) for \(k = 3\) groups, medium effect size (\(f = 0.25\)), \(\alpha = 0.05\), and power = 0.80.

title: Power Analysis in One-Way and Two-Way ANOVA
text:
library(pwr)

k <- 3
f <- 0.25
alpha <- 0.05
power <- 0.80

result <- pwr.anova.test(k = k, f = f, sig.level = alpha, power = power)
print(result)


     Balanced one-way analysis of variance power calculation 

              k = 3
              n = 52.3966
              f = 0.25
      sig.level = 0.05
          power = 0.8

NOTE: n is number in each group


Output:
     Balanced one-way analysis of variance power calculation 

              k = 3
              n = 52.39771
              f = 0.25
      sig.level = 0.05
          power = 0.8

NOTE: n is number in each group
We need approximately \(r = 53\) subjects per group, so total \(N = 3 \times 53 = 159\).

title: Power Analysis in One-Way and Two-Way ANOVA
text:
Degrees of Freedom:

\(df_1 = k - 1 = 2\)
\(df_2 = N - k = 3 \times 53 - 3 = 156\)

Noncentrality Parameter:

\[
\lambda = r k f^2 = 53 \times 3 \times 0.25^2 = 159 \times 0.0625 = 9.9375
\]

\[
F_{\text{crit}} = qf(0.95, 2, 156) \approx 3.05
\]

Power:

\[

\]

power_manual <- 1 - pf(qf(0.95, 2, 156), 2, 156, ncp = 9.9375)
print(power_manual)

[1] 0.8048873


Output: Approximately 0.803, confirming the power is close to 0.80, validating the pwr result.

title: Power Analysis in One-Way and Two-Way ANOVA
text:
What is Two-Way ANOVA?
Two-way ANOVA examines the effects of two categorical factors (e.g., teaching method and study time) on a response variable, testing:

Main Effect of Factor A
Main Effect of Factor B
Interaction Effect (A Ã— B)

title: Power Analysis in One-Way and Two-Way ANOVA
text:
Key Concepts
Power analysis in two-way ANOVA requires separate calculations for each effect, adjusting effect sizes and degrees of freedom accordingly.

title: Power Analysis in One-Way and Two-Way ANOVA
section: Effect Size: Cohenâ€™s F for Two-Way ANOVA
text:
Effect Size: Cohenâ€™s F for Two-Way ANOVA
For each effect, Cohenâ€™s f is the ratio of the effectâ€™s standard deviation to the within-group standard deviation (\(\sigma\)).

Main Effect A:

\[
f_A = \frac{\sigma_A}{\sigma}, \quad \sigma_A = \sqrt{\frac{\sum_{i=1}^a (\alpha_i)^2}{a}}
\]
where \(\alpha_i = \mu_{i.} - \mu\) (deviation of Factor Aâ€™s level means from the grand mean).

Main Effect B:

\[
f_B = \frac{\sigma_B}{\sigma}, \quad \sigma_B = \sqrt{\frac{\sum_{j=1}^b (\beta_j)^2}{b}}
\]
where \(\beta_j = \mu_{.j} - \mu\).

Interaction Effect:

\[
f_{AB} = \frac{\sigma_{AB}}{\sigma}, \quad \sigma_{AB} = \sqrt{\frac{\sum_{i=1}^a \sum_{j=1}^b (\gamma_{ij})^2}{a b}}
\]
where \(\gamma_{ij} = \mu_{ij} - \mu_{i.} - \mu_{.j} + \mu\) (interaction terms).

title: Power Analysis in One-Way and Two-Way ANOVA
text:
Noncentrality Parameter (Î»)
Assuming \(r\) replicates per cell, \(a\) levels of Factor A, and \(b\) levels of Factor B:

Main Effect A:

\[
\lambda_A = \frac{r b \sum_{i=1}^a (\alpha_i)^2}{\sigma^2} = r b a f_A^2
\]

Main Effect B:

\[
\lambda_B = \frac{r a \sum_{j=1}^b (\beta_j)^2}{\sigma^2} = r a b f_B^2
\]

Interaction:

\[
\lambda_{AB} = \frac{r \sum_{i=1}^a \sum_{j=1}^b (\gamma_{ij})^2}{\sigma^2} = r a b f_{AB}^2
\]

title: Power Analysis in One-Way and Two-Way ANOVA
text:
Degrees of Freedom

Total sample size: \(N = a b r\)
Main Effect A: \(df_1 = a - 1\), \(df_2 = N - a b\)
Main Effect B: \(df_1 = b - 1\), \(df_2 = N - a b\)
Interaction: \(df_1 = (a - 1)(b - 1)\), \(df_2 = N - a b\)

title: Power Analysis in One-Way and Two-Way ANOVA
text:
Numerical Example
Scenario: A 2Ã—2 design (Factor A: 2 levels, Factor B: 2 levels). We want to detect a main effect of Factor A with a difference of 4 units between levels, \(\sigma^2 = 7.5\), power = 0.80, \(\alpha = 0.05\). Find \(r\) (replicates per cell).

title: Power Analysis in One-Way and Two-Way ANOVA
text:
Step 1: Define the Effect
Suppose Factor Aâ€™s marginal means are \(\mu_{1.} = 12\), \(\mu_{2.} = 8\), so \(\mu_{1.} - \mu_{2.} = 4\). Grand mean \(\mu = 10\). Effects are:
\[
\alpha_1 = 12 - 10 = 2, \quad \alpha_2 = 8 - 10 = -2
\]
\[
\sum \alpha_i^2 = 2^2 + (-2)^2 = 8
\]

title: Power Analysis in One-Way and Two-Way ANOVA
text:
Step 2: Noncentrality Parameter
\[
\lambda_A = \frac{r b \sum \alpha_i^2}{\sigma^2} = \frac{r \times 2 \times 8}{7.5} = \frac{16 r}{7.5}
\]

title: Power Analysis in One-Way and Two-Way ANOVA
text:
Step 3: Degrees of Freedom

\(df_1 = a - 1 = 1\)
\(df_2 = N - a b = 2 \times 2 \times r - 4 = 4r - 4\)

title: Power Analysis in One-Way and Two-Way ANOVA
text:
Step 4: Manual Power Calculation
For \(r = 5\):

\(N = 2 \times 2 \times 5 = 20\)
\(df_2 = 20 - 4 = 16\)
\(\lambda_A = \frac{16 \times 5}{7.5} \approx 10.67\)
\(F_{\text{crit}} = qf(0.95, 1, 16) \approx 4.49\)

\[
\text{Power} = 1 - pf(4.49, 1, 16, ncp = 10.67)
\]

power <- 1 - pf(qf(0.95, 1, 16), 1, 16, ncp = 10.67)
print(power)

[1] 0.8654718


Output: ~0.85 > 0.80.
For \(r = 4\):

\(df_2 = 4 \times 4 - 4 = 12\)
\(\lambda_A = \frac{16 \times 4}{7.5} \approx 8.53\)
\(F_{\text{crit}} \approx 4.75\)
Power ~0.71 <- 0.80.

Thus, \(r = 5\) is the smallest integer satisfying power â‰¥ 0.80.

title: Power Analysis in One-Way and Two-Way ANOVA
text:
Using R (Approximation via pwr)
Since pwr doesnâ€™t directly handle two-way ANOVA, we approximate the main effect as a t-test (since \(df_1 = 1\)):
\[
d = \frac{\mu_{1.} - \mu_{2.}}{\sqrt{\sigma^2 / (r b)}} = \frac{4}{\sqrt{7.5 / (r \times 2)}}
\]
But for precision, use manual F-test or specialized tools like G*Power. The pwr2 package isnâ€™t standard for this; we rely on pwr for one-way or custom calculations.

title: Example: Resting Metabolic Rate Experiment
text:
This example highlights the design of an experiment to compare the effects of inpatient and outpatient protocols on the in-laboratory measurement of resting metabolic rate (RMR) in humans. The study was conducted to address discrepancies between different experimental protocols and their implications for RMR measurements.



A prior study observed that RMR measurements on elderly individuals were, on average, 8% higher using an outpatient protocol compared to an inpatient protocol.
Such discrepancies could undermine the comparability of results across laboratories using different protocols.
The goal of the study was to assess whether the protocol type has a negligible effect on RMR measurements.







To determine whether different protocols for measuring RMR significantly affect the results.



Three experimental treatments were defined based on the protocol type:

Inpatient Protocol with Controlled Meals:

Patients were fed a standardized evening meal and spent the night in the laboratory.
RMR was measured in the morning.

Outpatient Protocol with Controlled Meals:

Patients were fed the same standardized evening meal at the laboratory but spent the night at home.
RMR was measured in the morning.

Outpatient Protocol with Uncontrolled Meals:

Patients were instructed to eat their regular evening meal at home and spent the night at home.
RMR was measured in the morning.






Null Hypothesis (\(H_0\)): The protocol type has no effect on the measured RMR.
Alternative Hypothesis (\(H_a\)): The protocol type has a significant effect on the measured RMR.







To reduce variability unrelated to the protocols, blocking factors such as age, gender, or baseline metabolic rate could be included in the design.




Random assignment of participants to the three protocol groups ensures that systematic biases are minimized.





The primary response variable is the measured RMR (in units such as \(\text{kcal/day}\)).





Controlling meal content and timing for the controlled protocols.
Ensuring adherence to the protocols for the outpatient treatments.





The data collected from the experiment can be analyzed using Analysis of Variance (ANOVA), as it is well-suited for comparing means across multiple groups.



ANOVA Model:

Response variable: RMR.
Factor: Protocol type (3 levels: inpatient controlled, outpatient controlled, outpatient uncontrolled).

The ANOVA model can be expressed as:

\[
y_{ij} = \mu + \tau_i + \epsilon_{ij},
\]
where:

\(y_{ij}\): Observed RMR for the \(j\)-th participant in the \(i\)-th protocol.
\(\mu\): Overall mean RMR.
\(\tau_i\): Effect of the \(i\)-th protocol.
\(\epsilon_{ij}\): Random error term.


Null and Alternative Hypotheses:

\(H_0: \tau_1 = \tau_2 = \tau_3 = 0\) (no effect of protocol type).
\(H_a: \text{At least one } \tau_i \neq 0\) (protocol type has an effect).

F-statistic:

Compute the ratio of between-group variability to within-group variability.

Post-hoc Tests:

If \(H_0\) is rejected, conduct pairwise comparisons (e.g., Tukeyâ€™s test) to identify significant differences between protocol types.

title: Example: Resting Metabolic Rate Experiment
text:

title: Example: Resting Metabolic Rate Experiment
text:
The data collected from the experiment can be analyzed using Analysis of Variance (ANOVA), as it is well-suited for comparing means across multiple groups.



ANOVA Model:

Response variable: RMR.
Factor: Protocol type (3 levels: inpatient controlled, outpatient controlled, outpatient uncontrolled).

The ANOVA model can be expressed as:

\[
y_{ij} = \mu + \tau_i + \epsilon_{ij},
\]
where:

\(y_{ij}\): Observed RMR for the \(j\)-th participant in the \(i\)-th protocol.
\(\mu\): Overall mean RMR.
\(\tau_i\): Effect of the \(i\)-th protocol.
\(\epsilon_{ij}\): Random error term.


Null and Alternative Hypotheses:

\(H_0: \tau_1 = \tau_2 = \tau_3 = 0\) (no effect of protocol type).
\(H_a: \text{At least one } \tau_i \neq 0\) (protocol type has an effect).

F-statistic:

Compute the ratio of between-group variability to within-group variability.

Post-hoc Tests:

If \(H_0\) is rejected, conduct pairwise comparisons (e.g., Tukeyâ€™s test) to identify significant differences between protocol types.

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
In experimental research, understanding the effects of multiple factors and their interactions is crucial for optimizing outcomes and making informed decisions. Factorial designs allow researchers to evaluate not only the individual (main) effects of factors but also how factors interact with each other to influence a response variable. Higher-order factorial designs, involving three or more factors, extend these principles, enabling the exploration of complex relationships within data.
This lecture delves into the structure, analysis, and interpretation of higher-order factorial designs, with a focus on two-way ANOVA models. Weâ€™ll explore main effects, interaction effects, handling unequal sample sizes, and practical implementation using R.


Imagine youâ€™re a chef experimenting with different ingredients to perfect a recipe. Factor A could be the type of flour (whole wheat, all-purpose), Factor B the type of sugar (granulated, brown), and Factor C the baking temperature (350Â°F, 375Â°F, 400Â°F). Each factor influences the final productâ€™s taste and texture. However, the optimal combination might not be obvious because the effect of sugar type could depend on the type of flour and the baking temperature. Higher-order factorial designs help uncover these intricate interactions systematically.




Understand the structure and applications of higher-order factorial designs.
Differentiate between main effects and interaction effects.
Perform two-way ANOVA and interpret its results.
Address challenges posed by unequal replication in factorial experiments.
Visualize interactions and understand their implications.
Apply advanced statistical techniques using R for complex datasets.
Engage with exercises to reinforce understanding and application of concepts.




To run the R code examples in these notes, we recommend installing the following packages:

# Required R Packages
pacman::p_load(dplyr, ggplot2, emmeans, here, readr, ggpubr)

if (!requireNamespace("hecedsm", quietly = TRUE)) {
    pacman::p_install_gh("lbelzile/hecedsm")
}

theme_set(theme_pubr())


dplyr: Data manipulation and summarization.
ggplot2: Data visualization.
lsmeans and emmeans: Post hoc comparisons and multiple comparisons.
pacman: Package management.
here: File path management.
readr: Reading data files.

Each factor influences the final productâ€™s taste and texture. title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Factorial Design Notation
A factorial experiment involves multiple factors, each with different levels. The notation \(a \times b \times c \times \dots\) denotes the number of levels for each factor. For example:

2 Ã— 3 Ã— 4 Design:

Factor A: 2 levels
Factor B: 3 levels
Factor C: 4 levels
Total Treatment Combinations: \(2 \times 3 \times 4 = 24\)

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Experimental Objectives

Estimate Main Effects: Determine the independent influence of each factor on the response.
Quantify Two-Factor Interactions: Assess how pairs of factors jointly affect the response.
Investigate Higher-Order Interactions: Explore interactions involving three or more factors.

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Example
In a manufacturing process, factors could include machine speed (fast, medium, slow), material type (A, B), and temperature (high, low). Understanding not only how each factor affects product quality but also how combinations (e.g., fast speed with high temperature) influence outcomes is essential for process optimization.

title: Higher-Order Designs
section: General Model for â€œThree-Way Completeâ€ Model
text:
General Model for â€œThree-Way Completeâ€ Model
For three-way complete model with three factors, the general linear model is:
\[
Y_{ijkt} = \mu + \alpha_i + \beta_j + \gamma_k + (\alpha\beta)_{ij} + (\alpha\gamma)_{ik} + (\beta\gamma)_{jk} + (\alpha\beta\gamma)_{ijk} + \epsilon_{ijkt}
\qquad(1)\]
Where:

\(Y_{ijkt}\): Observed response.
\(\mu\): Overall mean.
\(\alpha_i, \beta_j, \gamma_k\): Main effects of factors \(A, B, C\).
\((\alpha\beta)_{ij}\): Two-factor interaction between \(A\) and \(B\).
\((\alpha\beta\gamma)_{ijk}\): Three-factor interaction.
\(\epsilon_{ijkt} \sim N(0, \sigma^2)\): Random error term.

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Cell Means Model Formulation
The cell means model expresses the response as a sum of cell means and deviations from these means:
\[
Y_{ijkt} = \mu + \tau_{ijk} + \epsilon_{ijkt}
\]
Where:

\(\mu\): Overall mean.
\(\tau_{ijk}\): Cell mean for the \(ijk\) treatment combination.
\(\epsilon_{ijkt}\): Random error term.
Note: The cell means model is a simplified version of the general linear model.
Objective: Estimate cell means and deviations to understand factor effects and interactions.

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Key Concepts

Model Simplification: If interaction effects are negligible, they can be removed from the model to create a submodel. This simplification aids in interpretation and model fitting. -For instance, if the factors A and B are known to be non-interacting in a three-factor experiment, then the AB and ABC interaction effects are negligible, necessitating the exclusion of the terms \((Î±Î²)_{ij}\) and \((Î±Î²Î³)_{i jk}\) from model in EquationÂ 1. In the most extreme scenario, if no factors are anticipated to interact, a main-effects model (which incorporates no interaction terms) can be employed.
Interaction Model Inclusion: When a model includes an interaction between a specific set of factors, all interaction terms involving subsets of those factors should be included.
Submodel Advantages: Simpler submodels generally yield tighter confidence intervals and more powerful hypothesis tests.

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Assumptions

Independence: Observations are independent.
Homoscedasticity: Constant variance across all treatment combinations.
Normality: Errors are normally distributed.


Importance
These assumptions underpin the validity of ANOVA results. Violations can lead to incorrect inferences, necessitating diagnostic checks and potential corrective measures.

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Introduction
In factorial experiments, interactions occur when the effect of one factor depends on the level of another factor. These interactions provide valuable insights into complex relationships between factors. Understanding interactions is crucial for accurately interpreting experimental results and making informed decisions in practical applications.

Two-Factor Interactions
An interaction between two factors, say A and B, occurs when the effect of A on the response variable depends on the level of B, or vice versa. A common method for detecting interactions is through interaction plots, where the response variable is plotted against one factor at different levels of another factor.

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Example: A Hypothetical \(3 \times 2 \times 2\) Experiment
Consider a factorial experiment with three factors:

A (3 levels)
B (2 levels)
C (2 levels)

The sample means for each treatment combination provide insight into possible interactions. A two-factor interaction plot (AB-interaction) can be examined by averaging over the levels of C. If the interaction plot reveals non-parallel lines, an interaction is likely present.

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Interpretation of an Interaction Plot

Parallel lines: No interaction, meaning the effect of one factor is consistent across the levels of the other.
Non-parallel lines: Possible interaction, indicating that the effect of one factor changes depending on the level of the other.

However, interpreting an interaction plot should be done cautiously since it does not account for experimental error.

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Three-Factor Interactions
A three-factor interaction (\(ABC\)) is present if the interaction between A and B changes depending on the level of C. This can be evaluated using separate interaction plots at different levels of C.

No three-factor interaction: The patterns in AB-interaction plots remain consistent across levels of C.
Significant three-factor interaction: The AB-interaction patterns change across levels of C, meaning the combined effect of A and B depends on C.

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Graphical Representation

Two-factor interaction plots at each level of C: If the interaction pattern remains the same, C does not influence the AB-interaction.
Differences in interaction patterns across C: Suggests an ABC-interaction, indicating that the effect of A and B together depends on C.

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Higher-Order Interactions
Interactions involving four or more factors become increasingly difficult to interpret. While graphical methods are useful for two and three-factor interactions, analysis of variance (ANOVA) tables become essential for evaluating higher-order interactions. In practice:

Higher-order interactions tend to be small and may be ignored unless evidence suggests otherwise.
Lower-order interactions (twoand three-factor interactions) are prioritized in interpretation.

title: Higher-Order Designs
section: What Is Separability of Factorial Effects?
text:
What Is Separability of Factorial Effects?
In a factorial experiment, several factors are varied simultaneously to study their effects on a response variable. Separability refers to the idea that if some interactions among factors are known or assumed to be negligible, then the effects of these factors can be analyzed separately (i.e., â€œseparatelyâ€ or â€œindependentlyâ€) from the others.

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Example

Suppose you have three factorsâ€”A, B, and C.
If prior knowledge or experimental evidence suggests that factor C does not interact with factors A or B, then the interactions AC, BC, and the three-factor interaction ABC can be removed from the model.
In practical terms, this means you can determine the optimal levels of A and B independently of C and vice versa, greatly simplifying both the design and interpretation of the experiment.

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Why Is It Useful?

Reduced Complexity: With fewer interaction terms, the model has fewer parameters to estimate, which can improve precision and make the analysis more straightforward.
Independent Decision-Making: When interactions are negligible, the optimal settings for one subset of factors can be determined without worrying about their influence on other factors.
Efficient Use of Data: A single, well-designed factorial experiment usually provides more comprehensive information than several smaller experiments done separately.







Important



The assumption of separability must be justified by prior knowledge or preliminary analysis. Otherwise, omitting important interactions might lead to biased conclusions.

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Imposing Separability
Consider a three-factor experiment with factors A, B, and C:
\[
Y_{ijkt} = \mu + \alpha_i + \beta_j + \gamma_k + (\alpha\beta)_{ij} + (\alpha\gamma)_{ik} + (\beta\gamma)_{jk} + (\alpha\beta\gamma)_{ijk} + \epsilon_{ijkt},
\]
If prior knowledge tells us that factor C does not interact with factors A or B, then the following interaction terms are assumed to be zero:
\[
(\alpha\gamma)_{ik} = 0,\quad (\beta\gamma)_{jk} = 0,\quad (\alpha\beta\gamma)_{ijk} = 0.
\]
Thus, the model simplifies to:
\[
Y_{ijkt} = \mu + \alpha_i + \beta_j + \gamma_k + (\alpha\beta)_{ij} + \epsilon_{ijkt}.
\qquad(2)\]

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Derivation Outline

Full Model Setup: Start with the full model including all interactions.
Hypothesis of Negligible Interactions: Hypothesize that \((\alpha\gamma)_{ik} = 0\), \((\beta\gamma)_{jk} = 0\), and \((\alpha\beta\gamma)_{ijk} = 0\). This assumption is based on prior experiments or domain knowledge (see Montgomery (2020)).
Simplification of the Model: Substitute the zero interaction terms into the full model to yield the simplified form:

\[
Y_{ijkt} = \mu + \alpha_i + \beta_j + \gamma_k + (\alpha\beta)_{ij} + \epsilon_{ijkt}.
\]

Parameter Estimation and Orthogonality: In a balanced (orthogonal) design, the estimates of the main effects and the remaining interaction (\(\alpha\beta\)) are independent of the omitted interaction terms. This follows from the Gauss-Markov theorem, which assures that the least squares estimators are the Best Linear Unbiased Estimators (BLUE) under the classical linear model assumptions (Box et al., 2005)

Orthogonality Condition: The design matrix is constructed so that the columns corresponding to main effects and the \(AB\) interaction are orthogonal to those corresponding to the omitted interactions. This ensures that the parameter estimates remain unbiased when the negligible interactions are excluded.

Degrees of Freedom: With fewer parameters to estimate, more degrees of freedom are available for estimating the error variance, leading to increased precision in hypothesis tests regarding the main effects and the \(AB\) interaction.

Summary: The mathematical derivation shows that by assuming certain interactions are zero, the model simplifies and the estimation of the remaining effects becomes more robust due to increased orthogonality and degrees of freedom.

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
What Are Interaction Graphs?
Interaction graphs provide a visual tool to decide which interactions to include in your model:

Nodes: Represent the factors (e.g., A, B, C, etc.).
Edges: Drawn between nodes that are suspected to interact.
Higher-Order Interactions: Triangular or complete connections among three or more nodes indicate the possibility of higher-order interactions.

title: Higher-Order Designs
section: Steps for Constructing an Interaction Graph
text:
Steps for Constructing an Interaction Graph

Plot the Factors: Draw points (nodes) for each factor in your experiment.
Connect Suspected Interacting Factors: Draw a line between two nodes if you suspect a two-factor interaction.

In our example, if factors A and B interact, connect them.

Indicate Higher-Order Interactions: If a three-factor interaction is possible, form a triangle among the three factors.

If factor C does not interact with A or B, leave C disconnected from A and B.

Complexity for More Factors: For experiments with more than three factors, complete graphs (all nodes interconnected) suggest potential four-factor or higher interactions.

Practical Implication: The interaction graph visually reinforces the decision to exclude certain interactions. For instance, in our example, if C is not connected to A or B, it supports the assumption that the interactions involving C (i.e., AC, BC, and ABC) can be dropped from the model.

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Degrees of Freedom (DF)

Factor A: \(a - 1\)
Factor B: \(b - 1\)
Interaction AB: \((a - 1)(b - 1)\)
Error: \(N - ab\)
Total: \(N - 1\)

Where \(N = abn\) is the total number of observations.

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Sum of Squares (SS)

Total SS (\(SS_{Total}\)): Total variability in responses.
Factor SS (\(SS_A, SS_B\)): Variability due to main effects.
Interaction SS (\(SS_{AB}\)): Variability due to interactions.
Error SS (\(SS_{Error}\)): Unexplained variability.

\[
SS_{Total} = \sum (Y - \bar{Y})^2
\]
\[
SS_A = \sum n_i (\bar{Y}_{i..} - \bar{Y})^2
\]
\[
SS_{AB} = \sum n_{ij} (\bar{Y}_{ij.} - \bar{Y}_{i..} - \bar{Y}_{.j.} + \bar{Y})^2
\]
\[
SS_{Error} = SS_{Total} - SS_A - SS_B - SS_{AB}
\]

Mean Squares (MS)
\[
MS = \frac{SS}{DF}
\]


ANOVA Table Example

Note: In unbalanced designs, Type I, II, and III sums of squares may be used to handle unequal sample sizes.

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Main Effects vs.Â Interaction Effects

Main Effect: The independent effect of a single factor on the response.
Interaction Effect: Occurs when the effect of one factor depends on the level of another factor.


Visualizing Interactions
Interaction Plots: Graphical representations where lines represent one factorâ€™s levels across another factorâ€™s levels.

Parallel Lines: Indicate no interaction; main effects are additive.
Non-Parallel Lines: Indicate interaction; effects are dependent.

Example in R:
interaction.plot(data$FactorA, data$FactorB, data$Response, col=c("blue", "red"))
Interpretation: If lines cross or are not parallel, there is an interaction effect, meaning the impact of one factor varies with the level of the other factor.

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Example: Popcorn-Microwave Experiment
Scenario: Three factorsâ€”brand (3 levels), power (2 levels), and time (3 levels)â€”are tested to maximize popcorn popping percentage.
Objective: Identify the optimal combination of brand, power, and time for best popping performance.
R Code Example:

# Load data
data <- read_table(here("data", "dean2017", "popcorn.microwave.txt")) |>
    mutate(
        brand = factor(brand, labels = c("A1", "A2", "A3")),
        power = factor(power, labels = c("Low", "High")),
        time = factor(time, labels = c("Short", "Medium", "Long"))
    ) |>
    rename(PoppingRate = y)

title: Higher-Order Designs
section: Interpreting the Three-Way ANOVA Results (With Consideration of Interactions)
text:
Interpreting the Three-Way ANOVA Results (With Consideration of Interactions)
The ANOVA table summarizes the effects of brand, power, and time on the response variable, along with their interactions. Below is a detailed interpretation:

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Key Findings

Three-Way Interaction

brand:power:time (p = 0.967) â†’ Not significant.

The combined effect of brand, power, and time does not show significant interaction.




Two-Way Interactions

brand:power (p = 0.349) â†’ Not significant.

The effect of power does not change depending on the brand.

brand:time (p = 0.016) â†’ Significant (p < 0.05).

The effect of brand varies across different time levels.

power:time (p = 0.765) â†’ Not significant.

The effect of power does not change over time.




Main Effects

power (p = 0.035) â†’ Significant (p < 0.05).

The level of power has a significant effect on the response.

section: Interaction Plot 1 for Three-Way Interaction- Popcorn-Microwave Experiment
text:

title: Higher-Order Designs
section: Post Hoc Comparisons for Brand:Time Interaction
text:
Post Hoc Comparisons for Brand:Time Interaction

Time = Short

A1 - A2: Difference not significant (p = 0.6882).
A1 - A3: Difference not significant (p = 0.9984).
A2 - A3: Difference not significant (p = 0.6550).
Conclusion: No significant differences in popping rate between brands at the short time level.



Time = Medium

A1 - A2: Difference not significant (p = 0.7384).
A1 - A3: Difference not significant (p = 0.1584).
A2 - A3: Difference significant (p = 0.0351).
Conclusion: Brand A2 has a significantly higher popping rate than A1 at the medium time level.

A1 - A3: Difference not significant (p = 0.2253).
A2 - A3: Difference not significant (p = 0.0733).
Conclusion: Brand A1 has a significantly higher popping rate than A2 at the long time level.

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Equal Sample Sizes: The Setup
Suppose we have an experiment with \(p\) crossed factors (e.g., factors \(A, B, C, \ldots\)), each having levels \(a, b, c, \ldots\). We focus on a complete model or any chosen submodel. Let the total number of replicates in each treatment combination be \(r\). Thus, each combination of factor levels has exactly \(r\) observations.
Key advantages of equal sample sizes:

Formulas for sums of squares and degrees of freedom are simpler.
Estimation of main effects and interactions via least squares takes a simpler form.
Sums of squares decompose additively among factors and interactions in many factorial designs.

We will illustrate with a four-factor design \(A, B, C, D\) (each with \(a, b, c, d\) levels respectively), though the concepts generalize to any number of factors.

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Model Description and Terminology
Consider a four-way complete model with crossed factors \(A, B, C, D\). Denote:

\(\mu\): overall mean
\(\alpha_i\), \(\beta_j\), \(\gamma_k\), \(\delta_l\): main effects for each factor, where \(i = 1,\ldots,a\), \(j = 1,\ldots,b\), \(k = 1,\ldots,c\), and \(l = 1,\ldots,d\).
\(\alpha \beta_{ij}\), \(\alpha \gamma_{ik}\), \(\beta \gamma_{jk}\), \(\ldots\): two-way interactions
\(\alpha \beta \gamma_{ijk}\), \(\ldots\): three-way interactions
\(\alpha \beta \gamma \delta_{ijkl}\): four-way interaction
\(\varepsilon_{ijklt}\): random error for observation \(t\) in the \((i, j, k, l)\)-th combination, where \(t = 1, \ldots, r\).

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Model Equation
\[
y_{ijklt}
= \mu
+ \alpha_i + \beta_j + \gamma_k + \delta_l
+ (\alpha\beta)_{ij} + (\alpha\gamma)_{ik} + (\beta\gamma)_{jk} + \ldots
+ (\alpha\beta\gamma\delta)_{ijkl}
+ \varepsilon_{ijklt}.
\]
When sample sizes are equal \((= r)\), standard formulas for the sums of squares become more direct. If a submodel omits certain higher-order interactions (assuming they are negligible), the same patterns of degrees of freedom and sums of squares still apply, but excluding those omitted terms.

title: Higher-Order Designs
section: Degrees of Freedom for Factorial Effects
text:
Degrees of Freedom for Factorial Effects
For any factorial effect, the degrees of freedom (\(\nu\)) is the product of â€œlevels minus 1â€ across all factors included in that effect. For example, an \(A\)-by-\(B\)-by-\(D\) interaction with factors \(A, B, D\) having \(a, b, d\) levels respectively yields:
\[
\nu_{ABD} = (a - 1)(b - 1)(d - 1).
\]
Similarly, a main effect \(A\) alone has \(\nu_A = a - 1\) degrees of freedom. This pattern continues for interactions of any order.

title: Higher-Order Designs
section: Sums of Squares in Factorial Models

title: Higher-Order Designs
section: Total Sum of Squares and Error
text:
Total Sum of Squares and Error
The total sum of squares,
\[
\text{SS}_{\text{Total}}
= \sum_{i,j,k,l,t}
\bigl(y_{ijklt} - \bar{y}_{\cdot\cdot\cdot\cdot\cdot}\bigr)^2,
\]
splits into sums of squares for factors and interactions plus the residual (or error) sum of squares,
\[
\text{SS}_E
= \text{SS}_{\text{tot}}
-
\bigl[\text{SS}_A + \text{SS}_B + \cdots + \text{SS}(\text{AB}) + \cdots + \text{SS}(\text{ABCD})\bigr].
\]
With equal sample sizes, each effect sum of squares has an interpretation corresponding to â€œhow much variability that effect and its sub-interactions explain,â€ and the remainder is attributed to the residual error.

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Mean Squares and F-Statistics
For an effect \(E\) (e.g.Â a main effect or an interaction), the mean square is:
\[
\text{MS}(E)
=
\frac{\text{SS}(E)}{\nu_E},
\]
where \(\nu_E\) is the degrees of freedom for that effect. Similarly, the error mean square is:
\[
\text{MS}(E) = \frac{\text{SS}(E)}{\nu_E},
\]
where \(\nu_E\) is the error degrees of freedom.
To test whether a factorial effect is negligible, we form an F-ratio:
\[
F = \frac{\text{MS}(E)}{\text{MS}_E},
\]
and compare with an \(F\)-distribution with \(\nu_E\) (effect) and \(\nu_E\) (error) degrees of freedom at a chosen significance level \(\alpha\).

title: Higher-Order Designs
section: Contrasts, Estimable Functions, and Confidence Intervals
text:
Contrasts, Estimable Functions, and Confidence Intervals
An estimable contrast for a factorial effect is a linear combination of relevant parameters whose coefficients sum to zero across each subscript index. Under equal sample sizes, the least squares estimate is obtained by substituting cell means for each parameter term. The sum of squares associated to testing that a specific contrast is zero is the square of the normalized contrast estimate.
Simultaneous confidence intervals for main effects, interactions, or contrasts can be constructed using methods such as Bonferroni, ScheffÃ©, Tukey, or Dunnett, adjusting critical values as appropriate.

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Numerical Example in R
We will illustrate the analysis of a four-way factorial design with equal sample sizes. Suppose each factor \(A, B, C, D\) has 2 levels, resulting in \(2^4 = 16\) cells, each with \(r = 3\) observations. Let us simulate the data in R and perform the standard ANOVA.

# Simulate data for a 2^4 factorial with equal sample size r = 3
# True means to illustrate a possible scenario
set.seed(1234)
n <- 16 * 3 # total observations
# Suppose factors A, B, C, D each with 2 levels: coded as 0,1 for simplicity
# We'll generate a design matrix with 16 unique rows
A <- rep(rep(c(0, 1), each = 8), times = 3)
B <- rep(rep(c(0, 1), each = 4, times = 2), times = 3)
C <- rep(rep(c(0, 1), each = 2, times = 4), times = 3)
D <- rep(rep(c(0, 1), times = 8), times = 3)

# Let's set up a plausible model
# y = grand mean + A + B + ... + AB + AD + ... + noise
grand_mean <- 10
a_eff <- 2
b_eff <- -1
c_eff <- 3
d_eff <- 0.5
ab_eff <- 1.5
ac_eff <- 0
bc_eff <- 0
ad_eff <- -0.8
bd_eff <- 0
cd_eff <- 0.7
abcd_eff <- 0.2

# Generate response
y_mean <- grand_mean +
    a_eff * A +
    b_eff * B +
    c_eff * C +
    d_eff * D +
    ab_eff * A * B +
    ac_eff * A * C +
    bc_eff * B * C +
    ad_eff * A * D +
    bd_eff * B * D +
    cd_eff * C * D +
    abcd_eff * A * B * C * D

# Add random error
y <- y_mean + rnorm(n, mean = 0, sd = 1.5)

my_data <- data.frame(
    A = factor(A),
    B = factor(B),
    C = factor(C),
    D = factor(D),
    y = y
)

Explanation:

We fit the complete 4-way factorial model in R: lm(y ~ A * B * C * D).
The ANOVA table from anova(fit_full) partitions the total sum of squares into main effects (A, B, C, D), two-way interactions (A:B, A:C, B:C, etc.), up to the 4-way interaction (A:B:C:D), plus the residual or error.

Running this snippet in R yields sums of squares for each effect, degrees of freedom, mean squares, \(F\)-statistics, and p-values. We can easily see which effects are significant and draw conclusions accordingly.

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Guidelines for Analysis and Interpretation

Check Interactions: Always examine higher-order interactions first. If they are negligible, remove them from the model for simplicity and improved precision on lower-order terms.
Check Residual Diagnostics: Plot residuals versus fitted values, check normal Qâ€“Q plots, etc., to verify that assumptions are not severely violated.
Conduct F-tests: Evaluate significance of main effects and interactions via the standard ANOVA approach.
Multiple Comparisons: If needed, build simultaneous confidence intervals for main effects or factor level means, using Tukey, Bonferroni, ScheffÃ©, or Dunnett methods to maintain appropriate error rates.
Factor Collapse: If factor interactions are not present, you can â€œcollapseâ€ factor levels to a simpler design or analysis. Equal cell sizes make these collapses straightforward.
Practical Significance: Consider not just p-values but effect sizes to determine whether a factor or interaction is meaningful in practice.

title: Higher-Order Designs
section: Advanced Section: Higher-Order Interactions and Orthogonal Decompositions
text:
Advanced Section: Higher-Order Interactions and Orthogonal Decompositions
When the design is balanced (equal \(r\)), the sums of squares due to main effects and interactions are orthogonal decompositions of the total variability. This orthogonality simplifies the structure of the F-tests. In advanced problems:

One can form a partial or incomplete model if some interactions are considered negligible.
One can compute sums of squares for a submodel easily by dropping negligible effects from the complete model.
In unbalanced settings, computations become more complex, often requiring specialized regression-based formulas or computational software to obtain Type I, II, or III sums of squares (Montgomery 2020, Christensen 2018).

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Exercises

Concept Check Suppose you have a 3-factor design \(A, B, C\) with levels \(a=3, b=2, c=2\) and each cell has \(r=4\) observations.

What is the total number of observations?
Write the degrees of freedom for each main effect and each interaction.
Show how you would write the sum of squares formula for \(ABC\).

Manual Computation Consider a 2-factor design \(A, B\) each with 2 levels (\(a=2, b=2\)) and \(r=3\) observations per cell. The four cell means are:

\[
\bar{y}_{11.} = 12,\quad \bar{y}_{12.} = 15,\quad \bar{y}_{21.} = 14,\quad \bar{y}_{22.} = 20.
\]

Compute the sums of squares for \(A\), \(B\), and \(AB\) using the â€œplus-minusâ€ expansions.

Verify that their sum plus ss(error) equals the total sum of squares.


R Analysis
Simulate a 3-factor balanced design with factors \(A, B, C\) each at 3 levels, with \(r=2\) observations in each cell. Introduce known main effects and interactions in your data-generating code. Then

Fit the full factorial model.

Examine the significance of each main effect and interaction.

Provide conclusions and interpret in context.

Interaction Plots
Suppose in a 3-factor design \(A, B, C\) with equal sample sizes, you suspect a strong \(AB\) interaction but negligible \(BC\) and \(AC\) interactions. Write the â€œrulesâ€ for the degrees of freedom and the sum of squares for \((AB)\). Provide a short explanation of how you would confirm or refute the presence of \(AB\) interaction in the data.

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Types of Sums of Squares

Type I (Sequential): Tests factors sequentially, dependent on the order of entry.
Type II (Marginal): Tests main effects after accounting for other main effects but ignoring interactions.
Type III (Conditional): Tests main effects after accounting for all other factors, including interactions.

R Implementation with car Package:
library(car)

# Fit ANOVA model
fit <- aov(Response ~ FactorA * FactorB * FactorC, data = data)

# Type II Sums of Squares
car::Anova(fit, type="II")

# Type III Sums of Squares
car::Anova(fit, type="III")
Considerations:

Type III is commonly used in software like SAS and SPSS, especially when interactions are present.
Type II is suitable when interactions are not of primary interest.

References: Christensen (2018) provides an in-depth discussion on handling unbalanced designs and choosing appropriate sums of squares.

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Three-Way ANOVA Example
To illustrate these concepts, letâ€™s walk through a three-way ANOVA example and use Râ€™s emmeans package to conduct simple effects analysis and probe interactions. We will use a dataset from a (fictional but realistic) experiment on memory retention (Three-way analysis of variance â€“ Experimental Designs and Statistical Methods). In this study, researchers manipulated:

Feedback given during learning (Factor A with levels: none, positive, negative),
Type of learning material (Factor B with levels: low freq/low emotion words, high freq/low emotion, high freq/high emotion),
Age group of participants (Factor C with levels: fifth graders vs.Â high school seniors).

The outcome is the number of words recalled one week later. There are \(3 \times 3 \times 2 = 18\) experimental conditions (cells), with a balanced design of \(n=5\) participants per cell (90 observations total) (Three-way analysis of variance â€“ Experimental Designs and Statistical Methods). We fit a three-way ANOVA to this data and then examine simple effects.



data(words, package = "hecedsm") # hypothetical dataset from Keppel & Wickens (2004)
xtabs(words ~ feedback + material + age, data = words)

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Three Way Interaction Interpretation
For padagogial purposes, we examine the three-way interaction between material type, feedback, and age group. We will use the emmeans package to probe the interaction.

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Simple Effects Analysis
Simple Two-Way Interactions at Each Level of C: The significant materialÃ—age interaction means the difference in recall between material types is different for fifth graders versus seniors. We can explore this by testing the simple two-way effect of material Ã— feedback within each age group. Essentially, we split the analysis by age to see how the other factors behave for each subgroup (Microsoft PowerPoint - Three-way ANOVAr.ppt).
We will use the emmeans package to probe the interaction.

text:
Interpreting the Simple Effects Analysis

Fifth Graders:

Feedback Ã— Material: Significant interaction (p â‰ˆ 0.021).

High School Seniors:

Interpreting the Two-Way ANOVA Results
According to the principles discussed, since the three-way interaction is not significant, we do not necessarily have to probe a three-way pattern. However, we do have a significant two-way interaction (material Ã— age). This suggests the effect of material type on memory depends on age group (or vice versa). title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Summary

Fifth Graders: Recall significantly differs between low/low and high/low, and between low/low and high/high materials. The high/high material yields the highest recall.
High School Seniors: Recall does not significantly differ between material types.

The results of the simple effects analysis show that the material type significantly affects recall in fifth graders, with the high-frequency/high-emotion material (letâ€™s call it the â€œdifficult materialâ€) yielding the highest recall. In contrast, material type does not significantly affect high school seniorsâ€™ recall. The significant interaction between material and age suggests that the effect of material type on memory retention differs between the two age groups. Specifically, the high-frequency/high-emotion material has a more pronounced impact on recall for fifth graders compared to high school seniors. This finding highlights the importance of considering age-specific factors when designing educational interventions or memory enhancement strategies.

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Addressing Complex Interactions

Higher-Order Interactions
Beyond three factors, interactions become increasingly complex and harder to interpret. Itâ€™s essential to focus on interactions that make theoretical sense and are supported by the data.


Simplifying the Model

Model Selection: Start with a full model including all interactions. If higher-order interactions are not significant, consider removing them for simpler interpretation.
Hierarchical Models: Retain lower-order interactions when higher-order interactions are present, but omit higher-order interactions if lower-order ones are not significant.

Example in R:
# Full model
full_fit <- aov(Response ~ FactorA * FactorB * FactorC, data = data)

# Reduced model without three-way interaction
reduced_fit <- aov(Response ~ FactorA * FactorB + FactorA * FactorC + FactorB * FactorC, data = data)

# Compare models
anova(reduced_fit, full_fit)

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Residual Analysis
Residuals (\(e_{ijkt}\)) are the differences between observed and predicted values. Analyzing residuals helps detect violations of model assumptions.

Residual Plots

Residuals vs.Â Fitted Values:

Purpose: Check for homoscedasticity and model fit.
Interpretation:

Random Scatter: Assumptions hold.
Patterns (e.g., funnel shape): Indicate heteroscedasticity.


Normal Q-Q Plot:

Purpose: Assess normality of residuals.
Interpretation:

Points near the line: Normality holds.
Deviations: Non-normality present.


Residuals vs.Â Order of Data:

Purpose: Detect non-independence or autocorrelation.
Interpretation:

Random Scatter: Independence holds.
Patterns or Trends: Violation of independence.

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
R Implementation
# Fit the model
fit <- aov(Response ~ FactorA * FactorB * FactorC, data = data)

# Residuals vs Fitted
plot(fit, which=1)

# Normal Q-Q Plot
plot(fit, which=2)

# Residuals vs Order
data$Order <- 1:nrow(data)
plot(data$Order, resid(fit), main="Residuals vs. Order", xlab="Order", ylab="Residuals")
abline(h=0, col="red")
Interpretation: Examine each plot for signs of assumption violations and consider corrective actions if needed.

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Remedies for Assumption Violations

Transformations:

Log Transformation: Useful for stabilizing variance when it increases with the mean.
Square-Root Transformation: Often used for count data.
Box-Cox Transformation: Systematic method to find the best power transformation.

R Implementation:

library(MASS)
# Box-Cox Transformation
boxcox_fit <- boxcox(fit, lambda=seq(-2, 2, by=0.1))

# Identify optimal lambda
optimal_lambda <- boxcox_fit$x[which.max(boxcox_fit$y)]

# Transform Response
data$Response_transformed <- (data$Response^optimal_lambda - 1) / optimal_lambda

# Re-fit the model with transformed data
fit_transformed <- aov(Response_transformed ~ FactorA * FactorB * FactorC, data = data)
summary(fit_transformed)

Alternative Models:

Mixed-Effects Models: Address non-independence by incorporating random effects.
Nonparametric Methods: Utilize methods like the Kruskal-Wallis test when assumptions are severely violated.

R Implementation:

library(lme4)

# Mixed-Effects Model Example
mixed_fit <- lmer(Response ~ FactorA * FactorB * FactorC + (1|RandomFactor), data = data)
summary(mixed_fit)

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Confidence Intervals for Higher-Order Contrasts
For a \(k\)-factor interaction, the confidence interval for a contrast \(L\) is given by:
\[
\text{CI} = \hat{L} \pm t_{\alpha/2, df} \sqrt{\text{Var}(\hat{L})}
\]
Where:

\(\hat{L}\): Estimated contrast.
\(t_{\alpha/2, df}\): Critical value from the t-distribution.
\(\text{Var}(\hat{L})\): Variance of the contrast estimate.

Derivation:

Estimator: \(\hat{L} = \sum c_i \hat{\mu}_i\)
Variance: \(\text{Var}(\hat{L}) = \sigma^2 \sum \frac{c_i^2}{n_i}\) (Assuming equal sample sizes and independence)
Confidence Interval: Using the properties of the normal distribution for large sample sizes or exact t-distribution for smaller samples.

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Box-Cox Transformation
The Box-Cox transformation seeks an optimal power transformation to stabilize variance and normalize residuals.
\[
Y'(\lambda) =
\begin{cases}
\frac{Y^\lambda - 1}{\lambda} & \text{if } \lambda \neq 0, \\
\ln(Y) & \text{if } \lambda = 0.
\end{cases}
\]
Steps in R:

Fit the ANOVA model:

fit <- aov(Response ~ FactorA * FactorB * FactorC, data = data)

Apply Box-Cox:

library(MASS)
boxcox_fit <- boxcox(fit, lambda=seq(-2,2, by=0.1))
optimal_lambda <- boxcox_fit$x[which.max(boxcox_fit$y)]

Transform the Response:

data$Response_transformed <- (data$Response^optimal_lambda - 1) / optimal_lambda

Re-fit the Model with Transformed Data:

fit_transformed <- aov(Response_transformed ~ FactorA * FactorB * FactorC, data = data)
summary(fit_transformed)
Interpretation: The optimal \(\lambda\) indicates the best power transformation to achieve homoscedasticity and normality. Re-fitting the model on transformed data should show improved diagnostic plots.

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Mathematical Proof of Interaction Contrasts

Interaction Contrasts Measure Deviations from Additivity
Definition: In a three-factor design, the interaction contrast measures how the combined effect of three factors deviates from the sum of their individual and two-factor interaction effects.
Proof Steps:

Model Setup:

\[
Y_{ijk} = \mu + \alpha_i + \beta_j + \gamma_k + (\alpha\beta)_{ij} + (\alpha\gamma)_{ik} + (\beta\gamma)_{jk} + (\alpha\beta\gamma)_{ijk} + \epsilon_{ijk}
\]

Additivity Condition: If \((\alpha\beta\gamma)_{ijk} = 0\) for all \(i,j,k\), then:

\[
Y_{ijk} = \mu + \alpha_i + \beta_j + \gamma_k + (\alpha\beta)_{ij} + (\alpha\gamma)_{ik} + (\beta\gamma)_{jk} + \epsilon_{ijk}
\]
This represents an additive model where the combined effects of factors are purely additive without higher-order interactions.

Interaction Contrast: Define the three-way interaction contrast as:

\[
L = (\alpha\beta\gamma)_{ijk}
\]

Zero Interaction Contrasts Imply Additivity: If \(L = 0\) for all combinations, then:

\[
Y_{ijk} = \mu + \alpha_i + \beta_j + \gamma_k + (\alpha\beta)_{ij} + (\alpha\gamma)_{ik} + (\beta\gamma)_{jk} + \epsilon_{ijk}
\]
Hence, the absence of three-way interactions leads to an additive relationship among factors.

Conclusion: The interaction contrasts \(L\) quantify the extent to which the actual response deviates from what would be expected under additivity. Non-zero contrasts indicate the presence of higher-order interactions.

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Key Points

Balanced Design:
A balanced design means that each treatment combination (or cell) has the same number of observations. This equality of replications helps in achieving uniform precision across estimates.
Orthogonality:
Orthogonality refers to the statistical property where the columns of the design matrix (which correspond to different effects, such as main effects or interactions) are uncorrelated. When the columns are orthogonal, the least squares estimates of the effects are independent of one another.

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Relationship Between the Two

Balanced â†’ Often Orthogonal (in Full Factorials):
In a full factorial experiment with equal replication (a balanced design) and proper coding (such as using orthogonal contrasts), the main effects and interaction effects tend to be orthogonal. This means that the estimates for one effect do not â€œborrowâ€ information from another, simplifying both interpretation and hypothesis testing. For example, in the model
\[
Y_{ijk} = \mu + \alpha_i + \beta_j + \gamma_k + (\alpha\beta)_{ij} + \epsilon_{ijk},
\] the main effects \(\alpha_i\), \(\beta_j\), and \(\gamma_k\) are orthogonal to each other, as are the interaction effects \((\alpha\beta)_{ij}\) with the main effects.
A balanced design will typically ensure that the estimates for \(\alpha_i\), \(\beta_j\), and \((\alpha\beta)_{ij}\) are independentâ€”provided that the design matrix is constructed with orthogonal contrasts. This is one of the reasons why balanced designs are highly valuedâ€”they help satisfy the conditions required for the Gauss-Markov theorem, ensuring that the least squares estimators are BLUE (Box et al., 2005).

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Orthogonality Without Balance: A Caveat
It is possible, in some cases, to have orthogonal contrasts even if the design is not perfectly balanced. However, achieving this often requires careful design construction (for instance, through specific contrast coding) that compensates for unequal sample sizes. In general, though, balance makes it much easier to achieve and verify orthogonality.

Balanced Does Not Always Imply Complete Orthogonality:
Not every balanced design will automatically produce orthogonal estimates for all effects. For instance:

In fractional factorial designs or designs with certain constraints, balance in the number of observations per cell does not guarantee that the factor levels or contrasts are arranged in an orthogonal fashion.
If the design involves aliasing or confounding (even in a balanced structure), some effects may not be independently estimated.

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Summary

Balance is a favorable condition for orthogonality, especially in full factorial experiments with equal replication and proper contrast coding.
However, balance alone does not guarantee orthogonality for every effect, particularly in more complex or constrained designs.
Orthogonality ensures independent estimation of the effects (including interactions), which is essential for clear interpretation and efficient testing of hypotheses. Yet, to achieve orthogonality, the design must be both balanced and appropriately structured.

Thus, while a balanced design is a key step toward orthogonal estimation of effects, it is not a blanket guaranteeâ€”additional considerations in the design (such as the structure of contrasts and the absence of confounding) are necessary to ensure that all effects, including interactions, are estimated orthogonally.

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
The Concept of Orthogonality
Two vectors (or columns in a design matrix) are said to be orthogonal if their inner product is zero. In the context of experimental design, consider two contrast vectors \(\mathbf{c}_1\) and \(\mathbf{c}_2\) corresponding to two treatment contrasts. They are orthogonal if
\[
\mathbf{c}_1^\top \mathbf{c}_2 = 0.
\]
Orthogonality implies that the information contained in one contrast is independent of the information in the other.

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
The Role of Balance
For a one-way ANOVA with \(t\) treatments and a common replication number \(n\) for each treatment, the design matrix \(\mathbf{X}\) can be structured so that the sum of the indicator variables for each treatment is equal. In such a design, the sum of squares associated with the treatments is completely independent of the error sum of squares.

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Matrix Proof of Orthogonality
Consider the following model for a balanced one-way design:
\[
Y_{ij} = \mu + \tau_i + \epsilon_{ij}, \quad i = 1, 2, \dots, t,\quad j = 1, 2, \dots, n,
\]
where

\(\mu\) is the overall mean,
\(\tau_i\) is the effect of the \(i\)-th treatment (subject to the constraint \(\sum_{i=1}^{t} \tau_i = 0\)),
\(\epsilon_{ij}\) are independent errors with \(E[\epsilon_{ij}] = 0\) and \(\operatorname{Var}(\epsilon_{ij}) = \sigma^2\).

Let the design matrix \(\mathbf{X}\) be partitioned as
\[
\mathbf{X} = \begin{pmatrix}
\mathbf{1} & \mathbf{X}_\tau
\end{pmatrix},
\]
where \(\mathbf{1}\) is an \(N \times 1\) vector of ones (with \(N = tn\)), and \(\mathbf{X}_\tau\) is the \(N \times (t-1)\) matrix representing the treatment effects with an appropriate set of contrasts.
For a balanced design the structure of \(\mathbf{X}_\tau\) ensures that
\[
\mathbf{X}_\tau^\top \mathbf{X}_\tau = k\, \mathbf{I}_{t-1},
\]
where \(k\) is a constant proportional to the number of replications and \(\mathbf{I}_{t-1}\) is the \((t-1)\times(t-1)\) identity matrix. This result shows that the columns (i.e., the treatment contrasts) are orthogonal.

Detailed Steps

Balanced Replication:
Each treatment appears \(n\) times so that the sum of the indicator for treatment \(i\) is \(n\). For any two different treatments \(i\) and \(j\):

\[
\sum_{l=1}^{N} x_{l,i} \, x_{l,j} = 0,
\]
when the columns are centered (i.e., after imposing the constraint \(\sum_{i=1}^{t} \tau_i = 0\)). This centering is key to orthogonality.

Contrast Construction:
When forming contrasts, one typically chooses contrast coefficients \(c_{i}\) such that

\[
\sum_{i=1}^{t} c_{i} = 0.
\] For two contrasts \(\mathbf{c}^{(1)}\) and \(\mathbf{c}^{(2)}\), the balance of the design implies
\[
\sum_{i=1}^{t} c^{(1)}_i \, c^{(2)}_i = 0.
\] This follows because, with equal replication, each contrast is scaled by \(n\) and the orthogonality condition is preserved.

Projection Interpretation:
The projection matrix onto the column space of \(\mathbf{X}_\tau\) is given by

\[
\mathbf{P} = \mathbf{X}_\tau \left(\mathbf{X}_\tau^\top \mathbf{X}_\tau\right)^{-1}\mathbf{X}_\tau^\top.
\]
When \(\mathbf{X}_\tau^\top \mathbf{X}_\tau\) is diagonal (as in the balanced case), the off-diagonal elements of the projection matrix vanish, indicating that the treatment effects are estimated independently (i.e., orthogonally).

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Intuitive Explanation
Imagine you have a set of equally weighted arrows (representing treatment contrasts) in a space. In a balanced design, these arrows point in mutually independent directionsâ€”none of the arrows â€œshadowâ€ any other. As a result, any movement (or change) in one direction does not influence the measurement in any other direction. This geometrical interpretation is exactly what orthogonality means and why it simplifies the ANOVA table: the treatment sum of squares does not â€œcontaminateâ€ the error sum of squares.

title: Higher-Order Designs
text:
Summary
The orthogonality in balanced designs stems from:

Equal replication: Each treatment is observed an equal number of times.
Properly constructed contrasts: With the constraint \(\sum_{i=1}^{t} \tau_i = 0\), contrasts satisfy \(\sum c_i = 0\) and, hence, their inner products are zero.
Diagonal structure of \(\mathbf{X}_\tau^\top \mathbf{X}_\tau\): This ensures that the estimated effects are uncorrelated.

This property is central in simplifying the statistical analysis, as it allows the decomposition of the total variability into independent components corresponding to treatments and error.

title: Model Diagnostics
text:
When using ANOVA or regression models, the reliability and validity of inferences depend on certain assumptions:

Independence of Errors: Observations should not be correlated.
Constant Variance (Homoscedasticity): The variability of errors should remain constant across treatments or predicted values.
Normality of Errors: Residuals should follow a normal distribution.

If these assumptions fail, confidence intervals and hypothesis tests may yield misleading conclusions. This lecture focuses on systematic ways to verify assumptions, diagnose problems, and apply corrective measures. By conducting proper diagnostic checks, we can maintain rigor and integrity in our statistical analyses.



Understand the importance of verifying model assumptions in ANOVA and regression.
Learn diagnostic tools (residual plots, normal probability plots) to detect assumption violations.
Explore transformations and alternative modeling strategies to address violations.
Develop proficiency in R for performing diagnostics and interpreting results.
Challenge understanding through exercises involving medium to complex scenarios and proofs.




To implement MCPs and contrasts in R, we will use the following packages:

pacman::p_load(dplyr, ggplot2, here, readr, flextable, PMCMRplus)


dplyr: Data manipulation and summarization.
ggplot2: Data visualization.
lsmeans and emmeans: Post hoc comparisons and multiple comparisons.
pacman: Package management.
here: File path management.
readr: Reading data files.
flextable: Creating tables.
PMCMRplus: Pairwise multiple comparisons.




Analogy: Imagine you have a pair of binoculars (your model). The assumptions are like cleaning the lenses before use. If the lenses are dirty (violated assumptions), you see distorted images (biased conclusions). Checking assumptions and fixing issues (cleaning lenses) ensures a clear view of the underlying relationships.
Simple Example: Suppose you test four treatments for battery life. After ANOVA suggests differences, you examine residuals. If residuals fan out like a megaphone, variance is not constant. Just as uneven ground makes walking difficult, uneven variance complicates inference. You may need transformations to â€œlevel the playing field.â€




Visual Inspection of Residuals: Residuals, defined as \(e_{ij} = Y_{ij} - \hat{Y}_{ij}\), reflect unexplained variation. By plotting residuals against fitted values or explanatory variables, patterns emerge.
Standardized Residuals: Standardized residuals \(z_{ij} = \frac{e_{ij}}{\sqrt{\text{MSE}}}\) help detect outliers and unusual patterns because they are put on a common scale.
Normality Checks: Normal probability plots (QQ-plots) show if residuals deviate from a straight line, indicating potential non-normality.
Independence Checks: Residuals plotted in the order of data collection can reveal time trends or autocorrelation, violating independence.
Variance Homogeneity Checks: Residuals vs.Â fitted value plots or group-specific standard deviations highlight heteroscedasticity.

Below is a step-by-step tutorial on standardized residuals in both ANOVA and Regression contexts. We will cover:

The difference between raw residuals and standardized residuals.
Various formulas/definitions of standardized residuals.
Usage in both ANOVA and regression models.
The relationship of these definitions to the rstandard() function in R.







In a linear modelâ€”be it for ANOVA or regressionâ€”the raw residual \(e_i\) for the \(i\)th observation is:

\[
e_i = y_i - \hat{y}_i,
\]
where:

\(y_i\) is the observed value,
\(\hat{y}_i\) is the fitted (predicted) value from the model.





Raw residuals are on the same scale as the response variable, so comparing residuals across data points or across different models can be less meaningful if the variance of the error changes or the scale of the response variable changes.
Standardized residuals (or scaled residuals) transform the raw residuals so that they take into account the modelâ€™s standard error of the residual for each point. This makes it easier to detect outliers or high-leverage points, because you put them on a comparable scale (akin to a z-score).





The exact formula for a â€œstandardizedâ€ residual can vary across textbooks and software. The major variants you will see are:

Simple Standardized Residual (often used in introductory ANOVA contexts):

\[
r_i = \frac{e_i}{\sqrt{\text{MSE}}},
\]
where MSE is the mean squared error (also called \(s^2\)) from the overall model.

This approach uses the same denominator (i.e., \(\sqrt{MSE}\)) for every residual.


Internally Studentized Residual (sometimes also called the â€œstandardized residualâ€ in many software packages, including base Râ€™s rstandard() for lm objects):

\[
r_i^\text{(int)} = \frac{e_i}{\sqrt{s^2(1 - h_{ii})}},
\]
where:

\(s^2\) is the residual (error) variance estimate from the full model,
\(h_{ii}\) is the hat value (or leverage) for observation \(i\). (In matrix terms, \(\mathbf{H} = X (X^\top X)^{-1} X^\top\) is the â€œhat matrix,â€ and \(h_{ii}\) is its \(i\)th diagonal element.)
\(1 - h_{ii}\) is a scale adjustment that accounts for leverage.


Externally Studentized Residual (also called the â€œdeleted residualâ€ or â€œR-studentâ€):

\[
r_i^\text{(ext)} = \frac{e_i}{\sqrt{s_{(-i)}^2 (1 - h_{ii})}},
\]
where:

\(s_{(-i)}^2\) is the mean squared error calculated by fitting the model without the \(i\)th observation (i.e., a leave-one-out MSE).
This further adjusts the estimate of residual variance by removing the \(i\)th point from the fit, which can detect outliers more sensitively.

Depending on the method or software, â€œstandardized residualsâ€ could refer to either the simple version or the internally studentized version. In most modern regression/ANOVA software:

rstandard() typically provides the internally studentized residuals.
rstudent() typically provides the externally studentized residuals.




ANOVA (Analysis of Variance) is essentially a special case of linear regression with categorical predictors. The concept of residuals is exactly the same: - In a one-way ANOVA, each group has a predicted mean \(\hat{y}_i\). The raw residual is \(y_i - \hat{y}_i\). - If you want to standardize by the overall MSE, you could compute
\[
r_i = \frac{y_i - \hat{y}_i}{\sqrt{MSE}}
\]
or the more general (internally studentized) version:
\[
r_i^\text{(int)} = \frac{y_i - \hat{y}_i}{\sqrt{MSE \cdot (1 - h_{ii})}}.
\]
In an ANOVA model, \(h_{ii}\) is often simpler to compute because design matrices are typically 0/1-coded for each group, so each pointâ€™s leverage depends on how many replicates are in each group, among other factors.
Regression (with continuous predictors) uses exactly the same approach: the raw residual is \(e_i = y_i - \hat{y}_i\). - In regression, the hat value \(h_{ii}\) depends on the design matrix \(X\) (i.e., the set of predictors, their transformations, interactions, etc.). - Standardized or studentized residuals are used to: - Check for outliers (extreme residuals). - Assess model fit in residual vs.Â fitted-value plots. - Evaluate if residuals follow typical assumptions (normality, equal variance).






If you fit a linear model in R using:

fit <- lm(y ~ x1 + x2, data = mydata)
Then you can get standardized residuals via:
std_res <- rstandard(fit)

By default, rstandard() returns the internally studentized residuals. Mathematically (for observation \(i\)):

\[
\text{rstandard}(i) = \frac{e_i}{\sqrt{s^2 (1 - h_{ii})}},
\]
where \(s^2\) is the estimated MSE from the full model, and \(h_{ii}\) is the leverage for observation \(i\).




rstudent(fit) returns the externally studentized residuals (sometimes called the R-student residuals):

\[
\text{rstudent}(i) = \frac{e_i}{\sqrt{s_{(-i)}^2 (1 - h_{ii})}},
\]

residuals(fit) or simply fit$residuals returns the raw (unstandardized) residuals:

\[
e_i = y_i - \hat{y}_i.
\]




Hereâ€™s a quick demonstration using a built-in dataset in R.



# Load the built-in dataset
data(mtcars)
# Fit a linear model (mpg ~ wt + hp)
fit <- lm(mpg ~ wt + hp, data = mtcars)
# Raw residuals
raw_res <- residuals(fit)
# Internally studentized (standardized) residuals
std_res <- rstandard(fit)
# Externally studentized residuals
stud_res <- rstudent(fit)
# Compare
head(data.frame(raw_res, std_res, stud_res))









raw_res
std_res
stud_res

-2.5723294
-1.0145865
-1.0151193

-1.5834826

-0.6166309

-0.9842273
