-0.9459788







TableÂ 1: Standardized Residuals Example




You can see how the raw residuals are just differences from fitted values, while the standardized and studentized ones have been scaled differently.






# A simple one-way ANOVA example
df <- data.frame(
    group = rep(c("A", "B", "C"), each = 10),
    y = c(
        rnorm(10, mean = 5, sd = 1),
        rnorm(10, mean = 7, sd = 1),
        rnorm(10, mean = 6, sd = 1)
    )
)

fit_anova <- lm(y ~ group, data = df) # identical to aov(y ~ group, data = df)
std_res_anova <- rstandard(fit_anova)

head(std_res_anova)

         1          2          3          4          5          6 
-1.8688760  1.1705936  0.7670691  0.6010791  0.9606203  0.2034584 



TableÂ 2: ANOVA Standardized Residuals Example



This again yields internally studentized residuals. The same formulas from regression hold for an ANOVA setting because ANOVA is just a linear model with categorical predictors.





Thresholds for potential outliers:

A standardized (or studentized) residual that exceeds about \(\pm 2\) could be noteworthy, and \(\pm 3\) is often considered large in typical Normal-error contexts.
However, the interpretation depends on your sample size and the distribution of residuals.

Leverage and influence:

If you see a large standardized residual, check also the pointâ€™s leverage \((h_{ii})\). A high-leverage point with a large standardized residual can strongly affect the regression line or ANOVA estimates.

Diagnostic Plots:

Plotting standardized residuals vs.Â fitted values is a common practice to detect patterns in the residuals. If the model is well-specified, these points should look like random scatter around 0 with no obvious pattern and relatively consistent variance.






Raw residuals tell you the difference between observed and fitted values on the scale of the original data.
Standardized (or Studentized) residuals provide a way to compare residuals on a common scale that accounts for the overall error variance and, importantly, each pointâ€™s leverage.
Râ€™s rstandard() function by default computes internally studentized residuals, which is often what people mean by â€œstandardized residualsâ€ in practice.
For more robust outlier detection, you can use rstudent() (externally studentized residuals), which removes the \(i\)th point when estimating its variance.



When someone says â€œstandardized residual,â€ check which version they are referring to. In modern usage (especially in R), â€œstandardized residualâ€ commonly refers to the internally studentized residual \(\frac{e_i}{\sqrt{s^2 (1-h_{ii})}}\), as provided by rstandard(). For more sensitive outlier detection, consider the externally studentized residuals \(\frac{e_i}{\sqrt{s_{(-i)}^2 (1-h_{ii})}}\) from rstudent(). Both are useful for checking model assumptions and identifying influential points.

r_i^\text{(int)} = \frac{y_i - \hat{y}_i}{\sqrt{MSE \cdot (1 - h_{ii})}}.
\]
In an ANOVA model, \(h_{ii}\) is often simpler to compute because design matrices are typically 0/1-coded for each group, so each pointâ€™s leverage depends on how many replicates are in each group, among other factors.
Regression (with continuous predictors) uses exactly the same approach: the raw residual is \(e_i = y_i - \hat{y}_i\). - In regression, the hat value \(h_{ii}\) depends on the design matrix \(X\) (i.e., the set of predictors, their transformations, interactions, etc.). - Standardized or studentized residuals are used to: - Check for outliers (extreme residuals). - Assess model fit in residual vs.Â fitted-value plots. - Evaluate if residuals follow typical assumptions (normality, equal variance).

title: Model Diagnostics
text:
If you fit a linear model in R using:

fit <- lm(y ~ x1 + x2, data = mydata)
Then you can get standardized residuals via:
std_res <- rstandard(fit)

By default, rstandard() returns the internally studentized residuals. Mathematically (for observation \(i\)):

\[
\text{rstandard}(i) = \frac{e_i}{\sqrt{s^2 (1 - h_{ii})}},
\]
where \(s^2\) is the estimated MSE from the full model, and \(h_{ii}\) is the leverage for observation \(i\).




rstudent(fit) returns the externally studentized residuals (sometimes called the R-student residuals):

\[
\text{rstudent}(i) = \frac{e_i}{\sqrt{s_{(-i)}^2 (1 - h_{ii})}},
\]

residuals(fit) or simply fit$residuals returns the raw (unstandardized) residuals:

\[
e_i = y_i - \hat{y}_i.
\]

title: Model Diagnostics
text:
Hereâ€™s a quick demonstration using a built-in dataset in R.



# Load the built-in dataset
data(mtcars)
# Fit a linear model (mpg ~ wt + hp)
fit <- lm(mpg ~ wt + hp, data = mtcars)
# Raw residuals
raw_res <- residuals(fit)
# Internally studentized (standardized) residuals
std_res <- rstandard(fit)
# Externally studentized residuals
stud_res <- rstudent(fit)
# Compare
head(data.frame(raw_res, std_res, stud_res))









raw_res
std_res
stud_res

You can see how the raw residuals are just differences from fitted values, while the standardized and studentized ones have been scaled differently.






# A simple one-way ANOVA example
df <- data.frame(
    group = rep(c("A", "B", "C"), each = 10),
    y = c(
        rnorm(10, mean = 5, sd = 1),
        rnorm(10, mean = 7, sd = 1),
        rnorm(10, mean = 6, sd = 1)
    )
)

fit_anova <- lm(y ~ group, data = df) # identical to aov(y ~ group, data = df)
std_res_anova <- rstandard(fit_anova)

head(std_res_anova)

         1          2          3          4          5          6 
-1.8688760  1.1705936  0.7670691  0.6010791  0.9606203  0.2034584 



TableÂ 2: ANOVA Standardized Residuals Example



This again yields internally studentized residuals. The same formulas from regression hold for an ANOVA setting because ANOVA is just a linear model with categorical predictors.

title: Model Diagnostics
text:
Thresholds for potential outliers:

A standardized (or studentized) residual that exceeds about \(\pm 2\) could be noteworthy, and \(\pm 3\) is often considered large in typical Normal-error contexts.
However, the interpretation depends on your sample size and the distribution of residuals.

Leverage and influence:

If you see a large standardized residual, check also the pointâ€™s leverage \((h_{ii})\). A high-leverage point with a large standardized residual can strongly affect the regression line or ANOVA estimates.

Diagnostic Plots:

Plotting standardized residuals vs.Â fitted values is a common practice to detect patterns in the residuals. If the model is well-specified, these points should look like random scatter around 0 with no obvious pattern and relatively consistent variance.

title: Model Diagnostics
text:
Raw residuals tell you the difference between observed and fitted values on the scale of the original data.
Standardized (or Studentized) residuals provide a way to compare residuals on a common scale that accounts for the overall error variance and, importantly, each pointâ€™s leverage.
Râ€™s rstandard() function by default computes internally studentized residuals, which is often what people mean by â€œstandardized residualsâ€ in practice.
For more robust outlier detection, you can use rstudent() (externally studentized residuals), which removes the \(i\)th point when estimating its variance.



When someone says â€œstandardized residual,â€ check which version they are referring to. In modern usage (especially in R), â€œstandardized residualâ€ commonly refers to the internally studentized residual \(\frac{e_i}{\sqrt{s^2 (1-h_{ii})}}\), as provided by rstandard(). For more sensitive outlier detection, consider the externally studentized residuals \(\frac{e_i}{\sqrt{s_{(-i)}^2 (1-h_{ii})}}\) from rstudent(). Both are useful for checking model assumptions and identifying influential points.

title: Model Diagnostics
text:
Checking Independence
Context: Consider a balloon inflation experiment where each time a subject inflates a balloon, they learn and get faster. Residuals vs.Â observation order might show a trend, indicating non-independence (learning effect).
R Implementation:

dataset <- readr::read_table(here("data", "dean2017", "balloon.txt"))
dataset |> head()

model <- lm(Time ~ Order, data = dataset)
summary(model)

Residuals:

title: Model Diagnostics
text:
Checking Independence
Visual Clue: A â€œmegaphoneâ€ shape in residuals vs.Â time suggests non-independence.

plot(resid(model) ~ Time, data = dataset)
abline(h = 0, col = "red")







FigureÂ 1: Residuals vs.Â Time Plot





If non-independence arises, consider mixed-effects models or time-series methods.

title: Model Diagnostics
text:
Checking Equal Variance (Homoscedasticity)
Visual Clue: A â€œmegaphoneâ€ shape in residuals vs.Â fitted values suggests variance grows with the mean. Rule of Thumb: If ratio of largest to smallest sample variance > 3, consider a transformation.
R Implementation:

plot(fitted(model), resid(model))
abline(h = 0, col = "red")







FigureÂ 2: Residuals vs.Â Fitted Values Plot





If variance is not constant, transformations (like log or square-root) can stabilize it. The Box-Cox method in R helps find a suitable lambda for transforming responses.

title: Model Diagnostics
text:
Checking Normality
QQ-Plot: If residuals follow a normal distribution, they align closely with the QQ-line.
R Implementation:

qqnorm(resid(model))
qqline(resid(model), col = "blue")







FigureÂ 3: Normal Probability Plot





If deviations are severe, consider transformations or nonparametric methods.

title: Model Diagnostics
text:
Remedies for Violations

Independence Violation: Use mixed-effects models or time-series methods to account for correlation.
Heteroscedasticity:

Transformations: Log, square-root, arcsine, or Box-Cox to stabilize variance.
Satterthwaiteâ€™s Approximation: For unequal variances in ANOVA.
Weighted Least Squares: Assign weights inversely proportional to varianceâ€“ not discussed here.
Robust Methods: Huber-White or bootstrapping to correct standard errors. We only discuss the former.
Generalized Least Squares (GLS): Model variance structure explicitly - not covered here.

title: Model Diagnostics
text:
Transformation
Transformations to stabilize variance in ANOVA are most effective when there is a systematic relationship between group means and variances (e.g., variance increases with the mean). If there is no apparent relationship between the mean and variance, a standard variance-stabilizing transformation (such as a log, square-root, or arcsine transform) often does not help and may even complicate interpretation. In such scenarios, other methods designed for heterogeneous variances (e.g., Welchâ€™s ANOVA, generalized linear models, or nonparametric tests) may be more appropriate.

title: Model Diagnostics
text:
Why Transform Data?

Homoscedasticity (equal variance assumption)
Classic (fixed-effects) one-way ANOVA assumes that the error variance is constant across groups (homoscedasticity). Violating this assumption can inflate Type I or Type II error rates.
Variance-Stabilizing Transformations

Common transformations include:

Logarithmic: used when the standard deviation is roughly proportional to the mean.
Square root: used for count data, especially when counts are low.
Arcsine: commonly used for proportional data with values between 0 and 1.

These transformations are meant to make the variance more constant across groups if the variance depends on the mean in a predictable way.

Role of Relationship Between Mean and Variance

When group means and variances show a positive relationship (e.g., bigger means have bigger variances in proportionate fashion), a variance-stabilizing transformation often helps.

If the variance is unrelated to the mean, applying a traditional â€œmean-basedâ€ transformation (like a log) may have little or no effect on stabilizing the variance.

title: Model Diagnostics
text:
When the Transformation Works

Detecting a relationship
Plot the group standard deviations (or group variances) against group means. If you see a pattern such as an increasing linear or non-linear trend, you can often guess an appropriate transformation (log, sqrt, etc.).
Selecting a transformation

Log transformation: Common if \(\text{variance} \propto (\text{mean})^\alpha\).

Box-Cox approach: A systematic way to find \(\lambda\) in a power transformation \(y^\lambda\).

Arcsine: For data restricted between 0 and 1 (e.g., proportions).

Checking success
After transforming, re-check the group variances (e.g., with a residual plot or a test for homogeneity). If the transformation was effective, the variances should appear more uniform across groups.

title: Model Diagnostics
section: Does the Transformation Work When There is No Meanâ€“Variance Relationship?
text:
Does the Transformation Work When There is No Meanâ€“Variance Relationship?

Likely not. If the group variances do not systematically depend on the group means, a standard transformation aimed at stabilizing â€œmean-relatedâ€ variance typically will not help.

In some cases, a transformation could still help if the original data are very skewed or if there are other distributional issues. However, if variance is truly unrelated to the mean, transformations specifically intended to fix mean-variance dependence will not systematically improve homogeneity of variance.

Alternatives: Instead of forcing a transformation, consider:

Welchâ€™s ANOVA (unequal variances ANOVA), which does not assume equal variances across groups.

Generalized Linear Models (GLMs), if the data structure suggests a particular distribution (e.g., Poisson for counts, binomial for proportions).

Nonparametric tests (e.g., Kruskalâ€“Wallis test) when distributional assumptions are severely violated.



Key Takeaways

Transformation â€œsuccessâ€ depends on whether the dataâ€™s variance problem stems from an identifiable meanâ€“variance relationship.

No relationship â†’ transformations designed for mean-related variance may not help.

Consider alternative methods (Welchâ€™s ANOVA, GLMs, or nonparametric) when classical ANOVAâ€™s equal variance assumption is clearly violated and transformations prove ineffective.

title: Model Diagnostics
text:
Transformations
Below is a detailed example of using the Box-Cox transformation in R. The Box-Cox transformation is a family of power transformations designed to stabilize the variance and make the data more normally distributed. This example will simulate a dataset with heteroscedasticity, fit a linear model, use the Box-Cox procedure to identify an optimal transformation, and then re-fit the model on the transformed response.

title: Model Diagnostics
text:
Background on Box-Cox Transformation
The Box-Cox transformation is defined as:
\[
Y^{(\lambda)} =
\begin{cases}
\frac{Y^\lambda - 1}{\lambda}, & \lambda \neq 0, \\
\ln(Y), & \lambda = 0.
\end{cases}
\]

Purpose

Stabilize Variance: When the variance of the response variable changes (i.e., heteroscedasticity is present).
Improve Normality: To make the distribution of the response more closely approximate a normal distribution.

title: Model Diagnostics
text:
Simulate a Dataset with Heteroscedasticity
In this example, we simulate data where the variance of the errors increases with the predictor \(X\).

set.seed(123)
n <- 100
X <- runif(n, 1, 10)
# Create Heteroscedastic Errors: Error variance Increases with X
errors <- rnorm(n, mean = 0, sd = 0.5 * X)
Y <- 2 + 3 * X + errors # Linear relationship with increasing variance
data_sim <- data.frame(X = X, Y = Y)
data_sim |> head()






X
Y




3.588198
13.219072


8.094746
26.168699


4.680792
15.942043


8.947157
34.964019


9.464206
29.324245


1.410008
7.299144



Simulated Data with Heteroscedasticity



# Visualize the Raw Data
ggplot(data_sim, aes(x = X, y = Y)) +
    geom_point() +
    labs(
        title = "Simulated Data with Heteroscedasticity",
        x = "Predictor (X)",
        y = "Response (Y)"
    )







FigureÂ 4: Simulated Data with Heteroscedasticity





Explanation:
The above code creates 100 observations where the error standard deviation increases with \(X\). This pattern may lead to heteroscedasticity in a linear regression model.

title: Model Diagnostics
text:
Fit an Initial Linear Model
We first fit a simple linear regression model to the simulated data and then examine its residuals.

model_initial <- lm(Y ~ X, data = data_sim)
summary(model_initial)


Call:
lm(formula = Y ~ X, data = data_sim)

Residuals:
    Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
-8.1305 -1.6273  0.0422  1.2916 10.1121 

Coefficients:
            Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept)   1.9557     0.6977   2.803   0.0061 ** 
X             2.9753     0.1153  25.805   <2e-16 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 2.943 on 98 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.8717,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.8704 
F-statistic: 665.9 on 1 and 98 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16


Interpretation:
Review the model summary and diagnostic plots to check for heteroscedasticity. A residual vs.Â fitted plot (see next code) may reveal a â€œfanning outâ€ pattern.

par(mfrow = c(1, 2))
plot(model_initial$fitted.values, residuals(model_initial),
    xlab = "Fitted Values", ylab = "Residuals",
    main = "Residuals vs Fitted"
)
abline(h = 0, col = "red")
qqnorm(residuals(model_initial), main = "QQ Plot")
qqline(residuals(model_initial), col = "blue")







FigureÂ 5: Diagnostic Plots for the Initial Model

title: Model Diagnostics
text:
Apply the Box-Cox Transformation
We use the boxcox() function from the MASS package to determine the optimal \(\lambda\) value for the transformation.

library(MASS)
boxcox_result <- MASS::boxcox(model_initial, lambda = seq(-2, 2, 0.1))








Explanation:

The boxcox() function examines a range of \(\lambda\) values (here from -2 to 2) and calculates the log-likelihood for each transformation.
The optimal \(\lambda\) is the one that maximizes the log-likelihood (the peak of the plot).

Observation:
After running the code, you should see a plot with \(\lambda\) on the horizontal axis and the corresponding log-likelihood on the vertical axis. Suppose the plot suggests an optimal \(\lambda \approx 0\) (i.e., a log transformation) or a value different from 0.

title: Model Diagnostics
section: Re-Fit the Model with the Transformed Response
text:
Re-Fit the Model with the Transformed Response
Assume the Box-Cox plot indicates that \(\lambda = 0\) is optimal (a log transformation). We then transform \(Y\) and re-fit the model.



data_sim <- data_sim |> mutate(Y_trans = log(Y))
model_transformed <- lm(Y_trans ~ X, data = data_sim)
summary(model_transformed)


Call:
lm(formula = Y_trans ~ X, data = data_sim)

Residuals:
     Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
-0.39876 -0.11500 -0.00162  0.13085  0.39509 

Coefficients:
            Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept) 1.803965   0.041251   43.73   <2e-16 ***
X           0.180587   0.006817   26.49   <2e-16 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 0.174 on 98 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.8775,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.8762 
F-statistic: 701.8 on 1 and 98 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16



TableÂ 3: Transformed Linear Model

title: Model Diagnostics
section: Compare Diagnostic Plots for the Transformed Model
text:
Compare Diagnostic Plots for the Transformed Model
After refitting the model, we check whether the transformation improved the model assumptions.

par(mfrow = c(1, 2))
plot(model_transformed$fitted.values, residuals(model_transformed),
    xlab = "Fitted Values", ylab = "Residuals",
    main = "Residuals vs Fitted (Transformed)"
)
abline(h = 0, col = "red")
qqnorm(residuals(model_transformed), main = "QQ Plot (Transformed)")
qqline(residuals(model_transformed), col = "blue")








Interpretation:
- Residuals vs.Â Fitted Plot: Look for a more random scatter with no apparent pattern (indicating stabilized variance). - Q-Q Plot: Check whether the residuals are more normally distributed compared to the initial model.

title: Model Diagnostics
text:
Summary of Findings

Before Transformation:
The initial model showed signs of heteroscedasticity as the variance of the residuals increased with the fitted values.
Box-Cox Analysis:
The Box-Cox procedure suggested an optimal \(\lambda\) value (in our example, \(\lambda \approx 0\), which corresponds to a log transformation).
After Transformation:
The re-fitted model using the log-transformed response showed improved diagnostic plots with more constant variance and residuals closer to normality.

title: Model Diagnostics
text:
Conclusion
The Box-Cox transformation is a powerful tool to address non-constant variance and non-normality in regression models. By applying the transformation, selecting the optimal \(\lambda\) based on the maximum log-likelihood, and re-fitting the model, we can often achieve a model that better meets the assumptions required for valid inference.
In practice, itâ€™s essential to interpret the Box-Cox plot, choose a transformation that makes sense for the data, and verify that the transformed model improves the diagnostic plots. When the assumptions of homoscedasticity and normality are met, the modelâ€™s estimates and inferences are more reliable.

title: Model Diagnostics
text:
The Statistical Model
A one-way layout with \(v\) treatments can be written:
\[
Y_{it} \;=\; \mu \;+\; \tau_i \;+\; \varepsilon_{it},
\quad
\varepsilon_{it} \,\sim\, N(0, \sigma_i^2),
\quad
\text{independently for each } i,t.
\]

\(i = 1, 2, \dots, v\) is the treatment index.
\(t = 1, 2, \dots, r_i\) indexes observations within the \(i\)-th treatment.

We do not assume \(\sigma_1^2 = \sigma_2^2 = \cdots = \sigma_v^2\). Instead, each group has its own variance \(\sigma_i^2\).
The sample mean and variance for group \(i\) are
\[
\bar{Y}_{i\cdot} \;=\; \frac{1}{r_i} \sum_{t=1}^{r_i} Y_{it},
\quad\quad
s_i^2 \;=\; \frac{1}{r_i - 1} \sum_{t=1}^{r_i} \bigl(Y_{it} - \bar{Y}_{i\cdot}\bigr)^2.
\]

title: Model Diagnostics
text:
Satterthwaiteâ€™s Approximation for a Contrast
A contrast in the group means \(\{\tau_i\}\) is a linear combination \(\sum_{i=1}^v c_i \tau_i\) such that \(\sum_i c_i = 0\). For pairwise differences, you can think of \(c_h = +1\), \(c_i = -1\), and the rest 0, to compare \(\tau_h - \tau_i\).
The least squares estimate of a contrast is
\[
\widehat{\sum_{i} c_i \tau_i}
\;=\;
\sum_{i} c_i \,\bar{Y}_{i\cdot}.
\]

title: Model Diagnostics
text:
Estimated Variance of the Contrast
Because group \(i\) has variance \(\sigma_i^2\), the variance of \(\bar{Y}_{i\cdot}\) is \(\sigma_i^2 / r_i\). Thus,
\[
\text{Var}\!\Bigl(\sum_{i} c_i \,\bar{Y}_{i\cdot}\Bigr)
\;=\;
\sum_{i} \frac{c_i^2 \,\sigma_i^2}{r_i}.
\]
In practice, we estimate \(\sigma_i^2\) by \(s_i^2\). Hence,
\[
\widehat{\text{Var}}\Bigl(\sum_{i} c_i \,\bar{Y}_{i\cdot}\Bigr)
\;=\;
\sum_{i} \frac{c_i^2 \,s_i^2}{r_i}.
\]

title: Model Diagnostics
Model Diagnostics
Model Diagnostics
text:
Multiple Comparisons: The Gamesâ€“Howell Method
When you want all pairwise comparisons, you can adapt the usual Tukey â€œHonestly Significant Differenceâ€ (HSD) approach by:

Computing the standard error \(\sqrt{(s_h^2/r_h) + (s_i^2/r_i)}\) for each pair \((h,i)\).
Computing the approximate df from Satterthwaiteâ€™s formula for that pair.
Using the studentized-range critical value \(q_{v,\text{df},\alpha}\) (the same one used in Tukeyâ€™s HSD) but evaluating it at each pairwise df if you want to be extra precise, or at a conservative minimum among the pairs.
Hence getting the â€œminimum significant differenceâ€ (\(\text{msd}\)) for each pair and deciding if \(|\bar{Y}_{h\cdot} - \bar{Y}_{i\cdot}|\) exceeds that msd.

In R, this is usually done through built-in or add-on functions called the Gamesâ€“Howell test.

title: Model Diagnostics
text:
Example: Trout Experiment (Illustrative Data)
In the â€œTrout Experimentâ€ example from many textbooks, there are 4 treatment levels (letâ€™s label them A, B, C, D) each with \(n=10\) observations. Suppose the raw data are as follows (fictitious for illustration). In practice, you would read them from a file or have them given in a data frame.
Below, we create a simulated dataset with unequal group variances roughly resembling the exampleâ€™s summary:

Treatment A: \(\bar{Y} \approx 7.7\), variance \(\approx 1.0\)
Treatment B: \(\bar{Y} \approx 9.5\), variance \(\approx 3.0\)
Treatment C: \(\bar{Y} \approx 9.2\), variance \(\approx 1.3\)
Treatment D: \(\bar{Y} \approx 8.8\), variance \(\approx 1.0\)

title: Model Diagnostics
text:
Trout Experiment Data
Below is a plain-language summary of the trout experiment data to help someone with little background in fish biology or statistics understand the context and technical terms:

What Is the Experiment About?
Researchers are trying out four different treatments (labeled â€œ1,â€ â€œ2,â€ â€œ3,â€ and â€œ4â€) on trout. These treatments are various sulfa-based or sulfonamide medications (often used to control bacterial infections or other conditions in fish). The main goal is to see whether different treatments lead to different outcomes in the troutâ€™s health.

title: Model Diagnostics
text:
Key Terms Explained

Trout

A common type of freshwater fish.

In the experiment, trout are the â€œtest subjects,â€ similar to patients in a medical study.

Sulfa

This refers to sulfonamide treatments (a type of medication).

The data labels (1, 2, 3, or 4) tell us which specific sulfa treatment each trout received.

Hemo

Short for â€œhemoglobinâ€ (or a similar blood measure).

Hemoglobin is the substance in blood that carries oxygen. A higher or lower level can indicate different states of health.

In the experiment, Hemo is the response variableâ€” what the researchers measure in each trout to see if the treatment had any effect.

Experimental Setup

Each of the four treatments was given to 10 different trout (total of 40 fish).

After some time, the Hemo level was measured for each fish, giving one reading per trout.



Why Are They Doing This?
Trout farmers or fisheries might want a medication to keep fish healthier or improve survival. By comparing different sulfa treatments:

They can see if one treatment leads to higher (better) or lower Hemo measurements than another.
They can learn which treatments seem to work best, or if they all perform about the same.



What Does the Data Look Like?
The data table has two columns: 1. Sulfa â€“ which of the four treatments the trout received.
2. Hemo â€“ the measured blood value after treatment.
Each row in the table is a single troutâ€™s record: - Sulfa (1, 2, 3, or 4)
- Hemo (a number, like 7.0 or 10.6)

title: Model Diagnostics
text:
Loading the Data in R

troutData <- readr::read_table(here("data", "dean2017", "trout.txt")) |> mutate(Sulfa = factor(Sulfa))

Each level (1 through 4) appears exactly 10 times, so we have 10 trout in each of the four treatments.

Hemo

Values: Numeric, typically representing some biological measurement linked to trout health or oxygen-carrying capacity in the blood.

This roughly replicates the scenario in the textbook example (\(s_1^2 \approx 1.04, s_2^2 \approx 2.95,\) etc.).

title: Model Diagnostics
section: Manual Gamesâ€“Howell Multiple Comparisons (Step-by-Step in R)
text:
Manual Gamesâ€“Howell Multiple Comparisons (Step-by-Step in R)
We can either:

Manually compute each pairwise difference, its standard error, degrees of freedom, and the corresponding â€œminimum significant difference.â€
Use an R package function that automates these calculations.

Below, we first show a brief â€œmanualâ€ approach, then a dedicated function from a package.

title: Model Diagnostics
text: Manual Calculations

title: Model Diagnostics
text:
Create a Summary Table

# Extract Means, Variances for Each Group
means <- troutSummary$meanVal
vars <- troutSummary$varVal
names(means) <- troutSummary$Sulfa
names(vars) <- troutSummary$Sulfa

# We'll Use 'combn' to Get All Pairs: This yields pairs like `A-B`, `A-C`, `A-D`, `B-C`, `B-D`, `C-D`.

groups <- levels(troutData$Sulfa)
pairs <- combn(groups, 2, simplify = TRUE)
pairs

     [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4] [,5] [,6]
[1,] "1"  "1"  "1"  "2"  "2"  "3" 
[2,] "2"  "3"  "4"  "3"  "4"  "4" 


This yields pairs like A-B, A-C, A-D, B-C, B-D, C-D.

title: Model Diagnostics
text:
Compute Each Pairâ€™s Stats
We can write a small function to compute:

The difference in means.
The standard error \(\sqrt{\frac{s_h^2}{n_h} + \frac{s_i^2}{n_i}}\).
The approximate df from Satterthwaiteâ€™s formula.


# Create a function that takes a data frame with a grouping column (factor)
# and a numeric response column, then computes pairwise comparisons
# (mean difference, standard error, and Satterthwaite df) for each pair.

pairwise_satterthwaite <- function(data, group_col, response_col) {
    # Ensure the grouping column is a factor
    data[[group_col]] <- as.factor(data[[group_col]])

    # Summarize mean, variance, n for each group
    summary_df <- data |>
        group_by(.data[[group_col]]) |>
        summarize(
            n       = n(),
            meanVal = mean(.data[[response_col]]),
            varVal  = var(.data[[response_col]]),
            .groups = "drop"
        )

    # For convenience
    group_levels <- levels(data[[group_col]])
    means <- setNames(summary_df$meanVal, summary_df[[group_col]])
    vars <- setNames(summary_df$varVal, summary_df[[group_col]])
    ns <- setNames(summary_df$n, summary_df[[group_col]])

    # Define Satterthwaite function
    satterthwaite_df <- function(var1, var2, n1, n2) {
        num <- (var1 / n1 + var2 / n2)^2
        denom <- (var1^2 / (n1^2 * (n1 - 1))) + (var2^2 / (n2^2 * (n2 - 1)))
        num / denom
    }

    # Get all pairs of groups
    pair_mat <- combn(group_levels, 2)

    # Calculate stats for each pair
    pair_list <- apply(pair_mat, 2, function(pair) {
        g1 <- pair[1]
        g2 <- pair[2]
        diff <- means[g2] - means[g1]
        se <- sqrt(vars[g1] / ns[g1] + vars[g2] / ns[g2])
        df <- satterthwaite_df(vars[g1], vars[g2], ns[g1], ns[g2])

        data.frame(
            group1 = g1,
            group2 = g2,
            meanDiff = diff,
            SE = se,
            df = round(df, 1)
        )
    })

    # Combine into a single data frame
    do.call(rbind, pair_list)
}

# Example usage (assuming your data frame is called 'troutData'
# and has columns 'Group' and 'Response'):
pairwiseDF <- pairwise_satterthwaite(troutData, group_col = "Sulfa", response_col = "Hemo")
print(pairwiseDF)

   group1 group2 meanDiff        SE   df
2       1      2     2.13 0.6312334 14.6
3       1      3     1.83 0.4823668 17.8
4       1      4     1.49 0.4515283 18.0
31      2      3    -0.30 0.6508285 15.6
41      2      4    -0.64 0.6283134 14.5
42      3      4    -0.34 0.4785394 17.7

title: Model Diagnostics
section: Compute the Gamesâ€“Howell Test Statistic and p-Values
text:
Compute the Gamesâ€“Howell Test Statistic and p-Values
For each pair \((h,i)\), we have:
\[
t_{hi}^* = \frac{\bar{Y}_{i\cdot} - \bar{Y}_{h\cdot}}{\text{SE}_{(h,i)}},
\quad
\text{df}_{(h,i)} \approx \text{(Satterthwaite formula)},
\]
and the p-value is based on the studentized range distribution if you want to replicate â€œTukey-likeâ€ inference, or you can do an approximate t-test approach. For a full Gamesâ€“Howell:

Studentized range approach:

\[
q = \frac{ |\bar{Y}_{i} - \bar{Y}_{h}| }{SE_{(h,i)}},
\]
compare with \(q_{v,\text{df},\alpha}\).

Alternative: Use a t-approximation with df from above. (This is a bit simpler to code manually.)

Below, we do the simpler t-based approach for each pair:

alpha <- 0.05
pairwiseDF <- pairwiseDF |>
    mutate(
        tval = meanDiff / SE,
        pval_satt = 2 * pt(-abs(tval), df) # two-sided p-value from t-distribution with Satterthwaite df
    )

That yields approximate pairwise t-tests that do not assume equal variances, with Satterthwaite df. However, be aware that controlling familywise error strictly with a t-test approach requires a correction or the studentized-range approach.

title: Model Diagnostics
section: Minimum Significant Difference (msd) for Each Pair (Tukey-likeness)
text:
Minimum Significant Difference (msd) for Each Pair (Tukey-likeness)
To emulate the Gamesâ€“Howell approach specifically, you compute:
\[
\text{msd}_{(h,i)}
\;=\;
\sqrt{\frac{s_h^2}{n_h} + \frac{s_i^2}{n_i}}
\;\times\;
\frac{q_{v,\,\text{df}_{(h,i)},\,\alpha}}{\sqrt{2}},
\]
where \(v=4\) is the number of treatments. Then you see if \(|\bar{Y}_{h\cdot} - \bar{Y}_{i\cdot}|\) is larger than msd.
A small snippet:

# We'll Define a Function that Approximates q_{v, Df, alpha}
# Because the 'df' is not Straightforward, We Might Do a Conservative Approach
# Or We Can Do Per-pair if We Like.
gamesHowell_msd <- function(var_hi, df_hi, alpha = 0.05, v = 4) {
    # We Have Pair-specific Df, but the 'Tukey' Distribution with Non-integer Df
    # Sometimes Requires Approximation.
    # We'll Do a Rough Approach: q_{v, floor(df_hi), alpha}

    df_floor <- floor(df_hi)
    df_round <- round(df_hi, 1)
    # q_{v, Df, alpha} = qtukey(1 - Alpha, nmeans=v, df_floor)
    # Then We Scale by 1/sqrt(2).

    qval <- qtukey(1 - alpha, nmeans = v, df = df_floor)
    msd <- sqrt(var_hi) * (qval / sqrt(2))
    msd
}

# Calculate group-specific variances and sample sizes
vars <- tapply(troutData$Hemo, troutData$Sulfa, var)
nvec <- tapply(troutData$Hemo, troutData$Sulfa, length)

# Now We Apply it Pairwise:
pairwiseDF <- pairwiseDF |>
    rowwise() |>
    mutate(
        var_hi = (vars[group1] / nvec[group1] + vars[group2] / nvec[group2]),
        qval = qtukey(1 - alpha, nmeans = 4, df = floor(df)),
        msd = sqrt(var_hi) * (qval / sqrt(2)),
        diffSignificant = (abs(meanDiff) > msd),
        pval_ght = ptukey(abs(tval) * sqrt(2), nmeans = 4, df = floor(df), lower.tail = FALSE)
    ) |>
    ungroup()

title: Model Diagnostics
text:
Using a Ready-Made R Function
Several R packages implement the Games-Howell test automatically. Two common approaches:

PairwiseTTest() from the DescTools package with the pool.sd = FALSE argument.

gamesHowellTest() from the PMCMRplus packages. See Games-Howell Post-Hoc Comparison for more details.

Below, we demonstrate the PMCMRplus packageâ€™s gamesHowellTest() function.



fit <- aov(Hemo ~ Sulfa, data = troutData)
gh_test <- PMCMRplus::gamesHowellTest(fit)
summary(gh_test)

           q value Pr(>|q|)   
2 - 1 == 0   4.772 0.019942  *
3 - 1 == 0   5.365 0.006735 **
4 - 1 == 0   4.667 0.018973  *
3 - 2 == 0  -0.652 0.966450   
4 - 2 == 0  -1.441 0.741476   
4 - 3 == 0  -1.005 0.891609   



TableÂ 5: Gamesâ€“Howell Test: Pairwise Comparisons



This will print out pairwise comparisons, confidence intervals, and p-values, controlling familywise error at alpha = 0.05. Youâ€™ll see a compact letter display or a table showing which pairs are significantly different.
NOTE: Different packages might handle rounding or approximate df differently, so minor numerical differences from manual calculations can occur.

title: Model Diagnostics
text:
Interpretation and Conclusion

Interpretation: If \(\bar{Y}_{h\cdot} - \bar{Y}_{i\cdot}\) exceeds the corresponding Gamesâ€“Howell msd in absolute value, we conclude that the treatments \(h\) and \(i\) differ significantly at the chosen familywise error rate (often 5%).

Advantages: No need to assume equal variances; results stay in original data units without forcing a transformation.

Disadvantages: Typically has lower power than methods that rely on a correct assumption of equal variances (or a well-chosen variance-stabilizing transformation).

In the trout example, we often find that Treatment B is significantly different from A, that A differs from B and C, etc., while B, C, and D might be close or show smaller pairwise differences (depending on the data).

title: Model Diagnostics
text:
Summary

Satterthwaiteâ€™s Approximation gives an approximate \(t\)-distribution for each contrast with a â€œfloatingâ€ degrees of freedom.

The Gamesâ€“Howell procedure adapts Tukeyâ€™s HSD to unequal variances, computing pair-specific standard errors and degrees of freedom.

In R, you can do these calculations manually (as demonstrated) or use a dedicated function from packages like DescTools or rcompanion to streamline the process.

Always check the assumptions (normality, independence, etc.). When in doubt, consider robust or nonparametric approaches as well.

title: Model Diagnostics
text:
Conclusion
Assumption checking in ANOVA and regression is not a mere formalityâ€”it safeguards against invalid conclusions. By using residual diagnostics, normality checks, and transformations, we ensure models accurately represent reality. While no single approach solves all problems, a combination of visual and formal diagnostic tools, along with informed corrective strategies, leads to more trustworthy and robust statistical inferences.

title: Completely Randomized Design and One-Way ANOVA
text:
In mathematical statistics, well-structured experimental designs and robust analytical methods are essential for drawing valid conclusions about treatment effects. One of the simplest yet fundamental designs is the completely randomized design (CRD). Under a CRD, each experimental unit is randomly assigned to one of several treatment conditions without any blocking factors. This approach ensures that all treatments have an equal chance of being applied to each unit, thereby mitigating systematic biases and facilitating straightforward inference.
A key tool for analyzing CRDs is the one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA). The one-way ANOVA tests whether at least two of several treatment means differ significantly. Building upon principles of linear models, least squares estimation, and classical hypothesis testing, the one-way ANOVA provides a comprehensive framework to quantify uncertainty and make decisions about treatments based on observed data.



Understand the structure and rationale behind the completely randomized design.
Learn the randomization procedure and the role of coding treatments.
Formulate the one-way ANOVA model and understand its assumptions.
Explore concepts of estimability, least squares estimation, and the distribution of estimators.
Apply the ANOVA test to decide whether treatments differ significantly.
Calculate sample size and power, and incorporate these insights when planning experiments.
Demonstrate procedures using R, including randomization, data input, fitting models, and producing ANOVA tables.




This lecture uses several R packages for data manipulation, analysis, and plotting:

pacman::p_load(emmeans, pwr, here)


pacman: A package management tool for installing and loading packages.
emmeans: For estimating treatment means and testing contrasts.
pwr: For power calculations in hypothesis testing.
here: For managing file paths in R projects.

title: Completely Randomized Design and One-Way ANOVA
text:
Understand the structure and rationale behind the completely randomized design.
Learn the randomization procedure and the role of coding treatments.
Formulate the one-way ANOVA model and understand its assumptions.
Explore concepts of estimability, least squares estimation, and the distribution of estimators.
Apply the ANOVA test to decide whether treatments differ significantly.
Calculate sample size and power, and incorporate these insights when planning experiments.
Demonstrate procedures using R, including randomization, data input, fitting models, and producing ANOVA tables.

title: Completely Randomized Design and One-Way ANOVA
text:
This lecture uses several R packages for data manipulation, analysis, and plotting:

pacman::p_load(emmeans, pwr, here)


pacman: A package management tool for installing and loading packages.
emmeans: For estimating treatment means and testing contrasts.
pwr: For power calculations in hypothesis testing.
here: For managing file paths in R projects.

title: Completely Randomized Design and One-Way ANOVA
text:
Defining Experimental Design
An experimental design is a rule determining how experimental units are assigned to treatments. In a completely randomized design (CRD), no blocking factors are considered; all experimental units are assigned to treatments purely at random. This simplicity allows:

Equal probability of treatment assignment.
Avoidance of experimenter bias.
Straightforward statistical analysis.

Examples include testing different battery types or comparing rotary pump speeds to measure fluid flow. When no major nuisance factors (like day-to-day variation or spatial differences) need controlling, a CRD is often appropriate.

title: Completely Randomized Design and One-Way ANOVA
text:
Randomization Procedure
Randomization ensures fairness and the validity of the statistical distributions underlying standard tests. Treatments, labeled 1 through \(v\), are assigned to experimental units by generating random numbers and sorting them. Modern software (R) or random number tables can be used. For instance, if testing three treatment levels (A, B, C) with equal sample sizes, we can:

Generate random numbers for each unit.
Rank units by their random numbers.
Assign treatments in order based on the desired allocation.

This procedure ensures every arrangement is equally likely, aligning with the assumptions in ANOVA and related inference.

title: Completely Randomized Design and One-Way ANOVA
text:
Randomization Concept
Randomization ensures that each experimental unit has an equal chance of receiving any treatment. This prevents systematic bias and justifies the assumptions underlying standard statistical tests.
Example: Use a random number generator to assign treatments to plots, ensuring no predetermined pattern.

title: Completely Randomized Design and One-Way ANOVA
text:
How to Perform Randomization

Procedure

INPUT: List of experimental units, List of treatments
OUTPUT: Randomized assignments of treatments to units


Define \(N\) = Total number of experimental units (e.g., 12).
Define \(T\) = List of treatments (e.g., A, B, C).
Repeat \(T\) to match the number of experimental units.
Shuffle the list of the repeated treatmentsn from step 3 randomly.
Assign shuffled treatments to the experimental units.
Return randomized assignments

title: Completely Randomized Design and One-Way ANOVA
section: R Implementation: Randomization Examples in CRD
text:
R Implementation: Randomization Examples in CRD



N <- 12 # Number of experimental units, Step 1
# Define experimental units and treatments
experimental_units <- 1:N ## 10 experimental units
treatments <- c("A", "B", "C") ## 3 treatments, Step 2

# Repeat treatments to match the number of units. The code covers both balanced and unbalanced designs.
treatments <- rep(treatments, length.out = N)  ## Step 3

# For a balanced design, we can also use:
# treatments <- rep(treatments, each = N/length(treatments))

# Shuffle (randomize) treatments randomly to assign to units, Step 4
set.seed(123) ## For reproducibility
randomized_treatments <- sample(treatments)

# Create a data frame with randomized assignments
randomization_crd <- data.frame(Unit = experimental_units, Treatment = randomized_treatments)  ## Step 5
print(randomization_crd)

   Unit Treatment
1     1         C
2     2         C
3     3         A
4     4         B
5     5         C
6     6         B
7     7         B
8     8         A
9     9         C
10   10         B
11   11         A
12   12         A



TableÂ 1: Randomized Assignments in CRD

title: Completely Randomized Design and One-Way ANOVA
text:
Model Formulation
Consider \(v\) treatments with \(n\) observations each (for simplicity). Let \(Y_{ij}\) denote the response from the \(j\)-th unit receiving treatment \(i\), with \(i=1,\dots,v\) and \(j=1,\dots,n\). A common model is:
\[
Y_{ij} = \mu + \tau_i + \varepsilon_{ij},
\qquad(1)\]
where:

\(\mu\) is the overall mean response.
\(\tau_i\) is the effect of the \(i\)-th treatment.
\(\varepsilon_{ij}\) are independent, normally distributed errors with mean 0 and variance \(\sigma^2\).

The assumptions are:

Errors \(\varepsilon_{ij}\) are i.i.d. \(N(0,\sigma^2)\).
Treatment effects sum to zero: \(\sum_{i=1}^v \tau_i = 0\) for identifiability.

This linear model model underpins the ANOVA. The null hypothesis for testing no treatment differences is \(H_0: \tau_1 = \tau_2 = \cdots = \tau_v = 0\).



identifiability:

title: Completely Randomized Design and One-Way ANOVA
text:
Estimability and Least Squares Estimation
Not all model parameters (\(\tau_i\)) are independently estimable. However, estimable functions, linear combinations of parameters that correspond to expected values of observed data, can be estimated uniquely.
The least squares estimators (LSEs) solve the normal equations obtained by minimizing the sum of squared errors (SSE):
\[
\text{SSE} = \sum_{i=1}^v \sum_{j=1}^n (Y_{ij} - \hat{\mu}_i)^2,
\qquad(2)\]
where \(\hat{\mu}_i\) is the estimated mean for treatment \(i\). The LSE for each treatment mean \(\mu_i = \mu + \tau_i\) is simply the sample mean \(\bar{Y}_i = \frac{1}{n}\sum_{j=1}^n Y_{ij}\).
Because the normal equations are linearly dependent, an additional constraint is needed (e.g., \(\sum \tau_i = 0\)). Still, any estimable function (like differences between treatment means) can be uniquely estimated.

title: Completely Randomized Design and One-Way ANOVA
text:
Distribution of Estimators
Under the normal error assumption, each estimator \(\bar{Y}_i\) is normally distributed, with:
\[
E(\bar{Y}_i) = \mu_i, \quad \text{Var}(\bar{Y}_i) = \frac{\sigma^2}{n}.
\qquad(3)\]
The error variance \(\sigma^2\) is estimated by the mean square error (MSE):
\[
\hat{\sigma}^2 = \frac{\text{SSE}}{N - v},
\qquad(4)\]
where \(N = v \cdot n\) is the total number of observations.

title: Completely Randomized Design and One-Way ANOVA
text:
The ANOVA F-Test
To test \(H_0: \tau_1 = \cdots = \tau_v = 0\) against \(H_a:\) at least two \(\tau_i\) differ, we use the ANOVA F-statistic:
\[
F = \frac{\text{MST}}{\text{MSE}},
\qquad(5)\]
where:

\(\text{SST}\) = treatment sum of squares measures variation among treatment means.
\(\text{MSE}\) = error mean square, \(\text{MSE} = \text{SSE}/(N-v)\).
\(\text{MST} = \text{SST}/(v-1)\).

Under \(H_0\), \(F \sim F_{v-1, N-v}\). If \(F\)-value exceeds a critical value (or the p-value is below a chosen \(\alpha\)), we reject \(H_0\).

title: Completely Randomized Design and One-Way ANOVA
text:
ANOVA Table
The ANOVA table summarizes the decomposition of total variability:






Source
DF

MS

TableÂ 2: ANOVA Table for a Completely Randomized Design



The table provides a concise summary of the ANOVA results, including degrees of freedom (DF), sum of squares (SS), mean squares (MS), and the F-ratio.
Rejecting \(H_0\) indicates that not all treatment means are equal.

title: Completely Randomized Design and One-Way ANOVA
text:
Determining Sample Size and Power
To ensure the experiment can detect meaningful differences, consider the power analysis. Power calculations (detailed in referenced texts) help determine the number of replicates \(n\) per treatment to achieve a desired probability of detecting a specified difference at a given significance level \(\alpha\).
Use methods from Montgomery, Peck & Vining (2020) or Dean, Voss & DraguljiÄ‡ (2017), along with pilot data, to estimate \(\sigma^2\) and decide on sample size. If resources are limited, one may have to adjust objectives or accept lower power.

title: Completely Randomized Design and One-Way ANOVA
text:
Confidence Limits for Variance
A one-sided confidence interval on \(\sigma^2\) prevents underestimating required observations. The upper confidence limit is derived from the chi-squared distribution:
\[
\frac{(N-v)\hat{\sigma}^2}{\sigma^2} \sim \chi^2_{N-v}.
\qquad(6)\]
Such intervals guide planning by addressing uncertainty in the variance estimate.

title: Completely Randomized Design and One-Way ANOVA
text:
Randomization in R
Suppose we have 3 treatments (A, B, C) and total 9 units (3 per treatment):

set.seed(123) # Total units
n <- 9 # Assign treatments to units, e.g., AAABBBCCC
treatments <- rep(c("A", "B", "C"), each = 3) # Assign random numbers
rand_nums <- runif(9) # Genrates random numbers
data_frame <- data.frame(Unit = 1:9, Treatment = treatments, RN = rand_nums)
data_frame_sorted <- data_frame[order(data_frame$RN), ] # Sort by RN

Explanation of the Key Functions in R

set.seed(123): Sets a seed for reproducibility.
rep(c("A", "B", "C"), each = 3): Creates a balanced treatment allocation, where each = 3 assigns 3 units to each treatment.
runif(9): Generates 9 random numbers from a uniform distribution.
order: Sorts the data frame based on the random numbers. The result of the function is row indices that would sort the data frame.

title: Completely Randomized Design and One-Way ANOVA
text:
Fitting a One-Way ANOVA Model
Assume we have data from a soap experiment (soap.txt) with three soap types (regular, deodorant, moisturizing):

pacman::p_load(here)
# Read data
soap.data <- read.table(here("data", "dean2017", "soap.txt"), header = TRUE)
soap.data$fSoap <- factor(soap.data$Soap)

# Fit a one-way ANOVA
fit <- aov(WtLoss ~ fSoap, data = soap.data)
summary(fit)

            Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F value   Pr(>F)    
fSoap        2 16.122   8.061   104.5 5.91e-07 ***
Residuals    9  0.695   0.077                     
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1


The ANOVA summary shows if soap type affects weight loss significantly.

title: Completely Randomized Design and One-Way ANOVA
text:
Estimating Means and Contrasts
We can estimate treatment means (least squares means) and test contrasts using emmeans or multcomp packages. For example:

pacman::p_load(emmeans)
emmeans(fit, ~fSoap)

 fSoap emmean    SE df lower.CL upper.CL
 1     -0.035 0.139  9   -0.349    0.279
 2      2.700 0.139  9    2.386    3.014
 3      1.992 0.139  9    1.678    2.307

Confidence level used: 0.95 


This provides estimates and confidence intervals for each soap typeâ€™s mean weight loss.

title: Completely Randomized Design and One-Way ANOVA
text:
Conclusion
A completely randomized design and its corresponding one-way ANOVA analysis form the bedrock of experimental inference when blocking is unnecessary. By carefully randomizing treatments, modeling responses, and applying least squares estimation, one can confidently infer whether treatments differ.
We introduced the conceptual framework and key formulae, showed how to conduct hypothesis tests and interpret ANOVA results, discussed sample size and power considerations, and provided R code for practical execution. Mastery of these fundamentals empowers researchers to design efficient experiments, maximize the utility of collected data, and confidently draw conclusions about treatment effects.

title: Completely Randomized Design and One-Way ANOVA
text:
References

Christensen, R. (2018). Analysis of variance, design, and regression: Linear modeling for unbalanced data (2nd Ed.). Chapman and Hall/CRC.
Dean, A., Voss, D., & DraguljiÄ‡, D. (2017). Design and analysis of experiments. Springer. https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-319-52250-0
Kempthorne, O. (1977). Design and Analysis of Experiments. Wiley.
Montgomery, D. C., Peck, E. A., & Vining, G. G. (2020). Introduction to linear regression analysis (5th Ed.). Wiley.

title: Completely Randomized Design and One-Way ANOVA
text:
A.1 Normal Equations and Estimability
The one-way ANOVA model can be written as:
\[
Y_{ij} = \mu_i + \varepsilon_{ij}, \quad \text{with } \mu_i = \mu + \tau_i.
\qquad(7)\]
The least squares approach forms normal equations from partial derivatives of SSE. Because \(\sum \tau_i = 0\), only differences in means are estimable. The space of estimable functions includes contrasts like \(\mu_1 - \mu_2\), but not individual \(\tau_i\) alone.

title: Completely Randomized Design and One-Way ANOVA
text:
A.2 Distribution of the F-Statistic
Under \(H_0\):
\[
F = \frac{MST}{MSE} \sim F_{v-1, N-v}.
\qquad(8)\]
If treatments truly differ, F follows a noncentral F-distribution, enabling power calculations and minimum detectable differences.

title: Completely Randomized Design and One-Way ANOVA
text:
A.3 Power Calculations
Power for detecting a difference \(\delta\) in means involves the noncentrality parameter of the F-distribution. By selecting \(\alpha, \sigma^2, \delta,\) and desired power, tables or software (e.g., pwr package in R) guide sample size choices.

pacman::p_load(pwr)
pwr.anova.test(k = 3, f = 0.4, sig.level = 0.05, power = 0.8)


     Balanced one-way analysis of variance power calculation 

              k = 3
              n = 21.10364
              f = 0.4
      sig.level = 0.05
          power = 0.8

NOTE: n is number in each group


This computes required sample size per treatment to achieve 80% power with a given effect size \(f\).

title: Fundamentals of Experimental Design
text:
In experimental design, the goal is to identify how various factors or treatments influence a response variable. Unlike observational studies, well-planned experiments leverage randomization, blocking, and replication to control and isolate sources of variation, thereby allowing robust causal conclusions. By thoughtfully designing experiments, researchers can more efficiently use resources, reduce systematic biases, and interpret data using classical statistical frameworks.
The following lecture notes will cover the fundamental principles of experimental design in the context of mathematical statistics. We will discuss the logic and practice of key techniquesâ€”randomization, blocking, and replicationâ€”and explore their role in ensuring valid and efficient inference. We will also highlight the interplay between design and analysis, referencing classical texts in design of experiments and illustrating concepts through examples and R code.

title: Fundamentals of Experimental Design
text:
In experimental design, the goal is to identify how various factors or treatments influence a response variable. Unlike observational studies, well-planned experiments leverage randomization, blocking, and replication to control and isolate sources of variation, thereby allowing robust causal conclusions. By thoughtfully designing experiments, researchers can more efficiently use resources, reduce systematic biases, and interpret data using classical statistical frameworks.
The following lecture notes will cover the fundamental principles of experimental design in the context of mathematical statistics. We will discuss the logic and practice of key techniquesâ€”randomization, blocking, and replicationâ€”and explore their role in ensuring valid and efficient inference. We will also highlight the interplay between design and analysis, referencing classical texts in design of experiments and illustrating concepts through examples and R code.

title: Fundamentals of Experimental Design
text:
Objectives

Understand the theoretical foundations and objectives of experimental design in statistics.
Distinguish between observational and experimental studies, emphasizing the advantages experiments provide.
Learn the fundamental techniques of replication, blocking, and randomization.
Discuss how factorial experiments efficiently explore multiple factors simultaneously.
Understand how design decisions affect data analysis and the validity of inferential procedures.
Reinforce concepts with R-based numerical examples and demonstrate their application to real or simulated data.
Explore advanced mathematical derivations and proofs in the Appendix.


Readings

Dean et al. (2017, Ch. 1 and 2)

title: Fundamentals of Experimental Design
text:
Experimentation vs.Â Observation

Observational studies record data without intervention, often leaving confounding factors unaccounted for. Causal interpretations are limited.
Controlled experiments, on the other hand, manipulate factor levels and apply treatments to subjects (experimental units). By controlling the allocation of treatments, experiments more reliably identify causes of variation and support causal conclusions.

title: Fundamentals of Experimental Design
text:
Goals of Experimentation

Determine causes of variation in response.
Find optimal conditions and treatment combinations.
Compare responses across different treatments.
Develop predictive models that accurately reflect the underlying process.

Effective experimental design ensures that maximum information is gained while efficiently using resources. These objectives directly influence how we choose the number of observations, treatment combinations, and the structure of the experimental layout.

title: Fundamentals of Experimental Design
text:
Importance of Experimental Design

Cause-and-Effect: Only experiments can directly assess causal relationships, unlike observational studies prone to confounding.
Resource Allocation: Deciding how many observations to collect and how to arrange them ensures the best return on time, effort, and material.
Efficient Analysis: A well-designed experiment simplifies subsequent data analysis and makes model assumptions (e.g., distributional forms, independence) more credible.

title: Fundamentals of Experimental Design
text:
Replication

Definition: Replication means repeating the entire set of treatments independently on different experimental units.
Purpose: Replication estimates the experimental error, allowing generalization of conclusions to a broader population of similar units.
Contrast with Repeated Measurements: Repeated measurements on the same unit (e.g., measuring the same subject multiple times) do not constitute independent replications. True replication involves distinct subjects or units.

Without adequate replication, it is difficult to separate true treatment effects from random noise.

title: Fundamentals of Experimental Design
text:
Blocking

Concept: Blocking is used to control extraneous variation by grouping experimental units into homogeneous subsets called blocks. Treatments are then compared within these blocks.
Example: If environmental conditions vary across different times of day, you may form blocks of time periods and randomly assign treatments within each block. This reduces noise and increases the precision of comparisons among treatments.
Outcome: Blocking improves the precision of inference by removing a known source of variability, making it easier to detect treatment differences.

title: Fundamentals of Experimental Design
text:
Randomization

Rationale: Random assignment of treatments to experimental units is fundamental. It ensures that no systematic bias influences treatment allocation.
Benefits:

Â  - Prevents experimenter preferences or unconscious patterns from influencing results. Â  - Justifies the use of standard statistical distributions (F, t) for inference. Â  - Confirms that observed effects can be attributed to treatments and not assignment bias.


Methods of Randomization

Random Number Generators (RNG): Computer programs or calculators produce pseudo-random digits, used to assign treatments.
Random Number Tables: Historically used, a random table combined with random starting points can ensure unbiased allocations.
Ensuring True Randomness: Use objective random devices (dice, RNGs) and avoid human-chosen â€œrandomâ€ sequences, as humans are prone to inadvertent patterns.

title: Fundamentals of Experimental Design
text:
Example: Random Assignment and ANOVA
Suppose we have three treatments (A, B, C) and want to randomly assign them to 9 experimental units.

# Set seed for reproducibility

set.seed(123)
# Treatments

treatments <- c("A", "B", "C")
# We have 9 units, randomly assign treatments

assignments <- sample(rep(treatments, each=3))
assignments

[1] "A" "B" "C" "A" "C" "B" "C" "A" "B"


This code generates a random permutation of A, B, and C assigned to the units.
Now assume we collected data (simulated responses):

# Simulate responses with a true difference: A <-  B <-  C
true_means <- c(A = 10, B = 12, C = 15)
responses <- rnorm(9, mean = rep(true_means, each = 3), sd = 2)
data <- data.frame(unit = 1:9, treatment = assignments, response = responses)
data |> head()








unit

response

TableÂ 1: Simulated Data




We can now fit an ANOVA model to test for treatment effects:



fit <- aov(response ~ treatment, data=data)
summary(fit)

            Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F value Pr(>F)
treatment    2  32.01   16.00   1.287  0.343
Residuals    6  74.61   12.44               



TableÂ 2: ANOVA Results



The ANOVA table will show how between-treatment variability compares to within-treatment variability. With a large enough difference and adequate replication, we expect a significant treatment effect.
Conclusion
Experimental design is a cornerstone of scientific inquiry. By employing replication, blocking, and randomization, statisticians and researchers can draw clearer causal conclusions, improve the efficiency of experimentation, and ensure the validity of statistical tests.
Key Takeaways:

Randomization prevents systematic bias and validates inferential methods.
Replication provides robust estimates of variability and supports generalizability.
Blocking controls known sources of variation, improving precision.
Factorial designs offer a more comprehensive view of multiple factors simultaneously.

Future sessions may delve deeper into specific complex designs (e.g., Latin squares, split-plots) and advanced analysis methods, ensuring students appreciate the rich interplay between design and analysis.

title: Fundamentals of Experimental Design
text: References

title: Fundamentals of Experimental Design
section: A Proof of Randomizationâ€™s Role in Distributional Assumptions
text:
A Proof of Randomizationâ€™s Role in Distributional Assumptions
Under a completely randomized design, every unit is equally likely to receive any treatment. Let \(Y_{ij}\) represent the response from the \(j\)-th replicate of treatment \(i\). Assuming \(Y_{ij} = \mu + \alpha_i + \varepsilon_{ij}\) with \(\varepsilon_{ij} \sim N(0,\sigma^2)\):

Randomization ensures that \((\varepsilon_{ij})\) are exchangeable random variables.
Under \(H_0: \alpha_i=0\), the test statistic (e.g., ANOVA F-statistic) follows an F-distribution derived from the ratio of quadratic forms in normal variables (ScheffÃ©, 1959).
Without randomization, the assumptions that justify the standard F and t distributions could be invalid, making inferences incorrect.

title: Fundamentals of Experimental Design
section: A Derivation of Expected Mean Squares
text:
A Derivation of Expected Mean Squares
For the simple one-way ANOVA model:
\[
Y_{ij} = \mu + \alpha_i + \varepsilon_{ij},
\]
with \(\sum \alpha_i = 0\), the expected mean squares are:
\[
E(MS_{\text{Treatment}}) = \sigma^2 + n \sum \alpha_i^2/(g-1),
\]
\[
E(MS_{\text{Error}}) = \sigma^2.
\]
These derivations rely on properties of orthogonal decompositions of sums of squares and can be found in Montgomery (2019) and ScheffÃ© (1959).

title: Assignment 8: Complete Block Designs
text:
Insole Cushion Experiment
Data Source: Dean et al.Â (2017), Chapter 10, Exercise 15
This experiment, conducted in 1995 by V. Agresti, S. Decker, T. Karakostas, E. Patterson, and S. Schwartz, investigated how different insole cushions and brands affect the vertical ground reaction force.

Brand (D): 1 (Name Brand), 2 (Store Brand)

Design:

Single participant, alternating between dominant (right) and non-dominant (left) legs over two blocks (days).
Each of the four treatment combinations measured five times in randomized order per block.

Response Variable: Maximum deceleration of the vertical ground reaction force (in Newtons).

text:
Exercise 7.7: Coating Experiment
This exercise examines the effects of spray parameters on the thermal spray coating properties of alumina (\(\text{Al}_2\text{O}_3\)). The experimental factors and levels are as follows:

Fuel ratio (A): 1:2.8 and 1:2.0
Carrier gas flow rate (B): 1.33 and 3.21 \(\text{L/s}^{-1}\)
Frequency of detonations (C): 2 and 4 Hz
Spray distance (D): 180 and 220 mm

The response variable is porosity (vol.Â %). Data are shown in Table 7.19.
Questions:

Design an Analysis

Assuming negligible threeand four-factor interactions, outline the steps required to analyze the data (refer to Step (g) of the checklist in Chapter 2).

Check Model Assumptions

Evaluate whether the assumptions underlying the model are valid.

Perform the Analysis

Conduct the analysis you outlined in part (1), including interaction plots if appropriate. Clearly state your conclusions.

title: Assignment 6: Higher-Order Factorial Designs
text:
Exercise 7.11: Antifungal Antibiotic Experiment
This exercise investigates the effects of incubation conditions on the yield of an antifungal antibiotic.

Factors and Levels:
Incubation temperature (A): 25, 30, and 37 \(^\circ \text{C}\)
Carbon concentration (B): 2%, 5%, and 7.5%
Nitrogen concentration (C): 0.5%, 1%, and 3%

The response variable is the antifungal yield (measured in activity against Candida albicans). Data are shown in Table 7.23.
Questions:

Assess Main Effects

Construct plots to assess the significance of main effects of \(A\), \(B\), and \(C\) on the response. What are your conclusions?

Interaction Assumptions

State the assumptions you made regarding interactions while analyzing main effects in part (1).

Two-Way Interactions

Construct plots to assess the significance of two-way interactions. Do they alter your conclusions from part (1)?

Fit a Model

Assuming no three-way interaction, fit a model with all main effects and two-way interactions. Discuss the significance of the effects and compare with your conclusions from part (3).

Model Diagnostics

Evaluate whether the assumptions of normality and equal error variances are satisfied. Identify potential outliers.

title: Assignment 6: Higher-Order Factorial Designs
text:
Exercise 7.12: Antifungal Antibiotic Experiment (Extended)
For this exercise, consider the data from Table 7.23 but assume no negligible three-factor interaction. Modify levels of \(A\) and \(B\) so their third levels are 35 and 8, respectively, to ensure equal spacing.
Questions:

Trend Contrasts

Create a table listing the 27 treatment combinations. Include contrast coefficients for:

Linear and quadratic trends in \(A\) and \(B\)
Interaction trends (\(A \times B\): Linear-Linear, Linear-Quadratic, etc.)


Normalize Contrasts

Identify divisors to normalize each contrast and manually compute least squares estimates for normalized Linear \(A\) and Quadratic \(A\) contrasts.

Orthogonal Contrasts for \(C\)

Propose two orthogonal contrasts for \(C\) to address its uneven spacing and add them to the table in part (1).

Orthogonal Contrasts Analysis

Use software to calculate least squares estimates for all 26 orthogonal contrasts. Generate a half-normal probability plot and interpret the results.

Alternative Analysis

Apply the Voss and Wang method to analyze the orthogonal contrasts. Compare these findings to part (4).

section: Set 2: Advanced Computational and Proof-Based Questions (Graduate Level)
text:
Set 2: Advanced Computational and Proof-Based Questions (Graduate Level)

2.1 Derivation of \(t\)-Statistic for Contrasts in ANOVA
Data Source: Christensen (2018)., Exercise 12.7.12
In a one-way ANOVA, the sum of squares for error (\(SSE\)) divided by the population variance (\(\sigma^2\)) follows a chi-squared distribution with degrees of freedom equal to \(df_E\):
\[
\frac{SSE}{\sigma^2} \sim \chi^2(df_E),
\]
and the mean square error (\(MSE\)) is independent of all sample means (\(\bar{y}_i\)). Show that the following expression follows a \(t\)-distribution with \(df_E\) degrees of freedom:
\[
\frac{\sum_{i=1}^a \lambda_i \bar{y}_i - \sum_{i=1}^a \lambda_i \mu_i}{\sqrt{MSE \sum_{i=1}^a \frac{\lambda_i^2}{N_i}}} \sim t(df_E).
\]
Tasks:

Derive the above expression step-by-step, starting with the variance of the contrast \(\sum_{i=1}^a \lambda_i \bar{y}_i\).
Explain why \(MSE\) serves as an unbiased estimate of \(\sigma^2\).
Using the result, construct a hypothesis test for a contrast in a one-way ANOVA and provide a practical interpretation of the result.



2.2 Implications of Assumption Violations

Discuss the implications of violating the assumption of homogeneity of variances in a one-way ANOVA. Suggest two methods to address such violations.



2.3 Power Analysis

Calculate the sample size required for a one-way ANOVA with four groups to detect a medium effect size (\(f = 0.25\)) at a significance level of \(\alpha = 0.05\) and a power of \(1 - \beta = 0.8\).

title: Testing Linear and Quadratic Trends with Unequal Variance in ANOVA
text:
Concept: In ANOVA, when groups have a natural order (e.g., drug doses: low, medium, high), we often test if the outcome follows a linear or quadratic trend. A linear trend implies a steady increase/decrease across groups, while a quadratic trend suggests a U-shaped or inverted U-shaped pattern.
Problem with Unequal Variance: Standard ANOVA assumes equal variance across groups. When variances differ (heteroscedasticity), the usual F-test becomes unreliable. For example, groups with larger variances may dominate the analysis, leading to incorrect conclusions.
Solution (Satterthwaiteâ€™s Approximation): Satterthwaiteâ€™s method adjusts the degrees of freedom (DF) for the t-test used to evaluate contrasts (e.g., linear/quadratic trends). This adjustment accounts for unequal variances, producing a more accurate p-value. Think of it as â€œbalancingâ€ the influence of each group based on its variability.

title: Testing Linear and Quadratic Trends with Unequal Variance in ANOVA
text:
Concept: In ANOVA, when groups have a natural order (e.g., drug doses: low, medium, high), we often test if the outcome follows a linear or quadratic trend. A linear trend implies a steady increase/decrease across groups, while a quadratic trend suggests a U-shaped or inverted U-shaped pattern.
Problem with Unequal Variance: Standard ANOVA assumes equal variance across groups. When variances differ (heteroscedasticity), the usual F-test becomes unreliable. For example, groups with larger variances may dominate the analysis, leading to incorrect conclusions.
Solution (Satterthwaiteâ€™s Approximation): Satterthwaiteâ€™s method adjusts the degrees of freedom (DF) for the t-test used to evaluate contrasts (e.g., linear/quadratic trends). This adjustment accounts for unequal variances, producing a more accurate p-value. Think of it as â€œbalancingâ€ the influence of each group based on its variability.

title: Testing Linear and Quadratic Trends with Unequal Variance in ANOVA
text:
Mathematical Foundations

Linear And Quadratic Contrasts
For \(k\) groups with means \(\bar{y}_1, \dots, \bar{y}_k\), define contrasts using coefficients \(c_i\):

Linear: \(c_i = \text{linear scaling (e.g., -1, 0, 1)}\)
Quadratic: \(c_i = \text{quadratic scaling (e.g., 1, -2, 1)}\)

Contrast Estimate:
\[
\psi = \sum_{i=1}^k c_i \bar{y}_i
\]
Standard Error (Unequal Variances):
\[
SE(\psi) = \sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^k \frac{c_i^2 s_i^2}{n_i}}
\]
where \(s_i^2\) is the variance of group \(i\), and \(n_i\) is its sample size.
Satterthwaiteâ€™s Degrees of Freedom:
\[
\nu = \frac{\left( \sum_{i=1}^k \frac{c_i^2 s_i^2}{n_i} \right)^2}{\sum_{i=1}^k \frac{c_i^4 s_i^4}{n_i^2 (n_i - 1)}}
\]
This formula approximates the effective DF by combining group-specific variances, derived from Welchâ€™s t-test extension.
Test Statistic:
\[
t = \frac{\psi}{SE(\psi)} \sim t_{\nu}
\]
Key Theorems:

Welch-Satterthwaite Equation: Approximates the distribution of a weighted sum of variances as a scaled chi-square distribution.
Central Limit Theorem: Justifies using the t-distribution for large samples.

title: Testing Linear and Quadratic Trends with Unequal Variance in ANOVA
text:
Numerical Example in R
Data Generation: Simulate three groups with unequal variances:

set.seed(123)
group <- factor(rep(1:3, each = 5))
y <- c(
    rnorm(5, 10, 1), # Group 1: Î¼=10, Ïƒ=1
    rnorm(5, 12, 2), # Group 2: Î¼=12, Ïƒ=2
    rnorm(5, 15, 3)
) # Group 3: Î¼=15, Ïƒ=3

Manual Calculation:

# Group statistics
means <- tapply(y, group, mean) # 10.19357 11.91136 15.92371
vars <- tapply(y, group, var) # 0.6577564 5.4148322 3.6802184
ns <- tapply(y, group, length) # 5 5 5

# Linear contrast coefficients (from contr.poly)
c_linear <- contr.poly(3)[, 1] # [-0.707, 0, 0.707]

# Contrast estimate
contrast_est <- sum(c_linear * means) # â‰ˆ 4.051817

# Standard error
se <- sqrt(sum((c_linear^2 * vars) / ns)) # 0.658633

# Satterthwaite DF
df_num <- (sum((c_linear^2 * vars) / ns))^2
df_den <- sum((c_linear^4 * vars^2) / (ns^2 * (ns - 1)))
df_satt <- df_num / df_den # â‰ˆ 5.6

# t-test
t_ratio <- contrast_est / se # â‰ˆ 6.15
p_value <- 2 * pt(abs(t_ratio), df_satt, lower.tail = FALSE)

# output create a table
data.frame(contrast_est, se, df_satt, t_ratio, p_value)





contrast_est
se
df_satt
t_ratio
p_value




4.051817
0.658633
5.385561
6.151859
0.0012627










pacman::p_load(emmeans)
library(nlme)

# Fit a model allowing unequal variances
model_gls <- gls(y ~ group, weights = varIdent(form = ~ 1 | group))
emm <- emmeans(model_gls, ~group)

# Test linear trend
contrast(emm, method = "poly", adjust = "none")

 contrast  estimate    SE   df t.ratio p.value
 linear        5.73 0.931 5.39   6.152  0.0013
 quadratic     2.29 2.280 5.60   1.006  0.3558

Degrees-of-freedom method: satterthwaite
