title: Hypothesis Testing Basics
text:
Hypothesis testing is a cornerstone of statistical analysis, used to evaluate assumptions about population parameters based on sample data. In R, several functions and packages provide extensive tools for hypothesis testing, ranging from basic tests in base R to more specialized tests available in external packages.



Packages/Functions:

Base R: t.test(), chisq.test(), var.test(), wilcox.test()
Additional Packages: stats::ks.test(), MASS::leveneTest()

Purpose:

To evaluate assumptions or hypotheses about data distributions and relationships.

Common Functions:

t.test() for t-tests.
chisq.test() for Chi-square tests.
ks.test() for Kolmogorov-Smirnov tests.
wilcox.test() for non-parametric Wilcoxon tests.






Comparing means between two groups.
Assessing the goodness-of-fit for categorical data.
Testing for equal variances across groups.
Non-parametric comparisons for skewed or ordinal data.





Easy to implement with a range of built-in functions.
Highly extensible for complex scenarios.
Seamless integration with visualization and other analytical tools.







Base R provides most hypothesis testing tools. Additional packages like MASS can be used for specialized tests.

library(MASS)






Testing whether the mean of a sample is equal to a specific value.

set.seed(42)
sample_data <- rnorm(30, mean = 5, sd = 2)

t.test(sample_data, mu = 5)


    One Sample t-test

data:  sample_data
t = 0.29933, df = 29, p-value = 0.7668
alternative hypothesis: true mean is not equal to 5
95 percent confidence interval:
 4.199903 6.074444
sample estimates:
mean of x 
 5.137174 












Performs one-sample, two-sample, and paired t-tests to compare means.



t.test(x, y = NULL, alternative = c("two.sided", "less", "greater"),
       mu = 0, paired = FALSE, var.equal = FALSE, conf.level = 0.95)

x, y: Numeric vectors of data values.
alternative: Type of hypothesis (â€œtwo.sidedâ€, â€œgreaterâ€, â€œlessâ€).
mu: Hypothesized mean (default is 0).
paired: Whether the test is paired (default is FALSE).
var.equal: Assume equal variances (default is FALSE).





group1 <- rnorm(20, mean = 5)
group2 <- rnorm(20, mean = 6)

t.test(group1, group2, alternative = "two.sided", var.equal = TRUE)


    Two Sample t-test

data:  group1 and group2
t = -4.6894, df = 38, p-value = 3.486e-05
alternative hypothesis: true difference in means is not equal to 0
95 percent confidence interval:
 -2.1057327 -0.8358574
sample estimates:
mean of x mean of y 
 4.807940  6.278735 








Tests for independence or goodness-of-fit in categorical data.



chisq.test(x, y = NULL, correct = TRUE, simulate.p.value = FALSE, rescale.p = FALSE)




observed <- matrix(c(30, 20, 50, 40), ncol = 2)

chisq.test(observed)


    Pearson's Chi-squared test with Yates' continuity correction

data:  observed
X-squared = 0.10954, df = 1, p-value = 0.7407








Performs the Wilcoxon rank-sum test (non-parametric alternative to the t-test).



wilcox.test(x, y = NULL, alternative = c("two.sided", "less", "greater"), mu = 0, paired = FALSE, exact = NULL)




x <- rnorm(30)
y <- rnorm(30, mean = 1)

wilcox.test(x, y, alternative = "less")


    Wilcoxon rank sum exact test

data:  x and y
W = 271, p-value = 0.003824
alternative hypothesis: true location shift is less than 0














Evaluate the effect of a treatment by comparing preand post-treatment scores.




Prepare the data.
Apply the paired t-test.
Visualize the differences.


pre <- c(12, 14, 11, 10, 13, 15)
post <- c(14, 16, 12, 11, 15, 17)

t.test(pre, post, paired = TRUE)


    Paired t-test

data:  pre and post
t = -7.9057, df = 5, p-value = 0.0005211
alternative hypothesis: true mean difference is not equal to 0
95 percent confidence interval:
 -2.208593 -1.124740
sample estimates:
mean difference 
      -1.666667 





Interpret the p-value to determine if there is a significant difference between preand post-treatment scores.









Check if a six-sided die is fair.




Collect observed frequencies of each side.
Specify expected frequencies.
Apply the Chi-square goodness-of-fit test.


observed <- c(12, 15, 14, 13, 16, 10)
expected <- rep(1/6, 6) * sum(observed)

chisq.test(observed, p = expected / sum(expected))


    Chi-squared test for given probabilities

data:  observed
X-squared = 1.75, df = 5, p-value = 0.8825





Evaluate the p-value to determine if the die is fair.









Set custom confidence levels in tests:

t.test(group1, group2, conf.level = 0.99)


    Welch Two Sample t-test

data:  group1 and group2
t = -4.6894, df = 37.995, p-value = 3.487e-05
alternative hypothesis: true difference in means is not equal to 0
99 percent confidence interval:
 -2.3212628 -0.6203274
sample estimates:
mean of x mean of y 
 4.807940  6.278735 









library(dplyr)

mtcars |>
  group_by(cyl) |>
  summarise(t_result = list(t.test(mpg ~ as.factor(am))$p.value))


  









Use vectorized operations or summary statistics for efficiency:

large_data <- rnorm(1e6)
t.test(large_data, mu = 0)


    One Sample t-test

data:  large_data
t = 0.59109, df = 1e+06, p-value = 0.5545
alternative hypothesis: true mean is not equal to 0
95 percent confidence interval:
 -0.001370263  0.002553645
sample estimates:
   mean of x 
0.0005916909 










Error: Data must be numeric

Ensure data is numeric by using as.numeric().

Warning: p-value approximation

Increase the sample size or use simulate.p.value = TRUE.






What is the minimum sample size for a t-test?

At least 5 observations per group are recommended.

Can I test for normality before t-tests?

Use shapiro.test() to check normality.







Always visualize your data before performing tests.
Check assumptions (e.g., normality for t-tests, independence for Chi-square tests).
Use appropriate alternatives (e.g., Wilcoxon test for non-normal data).




Hypothesis testing in R is a versatile and powerful tool for statistical analysis. From basic t-tests to advanced non-parametric methods, R provides comprehensive support for validating assumptions and making data-driven decisions.




R Documentation
R Graph Gallery
R Hypothesis Testing Guide

title: Figures, Tables, Captions, and Referencing in Quarto: A Comprehensive Tutorial
text:
Quarto is a publishing system that integrates R code, text, and output (figures, tables) into dynamic documents. This tutorial focuses on creating figures/tables with captions, cross-referencing them, and generating reproducible reports.
Key Features:

Add captions using #| fig-cap or #| tbl-cap in code chunks.
Cross-reference figures/tables with @label syntax.
Customize outputs using ggplot2, knitr, kableExtra, and gt.





Academic papers with numbered figures/tables.
Technical reports with automated cross-references.
Dashboards integrating dynamic visualizations and summaries.





Automation: Update figures/tables and references dynamically.
Consistency: Ensure captions and labels follow document structure.
Flexibility: Output to HTML, PDF, Word, or slides.

title: Figures, Tables, Captions, and Referencing in Quarto: A Comprehensive Tutorial
text:
Quarto is a publishing system that integrates R code, text, and output (figures, tables) into dynamic documents. This tutorial focuses on creating figures/tables with captions, cross-referencing them, and generating reproducible reports.

title: Figures, Tables, Captions, and Referencing in Quarto: A Comprehensive Tutorial
text:
2. Getting Started

Loading the Package

# Load required packages
pacman::p_load(ggplot2, dplyr, kableExtra, gt)
ggplot2::theme_set(theme_minimal())



Basic Usage
Figure with Caption:

ggplot2::ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = wt, y = mpg)) +
    geom_point()







FigureÂ 1: Scatterplot of car weight vs.Â MPG.





Reference the figure in text: See Figure @fig-mpg.
Table with Caption:

mtcars |>
    group_by(cyl) |>
    summarize(avg_mpg = mean(mpg)) |>
    knitr::kable()







cyl
avg_mpg

6
19.74286


8
15.10000






TableÂ 1: Summary of MPG by cylinders.




Reference the table: Table @tbl-summary showsâ€¦ produces â€œTableÂ 1 showsâ€¦â€.

title: Figures, Tables, Captions, and Referencing in Quarto: A Comprehensive Tutorial
text:
3. Key Functions and Features

Quarto Chunk Options
Description: Control figure/table captions, labels, and layout.
Syntax:
#| label: fig-example  
#| fig-cap: "Caption text"  
#| tbl-cap: "Table caption"  
#| layout: "l-body-outset"  
Example:

```{r}
#| label: fig-density
#| fig-cap: "Density plot of MPG."

ggplot(mtcars, aes(mpg)) +
    geom_density(fill = "skyblue")
```







FigureÂ 2: Density plot of MPG.





Refer to the figure: Figure @fig-density showsâ€¦ produces â€œFigureÂ 2 showsâ€¦â€.


kableExtra::kbl()
Description: Create customizable tables with captions.
Syntax:
data |>  
  kableExtra::kbl(  
    caption = "Table title",  
    align = "c",  
    format = "html"  
  ) |>  
  kableExtra::kable_styling()  
Example:

mtcars |>
    head(3) |>
    kableExtra::kbl(caption = "Sample Cars") |>
    kableExtra::kable_styling(full_width = FALSE)

title: Figures, Tables, Captions, and Referencing in Quarto: A Comprehensive Tutorial
text:
4. In-Depth Examples

Example 1: Dynamic Figure Captions
Objective: Generate a figure caption with variables.
Steps:

ggplot(mtcars, aes(mpg)) +
    geom_histogram(bins = 10, fill = "steelblue")







FigureÂ 3: MPG distribution for {{nrow(mtcars)}} cars.





Output: Caption dynamically updates if data changes.


Example 2: Multi-Column Table
Objective: Create a summary table grouped by cylinders.
Steps:

mtcars |>
    group_by(cyl) |>
    summarize(
        Avg_MPG = mean(mpg),
        SD_MPG = sd(mpg)
    ) |>
    gt::gt() |>
    gt::tab_header(title = "Cylinder Performance")

title: Figures, Tables, Captions, and Referencing in Quarto: A Comprehensive Tutorial
text:
5. Advanced Features

Customization
Conditional Table Formatting:

mtcars |>
    head() |>
    mutate(
        high_mpg = ifelse(mpg > 20, "green", "red")
    ) |>
    kableExtra::kbl() |>
    kableExtra::column_spec(6, background = mtcars$high_mpg)

title: Figures, Tables, Captions, and Referencing in Quarto: A Comprehensive Tutorial
text:
6. Troubleshooting and FAQs

Common Issues

Missing Captions: Ensure #| fig-cap or #| tbl-cap is placed inside the code chunk.
Broken Cross-References: Verify that labels match exactly (e.g., @fig-label vs.Â fig-label).



FAQs
Q: How to reference figures in PDF output? A: Use the same @label syntax; Quarto handles format-specific numbering.
Q: Can I use LaTeX in captions? A: Yes, for PDF output: #| fig-cap: "\\textbf{Bold} caption text".

title: Figures, Tables, Captions, and Referencing in Quarto: A Comprehensive Tutorial
text:
7. Best Practices

Use descriptive labels (e.g., fig-mpg-distribution instead of fig1).
Store reusable components (e.g., themes, table styles) in separate scripts.
Prefer gt for complex tables and kableExtra for quick HTML formatting.

title: Figures, Tables, Captions, and Referencing in Quarto: A Comprehensive Tutorial
text:
8. Conclusion

Summary
Quarto streamlines figure/table creation, captioning, and cross-referencing. Key tools include:

Chunk options (#| label, #| fig-cap).
ggplot2 for figures, gt/kableExtra for tables.



Next Steps
Explore Quartoâ€™s cross-referencing syntax for equations, sections, and theorems.

title: Figures, Tables, Captions, and Referencing in Quarto: A Comprehensive Tutorial
text:

Quarto Documentation: https://quarto.org
ggplot2 Cheat Sheet: https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org
Community Support: RStudio Community, Stack Overflow (tag: quarto).

title: Tutorial on the Games-Howell Test Using PMCMRplus
text:
The Games-Howell test is a post-hoc statistical procedure used to perform all-pairs comparisons between group means after a significant ANOVA result. It is particularly useful when the assumption of equal variances across groups is violated. Unlike the Tukey HSD test, which assumes homogeneity of variances, the Games-Howell test uses Welchâ€™s degrees of freedom to adjust for unequal variances, making it robust for such scenarios.
This tutorial will guide you through using the gamesHowellTest function from the PMCMRplus package in R.

title: Tutorial on the Games-Howell Test Using PMCMRplus
text:
The Games-Howell test is a post-hoc statistical procedure used to perform all-pairs comparisons between group means after a significant ANOVA result. It is particularly useful when the assumption of equal variances across groups is violated. Unlike the Tukey HSD test, which assumes homogeneity of variances, the Games-Howell test uses Welchâ€™s degrees of freedom to adjust for unequal variances, making it robust for such scenarios.
This tutorial will guide you through using the gamesHowellTest function from the PMCMRplus package in R.

title: Tutorial on the Games-Howell Test Using PMCMRplus
text:
Installation
First, install and load the PMCMRplus package if not already installed:

pacman::p_load("PMCMRplus")

title: Tutorial on the Games-Howell Test Using PMCMRplus
text:
Function Syntax
The gamesHowellTest function has three primary methods:

Default method: gamesHowellTest(x, g, â€¦)

x: Numeric vector of data or a list of numeric vectors.
g: Grouping vector/factor (ignored if x is a list).

Formula method: gamesHowellTest(formula, data, â€¦)

formula: Formula of the form response ~ group.
data: Data frame containing variables in the formula.

aov method: gamesHowellTest(x, â€¦)

x: A fitted model object of class aov.

title: Tutorial on the Games-Howell Test Using PMCMRplus
text:
Step-by-Step Examples

Example 1: Using an aov Object
Weâ€™ll use the built-in chickwts dataset to compare chicken weights across feed types.

Step 1: Check Assumptions

Normality: Shapiro-Wilk test on residuals.
Equal Variances: Bartlett test.


# Fit ANOVA model
fit <- aov(weight ~ feed, data = chickwts)

# Check normality of residuals
shapiro.test(residuals(fit))  # p > 0.05 â†’ normality assumed


    Shapiro-Wilk normality test

data:  residuals(fit)
W = 0.98616, p-value = 0.6272

# Check homogeneity of variances
bartlett.test(weight ~ feed, data = chickwts)  # small p â†’ unequal variances


    Bartlett test of homogeneity of variances

data:  weight by feed
Bartlett's K-squared = 3.2597, df = 5, p-value = 0.66




Step 2: Run ANOVA

anova(fit) 






Df
Sum Sq
Mean Sq
F value
Pr(>F)




feed
5
231129.2
46225.832
15.3648
0


Residuals
65
195556.0
3008.554
NA
NA








Step 3: Perform Games-Howell Test

res <- gamesHowellTest(fit)
summary(res)  # Pairwise comparisons with p-values

                           q value   Pr(>|q|)    
horsebean - casein == 0    -10.384 9.4359e-06 ***
linseed - casein == 0       -6.192 0.00310158  **
meatmeal - casein == 0      -2.445 0.52927013    
soybean - casein == 0       -4.631 0.03604278   *
sunflower - casein == 0      0.323 0.99990004    
linseed - horsebean == 0     4.267 0.06493843   .
meatmeal - horsebean == 0    7.155 0.00123741  **
soybean - horsebean == 0     6.441 0.00190148  **
sunflower - horsebean == 0  12.791 2.3072e-07 ***
meatmeal - linseed == 0      3.329 0.22093066    
soybean - linseed == 0       1.873 0.76889970    
sunflower - linseed == 0     7.547 0.00030424 ***
soybean - meatmeal == 0     -1.771 0.80599848    
sunflower - meatmeal == 0    3.050 0.30300311    
sunflower - soybean == 0     5.775 0.00508811  **




Step 4: Interpret Results

feed: A significant effect of feed type on weight is observed. The Games-Howell test suggests that the means of weight are different between the different feed types.
Residuals: The remaining variance is due to random error.




Example 2: Using the Formula Method
Simulate data with three groups (A, B, C) with unequal variances.

# Create data
set.seed(123)
group <- factor(rep(c("A", "B", "C"), each = 20))
values <- c(rnorm(20, mean=10, sd=2),  # Group A
            rnorm(20, mean=15, sd=4),  # Group B
            rnorm(20, mean=12, sd=3)) # Group C

# Perform Games-Howell Test
result <- gamesHowellTest(values ~ group)
summary(result)

           q value   Pr(>|q|)    
B - A == 0   7.416 3.2056e-05 ***
C - A == 0   3.713   0.033796   *
C - B == 0  -3.567   0.041576   *

title: Tutorial on the Games-Howell Test Using PMCMRplus
text:
Key Output Interpretation

statistic: Test statistic for each pair (t-value).
p.value: Adjusted p-values using the Tukey distribution.
Values are arranged in a lower-triangle matrix. A p-value <- 0.05 indicates a significant difference between groups.

title: Tutorial on the Games-Howell Test Using PMCMRplus
text:
Assumptions and Considerations

Normality: The test assumes normality. Check using Shapiro-Wilk or QQ-plots.
Unequal Variances: Use Games-Howell when variances are unequal (check via Bartlett/Levene test).
Post-Hoc Use: Conduct only after a significant ANOVA result.

title: Tutorial on the Games-Howell Test Using PMCMRplus
section: When to Use Games-Howell vs.Â Other Tests
text:
When to Use Games-Howell vs.Â Other Tests

Tukey HSD: Use when variances are equal.
Dunnettâ€™s Test: Compare all groups against a control.
Bonferroni: Conservative adjustment for any pairwise test.

title: Tutorial on the Games-Howell Test Using PMCMRplus
text:
Conclusion
The gamesHowellTest is ideal for comparing group means when variances are unequal. Always validate assumptions before applying the test. Use the formula or aov method for cleaner syntax with data frames or model objects.

title: Tukeyâ€™s Standardized Range Distribution
text: Below is a conceptual overview and step-by-step tutorial on the Studentized Range distribution. This distribution arises frequently in multiple comparisons procedures in statistics, particularly in Tukeyâ€™s Honestly Significant Difference (HSD) test. Weâ€™ll cover the definition, context, properties, and practical computation of the Studentized Range distribution.

title: Tukeyâ€™s Standardized Range Distribution
section: 1. What Is the Studentized Range Distribution?
text:
1. What Is the Studentized Range Distribution?
The Studentized Range distribution (often denoted \(q\)) describes the distribution of the range of a sample (i.e., the difference between the sampleâ€™s maximum and minimum) standardized by the sampleâ€™s estimated standard deviation.
Formally, suppose we have:

A sample of \(k\) observations, all from the same normal population with unknown variance \(\sigma^2\).
An independent estimate of the variance based on \(\nu\) (sometimes denoted \(df\)) degrees of freedom.

Define:
\[
\text{Range} = \max(X_1, \dots, X_k) - \min(X_1, \dots, X_k).
\]
Then the statistic
\[
q = \frac{\max(X_1, \dots, X_k) - \min(X_1, \dots, X_k)}{s},
\]
where \(s\) is the estimated standard deviation (based on \(\nu\) degrees of freedom), follows a Studentized Range distribution with parameters \(k\) (the number of means or groups being compared) and \(\nu\) (degrees of freedom).

Why â€œStudentizedâ€?

â€œStudentizedâ€ means it has been scaled by an estimate of the standard deviationâ€”analogous to how a \(t\)-distribution arises by dividing a (normal) mean difference by an estimated standard error.
The Studentized Range is a generalization of the \(t\)-distribution for comparing more than two means.

title: Tukeyâ€™s Standardized Range Distribution
text:
2. Context: Tukeyâ€™s HSD Test
The most common use case for the Studentized Range distribution is in Tukeyâ€™s Honestly Significant Difference (HSD) procedure, which is a multiple-comparison test for determining which means in a set of group means differ significantly:

Start with an ANOVA for \(k\) groups (each with sample size \(n_i\)), total number of degrees of freedom in error \(\nu = N - k\) (if each group has the same sample size \(n\), then \(\nu = k(n - 1)\)).
After finding that the overall ANOVA is significant, we want to compare each pair of group means.
The test statistic for comparing any two group means is

\[
q = \frac{\bar{X}_i - \bar{X}_j}{\sqrt{\frac{MSE}{n}}}
\]
where \(MSE\) is the mean square error from the ANOVA, and \(n\) is the per-group sample size (if balanced).

We compare \(q\) to critical values from the Studentized Range distribution with parameters \(k\) and \(\nu\).

Hence, the Studentized Range \(q\) helps control the family-wise error rate across multiple pairwise comparisons.

title: Tukeyâ€™s Standardized Range Distribution
text:
3. Defining the Distribution More Rigorously

3.1 PDF or CDF Definitions
The probability density function (PDF) and cumulative distribution function (CDF) of the Studentized Range are not as simple to express in closed form as, say, the normal or \(t\)-distribution. They involve integrals of the joint distribution of order statistics of normal variates.

A simplified conceptual approach

Let \(Z_1, Z_2, \dots, Z_k\) be i.i.d. standard normal.
Let \(\bar{Z}\) be their mean, and let \(S^2 = \sum_{i=1}^k (Z_i - \bar{Z})^2\) be an estimate of the variance (but note carefully how the degrees of freedom tie in).
The difference \(\max(Z) - \min(Z)\) is the â€œrangeâ€ in the numerator.
Scale that range by \(\sqrt{S^2 / \nu}\) to get \(q\).

This results in the Studentized Range distribution parameters \(k\) (number of sample points) and \(\nu\) (degrees of freedom).
In practice, tables (or software functions) for \(q\) are used to find critical values rather than dealing with the PDF or CDF directly.

title: Tukeyâ€™s Standardized Range Distribution
text:
4. Critical Values and Tables
When you see references to \(q_{\alpha, k, \nu}\), it means:

\(\alpha\) is the desired significance level (or tail probability),
\(k\) is the number of groups,
\(\nu\) is the error degrees of freedom.

For example, if you see \(q_{0.05, 4, 20}\), itâ€™s the critical value such that
\[
P(Q \geq q_{0.05, 4, 20}) = 0.05
\]
where \(Q \sim q\)-distribution with parameters \(k=4\), \(\nu=20\).
These tables are typically used in Tukeyâ€™s HSD test. Statistical software (R, Python, SAS, SPSS, etc.) also can provide these critical values.

title: Tukeyâ€™s Standardized Range Distribution
text:
5. Properties and Uses

Multiple Comparisons Adjustments

Tukeyâ€™s HSD is probably the best-known method leveraging the Studentized Range. It maintains the familywise error rate at a specified \(\alpha\) for all pairwise comparisons.

Relationship to Other Distributions

For \(k = 2\), the Studentized Range distribution is identical to the \(t\)-distribution, because the â€œrangeâ€ between exactly two points is just their difference.
When \(k > 2\), the distribution is distinct; the critical value for a given \(\alpha\) will be larger than the corresponding \(t\)-value to account for multiple comparisons.

Conservative Bound in Some Cases

The distribution is specifically tailored for pairwise range-based comparisons. In some cases (especially when group sizes are unequal or for non-pairwise contrasts), the distribution-based approach might be more conservative or only approximately correct. Adjustments exist for unbalanced designs.

title: Tukeyâ€™s Standardized Range Distribution
text:
6. Practical Computation
These days, manual table lookup is less common. Statistical software typically has built-in functions for either:

Generating quantiles (critical values),
Computing p-values for an observed Studentized Range statistic,
Directly implementing Tukeyâ€™s HSD test.


6.1 In R

qtukey() gives the quantiles of the Studentized Range distribution (critical values).
ptukey() gives the cumulative distribution function (CDF).
Functions like TukeyHSD() automatically handle calculations after an aov().



6.2 In Python
While there is not always a direct built-in in scipy.stats for the Studentized Range, there are packages like statsmodels that implement TukeyHSD. Alternatively, one might use tables or approximate expansions.


6.3 In Other Software

SAS has PROC GLM with MEANS statement: MEANS group / TUKEY;
SPSS has Post Hoc tests with a Tukey option as well.

title: Tukeyâ€™s Standardized Range Distribution
text:
7. Step-by-Step Example
Letâ€™s run through a conceptual example for clarity.
Scenario You have 4 groups (A, B, C, D), each with 10 observations, and youâ€™ve performed a one-way ANOVA. The ANOVA F-test is significant. You decide to do Tukeyâ€™s HSD to compare each pair of group means.

Obtain MSE and \(\nu\)

From your ANOVA table, suppose \(MSE = 2.5\).
Degrees of freedom for error, \(\nu = N - k = 40 - 4 = 36\).

Compute Pairwise Mean Differences

Suppose the sample means are:


\[
\bar{X}_A = 12.8,\; \bar{X}_B = 14.5,\; \bar{X}_C = 13.2,\; \bar{X}_D = 15.3.
\]

Pairwise differences (absolute values):

\[
|\bar{X}_A - \bar{X}_B| = 1.7,\quad
     |\bar{X}_A - \bar{X}_C| = 0.4,\quad
     |\bar{X}_A - \bar{X}_D| = 2.5, \quad
     |\bar{X}_B - \bar{X}_C| = 1.3,\quad
     |\bar{X}_B - \bar{X}_D| = 0.8,\quad
     |\bar{X}_C - \bar{X}_D| = 2.1.
\]

Calculate Standard Error

With equal sample size \(n = 10\), the standard error for the difference is


\[SE = \sqrt{\frac{MSE}{n}} = \sqrt{\frac{2.5}{10}} = \sqrt{0.25} = 0.5.
\]

Form the Tukey \(q\)-Statistic

For each pair, \(q = \frac{\text{difference}}{SE}\).
For instance, for \(\bar{X}_A - \bar{X}_D = 2.5\):


\[
q = \frac{2.5}{0.5} = 5.0.
\]

Compare to Critical Value

Look up (or compute via software) \(q_{0.05, k=4, \nu=36}\).
Suppose you find that \(q_{0.05, 4, 36} \approx 3.80\) (this is just an example value; actual lookups may differ).
Since \(q = 5.0\) for the Aâ€“D comparison is greater than 3.80, the difference between groups A and D is statistically significant at \(\alpha=0.05\).

Interpretation

You would interpret each pairâ€™s \(q\)-value by comparing to the Studentized Range critical value. Any pair with \(q\) above the critical threshold is considered to have a significant difference in means.

title: Tukeyâ€™s Standardized Range Distribution
text:
8. Key Takeaways

Range-Based Multiple Comparisons


The Studentized Range distribution is the distribution of the range (max - min) of \(k\) normally distributed variables, scaled by an estimate of standard deviation with \(\nu\) degrees of freedom.


Connection to Tukeyâ€™s HSD


It underpins Tukeyâ€™s HSD, a widely used method for controlling familywise error when comparing multiple group means post-ANOVA.


Critical Value Lookup


Values \(q_{\alpha, k, \nu}\) can be found in standard statistical tables or via statistical software.
For large \(\nu\), the distribution converges somewhat to a normal-based range, but always consult the exact distribution for accurate results.


Software Implementation


Because the PDF and CDF are complex integrals, usage typically relies on tables or built-in software routines (e.g., qtukey(), TukeyHSD(), etc.).


Degrees of Freedom


Always match the appropriate error degrees of freedom, typically from an ANOVAâ€™s residual or error term.

title: Tukeyâ€™s Standardized Range Distribution
text:
9. Further Reading

Hochberg, Y. and Tamhane, A. C. (1987). Multiple Comparison Procedures. Wiley.
Montgomery, D. C. (2012). Design and Analysis of Experiments. Wiley.
Kirk, R. E. (2013). Experimental Design: Procedures for the Behavioral Sciences. SAGE.

These sources go into more technical depth on the Studentized Range distribution, multiple comparisons, and the context of Tukeyâ€™s HSD.

Final Note
The Studentized Range distribution is essential whenever you deal with range-based statistics, especially in the context of comparing multiple means simultaneously. Its principal role in Tukeyâ€™s HSD makes it a standard tool in the statisticianâ€™s toolbox for post-ANOVA analyses, ensuring control of the familywise error rate in pairwise comparisons.

text:

Tasks: (a) Address steps (a)â€“(d) from the experimental planning checklist in detail:

Define the objectives of the experiment.

title: Assignment 3: Multiple Comparisons and Contrasts
section: 3. Meat Cooking Experiment (Continuation from Exercise 14, Chapter 3)
text:
3. Meat Cooking Experiment (Continuation from Exercise 14, Chapter 3)
An experiment was run to investigate the amount of weight lost (in grams) by ground beef ham- burgers after grilling or frying, and how much the weight loss is affected by the percentage fat in the beef before cooking. The experiment involved two factors: cooking method (factor A, with two levels frying and grilling, coded 1, 2), and fat content (factor B, with three levels 10, 15, and 20%, coded 1, 2, 3). Thus there were six treatment combinations 11, 12, 13, 21, 22, 23, relabeled as treatment levels 1, 2, â€¦, 6, respectively. Hamburger patties weighing 110 g each were prepared from meat with the required fat content. There were 30 â€œcooking time slotsâ€ which were randomly assigned to the treatments in such a way that each treatment was observed five times (r = 5). The patty weights after cooking are shown in Table 3.14.

Conduct pairwise comparisons for the six treatments using ScheffÃ©â€™s method with a 95% overall confidence level. Present your results with appropriate statistical summaries and visualizations.
Analyze the expressions \(\mu + \frac{(\tau_1 + \tau_4)}{2}\), \(\mu + \frac{(\tau_2 + \tau_5)}{2}\), and \(\mu + \frac{(\tau_3 + \tau_6)}{2}\):


Interpret what these expressions represent in the context of the experimental setup.
Perform pairwise comparisons among these three treatment averages using ScheffÃ©â€™s method with a 95% confidence level.
Summarize and interpret the findings in terms of practical significance and experimental insights.

title: Assignment 3: Multiple Comparisons and Contrasts
text:
4. Reaction Time Experiment
Source: (L. Cai, T. Li, Nishant, and A. van der Kouwe, 1996)
This experiment investigates the effects of auditory and visual cues on the speed of response of a human subject. A personal computer presents a stimulus to the subject, and the reaction time required to press a key is monitored. The subject is warned of the forthcoming stimulus through auditory or visual cues. The study also considers different elapsed times between cue and stimulus as a factor.
Factors and Levels:

Cue Stimulus: Auditory or Visual
Elapsed Time: 5, 10, or 15 seconds

Treatment Combinations and Codes:

1 = Auditory, 5 seconds
2 = Auditory, 10 seconds
3 = Auditory, 15 seconds
4 = Visual, 5 seconds
5 = Visual, 10 seconds
6 = Visual, 15 seconds

The pilot experiment data, involving one subject, are shown in Table 4.4.
Here is the recreated Table 4.4 in a structured format:

Understanding the Structure of the Data
The Reaction Time Experiment data consists of observations measuring how quickly a participant responds to an auditory or visual cue. The study manipulates two factors:

Cue Stimulus (Factor A): Auditory (A1) or Visual (A2).
Elapsed Time (Factor B): 5 seconds (B1), 10 seconds (B2), or 15 seconds (B3).

Each treatment combination represents a specific pairing of these two factors:

Tasks: (a) Identify Preplanned Contrasts:

Determine contrasts of interest, such as comparing auditory versus visual treatments. Specify the contrasts mathematically, including coefficients for the comparisons.


Plot the Data:


Visualize the reaction times using an appropriate plot (e.g., bar or line plot). Summarize what the plot reveals about the treatment effects.


Hypothesis Testing:


Test the null hypothesis \(H_0\): The treatments have no effect on reaction time against the alternative \(H_1\): The treatments have an effect on reaction time. Include a detailed explanation of the statistical test used and the results obtained.


Simultaneous Confidence Intervals:


Compute simultaneous 90% confidence intervals for the preplanned contrasts using a chosen method (e.g., Tukeyâ€™s or ScheffÃ©â€™s method). Interpret these intervals and state your conclusions about the treatment effects.

title: Assignment 3: Multiple Comparisons and Contrasts
text:
Grading Rubric for the Assignment










Task
Excellent (100%)
Good (85%)
Satisfactory (70%)
Needs Improvement (50%)




1. Buoyancy Experiment
Complete and detailed checklist, well-justified preplanned contrasts, proper simulation and analysis in R.
Detailed checklist but minor omissions in preplanned contrasts or R simulation.
Checklist addressed but lacks sufficient detail or justification. Simulation and analysis incomplete.
Major gaps in checklist completion, no simulation, or preplanned contrasts missing.


2. Cotton-Spinning Experiment
All contrasts identified clearly, and coefficients are mathematically accurate and fully explained.
Most contrasts identified, and coefficients mostly correct. Explanation somewhat unclear.
Contrasts partially correct; coefficients missing or inaccurate. Explanation lacks detail or clarity.
Incorrect or missing contrasts; coefficients absent or mathematically incorrect.


3. Meat Cooking Experiment
All pairwise comparisons and interpretations are correct and well-presented with visualizations and context.
Most pairwise comparisons correct, with minor errors in calculations or interpretations.
Comparisons incomplete or partially correct. Visualizations or interpretations are unclear.
Incorrect or missing pairwise comparisons, no visualizations, or failure to interpret findings.


4. Reaction Time Experiment
Accurate contrasts with coefficients, clear plots, correct hypothesis testing, and well-justified confidence intervals.
Correct contrasts and coefficients, minor issues with plots or hypothesis testing, intervals partially correct.
Partial contrasts or coefficients; plots unclear, hypothesis testing or intervals incomplete.
Contrasts missing or incorrect, no plots, hypothesis testing or intervals omitted or inaccurate.




Grading Allocation
Each question is worth 25 points, distributed as follows:

Completeness (10 points): Address all aspects of the question.
Accuracy (10 points): Provide correct methods, calculations, and R code.
Clarity (5 points): Present results in a clear, logical, and concise manner.

title: Assignment 5: Two-Factor ANOVA
text:
Exercise 6.12: Memory Experiment
The memory experiment investigates the effects of two factors:

Word type: Fruits, nouns, and mixed types.
Type of distraction: No distraction, constant distraction, or changing distraction.

The response variable is the number of words remembered, with variance approximated by \(30p(1-p)\).

Task
Determine the number of subjects required to reject the following hypotheses with a power of 0.9 at \(\alpha = 0.05\):

\(H_A\): The memorization rate is identical for the three word types.
\(H_B\): The distraction types have no effect on memorization.

Assume the minimum difference of interest in memorization rates is 4 words.

title: ðŸ“š Assignments
text:
Instructions

Visit the Assignment Page: Click on the Assignments page to access the assignment list. Then, click on the assignment link you wish to complete.
Download the Assignment Template Quarto File: Download Assignment Template file and Assignment Instruction file. For the template file, right-click on page and select Save As, type the file name as assignmentX_yourlastname.qmd, and save it to your local machine.

Note. Make sure the extension of the file is .qmd and not .txt.

Open in Quarto IDE: Use your preferred Quarto-supported IDE (e.g., RStudio, VS Code).
Complete the Assignment: Follow the instructions provided for each assignment and complete the tasks.

Esnure that you provide your name and the date at the top of the file in the YAML metadata section located at the beginning of the file (e.g., title, author).
You do not need to modify other parts of the YAML metadata.

Render to PDF: Render the quartofile. The default output format is PDF.

RStudio: Click on the Knit button.
VS Code: Use the Quarto extension to render the PDF. Make sure the Quarto extension is installed.

Submit on Canvas: Upload the rendered PDF on Canvas under the corresponding assignment section.

This course introduces key principles of experimental design and analysis of variance (ANOVA) integrated with regression models. Key topics include:

Randomization, replication, and blocking principles

One-way and factorial ANOVA models

Managing unbalanced data and covariates
Advanced designs: Latin square, split-plot, nested, and mixed-effects models

Diagnostics: residual analysis, transformations, and multiple comparisons

title: Planning Experiments
text:
Experimental design forms the foundation of scientific inquiry whenever the goal is to understand how certain controllable inputs (factors) influence outcomes (responses). By carefully planning how to collect data and assigning treatments to experimental units, we can draw valid causal inferences about these relationships. Unlike observational studies, experiments involve actively manipulating factors to reveal their effects while controlling for unwanted variability.
This set of lecture notes provides a comprehensive overview of experimental design concepts and applications. We will address how to define clear objectives, classify sources of variation, choose appropriate experimental designs, apply randomization, incorporate blocking, specify statistical models, and determine appropriate sample sizes. Real-world examples and R code snippets will illustrate key ideas. Additionally, we will integrate exercises, class activities, summaries, challenges, and visual aids to reinforce understanding.

title: Planning Experiments
text:
Experimental design forms the foundation of scientific inquiry whenever the goal is to understand how certain controllable inputs (factors) influence outcomes (responses). By carefully planning how to collect data and assigning treatments to experimental units, we can draw valid causal inferences about these relationships. Unlike observational studies, experiments involve actively manipulating factors to reveal their effects while controlling for unwanted variability.
This set of lecture notes provides a comprehensive overview of experimental design concepts and applications. We will address how to define clear objectives, classify sources of variation, choose appropriate experimental designs, apply randomization, incorporate blocking, specify statistical models, and determine appropriate sample sizes. Real-world examples and R code snippets will illustrate key ideas. Additionally, we will integrate exercises, class activities, summaries, challenges, and visual aids to reinforce understanding.

title: Planning Experiments
text:
Objectives

Understand how to identify and classify sources of variation in an experiment.
Define treatment factors, factor levels, and experimental units.
Explore blocking, nuisance factors, and strategies to manage them.
Grasp the principles of randomization and why it underpins statistical inference.
Examine standard experimental designs (CRD, RBD, Factorial, Latin Square, Split-Plot) and when to use each.
Understand the distinction between fixed and random effects in modeling.
Learn how to plan data collection, run pilot experiments, and determine the number of observations (sample size).
Gain hands-on experience using R code for randomization, exploratory data analysis, and basic ANOVA.


Readings

Dean et al. (2017, Ch. 3)

title: Planning Experiments
text:
Steps in Planning an Experiment
It is very tempting to jump into data collection without a clear plan. However, a well-thought-out experimental design is crucial for obtaining valid and interpretable results. Here is a checklist of steps to guide you through the planning process:

1. Define the Objectives of the Experiment

Clearly state the goals (e.g., comparing treatments, optimizing factors, studying interactions).
Write objectives as specific questions or hypotheses to guide the design.



2. Identify All Sources of Variation

Treatment Factors and Their Levels

Factors actively manipulated (e.g., temperature, dosage) and their specific levels.
Example: Dosage levels: 10 mg, 20 mg, 30 mg.

Experimental Units

Smallest division of material receiving a treatment independently.
Example: Individual plants in a field trial.

Blocking Factors, Noise Factors, and Covariates

Blocking: Group similar units (e.g., day of testing).
Noise: Uncontrollable variability (e.g., weather conditions).
Covariates: Measureable properties (e.g., baseline performance).





3. Choose a Rule for Assigning Experimental Units to Treatments

Select randomization techniques:

Completely Randomized Design (CRD).
Randomized Block Design (RBD).
Split-Plot Design.




4. Specify the Measurements, Procedure, and Anticipated Difficulties

Measurements

Specify precision, units, and frequency of measurement.
Example: Growth in cm, tensile strength in MPa.

Procedure

Step-by-step instructions for consistent data collection.

Anticipated Difficulties

Identify challenges (e.g., equipment failure) and mitigation strategies.





5. Run a Pilot Experiment

Test feasibility, validate instruments, and refine factor levels or treatment combinations.



6. Specify the Statistical Model

Example for one-way ANOVA: \[
Y_{ij} = \mu + \tau_i + \varepsilon_{ij},
\]

where:

\(Y_{ij}\): Observed response.
\(\mu\): Overall mean.
\(\tau_i\): Treatment effect.
\(\varepsilon_{ij}\): Random error term.




7. Outline the Analysis

Plan descriptive and inferential methods (e.g., ANOVA, regression).
Include diagnostic checks for model assumptions.



8. Calculate Sample Size

Perform power analysis based on variability estimates and desired precision.



9. Review and Revise

Revisit and refine all decisions based on pilot results and practical constraints.

title: Planning Experiments
section: Identifying Experiment Objectives and Variation Sources
text:
Identifying Experiment Objectives and Variation Sources

Setting Objectives
Every experiment must start with a clear research objective. Ask: What do we hope to learn or achieve? Objectives may include:

Determining which manufacturing process leads to the highest product quality.
Comparing new teaching methods for improved student performance.
Finding the optimal settings of machine parameters to reduce defects.

Without well-defined objectives, the experiment risks being unfocused, making the results difficult to interpret.


Variation Sources
Variation in responses can arise from multiple sources:

Major Variation (Treatment Effects): Due to the factors of interest (e.g., different fertilizers or drug dosages).
Nuisance Factors (noise): Variables that influence the response but are not of primary interest (e.g., room temperature, operator skill). Some nuisance factors can be controlled or incorporated as blocking factors, while others must be accepted as noise.

By identifying and classifying sources of variation, we can decide which factors to manipulate as treatments, which to fix or control, and which to block or treat as covariates.


Example






FigureÂ 2: Variation Sources in an Experiment



Consider an agricultural experiment testing different fertilizer types (A, B, C). The main factors are the fertilizer types. Soil heterogeneity could be a nuisance factor. If the field has varying soil quality, it might mask the fertilizer effect. Recognizing this early allows us to incorporate blocking or other strategies to handle this nuisance variation.


Activity (Work Out Experiment): Think-Pair-Share

Think: Imagine you are testing two workout plans (high-intensity vs.Â moderate-intensity) to improve muscle strength.
Pair: Discuss with a partner what the main objective is and what factors could cause unwanted variation (e.g., baseline fitness level, diet).
Share: Volunteer pairs share their classification of factors and whether they could be controlled or blocked.



Challenges and Common Mistakes

Starting without a clear objective can lead to inconclusive results.
Confusing major variation with nuisance variation can misdirect the design.



Exercises

Why must objectives be clear before starting an experiment?
Given three fertilizer types and two soil conditions, identify which factors should be considered treatments and which might be nuisance factors.
Explain how failing to control a nuisance factor increases the variance of treatment effect estimates.

Key Takeaways:

Well-defined objectives shape the experiment.
Classifying factors into treatment and nuisance categories enhances design efficiency.

title: Planning Experiments
text:
Treatment Factors and Levels

Defining Treatment Factors
A treatment factor is any variable deliberately manipulated by the experimenter to study its effect on the response.
Example: In a detergent study, water temperature and detergent concentration are treatment factors.


Factor Levels
Factor levels are the specific settings or categories of a factor. For instance, twist levels in a cotton-spinning experiment might be 1.63, 1.69, 1.78, and 1.90 turns per inch. Chosen based on subject matter knowledge, factor levels must be realistic and relevant.


Activity (Baking Experiment): Design Your Own Factorial Experiment
Individually pick a factor (e.g., cooking time) and propose three levels. Pair up with another student who has chosen a different factor (e.g., oven temperature), and combine them into a factorial design. Discuss the complexity and the number of total treatment combinations.


Challenges and Common Mistakes

Choosing impractical or irrelevant factor levels can undermine the experimentâ€™s usefulness.
Too many factor levels complicate analysis without necessarily adding insight.



Exercises

What criteria guide the selection of factor levels?
For a factor with 4 levels and another with 3 levels, determine how many treatment combinations exist.
Explain how replicates per factor level (with total resources fixed) decreases the variance of treatment effect estimates.

Key Takeaways: - Treatments factors are deliberately manipulated variables. - Factor levels must be meaningful, informed by real-world considerations or pilot data.

title: Planning Experiments
section: Experimental Units, Blocking, and Nuisance Factors
text:
Experimental Units, Blocking, and Nuisance Factors

Experimental Units
The experimental unit is the smallest entity to which treatments are independently assigned. This concept is crucial for valid statistical inference.


Examples of Experimental Units

Plants in a field trial if each plant gets a different fertilizer.
Engine test benches if each engine is run under a unique setup.
Students in a classroom if each student receives a different teaching method.
Patients in a clinical trial if each patient gets a different drug.



Blocking Factors
When a known nuisance factor could confound results, use blocking. Blocking forms groups of similar experimental units, each block receiving all treatments. This controls for block-to-block variation, increasing precision.
Equation (Block Design):
\[
Y_{ij} = \mu + \tau_i + \beta_j + \varepsilon_{ij}
\] {#eq:block-design}
Here, \(\tau_i\) is the treatment effect and \(\beta_j\) the block effect.


Noise Factors and Covariates

Noise Factors: Uncontrollable variations like daily temperature fluctuations.
Covariates: Measured continuous variables (e.g., initial weight) that help explain variation when included in the model.



Factor Classification Flowchart






flowchart TD
    A[All Factors]
    B[Interested in studying the effect?]
    C[Treatment Factors]
    D[Nuisance Factors]
    E[Can we group by factor levels?]
    F[Block Factor]
    G[Noise/Uncontrolled Factor]

    A --> B
    B -->|Yes| C
    B -->|No| D
    D --> E
    E -->|Yes| F
    E -->|No| G




FigureÂ 3: Factor Classification Flowchart







Activity: Blocking Brainstorm
Consider a baking experiment where ovens differ in temperature calibration. Could ovens form blocks? Discuss how blocking might improve detection of differences in recipes.


Challenges and Common Mistakes

Confusing the experimental unit with observational units leads to incorrect analysis.
Ignoring a known source of variation that could be blocked may inflate residual error.



Exercises

Conceptual: Differentiate between experimental and observational units.
Numerical: If you have 4 treatments and 6 blocks (each block gets all 4 treatments), how many total experimental units are there?
Proof/Derivation: Show that including a block factor in the model reduces the residual variance compared to an unblocked design.

Key Takeaways:

Correctly identifying experimental units is essential.
Blocking controls known nuisance factors, improving the experimentâ€™s power to detect treatment effects.

title: Planning Experiments
text:
Principles of Randomization

Randomization Concept
Randomization ensures that each experimental unit has an equal chance of receiving any treatment. This prevents systematic bias and justifies the assumptions underlying standard statistical tests.
Example: Use a random number generator to assign treatments to plots, ensuring no predetermined pattern.


How to Perform Randomization
Randomization ensures unbiased allocation of experimental units to treatments and reduces the risk of systematic error. Hereâ€™s how you can perform randomization in practice:

Procedure

List Experimental Units:

Create a list of all experimental units (e.g., subjects, plots of land).

List Treatments:

Specify the treatments or factor levels to be assigned.

Determine Design Type:

Choose a design type: Completely Randomized Design (CRD), Randomized Block Design (RBD), or Split-Plot Design.

Generate Random Numbers:

Use random number generation to assign treatments to units.

Assign Treatments:

Pair random numbers with treatments to allocate them to experimental units.

Verify:

Ensure assignments are correct and check for any unintended patterns.





Pseudocode for Randomization

Completely Randomized Design
INPUT: List of experimental units, List of treatments
OUTPUT: Randomized assignments of treatments to units

1. Define N = Total number of experimental units
2. Define T = List of treatments
3. Repeat T to match the number of experimental units if unbalanced
4. Shuffle the list of treatments randomly
5. Assign shuffled treatments to the experimental units
6. Return randomized assignments


Randomized Block Design
INPUT: List of blocks, List of treatments
OUTPUT: Randomized assignments within each block

1. For each block in blocks:
    a. Shuffle the list of treatments randomly
    b. Assign shuffled treatments to experimental units in the block
2. Combine all block-level assignments
3. Return randomized assignments



R Implementation: Randomization Examples

1. Completely Randomized Design



N <- 12 # Number of experimental units, Step 1
# Define experimental units and treatments
experimental_units <- 1:N ## 10 experimental units
treatments <- c("A", "B", "C") ## 3 treatments, Step 2

# Repeat treatments to match the number of units. The code covers both balanced and unbalanced designs.
treatments <- rep(treatments, length.out = N)  ## Step 3

# For a balanced design, we can also use:
# treatments <- rep(treatments, each = N/length(treatments))

# Shuffle (randomize) treatments randomly to assign to units, Step 4
set.seed(123) ## For reproducibility
randomized_treatments <- sample(treatments)

# Create a data frame with randomized assignments
randomization_crd <- data.frame(Unit = experimental_units, Treatment = randomized_treatments)  ## Step 5
print(randomization_crd)

   Unit Treatment
1     1         C
2     2         C
3     3         A
4     4         B
5     5         C
6     6         B
7     7         B
8     8         A
9     9         C
10   10         B
11   11         A
12   12         A



TableÂ 1: Randomized Assignments in CRD





2. Randomized Block Design



# Define blocks and treatments
blocks <- 1:4 # 4 blocks
treatments <- c("A", "B", "C") # 3 treatments

# Create a data frame to store results
randomization_rbd <- data.frame(Block = integer(), Unit = integer(), Treatment = character())

# Randomize within each block
set.seed(123)
for (block in blocks) {
    # Randomize treatments
    randomized_treatments <- sample(treatments)

    # Assign treatments to units within the block
    block_data <- data.frame(
        Block = block,
        Unit = seq_len(length(treatments)),
        Treatment = randomized_treatments
    )
    randomization_rbd <- rbind(randomization_rbd, block_data)
}

print(randomization_rbd)

   Block Unit Treatment
1      1    1         C
2      1    2         A
3      1    3         B
4      2    1         B
5      2    2         A
6      2    3         C
7      3    1         B
8      3    2         C
9      3    3         A
10     4    1         A
11     4    2         B
12     4    3         C



TableÂ 2: Randomized Assignments in RBD






Explanation in R

rep(): Repeats the treatment list to match the total number of experimental units.
sample(): Randomizes the order of the treatments.
set.seed(): Ensures reproducibility of the randomization process.
for loop (RBD): Iterates through blocks, randomizing treatments for each.

These R scripts provide easy-to-follow approaches to randomization, ensuring balanced and unbiased treatment assignment. Let me know if youâ€™d like further assistance with advanced designs!



See the help page for rep() in the Appendix for more details.
See the help page for sample() in the Appendix for more details.



R Example: Simple Random Assignment

set.seed(123)
treatments <- rep(c("A", "B", "C"), each = 4)
assignments <- sample(treatments)
assignments

 [1] "A" "C" "C" "A" "B" "C" "B" "A" "C" "B" "A" "B"




Activity: Randomization Drill
Write down three treatments on slips of paper and randomly assign them to hypothetical units. Discuss how randomization prevents biased placement of favorable treatments.


Challenges and Common Mistakes

Assigning treatments alphabetically or in a patterned manner is not randomization.
Randomization must be deliberate, not haphazard.



Exercises

Why is randomization crucial for valid statistical inference?
With 12 units and 3 treatments, show one method of random assignment.
Under randomization and the null hypothesis, show that the expected difference between treatment means is zero.

Key Takeaways:

Randomization removes systematic bias.
It underpins the validity of ANOVA and other inferential methods.

title: Planning Experiments
text:
Standard Experimental Designs

Completely Randomized Design (CRD)

No blocking, treatments assigned entirely at random.
Suitable when units are homogeneous.



Randomized Block Design (RBD)

Introduce a blocking factor to control known variation.
Each block receives all treatments, improving the precision of treatment comparisons.



Row-Column and Latin Squares

Control for two perpendicular nuisance factors simultaneously.



Factorial Designs

Study multiple factors and their interactions simultaneously.
Efficiently explore how factors work together.



Split-Plot Designs

Useful when some factors are harder to change than others.
Creates a hierarchy of experimental units (e.g., fields as main plots and subplots within fields).



Activity: Design Match-Up
Given three scenarios (no nuisance factor, known nuisance factor, and multiple factors with a complex structure), choose the appropriate design (CRD, RBD, Factorial, Latin Square).


Challenges and Common Mistakes

Using a CRD when a known nuisance factor should be blocked.
Ignoring interactions in factorial experiments.



Exercises

Conceptual: Under what conditions would you choose a CRD over an RBD?
Numerical: Compute the number of runs in a 2x4 factorial with 3 replicates.
Proof/Derivation: Show how the variance decomposition changes from CRD to RBD, highlighting the block effect.

Key Takeaways:

Different designs address different research needs.
Factorial designs detect interactions, blocking improves precision, and split-plots handle difficult-to-change factors.

title: Planning Experiments
text:
Model Specification and Effect Types

Linear Models and ANOVA
Experiments often use a linear model to relate responses to treatments and blocks:
\[
Y = \mu + \text{treatment effects} + \text{block effects} + \text{error}
\qquad(1)\]
ANOVA decomposes total variation into components attributable to treatments, blocks, and error, enabling inference on treatment effects.


Fixed vs.Â Random Effects

Fixed Effects: Chosen levels of interest; inferences apply only to those tested levels.
Random Effects: Levels are a random sample from a broader population; inferences generalize beyond observed levels.



Activity: Fixed or Random?
Consider an experiment with 3 specific fertilizer brands (likely fixed) vs.Â an experiment using 3 randomly chosen brands from a large market (random). Discuss how interpretation changes.


Challenges and Common Mistakes

Treating random factors as fixed or vice versa leads to incorrect conclusions.
Confusing the meaning of random effects with randomization.



Exercises

Conceptual: Why is it important to distinguish fixed and random effects?
Numerical: In an RBD, show how expected mean squares differ for a random block factor vs.Â a fixed block factor.
Proof/Derivation: Derive the expected mean squares for a two-way ANOVA with one random factor.

Key Takeaways:

Correct model specification ensures valid inference.
Fixed vs.Â random distinction affects interpretation and generalized conclusions.

title: Planning Experiments
section: Planning Data Collection and Pilot Experiments
text:
Planning Data Collection and Pilot Experiments

Measurement and Procedure
Careful data collection planning ensures relevance and quality:

Choose appropriate measurement scales and ensure instruments are calibrated.
Train personnel to reduce measurement errors.



Pilot Experiments
A small-scale pilot run can identify unforeseen difficulties, refine factor levels, and confirm data collection procedures before launching the main study.


Activity: Pilot Study Discussion
Discuss what a pilot experiment might reveal in a crop study (e.g., unexpected soil pests) and how that influences the main experimentâ€™s design.


Challenges and Common Mistakes

Omitting a pilot study can lead to costly mistakes in the main experiment.
Relying on untested procedures risks invalid data collection.



Exercises

Why are pilot experiments beneficial?
If pilot data suggest variance = 4 and you want a margin of error = 1, how many samples per treatment are needed (assuming normality)?
Show how a pilot-based variance estimate informs sample size calculations.

Key Takeaways:

Planning and pilot testing prevent wasted resources.
Well-designed procedures and preliminary runs ensure high-quality, interpretable data.

title: Planning Experiments
text:
Determining the Number of Observations

Sample Size and Power
The number of observations affects the experimentâ€™s ability to detect true effects:

Power: Probability of detecting a true effect if it exists.
Larger sample size generally increases power but also increases cost.

Power calculations balance desired precision, variance estimates, and available resources.


Activity: Sample Size Calculation
Given an estimated variance and a desired effect size, estimate the required sample size. Discuss trade-offs between resource constraints and statistical power.


Challenges and Common Mistakes

Choosing sample size arbitrarily can lead to low power or wasted resources.
Overly large samples may be unnecessary and expensive.



Exercises

Conceptual: Explain why sample size must be justified.
Numerical: Given effect size = 2 (SD=3) and desired power = 0.8, calculate required sample size per group.
Proof/Derivation: Derive a basic formula relating power, effect size, and sample size for a one-way ANOVA.

Key Takeaways:

Adequate sample size ensures meaningful, reliable conclusions.
Power analysis guides optimal resource allocation.

title: Planning Experiments
text:
Practical Example in R

Example: A Simple CRD
Compare three battery types (A, B, C) with 4 replicates each.


R Code



set.seed(123)
treatments <- rep(c("A", "B", "C"), each = 4)
assignments <- sample(treatments)

# Simulate some response data
response <- rnorm(12, mean = 50, sd = 5)

# Fit ANOVA model
model <- aov(response ~ factor(assignments))
summary(model)

                    Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F value Pr(>F)
factor(assignments)  2   14.2    7.08   0.163  0.852
Residuals            9  391.5   43.50               



TableÂ 3: ANOVA Table



Interpret the ANOVA table:

If the p-value for factor(assignments) is small, it suggests a difference among battery types.



Activity: Interpret R Output
Examine the ANOVA table. Identify the F-statistic and p-value, and discuss whether treatments differ.


Challenges and Common Mistakes

Misinterpreting p-values without context.
Ignoring model assumptions such as normality and equal variances.



Exercises

Conceptual: Explain why randomization is essential before running ANOVA.
Numerical: Modify the code for 2 treatments with 5 replicates and interpret results.
Proof/Derivation: Show how the F-statistic relates to the ratio of variances in ANOVA.

Key Takeaways:

R facilitates practical application of design concepts.
Interpreting software output requires understanding design principles and model assumptions.

title: Planning Experiments
text:
Summary of Key Takeaways

Objectives: Clear objectives guide the entire design and analysis.
Factors and Levels: Treatment factors and meaningful factor levels ensure relevance.
Experimental Units and Blocking: Correct identification of units and use of blocking increases precision.
Randomization: Ensures unbiased estimates and valid statistical inference.
Designs (CRD, RBD, Factorial, etc.): Different designs solve different problems; factorial designs explore interactions, blocking controls known variation.
Fixed vs.Â Random Effects: Proper classification determines the scope of inferences.
Planning and Pilots: Thoughtful planning and preliminary trials prevent costly errors.
Sample Size and Power: Adequate sample size ensures detectable effects without wasting resources.
R Implementation: Practical coding examples reinforce theoretical principles.

title: Planning Experiments
text:
Definitions of Key Terms

Objective: The main research question or goal of the experiment.
Nuisance Factor: A variable that affects the response but is not of primary interest.
Treatment Factor: A variable manipulated by the experimenter.
Factor Levels: The specific settings or categories of a factor.
Experimental Unit: The entity to which a treatment is applied independently.
Block Factor: A factor used to group units into homogeneous sets.
Randomization: Assigning treatments randomly to avoid bias.
CRD (Completely Randomized Design): A design without blocking; treatments are assigned randomly.
RBD (Randomized Block Design): A design that uses blocks to control known nuisance factors.
Factorial Design: A design that includes multiple factors simultaneously.
Fixed Effects: Effects of chosen factor levels of specific interest.
Random Effects: Effects of factor levels considered as a random sample from a population.
Pilot Experiment: A small preliminary study to refine methods before the main experiment.
Power: The probability of detecting a true treatment effect.
ANOVA: A statistical method for comparing means across groups.

title: Multiple Comparisons and Contrasts
text:
In many experiments, researchers compare multiple treatments or conditions to understand their effects on a response variable. For example, consider a horticulturalist testing various fertilizers on plant growth or a biologist examining different drugs on patient outcomes. After performing an ANOVA and finding evidence that not all treatment means are equal, the next step is to determine which treatments differ, and by how much.
Multiple Comparison Procedures (MCPs) and contrasts address this challenge:

MCPs control the overall probability of false positives (Type I errors) when making many comparisons.
Contrasts focus on specific, pre-defined linear combinations of treatment means, often reflecting scientific questions.

The combination of MCPs and contrasts ensures valid inferences, mitigating the risk of drawing erroneous conclusions from multiple tests while retaining interpretability and power.



Understand the rationale for performing multiple comparisons after ANOVA.
Explore common MCPs: Fisherâ€™s LSD, Tukeyâ€™s HSD, Bonferroni, and ScheffÃ© methods.
Learn how to construct orthogonal and non-orthogonal contrasts and interpret their results.
Utilize R to perform multiple comparisons and test contrasts on real or simulated data.
Discuss Type I error control, power considerations, and the trade-offs in choosing different procedures.
Develop deeper theoretical insights (in the Appendix) and practice through exercises of medium and challenging difficulty.




To implement MCPs and contrasts in R, we will use the following packages:

pacman::p_load(emmeans, pwr, multcomp, agricolae, lsmeans, car)


emmeans: For computing contrasts and post-hoc tests.
pwr: For power analysis and sample size calculations.
multcomp: For multiple comparison procedures.
agricolae: For conducting multiple comparisons and post-hoc tests.
lsmeans: For computing least-squares means and contrasts.
car: For linear contrasts and hypothesis testing.




Imagine testing four battery types (A, B, C, D) to see which lasts longest. After ANOVA suggests at least one mean differs, you want to pinpoint where differences lie:

Are A and B different?
Is C worse than the average of A and B?
Does D stand apart?

Without controlling for multiple testing, repeated pairwise comparisons inflate the risk of false positives. MCPs handle this by adjusting significance criteria, while contrasts let you test targeted hypotheses, such as comparing the average performance of two treatments against another groupâ€™s mean.



Mail Sorting Analogy: Consider sorting through a large pile of mail (treatment comparisons). Without rules (MCPs), you might mistakenly pick â€œimportantâ€ letters (differences) that are actually junk (Type I errors). MCPs act like filters, reducing the chance you misclassify too many letters as important.
Magnifying Glass for Specific Questions (Contrasts): Instead of looking at all letters at once, a contrast is like using a magnifying glass to focus on a subset of letters (treatment means) to answer a specific question.

title: Multiple Comparisons and Contrasts
text:
