 A vs Avg(B, C)    -2.12 0.621  6  -3.423  0.0141

Results are averaged over the levels of: Block 

The average of \(B\) and \(C\) significantly outperforms \(A\).

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
3.6 Interpretation

ANOVA Results:

Treatments significantly affect plant growth (\(p = 0.002\)).
Blocking controls variability due to fields.

Contrasts:

Fertilizer \(B\) is significantly better than \(A\) (\(t = -8.33, p < 0.001\)).
The average of \(B\) and \(C\) also significantly outperforms \(A\) (\(t = -9.39, p < 0.001\)).

Practical Implication:

Fertilizer \(B\) is the most effective. The contrast analysis provides detailed insights beyond ANOVA.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Summary

RCBD Benefits:

Controls variability from blocks (e.g., fields, classrooms).
Provides more precise estimates of treatment effects.

Contrasts:

Useful for testing specific hypotheses about treatment effects.
Add depth to the ANOVA by allowing targeted comparisons.

R Analysis:

ANOVA identifies significant differences.
Contrasts pinpoint specific treatment relationships.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
R Packages Used

# Load required packages using pacman for convenience.
pacman::p_load(dplyr, ggplot2, tidyr, knitr, readr, here, ggpubr)
theme_set(theme_pubr())

Explanation:

dplyr: data manipulation,
ggplot2: visualizations,
tidyr: data reshaping,
knitr: producing tables,
readr: reading in external data files. # Mathematical Foundations from Chapter 10

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Model without Interaction
\[
Y_{hit} = \mu + \theta_h + \tau_i + \varepsilon_{hit}, \quad \varepsilon_{hit} \sim N(0,\sigma^2)
\]

\(\mu\) is the overall mean.
\(\theta_h\) is the effect of the \(h\)th block.
\(\tau_i\) is the effect of the \(i\)th treatment.
\(\varepsilon_{hit}\) is the random error.
\(Y_{hit}\) is the response for treatment \(i\) in block \(h\) and replicate \(t\).
\(\nu\) is the number of treatments.
\(b\) is the number of blocks.
\(s\) is the number of replicates per treatment per block.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Sums of Squares Computation

Total Sum of Squares:

\[
SS_{\text{Total}} = \sum_{h=1}^{b} \sum_{i=1}^{v} \sum_{t=1}^{s} (Y_{hit} - \bar{Y}_{\cdots})^2
\]

Block Sum of Squares:

\[
SS_{\theta} = vs\sum_{h=1}^{b} (\bar{Y}_{h..} - \bar{Y}_{\cdots})^2
\]

Treatment Sum of Squares:

\[
SS_{Treatment} = bs\sum_{i=1}^{v} (\bar{Y}_{.i.} - \bar{Y}_{\cdots})^2
\]

Error Sum of Squares:

\[
SS_{Error} = SS_{\text{Total}} - SS_{\theta} - SS_{Treatment}
\]

Degrees of Freedom:

Blocks: \(b - 1\)
Treatments: \(v - 1\)
Error: \(bvs - b - v + 1\)
Total: \(bvs - 1\)

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Multiple Comparisons

Contrast Estimation: For any contrast \(\sum c_i \tau_i\) (with \(\sum c_i=0\)):

\[
\sum c_i \tau_i \in \left(\sum c_i \bar{Y}_{.i.} \pm w \sqrt{\frac{MS_{Error} \sum c_i^2}{bs}}\right)
\]

\(w\) is the critical value from the chosen method (Bonferroni, ScheffÃ©, Tukey, etc.).
Interpretation: This provides a simultaneous confidence interval for contrasts, ensuring control over the familywise error rate.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Experiment Context

Background: Bananas are stored using two methods:

Counter Storage: Conventional storage on a counter.
Hanging Storage: Using a banana hanging device to slow ripening.

Measured Outcome: The response variable \(y\) represents the percentage of black color on the banana peel (an indicator of ripeness).
Experimental Factors:

Block: Grouping factor (e.g., repeated measures over time or location).
Light: Level of illumination (affecting ripening).
Storage: Storage method (1 = counter, 2 = hanging).

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Data Overview
The banana.txt file has the following columns:

block: Block identifier.
light: Light condition (1 or 2).
storage: Storage method (1 = counter, 2 = hanging).
y: Measured percentage of black color.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
â€œComputationalâ€ Formulae

Blocks are indexed by \(h\) (from 1 to \(v\)).
Treatments indexed by \(i\).
Replicates indexed by \(t\).
\(s\) replicates per block-treatment combination.
Observed response: \(y_{hit}\).
Dot notation represents summation over the omitted index.

Then, the corrected equations are:

Treatment Sum of Squares (Blocks), \(SS_{\theta}\)
\[
SS_{\theta} = v s \sum_{h=1}^{b} \bar{y}_{h..}^2 - b v s \bar{y}_{â€¦}^2
\]


Total Sum of Squares, \(SS_{\text{Total}}\)
\[
SS_{\text{Total}} = \sum_{h=1}^{b}\sum_{i=1}^{v}\sum_{t=1}^{s} y_{hit}^2 - b v s \bar{y}_{â€¦}^2
\]


Treatment Sum of Squares, \(SS_{Treatment}\)
\[
SS_{Treatment} = b s \sum_{i=1}^{v} \bar{y}_{.i.}^2 - b v s \bar{y}_{â€¦}^2
\]


Error Sum of Squares, \(SS_{Error}\)
\[
SS_{Error} = SS_{\text{Total}} - SS_{\theta} - SS_{Treatment}
\]


Definitions of Means Used

Overall mean (\(\bar{y}_{â€¦}\)):

\[
\bar{y}_{â€¦} = \frac{1}{b v s}\sum_{h=1}^{b}\sum_{i=1}^{v}\sum_{t=1}^{s}y_{hit}
\]

Block Means (\(\bar{y}_{h..}\)):

\[
\bar{y}_{h..} = \frac{1}{v s}\sum_{i=1}^{v}\sum_{t=1}^{s}y_{hit}
\]

Treatment Means (\(\bar{y}_{.i.}\)):

\[
\bar{y}_{.i.} = \frac{1}{b s}\sum_{h=1}^{b}\sum_{t=1}^{s}y_{hit}
\]


Error Sum of Squares, \(SS_{Error}\)
Defined as:
\[
SS_{Error} = SS_{\text{Total}} - SS_{\theta} - SS_{Treatment}
\]


Explanation of Terms

\(b\): Number of blocks
\(v\): Number of treatment levels
\(s\): Number of replicates per block-treatment combination
\(y_{hit}\): Observed response at block \(h\), treatment \(i\), and replicate \(t\)



Interpretation

\(SS_{\theta}\): Measures the variability due to differences between blocks.
\(SS_{Treatment}\): Measures the variability due to treatment differences.
\(SS_{Error}\): Captures residual (unexplained) variability after accounting for block and treatment effects.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
3. ANOVA Decision Rule
The F-test for treatments in a complete block design is:
\[
F = \frac{MS_{Treatment}}{MS_{Error}}
\]
where:

\(MS_{Treatment} = \frac{SS_{Treatment}}{v-1}\)
\(MS_{Error} = \frac{SS_{Error}}{bvs - b - v + 1}\)

Reject the null hypothesis \(H_0: \tau_1 = \tau_2\) if:
\[
F > F_{\alpha; \, \nu-1, b\nu s-b-\nu+1}
\]

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Calculating Sums of Squares

# Compute the sums of squares
b <- length(unique(banana_data$block))
v <- length(unique(banana_data$storage))
s <- storage_cell_means$n[1]
n <- nrow(banana_data)

# Overall mean
y_bar <- mean(banana_data$y)

# Block sum of squares
SS_theta <- v *
    s *
    sum((storage_block_means$Mean - y_bar)^2) -
    b * v * s * (mean(storage_block_means$Mean) - y_bar)^2

# Treatment sum of squares
SS_Treatment <- b *
    s *
    sum((storage_margin_means$Mean - y_bar)^2) -
    b * v * s * (mean(storage_margin_means$Mean) - y_bar)^2

# Total sum of squares
SS_Total <- sum(banana_data$y^2) - b * v * s * y_bar^2

# Error sum of squares
SS_Error <- SS_Total - SS_theta - SS_Treatment

# Degrees of freedom
df_theta <- b - 1
df_Treatment <- v - 1
df_Error <- b * v * s - b - v + 1
df_Total <- b * v * s - 1

# MS for Treatment and Error
MS_Treatment <- SS_Treatment / df_Treatment
MS_Error <- SS_Error / df_Error

# F-statistic
F_stat <- MS_Treatment / MS_Error

res_aov_storage_block <- data.frame(
    Component = c("Block", "Treatment", "Error", "Total"),
    SS = c(SS_theta, SS_Treatment, SS_Error, SS_Total),
    DF = c(df_theta, df_Treatment, df_Error, df_Total),
    MS = c(SS_theta / df_theta, MS_Treatment, MS_Error, NA),
    F = c(NA, F_stat, NA, NA),
    p_value = c(
        NA,
        pf(F_stat, df_Treatment, df_Error, lower.tail = FALSE),
        NA,
        NA
    )
)

    knitr::kable(
        caption = "ANOVA Components for Banana Experiment"

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Derivation of Treatment Contrast Variance
For a contrast \(L = \sum c_i \tau_i\), the estimated contrast is:
\[
\hat{L} = \sum c_i \bar{Y}_{.i.}
\]
with variance given by:
\[
\text{Var}(\hat{L}) = \sigma^2 \sum \frac{c_i^2}{bs}
\]
Thus, a \(100(1-\alpha)\%\) confidence interval for \(L\) is:
\[
\hat{L} \pm w \sqrt{MS_{Error} \sum \frac{c_i^2}{bs}}
\]
where \(w\) is the critical value from the chosen method:

Tukeyâ€™s method: \(w_T = q_{\alpha;\, \nu, bvs-b-v+1}/ \sqrt{2}\)
ScheffÃ©â€™s method: \(w_S = \sqrt{(\nu-1) F_{\alpha; \,\nu-1, bvs-b-v+1}}\)
Bonferroniâ€™s method: \(w_B = t_{\alpha/2m;\, bvs-b-v+1}\), where \(m\) is the number of contrasts.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Model Overview
For experiments with replicated treatments within blocks, the model extends to include block Ã— treatment interaction:
\[
Y_{hit} = \mu + \theta_h + \tau_i + (\theta \tau)_{hi} + \epsilon_{hit}
\]
Where:

\(Y_{hit}\): Response for treatment \(i\) in block \(h\) on replicate \(t\).
\(\mu\): Overall mean.
\(\theta_h\): Effect of block \(h\).
\(\tau_i\): Effect of treatment \(i\).
\((\theta \tau)_{hi}\): Interaction effect between block \(h\) and treatment \(i\).
\(\epsilon_{hit}\): Random error, assumed \(N(0,\sigma^2)\).

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Component Explanation

1. Overall Mean and Block Effects

Overall Mean \(\mu\): The grand average of all observations.
Block Effect \(\theta_h\): Adjusts for systematic differences among blocks (e.g., different environmental conditions).



2. Treatment Effect and Interaction

Treatment Effect \(\tau_i\): The deviation of treatment \(i\)â€™s mean from \(\mu\).
Interaction \((\theta \tau)_{hi}\): Captures how treatment \(i\)â€™s effect varies in block \(h\). Example: A storage method might perform differently in Block 1 than in Block 2 due to unobserved factors.



3. Random Error \(\epsilon_{hit}\)

Accounts for unexplained variation.
Assumed to be independent and normally distributed.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Data Overview
The banana data includes:

block: Block identifier (e.g., location or time).
light: Light condition (1 = low light, 2 = high light).
storage: Storage method (1 = Counter, 2 = Hanging).
y: Percentage of black color on banana peel (measure of ripeness).

We will focus on â€œstorageâ€ as the treatment and â€œblockâ€ as the blocking factor, and illustrate the block-by-treatment interaction.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Step 1. Compute Means

Overall Mean:

\[
\bar{Y}_{â€¦} = \frac{1}{n}\sum y
\]

Treatment (Storage) Mean:

\[
\bar{Y}_{.i.} = \frac{1}{n_i}\sum_{\text{storage}=i} y
\]

Block Mean:

\[
\bar{Y}_{h..} = \frac{1}{n_h}\sum_{\text{block}=h} y
\]

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Step 2. Sums of Squares

Total Sum of Squares:

\[
SS_{\text{Total}} = \sum (y - \bar{Y}_{â€¦})^2
\]

Block Sum of Squares:

\[
SS_{\theta} = vs\sum_{h} (\bar{Y}_{h..} - \bar{Y}_{â€¦})^2
\]

Treatment Sum of Squares:

\[
SS_{Treatment} = bs\sum_{i} (\bar{Y}_{.i.} - \bar{Y}_{â€¦})^2
\]

Interaction Sum of Squares:

\[
SS_{\theta\tau} = \sum_{h}\sum_{i} \left(\bar{Y}_{hi.} - \bar{Y}_{h..} - \bar{Y}_{.i.} + \bar{Y}_{â€¦}\right)^2
\]

Error Sum of Squares:

\[
SS_{Error} = SS_{\text{Total}} - SS_{\theta} - SS_{Treatment} - SS_{\theta\tau}
\]
Here, \(b\) is the number of blocks, \(v\) the number of treatments, and \(s\) the number of replicates per treatment per block.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
section: Fitting the General Complete Block Design Model
text:
Fitting the General Complete Block Design Model
We now fit the model that includes the block, treatment (storage), and their interaction.



# including block:storage interaction.
fit_banana_int <- aov(y ~ block * storage, data = banana_data)
summary(fit_banana_int)

block          2   1256   627.9   3.409 0.0425 *
storage        1    154   154.1   0.836 0.3656

Residuals     42   7736   184.2                 
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1



TableÂ 13: Treatment Means by Storage Method



Interpretation:

Block: Variation among blocks.
Storage (Treatment): Main effect of storage method.
Block:Storage: Interaction term, indicating if storage method performance varies by block.
Residuals: Unexplained variability.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Detailed Interpretation of ANOVA Results

F-statistics: Compare the mean squares (MS) for storage and the interaction against the error MS.
p-values: Determine if storage method and/or the interaction is statistically significant.

If the interaction term is significant, it suggests that the effect of the storage method on ripening (percentage black) differs among blocks.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
section: Deriving a Contrast for Storage Methods
text:
Deriving a Contrast for Storage Methods
Assume we want to compare:
\[
L = \tau_1 - \tau_2
\]
with:
\[
\hat{L} = \bar{Y}_{.1.} - \bar{Y}_{.2.}
\]
The estimated variance of \(\hat{L}\) is:
\[
\text{Var}(\hat{L}) = \sigma^2 \left(\frac{1}{bs} + \frac{1}{bs}\right) = \frac{2\sigma^2}{bs}
\]
Thus, a 95% confidence interval for \(L\) is given by:
\[
\hat{L} \pm t_{df,0.025} \sqrt{\frac{2MS_{Error} }{bs}}
\]
where \(MS_{Error}\) is the error mean square from the ANOVA.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
section: R Code for Contrast and Confidence Interval
text:
R Code for Contrast and Confidence Interval



storage_means <- banana_data |>
    group_by(storage) |>
    summarize(Mean = mean(y))

# Extract the error mean square from the ANOVA table
mse <- anova_banana["Residuals", "Mean Sq"]
# Define number of blocks (b) and replicates per cell (s)
b <- length(unique(banana_data$block))
# For simplicity, assume equal replication: s = n / (b * number_of_treatments)
s <- nrow(banana_data) / (b * 2)

# Compute contrast: difference between storage method 1 and 2
L_hat <- storage_means$Mean[1] - storage_means$Mean[2]
# Degrees of freedom for error from ANOVA table
df_error <- anova_banana["Residuals", "Df"]

# Calculate standard error of the contrast
SE_L <- sqrt(2 * mse / (b * s))

# Critical t-value for 95% CI
t_val <- qt(0.975, df = df_error)

# Confidence Interval for the contrast
CI_lower <- L_hat - t_val * SE_L
CI_upper <- L_hat + t_val * SE_L

cat("Contrast (Storage 1 - Storage 2):", L_hat, "\n")

Contrast (Storage 1 - Storage 2): 3.583333 

cat("95% CI: [", CI_lower, ",", CI_upper, "]\n")

95% CI: [ -4.342467 , 11.50913 ]

# Conform with emmeans package

library(emmeans)
emm <- emmeans(fit_banana, ~storage)
contrast(emm, list("1 - 2" = c(1, -1)))

 contrast estimate   SE df t.ratio p.value
 1 - 2        3.58 3.93 44   0.911  0.3672

Results are averaged over the levels of: block 



TableÂ 14: Treatment Means by Storage Method



Interpretation: This code computes the difference in means between storage methods, its standard error, and a 95% confidence interval using the error variance from the ANOVA table.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Summary and Takeaways

We extended the basic block design model to include a block-by-treatment interaction.
Detailed computations:

Means, Sums of Squares, and Variance Components are essential for constructing the ANOVA.
Contrast and Confidence Intervals: Demonstrated using storage method differences.

The R code illustrates how to read data, fit the model, and interpret the outputs.
Always check the significance of the interaction to decide whether to interpret the main effects directly.

title: ANCOVA and Causal Inference Using the Potential Outcomes Framework
text:
By the end of this lesson, you will be able to:

Define potential outcomes and causal effects: Understand what each outcome represents and why we cannot observe both for a single unit.
Describe the assumptions required for causal inference: Learn the key conditions needed to draw causal conclusions.
Connect potential outcomes to classical methods: See how ANOVA and ANCOVA relate to causal inference.
Interpret numerical examples: Use examples to visualize and calculate treatment effects.
Practice with problems: Build your skills through structured practice.

title: ANCOVA and Causal Inference Using the Potential Outcomes Framework
text:
By the end of this lesson, you will be able to:

Define potential outcomes and causal effects: Understand what each outcome represents and why we cannot observe both for a single unit.
Describe the assumptions required for causal inference: Learn the key conditions needed to draw causal conclusions.
Connect potential outcomes to classical methods: See how ANOVA and ANCOVA relate to causal inference.
Interpret numerical examples: Use examples to visualize and calculate treatment effects.
Practice with problems: Build your skills through structured practice.

title: ANCOVA and Causal Inference Using the Potential Outcomes Framework
text:
ðŸ§  The Big Question
Imagine you want to know if a treatmentâ€”whether itâ€™s a tutoring session, a new medication, or a teaching methodâ€”leads to better outcomes. The key challenge is: How do we know if the treatment actually causes the improvement?

title: ANCOVA and Causal Inference Using the Potential Outcomes Framework
text:
ðŸ” Understanding Potential Outcomes
Every unit (like a student, patient, or plant) in our study has two potential outcomes:

\(Y_i(1)\): The outcome if unit i receives the treatment.
\(Y_i(0)\): The outcome if unit i does not receive the treatment (control condition).

Key Intuition: Each unit has a â€œwhat ifâ€ scenario for both conditions. However, in reality, we only observe one of these scenariosâ€”the one that actually happens. The unobserved outcome is called the counterfactual.

Why is this tricky? If we can only see one outcome per unit, comparing outcomes directly might mix up the treatment effect with differences inherent to the units.

title: ANCOVA and Causal Inference Using the Potential Outcomes Framework
text:
ðŸ§¾ Scaffolding Example: Two Students
Consider two students:

Alice: If she receives a special tutoring program, her test score might be 90. Without tutoring, it might be 80.
Ben: If he receives tutoring, his score might be 85; without it, perhaps it remains 85.

We can only observe one outcome per student. For instance, if Alice is tutored, we see her score as 90. We never get to see what her score would have been without tutoring. This missing information (80 for Alice) is our counterfactual.

ðŸ§® Calculating Causal Effects

Individual Causal Effect:

\[
\text{Effect}_i = Y_i(1) - Y_i(0)
\]
For Alice, the causal effect would be \(90 - 80 = 10\).

Average Treatment Effect (ATE): This is the average of the individual effects over all units:

\[
\text{ATE} = \mathbb{E}[Y(1) - Y(0)]
\]
It tells us the overall expected improvement if everyone were to receive the treatment.

Average Treatment on the Treated (ATT): Sometimes we care only about those who actually received the treatment:

\[
\text{ATT} = \mathbb{E}[Y(1) - Y(0) \mid T = 1]
\]
This average is calculated only for the treated group.

Note: Since we canâ€™t observe both outcomes for a single unit, we use various strategies (like randomization) to estimate these averages.

title: ANCOVA and Causal Inference Using the Potential Outcomes Framework
text:
ðŸ” Mathematical Justification
With random assignment:
\[
\mathbb{E}[Y(1) \mid T = 1] = \mathbb{E}[Y(1)]
\]
\[
\mathbb{E}[Y(0) \mid T = 0] = \mathbb{E}[Y(0)]
\]
Thus, the Average Treatment Effect (ATE) can be estimated as:
\[
\text{ATE} \approx \mathbb{E}[Y \mid T = 1] - \mathbb{E}[Y \mid T = 0]
\]

title: ANCOVA and Causal Inference Using the Potential Outcomes Framework
text:
ðŸ§¾ Detailed Numerical Example
Imagine we have two groups:

Group A (Control): Scores = [70, 75, 80]
Group B (Treatment): Scores = [85, 88, 90]

Step 1: Compute the group means: - Mean for Group A:
\[
\text{Mean A} = \frac{70 + 75 + 80}{3} = 75
\]

Mean for Group B:

\[
\text{Mean B} = \frac{85 + 88 + 90}{3} \approx 87.67
\]
Step 2: Estimate the ATE:
\[
\text{Estimated ATE} = 87.67 - 75 \approx 12.67
\]
This means that, on average, the treatment is associated with a score increase of about 12.67 points.

title: ANCOVA and Causal Inference Using the Potential Outcomes Framework
text:
âœ… Causal Use of ANOVA
ANOVA Model:
\[
Y_{ij} = \mu + \tau_j + \epsilon_{ij}
\]
When groups are formed via random assignment, any observed difference in means can be attributed to the treatment effect. Specifically, for group \(j\):
\[
\tau_j = \mathbb{E}[Y \mid T = j] - \mu
\]

title: ANCOVA and Causal Inference Using the Potential Outcomes Framework
text:
ðŸ§¾ Worked Example
Consider the two groups from our numerical example:

Group A (Control): Mean = 75
Group B (Treatment): Mean = 87.67

The treatment effect for Group B can be seen as:
\[
\tau_B = 87.67 - 75 \approx 12.67
\]
This confirms that the treatment (Group B) is associated with a 12.67 point increase in the outcome compared to the overall mean.

title: ANCOVA and Causal Inference Using the Potential Outcomes Framework
text:
ðŸ”Ž What is ANCOVA?
ANCOVA (Analysis of Covariance) extends ANOVA by adjusting for one or more covariatesâ€”variables that might influence the outcome. This method helps us control for differences that existed before the treatment, allowing a clearer picture of the treatmentâ€™s effect.
Basic ANCOVA Model:
\[
Y_i = \alpha + \tau T_i + \beta X_i + \epsilon_i
\]
Where:

\(T_i\) is a binary indicator for treatment (1 if treated, 0 if control).
\(X_i\) is a covariate, such as a pre-test score.
\(\tau\) represents the treatment effect after controlling for the covariate.
\(\beta\) measures how the covariate influences the outcome.

title: ANCOVA and Causal Inference Using the Potential Outcomes Framework
text:
Without Adjustment

The treated groupâ€™s mean post-test might appear higher simply because they had higher pre-test scores.
Treated group post-test mean: \((90 + 95)/2 = 92.5\)
Control group post-test mean: \((75 + 70)/2 = 72.5\)
Difference = 20

Why Adjust? The difference of 20 could be inflated because the treated group was already more prepared (higher pre-tests). ANCOVA helps us adjust the post-test scores by accounting for pre-test differences, thereby estimating the treatment effect (\(\tau\)) more accurately.
How It Works: - The model â€œremovesâ€ the part of the outcome variation that is explained by the covariate (the pre-test score). - What remains is a cleaner comparison between the treatment and control groups.

title: ANCOVA and Causal Inference Using the Potential Outcomes Framework
section: âœ… 1. SUTVA (Stable Unit Treatment Value Assumption)
text:
âœ… 1. SUTVA (Stable Unit Treatment Value Assumption)

Meaning: Each unitâ€™s potential outcomes are unaffected by the treatments given to other units, and the treatment itself is clearly defined.
Intuition: Imagine a classroom: if one studentâ€™s treatment (like receiving extra tutoring) somehow affects another studentâ€™s performance, then the assumption is violated.

title: ANCOVA and Causal Inference Using the Potential Outcomes Framework
text:
âœ… 2. Ignorability (or Unconfoundedness)

Meaning: Given the covariates (and with randomization, naturally), the treatment assignment is independent of the potential outcomes.
Intuition: This is like saying that there are no hidden factors that both affect who gets the treatment and the outcomes. If we control for observed factors, the treatment assignment should be â€œas good as random.â€

title: ANCOVA and Causal Inference Using the Potential Outcomes Framework
text:
âœ… 3. Overlap (Common Support)

Meaning: Every unit has a positive probability of receiving either the treatment or the control.
Intuition: If some individuals are never eligible for treatment, then comparing them to those who can be treated can lead to biased estimates.

title: ANCOVA and Causal Inference Using the Potential Outcomes Framework
text:
Final Thoughts and Practice

Why All This Matters: Understanding these concepts helps you rigorously think about what it means to say one thing causes another. Whether youâ€™re running an experiment or analyzing observational data, these ideas guide your interpretation.
Scaffolding Your Learning:

Start Simple: Work through individual examples like the ones above.
Build Complexity: Gradually introduce additional variables (like covariates in ANCOVA) and consider their impact.
Practice Problems: Apply these concepts in simulated data scenarios to see how the methods work in practice.

\[

\]


Treated Group

1 \cdot (87 - 86.5) &= 1 \cdot (+0.5) \\

\]

title: Row and Column Designs
text:
In the realm of experimental design, Rowâ€“Column Designs serve as an extension of traditional blocking techniques by incorporating two independent blocking factors: rows and columns. These designs are instrumental in controlling multiple sources of variability, thereby enhancing the precision and efficiency of treatment comparisons. By organizing experimental units into a matrix of rows and columns, Rowâ€“Column Designs mitigate the influence of two distinct nuisance factors, enabling clearer insights into the effects of the primary treatments under investigation.
Intuitive Example: Imagine conducting an agricultural experiment to test different crop varieties. The field is naturally divided into rows and columns due to varying sunlight and soil moisture gradients. By applying each variety once per row and column, you control for these environmental gradients, ensuring that differences in crop performance are attributable to the varieties themselves rather than external factors.
This lecture delves into the structure, analysis, and practical applications of Rowâ€“Column Designs, with a focus on specific examples like Latin Square Designs and Youden Designs. We will explore theoretical foundations, implement analyses using R, and engage with advanced topics to provide a comprehensive understanding suitable for graduate-level studies.



Understand the principles and utility of Rowâ€“Column Designs.
Explore specific examples such as Latin Square and Youden Designs.
Analyze data using ANOVA tailored for Rowâ€“Column Designs.
Extend designs to accommodate factorial experiments.
Implement Rowâ€“Column Designs in R with step-by-step guidance.
Reinforce concepts through exercises covering numerical examples, conceptual understanding, and mathematical proofs.
Explore advanced mathematical derivations and proofs in the Appendix.

title: Row and Column Designs
text:

title: Row and Column Designs
text:
Rowâ€“Column Design Structure
A Rowâ€“Column Design arranges experimental units in a two-dimensional grid comprising rows and columns. Each cell in the grid represents an experimental unit to which a treatment is applied. This design incorporates two independent blocking factors:

Rows: Control for variability along the horizontal dimension.
Columns: Control for variability along the vertical dimension.

Diagram of a 3x3 Latin Square:




Column 1
Column 2
Column 3

A
B
C


Row 2
B
C
A


Row 3

title: Row and Column Designs
text:
Blocking Factors

Row Blocks: Address systematic variability across rows, such as gradients in environmental conditions.
Column Blocks: Address systematic variability across columns, such as variations in soil composition.

Intuitive Explanation: Consider a greenhouse experiment where temperature gradients run horizontally and light intensity gradients run vertically. By arranging treatments in a rowâ€“column grid, you control for these two sources of environmental variability, ensuring that treatment effects are not confounded with spatial gradients.

title: Row and Column Designs
text:
Advantages

Reduced Variability: By controlling two sources of variability, Rowâ€“Column Designs offer greater precision in estimating treatment effects.
Efficiency: These designs make efficient use of experimental units, especially in small-scale experiments with inherent multidimensional variability.
Flexibility: They can be extended to accommodate factorial experiments and multiple interactions.
Enhanced Analytical Power: ANOVA tailored for Rowâ€“Column Designs can effectively isolate treatment effects from block effects.

Reference: Montgomery, D. C., Peck, E. A., & Vining, G. G. (2020). Introduction to Linear Regression Analysis. Wiley.

title: Row and Column Designs
text:
Definition
A Latin Square Design is a specialized type of Rowâ€“Column Design where:

Each treatment appears exactly once in each row.
Each treatment appears exactly once in each column.

This ensures that the design is balanced and controls for both row and column effects effectively.

title: Row and Column Designs
text:
Construction

Standard Latin Squares:
For \(v = 3\) treatments, a Latin Square can be constructed as follows:

\[
\begin{array}{|c|c|c|}
   \hline
   A & B & C \\
   \hline
   B & C & A \\
   \hline
   C & A & B \\
   \hline
   \end{array}
\]

Rows and Columns: Each treatment \(A\), \(B\), and \(C\) appears once per row and column.


Randomization:
To prevent systematic bias, randomize the order of treatments within rows and columns. This can be achieved by randomly permuting the treatment labels for rows and columns.

title: Row and Column Designs
text:
Model
For a Rowâ€“Column Design with \(b\) rows, \(c\) columns, and \(v\) treatments, the ANOVA model is defined as:
\[
Y_{hqi} = \mu + \theta_h + \phi_q + \tau_i + \epsilon_{hqi},
\]
where:

\(Y_{hqi}\): Response for treatment \(i\) in row \(h\) and column \(q\).
\(\mu\): Overall mean.
\(\theta_h\): Effect of row \(h\).
\(\phi_q\): Effect of column \(q\).
\(\tau_i\): Effect of treatment \(i\).
\(\epsilon_{hqi} \sim N(0, \sigma^2)\): Random error term.


Key Assumptions

Normality: The residuals (\(\epsilon_{hqi}\)) are normally distributed.
Homogeneity of Variance (Homoscedasticity): The variance of residuals is constant across all treatments, rows, and columns.
Independence: Observations are independent of each other.
No Interaction: There is no interaction between rows and treatments or columns and treatments, i.e., the effects of treatments are consistent across rows and columns.



ANOVA Table










Source of Variation
Degrees of Freedom (DF)
Sum of Squares (SS)
Mean Square (MS)
F-ratio




Rows
\(b - 1\)
\(SS_{\text{Rows}}\)
\(MS_{\text{Rows}} = \frac{SS_{\text{Rows}}}{b - 1}\)
\(F = \frac{MS_{\text{Rows}}}{MS_{\text{Error}}}\)


Columns
\(c - 1\)
\(SS_{\text{Columns}}\)
\(MS_{\text{Columns}} = \frac{SS_{\text{Columns}}}{c - 1}\)
\(F = \frac{MS_{\text{Columns}}}{MS_{\text{Error}}}\)


Treatments adj
\(v - 1\)
\(SS_{\text{Trt adj}}\)
\(MS_{\text{Trt adj}} = \frac{SS_{\text{Trt adj}}}{v - 1}\)
\(F = \frac{MS_{\text{Treatments}}}{MS_{\text{Error}}}\)


Error
\(bc - b - c - v + 2\)
\(SS_{\text{Error}}\)
\(MS_{\text{Error}} = \frac{SS_{\text{Error}}}{bc - b - c - v + 2}\)
-


Total
\(b c - 1\)
\(SS_{\text{Total}}\)

title: Row and Column Designs
text:
Hypothesis Testing

Null Hypothesis (\(H_0\)): All treatment means are equal (\(\tau_i = 0\) for all \(i\)).
Alternative Hypothesis (\(H_A\)): At least one treatment mean differs.

Decision Rule: Reject \(H_0\) if the F-ratio for treatments exceeds the critical value from the F-distribution with degrees of freedom \((v - 1, bc - b - c - v + 2)\) at the chosen significance level (\(\alpha\)).

title: Row and Column Designs
text:
Example Interpretation

Rows and Columns: Assess the significance of row and column effects. Significant row or column effects indicate that these blocking factors explain a substantial portion of the variability in the response.
Treatments: Determine if treatments have a significant impact on the response variable after accounting for row and column effects.
Error: Represents unexplained variability, serving as the denominator for F-ratios.

title: Row and Column Designs
text:
Computational Formula
These formulas typically apply to the Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) for experimental designs involving treatments laid out in a structure with rows and columns, aiming to control for variability from these two sources (e.g., Latin Squares, Youden Squares, Row-Column Designs).

\(b\): Number of rows
\(c\): Number of columns
\(v\): Number of treatments
\(y_{hq}\): Observation in rowÂ \(h\)Â and columnÂ \(q\)
\(t(h,q)\): Treatment applied in cellÂ \((h,q)\)
\(N = bc\): Total number of observations (assuming a complete layout)
\(B_h = \sum_{q=1}^{c} y_{hq}\): Total for rowÂ \(h\)Â (sum ofÂ \(c\)Â observations)
\(C_q = \sum_{h=1}^{b} y_{hq}\): Total for columnÂ \(q\)Â (sum ofÂ \(b\)Â observations)
\(T_i = \sum_{(h,q): t(h,q)=i} y_{hq}\): Total for treatmentÂ \(i\)
\(G = \sum_{h=1}^{b} \sum_{q=1}^{c} y_{hq}\): Grand total (sum ofÂ \(N=bc\)Â observations)
\(r\): Number of replications per treatment (assumed constant in some provided formulas, but could beÂ \(r_i\))
\(n_{h.i}\): Number of times treatmentÂ \(i\)Â appears in rowÂ \(h\)
\(n_{.qi}\): Number of times treatmentÂ \(i\)Â appears in columnÂ \(q\)
\(CF = \frac{G^2}{N} = \frac{G^2}{bc}\): Correction Factor

Note. We have \(r\) replications per treatment in a complete design, but in some cases, \(r_i\) may vary. The formulas provided assume a complete layout with equal replication. ## Unadjusted Row Effect Sum of Squares (\(SS_\theta\))
\[
SS_{Rows} = \frac{1}{c} \sum_{h=1}^{b} B_h^2 - \frac{2 G^2}{bc} + \frac{b G^2}{bc} = \frac{1}{c} \sum_{h=1}^{b} B_h^2 - \frac{G^2}{bc}
\]

title: Row and Column Designs
section: Derivation of Row Effect Sum of Squares
text:
Derivation of Row Effect Sum of Squares
The unadjusted sum of squares for rows measures the variability between row means.

Row meanÂ \(h\):Â \(\bar{y}_{h.} = B_h / c\)
Grand mean:Â \(\bar{y}_{..} = G / N = G / (bc)\)
The sum of squares is the sum of squared deviations from the grand mean, weighted by the number of observations per row:

\[
SS_{Rows} = \sum_{h=1}^{b} \sum_{q=1}^{c} (\bar{y}_{h.} - \bar{y}_{..})^2 = \sum_{h=1}^{b} c (\bar{y}_{h.} - \bar{y}_{..})^2
\]

Substitute the means:

\[
SS_{Rows} = \sum_{h=1}^{b} c \left(\frac{B_h}{c} - \frac{G}{bc}\right)^2 = \sum_{h=1}^{b} c \left[\frac{B_h^2}{c^2} - \frac{2 B_h G}{bc^2} + \frac{G^2}{(bc)^2}\right]
\]

Distribute the sum and simplify:

\[
SS_{Rows} = \sum_{h=1}^{b} \left[\frac{B_h^2}{c} - \frac{2 B_h G}{bc} + \frac{c G^2}{b^2 c^2}\right]
\]
\[
SS_{Rows} = \left(\frac{1}{c} \sum_{h=1}^{b} B_h^2\right) - \frac{2 G}{bc} \left(\sum_{h=1}^{b} B_h\right) + \sum_{h=1}^{b} \frac{G^2}{bc}
\]

SinceÂ \(\sum B_h = G\)Â and the last term sumsÂ \(b\)Â times:

\[
SS_{Rows} = \frac{1}{c} \sum_{h=1}^{b} B_h^2 - \frac{2 G^2}{bc} + \frac{b G^2}{bc} = \frac{1}{c} \sum_{h=1}^{b} B_h^2 - \frac{G^2}{bc}
\]

The formulaâ€™sÂ \(1/c\)Â factor arises naturally because eachÂ \(B_h\)Â is the sum ofÂ \(c\)Â observations. Dividing the squared totalÂ \(B_h^2\)Â byÂ \(c\)Â scales it appropriately for the sum of squares calculation based on means.

title: Row and Column Designs
section: Unadjusted Column Effect Sum of Squares (\(ss_\phi\))
text:
Unadjusted Column Effect Sum of Squares (\(ss_\phi\))
\[
SS_{Cols} = \frac{1}{b} \sum_{q=1}^{c} C_q^2 - \frac{G^2}{bc}
\]

Derivation of Standard Formula:

The derivation is analogous to the Row SS derivation, swapping roles of rows and columns.

Column meanÂ \(q\):Â \(\bar{y}_{.q} = C_q / b\)
Grand mean:Â \(\bar{y}_{..} = G / (bc)\)
Sum of squares:

\[
SS_{Cols} = \sum_{q=1}^{c} \sum_{h=1}^{b} (\bar{y}_{.q} - \bar{y}_{..})^2 = \sum_{q=1}^{c} b (\bar{y}_{.q} - \bar{y}_{..})^2
\]

Following similar algebraic steps as forÂ \(SS_{Rows}\)Â leads to:

\[
SS_{Cols} = \frac{1}{b} \sum_{q=1}^{c} C_q^2 - \frac{G^2}{bc}
\]

Treatment Effect (Adjusted for Rows and Columns)
Adjustment is needed because treatments are generally not orthogonal to rows and columns. We first find adjusted treatment totals (\(Q_i\)) and then use them to calculate the adjusted treatment sum of squares (\(SS_\text{Trt adju}\)).

Adjusted Treatment Totals (\(Q_i\))
\[
Q_i = T_i - \frac{1}{c} \sum_{h=1}^{b} n_{h.i} B_h - \frac{1}{b} \sum_{q=1}^{c} n_{.qi} C_q + \frac{b}{c} r_i G
\]
where

\(T_i\): Total for treatment \(i\)
\(B_h\): Total for row \(h\)
\(C_q\): Total for column \(q\)
\(G\): Grand total
\(h\): Row index
\(q\): Column index
\(n_{h.i}\): Number of times treatment \(i\) appears in row \(h\)
\(n_{.qi}\): Number of times treatment \(i\) appears in column \(q\)

Note. This uses potentially variable replication \(r_i\). If \(r\) is constant, \(r_i\) becomes \(r\). This formula assumes \(r_i\) replications per treatment.

title: Row and Column Designs
text:
Explanation of Standard Formula:

The adjusted total \(Q_i\) is the raw treatment total$ T_i$ corrected for the effects of the specific rows and columns where treatment \(i\) appeared.
The adjustment subtracts the estimated contribution of row means (\(B_h/c\)) and column means (\(C_q/b\)) for the units receiving treatment i and adds back the overall mean effect (\(G/bc\)) scaled by the number of replications (\(r_i\)).
This quantity arises naturally from the normal equations for estimating treatment effects (\(\tau_i\)) in the linear model \(y_{hq(i)} = \mu + \theta_h + \phi_q + \tau_i + \epsilon_{hq(i)}\) after eliminating row and column parameters. The \(Q_i\) form the right-hand side of the reduced normal equations for the treatment effects.

title: Row and Column Designs
section: Adjusted Treatment Sum of Squares (\(SS_\text{Trt adj}\))
text:
Adjusted Treatment Sum of Squares (\(SS_\text{Trt adj}\))
\[
SS_\text{Trt adj} = \sum_{i=1}^{v} Q_i \hat{\tau}_i
\]
where:

\(ss_{Tadj}\): Adjusted treatment sum of squares
\(Q_i\): Adjusted treatment total for treatment \(i\)
\(\hat{\tau}_i\): Estimated treatment effect for treatment \(i\)
\(v\): Number of treatments
\(\hat{\tau}_i\): Estimated treatment effect (solution to the reduced normal equations)

title: Row and Column Designs
text:
Explanation of Standard Formula:

This formula arises directly from the theory of linear models.
The adjusted sum of squares for a factor (here, treatments) can be expressed as the quadratic form \(\hat{\tau}' Q\), where \(\hat{\tau}\) is the vector of estimated treatment effects (solutions to the reduced normal equations \(C \hat{\tau} = Q\)) and \(Q\) is the vector of adjusted totals.
Expanding \(\hat{\tau}' Q\) gives the summation \(\sum Q_i \hat{\tau}_i\).
Alternative computational formulas often exist, especially for balanced designs (e.g., involving \(\sum Q_i^2\)), but this form is theoretically fundamental.

title: Row and Column Designs
text:
Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)
For a Latin Square Design with \(v\) treatments, the ANOVA model includes:
\[
Y_{hqi} = \mu + \theta_h + \phi_q + \tau_i + \epsilon_{hqi},
\]
where:

\(Y_{hqi}\): Response for treatment \(i\) in row \(h\) and column \(q\).
\(\mu\): Overall mean.
\(\theta_h\): Effect of row \(h\).
\(\phi_q\): Effect of column \(q\).
\(\tau_i\): Effect of treatment \(i\).
\(\epsilon_{hqi} \sim N(0, \sigma^2)\): Random error term.

In a classical (fully balanced) Latin Square, the treatment sum of squares is the same whether you view it as â€œadjustedâ€ (after removing row and column effects) or â€œunadjustedâ€ (looking at treatments alone). In other words, they do not differ.

title: Row and Column Designs
text:
Why They Are the Same

Orthogonality
In a Latin Square, the design is constructed so that treatments are orthogonal (statistically independent) to the row and column factors. Orthogonality means that when you estimate the effect of treatments, you are not â€œborrowingâ€ or â€œconfoundingâ€ variation that belongs to the row or column blocks.
Balanced Cells
Each treatment occurs exactly once in every row and once in every column, so there is no overlap in the sum of squares partition:
\[
\text{SSTotal} \;=\; \text{SSRows} \;+\; \text{SSColumns} \;+\; \text{SSTreatments} \;+\; \text{SSError}.
\] Because of this strict balance, the decomposition of sums of squares is clean and unique.
Adjusted = Unadjusted for Orthogonal Designs
When factors are orthogonal, â€œpartialâ€ or â€œadjustedâ€ sum of squares for a given factor (e.g.Â treatments) equals the â€œunadjustedâ€ sum of squares you would get if you calculated it before removing the other factors. No matter the sequence in which you enter factors into the model, the SS for each orthogonal factor is unchanged.

title: Row and Column Designs
text:
When They Might Differ

Missing Data or Unbalanced Layout
If some runs are missing or the design is not balanced, the orthogonality breaks. Then the â€œadjustedâ€ (Type III or partial) sum of squares for treatments can differ from the â€œunadjustedâ€ (Type I or sequential) sum of squares.
Non-orthogonal Blocks/Treatments
If blocking factors and treatments are not arranged in an orthogonal way (as in some incomplete-block or more complex designs), you can again see discrepancies.

In the standard (complete, balanced) Latin Square, however, there is perfect orthogonality among row blocks, column blocks, and treatmentsâ€”so the treatment SS is invariant to whether you consider it â€œadjustedâ€ or â€œunadjusted.â€

title: Row and Column Designs
section: Example ANOVA Table for Latin Square
text:
Example ANOVA Table for Latin Square










Source of Variation
Degrees of Freedom

Rows
\(v - 1\)
\(SS_\text{Rows}\)
\(MS_\text{Rows}\)
\(F = \frac{MS_\text{Rows}}{MS_\text{Error}}\)


Columns
\(v - 1\)
\(SS_\text{Columns}\)
\(MS_\text{Columns}\)

\(v - 1\)
\(SS_\text{Trt Adj}\)
\(MS_\text{Trt adj}\)

\((v-2)(v-1)\)
\(SS_\text{Error}\)

Total
\(v^2 - 1\)
\(SS_\text{Total}\)





Hypothesis Testing:

Null Hypothesis (\(H_0\)): All treatment means are equal (\(\tau_k = 0\) for all \(k\)).
Alternative Hypothesis (\(H_A\)): At least one treatment mean differs.

Decision Rule: Reject \(H_0\) if the F-ratio for treatments exceeds the critical value from the F-distribution with degrees of freedom \((v - 1, (v-2)(v-1))\) at the chosen significance level (\(\alpha\)).

title: Row and Column Designs
text:
Example in R

# Simulated Data for Latin Square Design
set.seed(123)
data <- data.frame(
    row = factor(rep(1:3, each = 3)),
    column = factor(rep(1:3, times = 3)),
    treatment = factor(c("A", "B", "C", "B", "C", "A", "C", "A", "B")),
    response = c(10.2, 15.3, 20.1, 14.8, 19.5, 9.7, 19.0, 9.9, 14.2)
)

# Fit ANOVA Model
fit <- lm(response ~ row + column + treatment, data = data)
anova(fit)
