title: Mixed Models
text:
In the landscape of statistical modeling, Random-Effects and Mixed-Effects Models play a pivotal role in analyzing data that exhibit hierarchical or grouped structures. Unlike fixed-effects models, which assume that the levels of a factor are the only ones of interest, random-effects models consider factors as random samples from a larger population. This distinction allows for the assessment of variability not just within treatments but also across different groups or clusters.
Intuitive Analogy: Imagine conducting a study on the effectiveness of a new teaching method across various schools. If we treat schools as fixed effects, weâ€™re only interested in those specific schools. However, if we consider schools as random effects, we acknowledge that these schools are a random sample from a broader population, enabling us to generalize our findings beyond the studied institutions.
This weekâ€™s focus encompasses:

Differentiating between fixed-effects and random-effects models.
Delving into single and multiple random-effects models.
Exploring mixed-effects models that integrate both fixed and random components.
Implementing these models in R with practical examples.
Engaging with advanced topics through detailed proofs and mathematical derivations.
Reinforcing learning through targeted exercises.



By the end of this lecture, you will be able to:

Differentiate between fixed-effects and random-effects models.
Apply single random-effects models and interpret their results.
Analyze mixed-effects models, combining fixed and random components.
Evaluate model assumptions and perform diagnostic checks.
Compute confidence intervals and test hypotheses for random effects.
Engage with advanced mathematical concepts through proofs and derivations.
Enhance your understanding through practical R examples and exercises.

title: Mixed Models
text:
By the end of this lecture, you will be able to:

Differentiate between fixed-effects and random-effects models.
Apply single random-effects models and interpret their results.
Analyze mixed-effects models, combining fixed and random components.
Evaluate model assumptions and perform diagnostic checks.
Compute confidence intervals and test hypotheses for random effects.
Engage with advanced mathematical concepts through proofs and derivations.
Enhance your understanding through practical R examples and exercises.

title: Mixed Models
text:
Fixed Effects

Definition
Fixed Effects are factors in a model where the levels are specifically chosen and of primary interest. The goal is to make inferences about these particular levels.


Examples

Comparing the effectiveness of three specific fertilizers (A, B, C).
Evaluating the performance of particular teaching methods.



Modeling Assumptions

Factor levels are constants and not random.
Effects are modeled as fixed parameters.

Intuitive Example: Assessing the impact of three distinct fertilizers on plant growth where only these three fertilizers are of interest.

title: Mixed Models
text:
Random Effects

Definition
Random Effects are factors in a model where the levels are randomly sampled from a larger population. The focus is on understanding the variability across these random levels rather than the levels themselves.


Examples

Variability among machine operators selected randomly from a factory.
Batch-to-batch variability in a manufacturing process.



Modeling Assumptions

Factor levels are random variables, typically assumed to follow a normal distribution.
Effects are modeled as random variables with a specified distribution.

Intuitive Example: Studying the effect of different classrooms (randomly selected from all classrooms in a district) on student performance, aiming to generalize findings beyond the sampled classrooms.

title: Mixed Models
text:
Random-Effects One-Way Model
The Random-Effects One-Way Model is suitable when a single random factor influences the response variable. This model accounts for variability due to the random factor and the inherent experimental error.

Model Specification
\[
Y_{it} = \mu + T_i + \varepsilon_{it}, \quad T_i \sim N(0, \sigma_T^2), \quad \varepsilon_{it} \sim N(0, \sigma^2)
\]
Where:

\(Y_{it}\): Response for the \(t\)-th observation in the \(i\)-th group.
\(\mu\): Overall mean.
\(T_i\): Random effect for the \(i\)-th group.
\(\varepsilon_{it}\): Random error term.



Key Properties

Expectation: \(E[Y_{it}] = \mu\)
Variance: \(Var(Y_{it}) = \sigma_T^2 + \sigma^2\)
Covariance: \(Cov(Y_{it}, Y_{is}) = \sigma_T^2\) for \(t \neq s\) within the same group.



ANOVA for Random-Effects Models
Unlike fixed-effects ANOVA, random-effects ANOVA decomposes the total variability into components attributable to random effects and residual error.
ANOVA Table:










Source
Degrees of Freedom
Sum of Squares (SS)
Mean Square (MS)
Expected Mean Square




Treatments
\(a - 1\)
\(SS_T\)
\(MS_T = \frac{SS_T}{a - 1}\)
\(a \sigma_T^2 + \sigma^2\)


Error
\(a(n - 1)\)
\(SS_E\)
\(MS_E = \frac{SS_E}{a(n - 1)}\)
\(\sigma^2\)


Total
\(an - 1\)
\(SS_{Total}\)





Where:

\(a\): Number of groups.
\(n\): Number of observations per group.



Estimation of Variance Components
Using Restricted Maximum Likelihood (REML), we estimate:
\[
\hat{\sigma}^2_T = \frac{MS_T - MS_E}{n}, \quad \hat{\sigma}^2 = MS_E
\]
Example in R:
# Load necessary library
library(lme4)

# Simulated Data
set.seed(123)
data_single_random <- data.frame(
  group = factor(rep(1:5, each = 4)),
  response = c(
    rnorm(4, mean = 10, sd = 2),
    rnorm(4, mean = 12, sd = 2),
    rnorm(4, mean = 11, sd = 2),
    rnorm(4, mean = 13, sd = 2),
    rnorm(4, mean = 12, sd = 2)
  )
)

# Fit Random-Effects Model
model_random <- lmer(response ~ 1 + (1 | group), data = data_single_random)
summary(model_random)

# Extract Variance Components
VarCorr(model_random)
Step-by-Step Interpretation: 1. Model Fitting: The lmer function fits a random-intercept model where group is the random effect. 2. Summary Output: Provides estimates of fixed effects (overall mean) and random effects (variance components). 3. Variance Components: Extracted using VarCorr, showing the estimated variances for random effects and residuals.

title: Mixed Models
text:
Model Specification
\[
Y_{ij} = \mu + \alpha_i + T_j + \varepsilon_{ij}
\]
Where:

\(Y_{ij}\): Response for the \(i\)-th fixed effect level and \(j\)-th random effect level.
\(\mu\): Overall mean.
\(\alpha_i\): Fixed effect for the \(i\)-th level of a fixed factor.
\(T_j \sim N(0, \sigma_T^2)\): Random effect for the \(j\)-th level of a random factor.
\(\varepsilon_{ij} \sim N(0, \sigma^2)\): Random error term.

Intuitive Example: Assessing the impact of different teaching methods (fixed effect) across various schools (random effect) on student performance.

Example: Randomized Block Design with Random Blocks
\[
Y_{ij} = \mu + \alpha_i + B_j + \varepsilon_{ij}, \quad B_j \sim N(0, \sigma_B^2)
\]
Where:

alpha_i: Fixed effect of treatment.
B_j: Random effect of block (e.g., different classrooms).



R Implementation
# Load necessary library
library(lme4)

# Simulated Data for Mixed-Effects Model
set.seed(456)
data_mixed <- data.frame(
  treatment = factor(rep(c("A", "B", "C"), times = 10)),
  block = factor(rep(1:10, each = 3)),
  response = c(
    rnorm(3, mean = 5, sd = 1),
    rnorm(3, mean = 6, sd = 1),
    rnorm(3, mean = 7, sd = 1),
    rnorm(3, mean = 5, sd = 1),
    rnorm(3, mean = 6, sd = 1),
    rnorm(3, mean = 7, sd = 1),
    rnorm(3, mean = 5, sd = 1),
    rnorm(3, mean = 6, sd = 1),
    rnorm(3, mean = 7, sd = 1),
    rnorm(3, mean = 5, sd = 1)
  )
)

# Fit Mixed-Effects Model
model_mixed <- lmer(response ~ treatment + (1 | block), data = data_mixed)
summary(model_mixed)

# Confidence Intervals for Fixed Effects
confint(model_mixed, parm = "treatment")

# Diagnostics
par(mfrow = c(2, 2))
plot(model_mixed)
Interpretation: - Fixed Effects (treatment): Assess the impact of different treatments on the response variable. - Random Effects (block): Account for variability across different blocks (e.g., schools, classrooms). - Confidence Intervals: Provide a range of plausible values for the fixed effects. - Diagnostics: Residual plots help verify model assumptions such as normality and homoscedasticity.

title: Mixed Models
text:
Key Assumptions

Normality: Random effects and residuals are normally distributed.
Independence: Observations are independent within and across groups.
Homogeneity of Variance (Homoscedasticity): Variance is constant across all levels of fixed and random factors.
No Correlation: Random effects are uncorrelated with fixed effects.

title: Mixed Models
text:
Diagnostic Procedures

Residual Analysis

Residuals vs.Â Fitted Values Plot: Checks for non-linearity, unequal error variances, and outliers.
Q-Q Plot of Residuals: Assesses the normality of residuals.
Scale-Location Plot: Evaluates homoscedasticity.
Residuals vs.Â Random Effects Plot: Detects any patterns that suggest violations of independence or homogeneity.



Variance Components Estimation

REML (Restricted Maximum Likelihood): Preferred method for estimating variance components as it accounts for the loss of degrees of freedom.



R Implementation for Diagnostics
# Fit the mixed-effects model
model <- lmer(response ~ treatment + (1 | block), data = data_mixed)

# Diagnostic Plots
par(mfrow = c(2, 2))
plot(model)

# Shapiro-Wilk Test for Normality of Residuals
shapiro.test(resid(model))

# Check for Homoscedasticity
library(car)
leveneTest(response ~ treatment, data = data_mixed)
Interpretation: - Normality Tests: Non-significant p-values indicate no evidence against normality. - Leveneâ€™s Test: Assesses equality of variances across groups; non-significant p-values suggest homoscedasticity. - Residual Plots: Should display random scatter without discernible patterns.

title: Mixed Models
text:
Fitting Random-Effects Models
Random-effects models are essential when dealing with grouped or hierarchical data. Below is a step-by-step example of fitting a random-effects model using R.

Example: Single Random Effect
Scenario: Assessing the effect of different diets on weight loss across various clinics. Clinics are randomly sampled from a larger population.
# Load necessary library
library(lme4)

# Simulated Data
set.seed(123)
data_random <- data.frame(
  clinic = factor(rep(1:10, each = 5)),
  diet = factor(rep(c("Diet1", "Diet2", "Diet3", "Diet4", "Diet5"), times = 10)),
  weight_loss = c(
    rnorm(5, mean = 2, sd = 0.5),
    rnorm(5, mean = 2.5, sd = 0.5),
    rnorm(5, mean = 3, sd = 0.5),
    rnorm(5, mean = 3.5, sd = 0.5),
    rnorm(5, mean = 4, sd = 0.5),
    rnorm(5, mean = 2, sd = 0.5),
    rnorm(5, mean = 2.5, sd = 0.5),
    rnorm(5, mean = 3, sd = 0.5),
    rnorm(5, mean = 3.5, sd = 0.5),
    rnorm(5, mean = 4, sd = 0.5)
  )
)

# Fit Random-Effects Model
model_random <- lmer(weight_loss ~ 1 + (1 | clinic), data = data_random)
summary(model_random)

# Extract Variance Components
VarCorr(model_random)
Step-by-Step Interpretation: 1. Data Preparation: Simulated data includes 10 clinics, each with 5 diet treatments. 2. Model Fitting: lmer fits a model with a random intercept for clinics. 3. Summary Output: Provides estimates for the overall mean, random effects variance, and residual variance. 4. Variance Components: VarCorr displays the estimated variances for the random effects and residuals.

title: Mixed Models
text:
Fitting Mixed-Effects Models
Mixed-Effects Models accommodate both fixed and random factors, offering a versatile framework for complex data structures.

Example: Two-Way Factorial with Random Blocks
Scenario: Investigating the effect of two factors (e.g., fertilizer type and watering frequency) on plant growth across randomly selected greenhouses.
# Load necessary library
library(lme4)

# Simulated Data
set.seed(456)
data_mixed <- data.frame(
  greenhouse = factor(rep(1:15, each = 4)),
  fertilizer = factor(rep(c("F1", "F2"), each = 2, times = 15)),
  watering = factor(rep(c("W1", "W2"), times = 30)),
  growth = c(
    rnorm(60, mean = 10, sd = 1),
    rnorm(60, mean = 12, sd = 1)
  )
)

# Introduce Interaction Effect
data_mixed$growth <- with(data_mixed, growth + ifelse(fertilizer == "F2" & watering == "W2", 2, 0))

# Fit Mixed-Effects Model with Interaction
model_mixed <- lmer(growth ~ fertilizer * watering + (1 | greenhouse), data = data_mixed)
summary(model_mixed)

# Estimated Marginal Means and Pairwise Comparisons
library(emmeans)
emm <- emmeans(model_mixed, ~ fertilizer * watering)
pairs(emm)
Interpretation: - Fixed Effects (fertilizer, watering, fertilizer:watering): Assess the main effects and interaction between fertilizer type and watering frequency. - Random Effects (greenhouse): Account for variability across different greenhouses. - Interaction Effect: Significant interaction indicates that the effect of one factor depends on the level of the other factor. - Pairwise Comparisons: Identify specific group differences after accounting for other factors.

title: Mixed Models
text:
Example: Resting Metabolic Rate

Scenario
A study aims to compare three different exercise protocols (Treatments A, B, C) on subjectsâ€™ resting metabolic rates. To control for age-related variability, subjects are grouped into four blocks based on age groups.


Step-by-Step R Code

1. Load and Prepare Data
# Set seed for reproducibility
set.seed(789)

# Define blocks and treatments
blocks <- factor(rep(1:4, each = 3))
treatments <- factor(rep(c("A", "B", "C"), times = 4))

# Simulate response variable (resting metabolic rate in kcal/day)
response <- c(
  rnorm(3, mean = 1500, sd = 50),  # Block 1
  rnorm(3, mean = 1550, sd = 50),  # Block 2
  rnorm(3, mean = 1480, sd = 50),  # Block 3
  rnorm(3, mean = 1520, sd = 50)   # Block 4
)

# Create data frame
data_rmr <- data.frame(blocks, treatments, response)

# View the data
print(data_rmr)
Output Interpretation: The dataset comprises four blocks (age groups), each containing three treatments (A, B, C). The response variable represents the resting metabolic rate, simulated with slight block-specific means to reflect age-related variability.


2. Fit the RCBD Model
# Fit the RCBD model using ANOVA
model_rcbd <- aov(response ~ blocks + treatments, data = data_rmr)

# Summary of the model
summary(model_rcbd)
Interpretation: - Blocks: Capture variability due to different age groups. - Treatments: Assess the effect of exercise protocols after accounting for age-related variability. - Error: Represents unexplained variability in resting metabolic rates.


3. Diagnostic Plots
# Diagnostic plots for the ANOVA model
par(mfrow = c(2, 2))
plot(model_rcbd)
Interpretation: Examine residual plots to ensure that assumptions of normality, homoscedasticity, and independence are met. Look for random scatter in Residuals vs Fitted and Q-Q plots to assess normality.


4. Post-Hoc Analysis (Multiple Comparisons)
# Load emmeans package for estimated marginal means
library(emmeans)

# Estimated marginal means for treatments
emm_rmr <- emmeans(model_rcbd, ~ treatments)

# Pairwise comparisons
pairwise_comparisons_rmr <- contrast(emm_rmr, method = "pairwise")
summary(pairwise_comparisons_rmr)
Interpretation: Identify which exercise protocols significantly differ in their effect on resting metabolic rates after adjusting for age-related variability.

title: Mixed Models
text:
Variance Component Estimation

Deriving Expected Mean Squares
In random-effects models, the Expected Mean Squares (EMS) are fundamental for estimating variance components.


Random-Effects One-Way Model
\[
Y_{it} = \mu + T_i + \varepsilon_{it}, \quad T_i \sim N(0, \sigma_T^2), \quad \varepsilon_{it} \sim N(0, \sigma^2)
\]
Expected Mean Squares:
\[
EMS_T = \sigma_T^2 + \sigma^2
\]
\[
EMS_E = \sigma^2
\]
Derivation:

For Treatments:

\[
EMS_T = Var(T_i) + Var(\varepsilon_{it}) = \sigma_T^2 + \sigma^2
\]

For Error:

\[
EMS_E = Var(\varepsilon_{it}) = \sigma^2
\]
Estimation:
Using ANOVA sums of squares, we set up equations based on EMS to solve for variance components.
\[
MS_T = \sigma_T^2 + \sigma^2
\]
\[
MS_E = \sigma^2
\]
Solving for \(\sigma_T^2\):
\[
\hat{\sigma}_T^2 = MS_T - MS_E
\]
Conclusion: This derivation highlights how ANOVA estimates variance components by leveraging the properties of expected mean squares.
Reference: Montgomery, D. C., & Runger, G. C. (2020). Applied Statistics and Probability for Engineers. Wiley.

title: Mixed Models
text:
Confidence Intervals for Variance Components

Satterthwaite Approximation
The Satterthwaite Approximation provides a method to estimate the degrees of freedom for variance components, facilitating the construction of confidence intervals.


Steps

Estimate Variance Components: Using REML or other estimation methods.
Calculate Degrees of Freedom: Approximated based on the variance component estimates.
Construct Confidence Intervals:

\[
CI = \hat{\sigma}^2 \pm t_{\alpha/2, df} \times SE(\hat{\sigma}^2)
\]
Where:

\(\hat{\sigma}^2\): Estimated variance component.
\(t_{\alpha/2, df}\): Critical value from the t-distribution.
\(SE(\hat{\sigma}^2)\): Standard error of the variance component estimate.

Example in R:
# Fit the model
model <- lmer(response ~ 1 + (1 | group), data = data_random)

# Extract variance components
var_components <- VarCorr(model)
sigma_T_sq <- as.numeric(var_components$group)
sigma_sq <- attr(var_components, "sc")^2

# Estimate standard errors using the lme4 package's built-in functions
confint(model, parm = "theta_", method = "Wald")
Interpretation: The confint function provides confidence intervals for the variance components, allowing for inference about the population variability.
Reference: Christensen, R. (2018). Analysis of Variance, Design, and Regression. Chapman and Hall/CRC.

title: Mixed Models
text:
Medium Difficulty

1. Two-Way ANCOVA with Interaction
Dataset: Simulate a dataset with three treatments and one covariate.
Tasks:

Generate data for treatments A, B, C with a covariate \(X\).
Fit an ANCOVA model adjusting for \(X\).
Test the significance of treatment effects and the covariate.
Generate diagnostic plots and interpret them.

R Code Example:
set.seed(123)

# Define factors and covariate
Treatment <- factor(rep(c("A", "B", "C"), each=30))
X <- rnorm(90, mean=50, sd=10)

# Simulate responses with treatment effects and covariate effect
Y <- 5 + 
     ifelse(Treatment == "A", 0, ifelse(Treatment == "B", 2, 4)) + 
     0.5 * (X - mean(X)) + 
     rnorm(90, mean=0, sd=3)

data_sim <- data.frame(Treatment, X, Y)

# Fit ANCOVA model
model_sim <- lm(Y ~ Treatment + X, data = data_sim)
summary(model_sim)

# Diagnostic plots
par(mfrow = c(2, 2))
plot(model_sim)

# Estimated marginal means
library(emmeans)
emm_sim <- emmeans(model_sim, ~ Treatment)
pairwise_sim <- contrast(emm_sim, method = "pairwise")
summary(pairwise_sim)
Questions:

Main Effects:

Treatment: What are the estimated effects of treatments A, B, and C?
Covariate \(X\): How does \(X\) influence the response variable \(Y\)?

Significance Testing:

Are the treatment effects statistically significant after adjusting for \(X\)?
Is the covariate \(X\) a significant predictor of \(Y\)?

Diagnostic Plots:

Do the residual plots indicate any violations of ANCOVA assumptions such as non-linearity, heteroscedasticity, or non-normality?
Are there any influential observations that may affect the modelâ€™s validity?

Interpretation of Pairwise Comparisons:

Which treatments significantly differ from each other after adjusting for \(X\)?
How do the adjusted means compare across treatments?


Expected Answers:

Main Effects:

Treatments B and C have positive effects relative to Treatment A.
Covariate \(X\) has a positive influence on \(Y\), indicating that as \(X\) increases, \(Y\) tends to increase.

Significance Testing:

If the p-values for Treatment are below the significance level (e.g., 0.05), treatments have significant effects.
If the p-value for \(X\) is below the significance level, \(X\) is a significant predictor.

Diagnostic Plots:

Random scatter in Residuals vs Fitted suggests homoscedasticity and linearity.
Q-Q plot close to the diagonal indicates normality of residuals.
No points with high leverage or large residuals indicate no influential observations.

Interpretation of Pairwise Comparisons:

Significant pairwise differences indicate which specific treatments differ after adjusting for \(X\).
Adjusted means provide a clearer comparison by accounting for the covariateâ€™s effect.

title: Mixed Models
text:
Challenging Problems

1. Unbalanced Two-Factor ANCOVA Analysis
Dataset: Utilize a dataset with unequal numbers of replicates across treatment combinations.
Tasks:

Simulate an unbalanced dataset with two factors and one covariate.
Fit an ANCOVA model using both Type II and Type III sums of squares.
Compare the results and discuss how imbalance affects the interpretation of main and interaction effects.

R Code Example:
library(car)

set.seed(456)

# Simulate unbalanced data
FactorA <- factor(rep(c("A1", "A2", "A3"), times = c(4, 6, 5)))
FactorB <- factor(rep(c("B1", "B2"), each = 7, times = 2))
X <- rnorm(15, mean = 50, sd = 10)

# Simulate responses with treatment and covariate effects
Y <- 5 + 
     ifelse(FactorA == "A1", 0, ifelse(FactorA == "A2", 2, 4)) + 
     ifelse(FactorB == "B1", 0, 3) + 
     0.5 * (X - mean(X)) + 
     rnorm(15, mean=0, sd=3)

data_unbalanced <- data.frame(FactorA, FactorB, X, Y)

# Fit ANCOVA model
fit_unbalanced <- lm(Y ~ FactorA * FactorB + X, data = data_unbalanced)

# Type II Sum of Squares
typeII <- Anova(fit_unbalanced, type = "II")
print(typeII)

# Type III Sum of Squares
typeIII <- Anova(fit_unbalanced, type = "III")
print(typeIII)
Discussion Points:

Type II vs.Â Type III SS:

Type II: Tests main effects after accounting for other main effects but ignores interactions.
Type III: Tests main effects after accounting for all other factors, including interactions.

Impact of Imbalance:

Imbalanced designs can lead to different interpretations under Type II and Type III SS.
Type I SS is not appropriate here as it is sequential and depends on the order of factors.

Significance of Effects:

Identify which factors and interactions are significant under each type.
Discuss how imbalance might inflate or deflate the significance levels of certain effects.

Implications for Experimental Conclusions:

Choosing the appropriate type of sums of squares is crucial for accurate inference.
Misinterpretation can lead to incorrect conclusions about factor effects and interactions.


Expected Insights:

Type II SS: Often preferred when interactions are not of primary interest. It provides unbiased estimates of main effects under the assumption of no interaction.
Type III SS: Necessary when interactions are present or when the design is unbalanced. It accounts for all factors simultaneously, providing conditional main effects.
Imbalance Effects: Can distort the Type I SS results, leading to misleading conclusions. Type II and III SS offer more robust alternatives in unbalanced settings.

Reference: Christensen, R. (2018). Analysis of Variance, Design, and Regression. Chapman and Hall/CRC.


2. Three-Factor Interaction Interpretation
Dataset: Use a simulated dataset with three factors exhibiting a significant three-way interaction.
Tasks:

Simulate data with three factors and one covariate.
Fit a three-way ANCOVA model.
Visualize the three-way interaction.
Use emmeans to estimate marginal means and perform pairwise comparisons.
Explain how the three-way interaction affects the interpretation of main and two-way interactions.

R Code Example:
library(emmeans)
library(ggplot2)

set.seed(789)

# Simulate data
FactorA <- factor(rep(c("A1", "A2", "A3"), each = 24))
FactorB <- factor(rep(c("B1", "B2"), each = 12, times = 3))
FactorC <- factor(rep(c("C1", "C2", "C3"), times = 8))
X <- rnorm(72, mean = 50, sd = 10)

# Simulate responses with three-way interaction
Y <- 5 + 
     ifelse(FactorA == "A1", 0, ifelse(FactorA == "A2", 2, 4)) + 
     ifelse(FactorB == "B1", 0, 3) + 
     ifelse(FactorC == "C1", 0, ifelse(FactorC == "C2", 1.5, 3)) + 
     0.5 * (X - mean(X)) + 
     ifelse(FactorA == "A1" & FactorB == "B1", 0, 
            ifelse(FactorA == "A2" & FactorB == "B2", 1, 2)) + 
     rnorm(72, mean=0, sd=3)

data_three <- data.frame(FactorA, FactorB, FactorC, X, Y)

# Fit three-way ANCOVA model
fit_three <- lm(Y ~ FactorA * FactorB * FactorC + X, data = data_three)
summary(fit_three)

# Plot three-way interaction
ggplot(data_three, aes(x=FactorA, y=Y, color=FactorB, group=FactorB)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_line() +
  facet_wrap(~ FactorC) +
  labs(title="Three-Way Interaction Plot", x="Factor A", y="Response") +
  theme_minimal()

# Estimated marginal means
emm_three <- emmeans(fit_three, ~ FactorA * FactorB * FactorC)
contrast_results <- contrast(emm_three, method = "pairwise", adjust = "none")
summary(contrast_results)
Interpretation:

Three-Way Interaction:

The interaction plot demonstrates how the interaction between Factor A and Factor B varies across different levels of Factor C.
Non-parallel lines across facets indicate a significant three-way interaction.

Impact on Main and Two-Way Interactions:

Significant higher-order interactions imply that main effects and two-way interactions cannot be interpreted in isolation.
The effect of one factor depends on the combination of other factors, necessitating a comprehensive analysis.

Practical Implications:

Understanding three-way interactions provides nuanced insights into how multiple factors jointly influence the response variable.
This can inform more sophisticated decision-making and strategy development in experimental settings.


Reference: Dean, Voss & DraguljiÄ‡ (2017). Design and Analysis of Experiments. Springer.


3. Mathematical Proof of Interaction Contrasts
Task: Derive formulas for interaction contrasts in a three-factor design and prove that they measure deviations from additivity.
Requirements:

Show how to construct interaction contrasts.
Prove that if all interaction contrasts are zero, the model is additive.

Hints:

Utilize the definitions of main effects and interaction terms.
Employ properties of linear algebra to demonstrate the relationship between interaction contrasts and additivity.
Reference Dean et al.Â (2017) and Christensen (2018) for theoretical foundations.

Proof Outline:

Define the Three-Factor Model:

\[
Y_{ijk} = \mu + \alpha_i + \beta_j + \gamma_k + (\alpha\beta)_{ij} + (\alpha\gamma)_{ik} + (\beta\gamma)_{jk} + (\alpha\beta\gamma)_{ijk} + \epsilon_{ijk}
\]
where \(\sum \alpha_i = \sum \beta_j = \sum \gamma_k = 0\).

Construct Interaction Contrasts:

Two-Way Interactions:

\((\alpha\beta)_{ij}\): Measures the interaction between Factors A and B.
Similarly for \((\alpha\gamma)_{ik}\) and \((\beta\gamma)_{jk}\).

Three-Way Interaction:

\((\alpha\beta\gamma)_{ijk}\): Measures the deviation from additivity among all three factors.


Prove Deviations from Additivity:

Additive Model: If all interaction terms are zero (\((\alpha\beta)_{ij} = (\alpha\gamma)_{ik} = (\beta\gamma)_{jk} = (\alpha\beta\gamma)_{ijk} = 0\)), the model simplifies to:


\[
Y_{ijk} = \mu + \alpha_i + \beta_j + \gamma_k + \epsilon_{ijk}
\]
 This represents a purely additive model where the combined effect of factors is the sum of their individual effects.

Non-Additive Model: If any of the interaction terms are non-zero, the model deviates from additivity, indicating that the effect of one factor depends on the levels of other factors.


Conclusion:
Interaction contrasts (\((\alpha\beta)_{ij}\), \((\alpha\gamma)_{ik}\), \((\beta\gamma)_{jk}\), and \((\alpha\beta\gamma)_{ijk}\)) measure the extent to which the observed responses deviate from an additive model. Non-zero contrasts signify the presence of interactions, emphasizing the importance of considering these higher-order effects in experimental analysis.

Reference: Dean, Voss & DraguljiÄ‡ (2017). Design and Analysis of Experiments. Springer.

title: Mixed Models
section: Variance Calculations for Latin Square Designs
text:
Variance Calculations for Latin Square Designs
In a Latin Square Design with \(v\) treatments, the variance of the estimated treatment effects is influenced by the designâ€™s structure.

Formula
For a Latin Square with \(v\) treatments:
\[
Var(\tau_i) = \frac{\sigma^2}{v}
\]


Derivation

Model Setup:
The ANOVA model for a Latin Square is:

\[
Y_{ijk} = \mu + \alpha_i + \beta_j + \tau_k + \epsilon_{ijk},
\]
where \(\epsilon_{ijk} \sim N(0, \sigma^2)\).

Estimator for Treatment Effect (\(\tau_k\)):
The treatment effects are estimated as:

\[
\hat{\tau}_k = \bar{Y}_{\cdot \cdot k} - \bar{Y}_{\cdot \cdot \cdot},
\]
where \(\bar{Y}_{\cdot \cdot k}\) is the mean response for treatment \(k\) and \(\bar{Y}_{\cdot \cdot \cdot}\) is the grand mean.

Variance of \(\hat{\tau}_k\):
Since each treatment is replicated \(v\) times (once per row and column):

\[
Var(\hat{\tau}_k) = \frac{\sigma^2}{v}
\]
Conclusion: The variance of the treatment effect estimates decreases with increasing number of treatments in the Latin Square, enhancing the precision of the estimates.
Reference: Montgomery, D. C., & Runger, G. C. (2020). Applied Statistics and Probability for Engineers. Wiley.

title: Mixed Models
section: Degrees of Freedom in Youden Designs
text:
Degrees of Freedom in Youden Designs
For a Youden Design with parameters \(v = 4\) treatments, \(b = 4\) blocks (rows), and \(c = 3\) columns, the degrees of freedom for the error term are calculated as follows:

Formula
\[
df_{\text{Error}} = bc - b - c - v + 2
\]


Calculation
Given:

\(v = 4\)
\(b = 4\)
\(c = 3\)

Plugging into the formula:
\[
df_{\text{Error}} = (4 \times 3) - 4 - 3 - 4 + 2 = 12 - 4 - 3 - 4 + 2 = 3
\]
Interpretation: The error degrees of freedom indicate the number of independent pieces of information available to estimate the error variance. In this case, with 3 error degrees of freedom, the design is sufficiently constrained to estimate treatment effects after accounting for row and column effects.
Reference: Dean, Voss & DraguljiÄ‡ (2017). Design and Analysis of Experiments. Springer.

title: Mixed Models
text:
Proof of Interaction Contrasts

Interaction Contrasts Measure Deviations from Additivity
Definition: In a three-factor design, interaction contrasts quantify how the combined effect of three factors deviates from the additive effects of each factor individually and their two-way interactions.


Proof Steps

Define the Three-Factor Model:

\[
Y_{ijk} = \mu + \alpha_i + \beta_j + \gamma_k + (\alpha\beta)_{ij} + (\alpha\gamma)_{ik} + (\beta\gamma)_{jk} + (\alpha\beta\gamma)_{ijk} + \epsilon_{ijk}
\]
where \(\sum \alpha_i = \sum \beta_j = \sum \gamma_k = 0\).

Construct Interaction Contrasts:

Two-Way Interactions:

\((\alpha\beta)_{ij}\): Measures the interaction between Factors A and B.
Similarly for \((\alpha\gamma)_{ik}\) and \((\beta\gamma)_{jk}\).

Three-Way Interaction:

\((\alpha\beta\gamma)_{ijk}\): Measures the deviation from additivity among all three factors.


Prove Deviations from Additivity:

Additive Model: If all interaction terms are zero (\((\alpha\beta)_{ij} = (\alpha\gamma)_{ik} = (\beta\gamma)_{jk} = (\alpha\beta\gamma)_{ijk} = 0\)), the model simplifies to:


\[
Y_{ijk} = \mu + \alpha_i + \beta_j + \gamma_k + \epsilon_{ijk}
\]
 This represents a purely additive model where the combined effect of factors is the sum of their individual effects.

Non-Additive Model: If any of the interaction terms are non-zero, the model deviates from additivity, indicating that the effect of one factor depends on the levels of other factors.


Conclusion:
Interaction contrasts (\((\alpha\beta)_{ij}\), \((\alpha\gamma)_{ik}\), \((\beta\gamma)_{jk}\), and \((\alpha\beta\gamma)_{ijk}\)) measure the extent to which the observed responses deviate from an additive model. Non-zero contrasts signify the presence of interactions, emphasizing the importance of considering these higher-order effects in experimental analysis.

Reference: Dean, Voss & DraguljiÄ‡ (2017). Design and Analysis of Experiments. Springer.

title: Mixed Models
text:
Adjusted Treatment Means
The Adjusted Mean for treatment \(i\) accounts for the influence of blocking factors, providing a more accurate estimate of the treatment effect.
\[
\mu + \tau_i = \bar{Y}_i - \beta (\bar{X}_i - \bar{X})
\]
Where:

\(\mu\): Overall mean.
\(\tau_i\): Treatment effect for treatment \(i\).
\(\bar{Y}_i\): Mean response for treatment \(i\).
\(\beta\): Regression coefficient for the covariate.
\(\bar{X}_i\): Mean covariate value for treatment \(i\).
\(\bar{X}\): Overall mean of the covariate.


Derivation

Model Equation:

\[
Y_{ij} = \mu + \tau_i + \beta (X_{ij} - \bar{X}) + \epsilon_{ij}
\]

Taking the Mean for Treatment \(i\):

\[
\bar{Y}_i = \mu + \tau_i + \beta (\bar{X}_i - \bar{X}) + \bar{\epsilon}_i
\]
Since \(\bar{\epsilon}_i = 0\) (assuming errors have mean zero),
\[
\bar{Y}_i = \mu + \tau_i + \beta (\bar{X}_i - \bar{X})
\]

Solving for Adjusted Mean:

\[
\mu + \tau_i = \bar{Y}_i - \beta (\bar{X}_i - \bar{X})
\]
This equation represents the adjusted treatment mean, accounting for differences in the covariate.
Reference: Montgomery, D. C., & Runger, G. C. (2020). Applied Statistics and Probability for Engineers. Wiley.

title: Mixed Models
text:
F-Test for Homogeneity of Slopes
Testing the assumption of homogeneity of regression slopes ensures that the relationship between the covariate and the response is consistent across all treatment groups.

Model Comparison

Model Without Interaction (Assuming Homogeneous Slopes):

\[
Y_{hi} = \mu + \theta_h + \tau_i + \beta X_{hi} + \epsilon_{hi}
\]

Model With Interaction (Allowing Slopes to Vary):

\[
Y_{hi} = \mu + \theta_h + \tau_i + \beta X_{hi} + (\theta \tau)_{hi} + \epsilon_{hi}
\]
Where \((\theta \tau)_{hi}\) allows the slope of the covariate to vary with treatments.


Hypothesis Testing

Null Hypothesis (\(H_0\)): Homogeneity of slopes (\(\beta\) is the same across treatments).
Alternative Hypothesis (\(H_A\)): Slopes vary across treatments (\(\beta_i \neq \beta_j\) for some \(i, j\)).



Test Procedure

Fit Both Models:

Reduced Model: Without interaction.
Full Model: With interaction.

Compare Models Using ANOVA:
# Fit reduced model
model_reduced <- lm(Time ~ fColor + x, data = balloon.data)

# Fit full model with interaction
model_full <- lm(Time ~ fColor * x, data = balloon.data)

# Compare models
anova(model_reduced, model_full)
Decision Rule:

If the interaction term is significant (\(p < \alpha\)), reject \(H_0\) and conclude that slopes are not homogeneous.
If not significant, accept \(H_0\) and proceed with the reduced model.


Conclusion: A significant interaction term indicates that the effect of the covariate varies across treatments, violating the homogeneity of slopes assumption and necessitating a more complex model.
Reference: ScheffÃ©, H. (1959). The Analysis of Variance. Wiley.

title: Mixed Models
text:
Confidence Intervals for Higher-Order Contrasts
For higher-order interactions involving multiple factors, confidence intervals for contrasts provide insights into the magnitude and significance of these interactions.

Formula
\[
CI = \hat{L} \pm t_{\alpha/2, df} \sqrt{\text{Var}(\hat{L})}
\]
Where:

\(\hat{L}\): Estimated contrast.
\(t_{\alpha/2, df}\): Critical value from the t-distribution.
\(\text{Var}(\hat{L})\): Variance of the contrast estimate.



Steps in R

Estimate the Contrast:
Using the emmeans package to define and estimate contrasts.
Calculate the Confidence Interval:
The emmeans package automatically provides confidence intervals when performing contrasts.

Example:
library(emmeans)

# Fit the ANCOVA model
model <- lm(Y ~ Treatment + X, data = data_sim)

# Define estimated marginal means
emm <- emmeans(model, ~ Treatment)

# Define a contrast (e.g., Treatment B vs. Treatment A)
contrast_AB <- contrast(emm, method = "pairwise")
summary(contrast_AB, infer = TRUE)
Interpretation: The output provides the estimated difference, standard error, t-value, and confidence interval for the contrast. If the confidence interval does not include zero, the contrast is statistically significant.
Reference: Christensen, R. (2018). Analysis of Variance, Design, and Regression. Chapman and Hall/CRC.

title: Mixed Models
text:
Medium Difficulty

1. Two-Way ANCOVA with Interaction
Dataset: Simulate a dataset with three treatments and one covariate.
Tasks:

Generate data for treatments A, B, C with a covariate \(X\).
Fit an ANCOVA model adjusting for \(X\).
Test the significance of treatment effects and the covariate.
Generate diagnostic plots and interpret them.

R Code Example:
set.seed(123)

# Define factors and covariate
Treatment <- factor(rep(c("A", "B", "C"), each=30))
X <- rnorm(90, mean=50, sd=10)

# Simulate responses with treatment effects and covariate effect
Y <- 5 + 
     ifelse(Treatment == "A", 0, ifelse(Treatment == "B", 2, 4)) + 
     0.5 * (X - mean(X)) + 
     rnorm(90, mean=0, sd=3)

data_sim <- data.frame(Treatment, X, Y)

# Fit ANCOVA model
model_sim <- lm(Y ~ Treatment + X, data = data_sim)
summary(model_sim)

# Diagnostic plots
par(mfrow = c(2, 2))
plot(model_sim)

# Estimated marginal means
library(emmeans)
emm_sim <- emmeans(model_sim, ~ Treatment)
pairwise_sim <- contrast(emm_sim, method = "pairwise")
summary(pairwise_sim)
Questions:

Main Effects:

Treatment: What are the estimated effects of treatments A, B, and C?
Covariate \(X\): How does \(X\) influence the response variable \(Y\)?

Significance Testing:

Are the treatment effects statistically significant after adjusting for \(X\)?
Is the covariate \(X\) a significant predictor of \(Y\)?

Diagnostic Plots:

Do the residual plots indicate any violations of ANCOVA assumptions such as non-linearity, heteroscedasticity, or non-normality?
Are there any influential observations that may affect the modelâ€™s validity?

Interpretation of Pairwise Comparisons:

Which treatments significantly differ from each other after adjusting for \(X\)?
How do the adjusted means compare across treatments?


Expected Answers:

Main Effects:

Treatments B and C have positive effects relative to Treatment A.
Covariate \(X\) has a positive influence on \(Y\), indicating that as \(X\) increases, \(Y\) tends to increase.

Significance Testing:

If the p-values for Treatment are below the significance level (e.g., 0.05), treatments have significant effects.
If the p-value for \(X\) is below the significance level, \(X\) is a significant predictor.

Diagnostic Plots:

Random scatter in Residuals vs Fitted suggests homoscedasticity and linearity.
Q-Q plot close to the diagonal indicates normality of residuals.
No points with high leverage or large residuals indicate no influential observations.

Interpretation of Pairwise Comparisons:

Significant pairwise differences indicate which specific treatments differ after adjusting for \(X\).
Adjusted means provide a clearer comparison by accounting for the covariateâ€™s effect.

R Code Example:
library(emmeans)
library(ggplot2)

set.seed(789)

     ifelse(FactorA == "A1", 0, ifelse(FactorA == "A2", 2, 4)) +

     rnorm(72, mean=0, sd=3)

data_three <- data.frame(FactorA, FactorB, FactorC, X, Y)

  theme_minimal()

# Estimated marginal means

contrast_results <- contrast(emm_three, method = "pairwise", adjust = "none")

This can inform more sophisticated decision-making and strategy development in experimental settings.

text:
F-Test for Homogeneity of Slopes
Testing the assumption of homogeneity of regression slopes ensures that the relationship between the covariate and the response is consistent across all treatment groups.

Model Comparison

Model Without Interaction (Assuming Homogeneous Slopes):

\[
Y_{hi} = \mu + \theta_h + \tau_i + \beta X_{hi} + \epsilon_{hi}
\]

Model With Interaction (Allowing Slopes to Vary):

\[
Y_{hi} = \mu + \theta_h + \tau_i + \beta X_{hi} + (\theta \tau)_{hi} + \epsilon_{hi}
\]
Where \((\theta \tau)_{hi}\) allows the slope of the covariate to vary with treatments.


Hypothesis Testing

Null Hypothesis (\(H_0\)): Homogeneity of slopes (\(\beta\) is the same across treatments).
Alternative Hypothesis (\(H_A\)): Slopes vary across treatments (\(\beta_i \neq \beta_j\) for some \(i, j\)).



Test Procedure

Fit Both Models:

Reduced Model: Without interaction.
Full Model: With interaction.

Compare Models Using ANOVA:
# Fit reduced model
model_reduced <- lm(Time ~ fColor + x, data = balloon.data)

# Fit full model with interaction
model_full <- lm(Time ~ fColor * x, data = balloon.data)

# Compare models
anova(model_reduced, model_full)
Decision Rule:

If the interaction term is significant (\(p < \alpha\)), reject \(H_0\) and conclude that slopes are not homogeneous.
If not significant, accept \(H_0\) and proceed with the reduced model.


Conclusion: A significant interaction term indicates that the effect of the covariate varies across treatments, violating the homogeneity of slopes assumption and necessitating a more complex model.
Reference: ScheffÃ©, H. (1959). The Analysis of Variance. Wiley.

title: Mixed Models
text:
Confidence Intervals for Higher-Order Contrasts
For higher-order interactions involving multiple factors, confidence intervals for contrasts provide insights into the magnitude and significance of these interactions.

Formula
\[
CI = \hat{L} \pm t_{\alpha/2, df} \sqrt{\text{Var}(\hat{L})}
\]
Where:

\(\hat{L}\): Estimated contrast.
\(t_{\alpha/2, df}\): Critical value from the t-distribution.
\(\text{Var}(\hat{L})\): Variance of the contrast estimate.



Steps in R

Estimate the Contrast:
Using the emmeans package to define and estimate contrasts.
Calculate the Confidence Interval:
The emmeans package automatically provides confidence intervals when performing contrasts.

Example:
library(emmeans)

# Fit the ANCOVA model
model <- lm(Y ~ Treatment + X, data = data_sim)

# Define estimated marginal means
emm <- emmeans(model, ~ Treatment)

# Define a contrast (e.g., Treatment B vs. Treatment A)
contrast_AB <- contrast(emm, method = "pairwise")
summary(contrast_AB, infer = TRUE)
Interpretation: The output provides the estimated difference, standard error, t-value, and confidence interval for the contrast. If the confidence interval does not include zero, the contrast is statistically significant.
Reference: Christensen, R. (2018). Analysis of Variance, Design, and Regression. Chapman and Hall/CRC.

title: Split-Plot ANOVA
text:
Split-plot designs are a powerful class of experimental designs that originated in agricultural settings but now see extensive use across engineering and scientific fields where certain factors are hard to change and others are easy to change. First formalized by R. A. Fisher at Rothamsted Experimental Station, these designs address practical limitations in experimentationâ€”for instance, when adjusting equipment temperature is costly or time-consuming (Kempthorne, 1977; ScheffÃ©, 1959).



Early Development: Split-plot methodology emerged from agricultural research, where entire fields (whole plots) were assigned to certain treatments (e.g., irrigation methods), and sub-portions of each field (split plots) received additional treatments (e.g., fertilizer types).
Modern Applications: Today, split-plot designs are prevalent in industrial experiments (Dean et al., 2017), such as semiconductor manufacturing or paint-curing processes. They enable investigators to manipulate â€œhard-to-changeâ€ variables at the whole-plot level while fine-tuning other variables at the split-plot level.




After working through this material, you will be able to:

Recognize when split-plot designs are appropriate.
Formulate the statistical models underpinning split-plot experiments.
Analyze split-plot data using R and interpret the output.
Understand the hierarchical (two-error) structure inherent in split-plot designs.
Conduct diagnostic checks and manage potential pitfalls such as unbalanced data or pseudo-replication.

title: Split-Plot ANOVA
text:
Early Development: Split-plot methodology emerged from agricultural research, where entire fields (whole plots) were assigned to certain treatments (e.g., irrigation methods), and sub-portions of each field (split plots) received additional treatments (e.g., fertilizer types).
Modern Applications: Today, split-plot designs are prevalent in industrial experiments (Dean et al., 2017), such as semiconductor manufacturing or paint-curing processes. They enable investigators to manipulate â€œhard-to-changeâ€ variables at the whole-plot level while fine-tuning other variables at the split-plot level.

title: Split-Plot ANOVA
text:
After working through this material, you will be able to:

Recognize when split-plot designs are appropriate.
Formulate the statistical models underpinning split-plot experiments.
Analyze split-plot data using R and interpret the output.
Understand the hierarchical (two-error) structure inherent in split-plot designs.
Conduct diagnostic checks and manage potential pitfalls such as unbalanced data or pseudo-replication.

title: Split-Plot ANOVA
text:
2.1 Two-Error Structure
A defining feature of split-plot designs is the presence of two distinct experimental error terms (Dean et al., 2017; Montgomery & Runger, 2010; Christensen, 2018):

Whole-Plot Error (\(\sigma^2_W\))

Arises from variation among the â€œhard-to-changeâ€ factors (e.g., temperature, irrigation).
Typically larger due to the cost and complexity of changing these factors.
Example: Oven-to-oven variability when testing different oven temperatures.

Split-Plot Error (\(\sigma^2_S\))

Captures variability within each whole plot for the â€œeasy-to-changeâ€ factors.
Usually smaller since these factors are more straightforward to manipulate.
Example: Variation among parts painted in the same oven run.


This nested structure means that each whole plot is subdivided into several split plots, and different analysis methods are needed to properly separate the two sources of variability.

title: Split-Plot ANOVA
text:
2.2 Intuitive Analogy: Paint Curing Process
Consider an industrial paint-curing process:

Whole-Plot Factor: Oven Temperature (Low, Medium, High)
Split-Plot Factor: Paint Type (A, B, C)
Response: Coating Durability

Running the experiment:

Set the oven to a specific temperature (hard to change).
Paint several parts (easy to change) in that oven run.
Measure the durability of each partâ€™s coating.

Because the oven temperature remains fixed for a batch of painted parts, any variation among parts at the same temperature is captured by \(\sigma^2_S\) (split-plot error), whereas variation across different oven temperatures is captured by \(\sigma^2_W\) (whole-plot error).

title: Split-Plot ANOVA
text:
6.1 Manufacturing Example
Suppose you have:

Whole-Plot Factor: Furnace Temperature (\(800^\circ\)C vs.Â \(900^\circ\)C)
Split-Plot Factor: Gas Flow Rate (10, 20, 30 sccm)
Blocks: 4 furnace runs
Response: Film Thickness Uniformity


set.seed(123)
semi_data <- data.frame(
  run = rep(1:4, each = 6),
  temp = rep(rep(c("800C", "900C"), each = 3), 4),
  flow = rep(c("10", "20", "30"), times = 8),
  uniformity = rnorm(24,
    mean = rep(c(85, 90), each = 12) +
      rep(c(0, 2, 4), times = 8),
    sd = 2
  )
)

semi_model <- lmer(uniformity ~ temp * flow + (1 | run) + (1 | run:temp),
  data = semi_data
)

title: Split-Plot ANOVA
text:
6.2 Agricultural Example

Whole-Plot Factor: Irrigation Method (Drip, Sprinkler)
Split-Plot Factor: Fertilizer (None, Organic, Chemical)
Blocks: 6 fields
Response: Crop Yield


set.seed(456)
ag_data <- data.frame(
  field = rep(1:6, each = 6),
  irrigation = rep(rep(c("Drip", "Sprinkler"), each = 3), 6),
  fertilizer = rep(c("None", "Organic", "Chemical"), times = 12),
  yield = rnorm(36,
    mean = rep(c(40, 45), each = 18) +
      rep(c(0, 5, 8), times = 12),
    sd = 3
  )
)

ag_model <- lmer(
  yield ~ irrigation * fertilizer +
    (1 | field) + (1 | field:irrigation),
  data = ag_data
)

title: Split-Plot ANOVA
text:
7.1 Power Analysis
In split-plot designs, we have distinct power calculations for the whole-plot factor and the split-plot factor (Dean et al., 2017). Each factor is tested against a different error term.
\[
\text{Power}^*_{\text{whole-plot}} \quad=\quad P\bigl(F^*_{a-1,(b-1)(a-1)} > F_{\alpha;a-1,(b-1)(a-1)} \;\bigm|\; \delta\bigr),
\]
\[
\text{Power}^*_{\text{split-plot}} \quad=\quad P\bigl(F^*_{s-1,a(b-1)(s-1)} > F_{\alpha;s-1,a(b-1)(s-1)} \;\bigm|\; \delta\bigr).
\]

\(\delta\) represents the noncentrality parameter linked to the effect size.
Software such as pwr, simr, or custom code can be used to approximate power.

title: Split-Plot ANOVA
text:
7.2 Optimal Design Considerations
For large-scale experiments, cost constraints and logistical feasibility often dictate the chosen design structure (Kempthorne, 1977; Dean et al., 2017). Key elements include:

Balance: Achieving uniform replication across factor levels.
Resource Allocation: The ratio of whole-plot replicates to split-plot replicates.
Variance Component Estimates: Anticipating or pilot-testing \(\sigma_W^2\) and \(\sigma_S^2\) to inform design decisions.

title: Split-Plot ANOVA
text:
8.1 Pseudo-Replication
A critical error is to treat measurements within a single whole plot as fully independent replicates for the whole-plot factor. This leads to inflated Type I error rates and overly optimistic standard errors.
Incorrect:
# Failing to account for hierarchical structure
lm_model <- lm(yield ~ temp * flow, data = semi_data)
Correct:
# Using a mixed-effects model to capture nested variability
lmer_model <- lmer(uniformity ~ temp * flow + (1|run) + (1|run:temp),
                   data = semi_data)

title: Split-Plot ANOVA
text:
8.2 Unbalanced Data
Real-world settings often produce unbalanced data (missing cells, unequal replicates):

Use lmerTest for Satterthwaite or Kenward-Roger df approximations.
Examine residuals and leverage robust inference methods if necessary.


library(lmerTest)
unbalanced_data <- subset(semi_data, !(run == 4 & flow == "10")) # remove some observations
model_unbalanced <- lmer(
  uniformity ~ temp * flow +
    (1 | run) + (1 | run:temp),
  data = unbalanced_data
)
anova(model_unbalanced, ddf = "Satterthwaite")

title: Split-Plot ANOVA
text:
9.1 Medium-Difficulty Problems

Split-Plot Degrees of Freedom

A two-factor split-plot experiment has 3 whole-plot factor levels, 4 split-plot factor levels, and 3 blocks.

Calculate the df for the whole-plot factor.
Calculate the df for the split-plot error.
Explain why whole-plot and split-plot errors differ.


Model Formulation

Write down the full split-plot model with two factors (A, B) and one blocking factor (r blocks). Identify which terms belong to the whole-plot portion vs.Â the split-plot portion.

Interpreting lmer Output

Fit a split-plot model using the ag_data dataset.
Report which random effects are estimated and how they impact the F-tests for the main factors.

title: Split-Plot ANOVA
text:
9.2 Challenging Problems

Deriving Expected Mean Squares

Task: Show that \(E(MS_{whole}) = \sigma^2_S + s\sigma^2_W\).
Hint: Partition the sum of squares for the whole plot and use properties of the normal distribution.
Reference: See derivations in ScheffÃ© (1959) and Appendix A below.

Power Calculation

Suppose \(\sigma_W^2 = 15\) and \(\sigma_S^2 = 5\). You have 3 levels of a whole-plot factor (A) and 4 levels of a split-plot factor (B), with 3 replicates (blocks).
Task: Outline how you would simulate data in R to estimate the power to detect a particular effect size \(\delta\) on factor A.

Design Optimization

You have a cost function \(C = c_w n_w + c_s n_s\), and you want to keep the variance of \(\hat{\tau}*i - \hat{\tau}*{i'}\) below a threshold \(V_0\). Show how to derive the ratio \(n_w^* / n_s^*\) that minimizes cost subject to the variance constraint (Kempthorne, 1977).

title: Split-Plot ANOVA
text:
A.1 Expected Mean Squares
Using the notation in Dean et al.Â (2017) and ScheffÃ© (1959):
\[
\text{For a balanced split-plot design:}
\]

Whole-plot error:

\[
E(MS_{\text{whole}}) = \sigma^2_S + s\,\sigma^2_W.
\]

Split-plot error:

\[
E(MS_{\text{split}}) = \sigma^2_S.
\]
The derivation partitions sums of squares and leverages properties of normal distributions (see Christensen, 2018, for a modern ANOVA treatment).

title: Split-Plot ANOVA
section: A.2 Power Analysis for Whole-Plot Factor
text:
A.2 Power Analysis for Whole-Plot Factor
\[
\lambda \;=\; \frac{n_w \sum_{i=1}^a \tau_i^2}{a\,\sigma_W^2},
\]
where \(n_w\) is the number of whole-plot replicates, \(\tau_i\) are the treatment contrasts, and \(\sigma_W^2\) is the whole-plot variance. The power to detect a nonzero \(\tau_i\) at significance level \(\alpha\) becomes:
\[
1 - \beta \;=\; P\!\bigl(F_{a-1,(b-1)(a-1)} > F_{\alpha;a-1,(b-1)(a-1)} \;\bigm|\; \lambda\bigr).
\]

title: Split-Plot ANOVA
text:
A.3 Optimal Design Theory
Following Kempthorne (1977):
\[
\text{Minimize } C = c_w n_w + c_s n_s \quad \text{subject to }
Var(\hat{\tau}^*_i - \hat{\tau}^*_{i'}) \leq V_0.
\]
If \(\sigma_W^2\) and \(\sigma_S^2\) are known (or estimated from pilot data):
\[
n_w^* = \sqrt{\frac{c_s}{c_w}} \;\frac{\sigma_W}{\sigma_S}\;n_s^*.
\]
This balance ensures cost efficiency while meeting variance constraints.

Incorporating covariates into ANOVA
Adjusted treatment means
ANCOVA assumptions



Learning Objectives

Implement ANCOVA in R.
Interpret adjusted means and significance.
Apply ANCOVA in experimental studies.



Class Activities

Lecture: ANCOVA theory and application (Dean et al., Ch. 9, Sec. 9.1â€“9.4).
R Practical: Performing ANCOVA and interpreting results.
Discussion: Comparing ANCOVA to standard ANOVA.



Homework

Homework 9: ANCOVA Analysis (due Apr.Â 10).

title: ðŸ“„ Course Syllabus
text:
Course Description
This course provides a rigorous introduction to experimental design and analysis of variance (ANOVA) methodologies, with an emphasis on their integration into linear modeling frameworks. Topics include fundamental principles of experimental design (randomization, replication, and blocking), handling unbalanced data, diagnostics for model assumptions, and advanced designs such as split-plot, nested, and mixed-effects models. Students will develop skills in designing experiments, selecting appropriate statistical approaches, analyzing data using R, and communicating findings effectively.

title: ðŸ“„ Course Syllabus
text:
Learning Outcomes
By the end of this course, students will be able to:

Design experiments using principles of randomization, replication, and blocking.
Implement one-way, two-way, and higher-order factorial ANOVA techniques.
Analyze unbalanced data using modern statistical methods.
Conduct residual analysis, transformations, and diagnostics for model assumptions.
Perform multiple comparisons and construct contrasts for treatment effect interpretation.
Incorporate covariates into ANOVA frameworks through analysis of covariance (ANCOVA).
Apply advanced designs like row-column, nested, and split-plot experiments.
Utilize statistical software (e.g., R) to perform experimental analyses and generate reproducible workflows.

title: ðŸ“„ Course Syllabus
text:
Prerequisite
A prior course in statistics, such as STAT 440/550, is strongly recommended. Students without this background must meet with the instructor to discuss their preparation.

title: ðŸ“„ Course Syllabus
text:
Textbook And Software

Primary Textbook: Dean, A., Voss, D., & DraguljiÄ‡, D. (2017). Design and Analysis of Experiments. Springer.

Available as a free eBook for UNM students through the UNM Library. Use your UNM credentials to access it. The eBook formats are in PDF and EPUB.

Supplemental Textbooks
Libre Textbook from Penn State University: Analysis of Variance and Design of Experiments

This book privides an accessible introduction to the principles of experimental design and ANOVA. If you find the primary textbook challenging, this resource may offer additional support.

First version of Prof.Â Christensenâ€™s book from his UNM website

Note that this is an older (first) version of the book from Prod. Christensenâ€™s website. The book is available in PDF format.
An execellent R companion, which is freely available, to the book is R Companion to Applied Regression. 

Software:

Wickham, H., Ã‡etinkaya-Rundel, M., & Grolemund, G. (2023). R for data science: Import, tidy, transform, visualize, and model data (2nd edition). Oâ€™Reilly.
This book is available online for free and provides a comprehensive guide to using R for data analysis and visualization.
R (version 4.2 or higher), paired with RStudio, VS Code, or Positron, along with Quarto for reproducible workflows.
Key R packages: lm, emmeans, pwr, multcomp, lme4, and others as introduced during the course.
Cran Task View: Experimental Design and Analysis

This resource provides an overview of R packages for experimental design and analysis, including links to package documentation and tutorials.

Package daewr accompanies the book Design and Analysis of Experiments with R by Lawson (2014) and does not only provide data sets from the book but also some standalone functionality that is not available elsewhere in R, e.g.Â definitive screening designs.
Package agricolae is a package for statistical analysis of experimental designs.

Attendance Policy

Attendance Expectations

Mandatory Attendance: Students are expected to attend and actively participate in all class sessions to maximize learning and engagement with the course material.
Attendance Tracking: Attendance will be recorded at the start of every class session. It is the studentâ€™s responsibility to ensure they are marked present.
Accountability: Attendance is critical, as the course material is cumulative and often discussed interactively.



Attendance Limits and Drop Policy

Absence Limits:

Students may accumulate up to 4 unexcused absences (equivalent to 15% of the total 28 class sessions). Students with 5 or more unexcused absences may be subject to an administrative drop from the course.

Administrative Drop:

If a student exceeds the allowed 4 unexcused absences, they may be administratively dropped from the course.
Students dropped before the withdrawal deadline will receive a grade of â€œWâ€.
Students dropped after the withdrawal deadline may receive a grade of â€œFâ€, depending on their overall course performance and UNMâ€™s Grading Policies.




Excused vs.Â Unexcused Absences

Excused Absences: Absences may be excused if they meet the criteria outlined in the UNM Attendance Policy. Examples include:

University-sponsored activities (e.g., athletic or academic events).
Illness or medical emergencies (with appropriate documentation).
Personal emergencies (with prior approval when possible).

Unexcused Absences: Any absence that does not meet the criteria for excused absences will be considered unexcused.

Homework Submission Guidelines

Format and Template:
All homework assignments must be completed using the Quarto template provided on the course website. You are required to submit the rendered PDF version of the Quarto document. Failure to use the provided template or submit the correct format will result in point deductions.
Submission Platform:
Submit your completed assignments electronically through Canvas. Navigate to the â€œAssignmentsâ€ folder, click on the appropriate homework assignment, and attach your rendered PDF file.
Plagiarism Check:
All submitted assignments will be automatically checked for plagiarism by Canvas. Any instances of plagiarism or academic dishonesty will be handled in accordance with UNMâ€™s Student Code of Conduct and the Support in Receiving Help and Doing What is Right section outlined in this syllabus. Please familiarize yourself with the academic integrity policies detailed in the syllabus and on the UNM website. Ignorance of the policy is not an excuse for violations.
No Late Submissions Accepted:
All homework assignments are due by the specified deadline on Canvas. Late submissions will not be accepted under any circumstances. This policy is strict and applies to all students without exceptions.
Extra Credit Opportunity:
If you miss an assignment, you may compensate for it by earning extra credit as outlined in the syllabus. This provides an opportunity to recover points without requiring extensions or exceptions for missed deadlines.
Do Not Email About Late Assignments:
Please do not email me or the TA regarding missed or late homework submissions. We cannot make exceptions or accept late assignments under any conditions. Instead, focus on utilizing the extra credit opportunities provided in the syllabus.
Content Requirements:

All responses must be typed within the Quarto document.
If you include hand-written calculations or derivations, they must be scanned and appended to the Quarto document as an appendix before rendering the final PDF.

Independence:

Grading and Feedback:
Assignments will be graded and feedback will be provided through Canvas. Be sure to review comments and feedback promptly to address any misunderstandings before the next assignment.

Exam Guidelines

Question Types: Includes a combination of short-answer questions, computations, and application-based problems.

No Make-Up Exams Policy

Make-up exams will only be granted in cases of proven emergency that meet the criteria set forth by the Department of Mathematics and Statistics and UNM policies (e.g., documented medical emergencies, official university-sponsored activities, or other unavoidable situations as defined by university guidelines).
If you anticipate a potential conflict or emergency, you must notify the instructor in advance of the exam date whenever possible. Failure to do so will result in forfeiture of the opportunity to take a make-up exam.
For non-emergency situations, personal conflicts, or reasons outside of those outlined in this document (e.g., vacation, workload, or personal oversight), make-up exams will not be permitted.

In all cases, documentation must be provided as soon as possible and must align with UNMâ€™s student policies on academic integrity and attendance. For more information, consult the UNM Student Handbook.
Importance of Timely Notification
If you foresee a conflict or are unable to attend an exam due to an emergency, notify the instructor as early as possible. While advance notice does not guarantee a make-up exam, failing to provide notice will disqualify you from consideration for a make-up opportunity.
By adhering to this policy, we ensure fairness and consistency for all students while maintaining compliance with university guidelines. If you have further questions or concerns, please contact the instructor before the exam dates.

section: What to Expect and How to Study and Be Successful in This Course
text:
What to Expect and How to Study and Be Successful in This Course
This course is designed to be both rigorous and rewarding, equipping you with essential skills in experimental design and analysis of variance (ANOVA). Success in this course requires preparation, consistent effort, and active engagement with the material. Below are some key recommendations and expectations to help you succeed:
1. Expect to Invest Significant Time

Mastery of the material requires dedicated study time each week. Plan to spend at least 8-10 hours per week outside of class on:
Reading assigned materials.
Completing homework assignments.
Practicing statistical techniques in R.
Reviewing notes and working through practice problems.

2. Prioritize Class Attendance

Attendance is critical to your success in this course.
Classes are designed to build upon each other, with cumulative content.
Discussions, group activities, and real-time problem-solving in class will reinforce your understanding.
Historical data has shown that students who miss class sessions struggle to keep up with the material.
If you must miss a class, review the lecture notes and course materials promptly, and reach out to classmates for additional support.

3. Come Prepared for Every Class

Read the assigned materials before class:
Familiarize yourself with the key topics to be covered.
Jot down questions or areas of confusion to bring to class discussions.
Engage with supplemental materials like videos, tutorials, or examples provided on Canvas.
Stay organized by keeping track of due dates, reading assignments, and planned lectures using the course schedule.

4. Stay Active During Class

Take detailed notes during lectures and participate in discussions.
Actively engage in group activities. Collaborating with classmates helps deepen your understanding and clarifies difficult concepts.
Ask questions during class or post them on Canvas if you need further clarification.

5. Utilize Office Hours and Discussion Boards

Office hours are an excellent opportunity for one-on-one assistance with:
Understanding difficult concepts.
Reviewing homework problems.
Discussing your specific challenges with course material.
Use the Canvas Discussion Boards for peer-to-peer support and quick clarifications from the instructor or TA.

6. Practice Regularly

Mastery of statistical methods requires consistent practice.
Work through examples provided in class and additional exercises from the textbook.
Attempt problems in R to solidify your understanding of statistical tools and software.

7. Review and Revise

After each class, set aside time to:
Review your notes.
Summarize key concepts in your own words.
Attempt practice problems to apply what youâ€™ve learned.

8. Focus on Understanding, Not Memorization

This course emphasizes application and critical thinking.
Strive to understand the â€œwhyâ€ behind statistical techniques and experimental designs.
Apply concepts to real-world scenarios or examples from your own field of study.

9. Manage Your Time Wisely

Start assignments early to avoid last-minute stress.
Break down large tasks into smaller steps and set achievable goals for each study session.
Use tools like planners or digital calendars to track deadlines and manage your workload effectively.

10. Maintain a Growth Mindset

Statistics can be challenging, but persistence is key.
Embrace mistakes as part of the learning process.
Reach out for help early if youâ€™re struggling with a concept or assignment.

11. Make Use of the Resources Provided

The course provides several resources to support your learning:
A Quarto template for homework submissions.
Supplemental readings, videos, and tutorials.
Access to the course textbook through UNMâ€™s library system.
R and VS Code or RStudio (or equivalent IDEs) for conducting statistical analyses.

12. Avoid Falling Behind

Given the cumulative nature of this course, falling behind on one topic will make subsequent topics more difficult to grasp.
Stay on top of assignments and make reviewing previous material part of your weekly routine.

13. Academic Honesty and Collaboration

While collaboration is encouraged during study sessions or discussions, ensure all submitted work reflects your own understanding.
Familiarize yourself with the Support In Receiving Help and Doing What is Right section of the syllabus to avoid issues related to academic dishonesty.

By following these recommendations, staying engaged, and managing your time wisely, youâ€™ll position yourself for success in this course. Remember, learning statistics is a journey that requires consistent effort and a positive attitude. I am here to support you every step of the way, so donâ€™t hesitate to reach out for assistance.

title: Latin Square Design: Step-by-Step Worksheet
text: Below is a self-contained classroom handout illustrating step-by-step how to set up and analyze a Latin Square design, inspired by the ideas in Box, Hunter, and Hunter (â€œStatistics for Experimentersâ€) regarding experiments that must block on two factors in addition to comparing several treatments.

title: Latin Square Design: Step-by-Step Worksheet
text:
1. Context and Purpose
We want to compare four teaching methods (labeled A, B, C, D) for their effect on studentsâ€™ test scores. However, the teacher suspects that two other factors also cause variability:

Teacher differences. Four different teachers (labeled T1, T2, T3, T4) may have different baseline abilities or styles.
Classroom differences. Four classrooms (labeled R1, R2, R3, R4) may differ in environment, resources, or size.

We would like to â€œblockâ€ on both Teachers and Classrooms so that the primary comparison (A vs B vs C vs D) is not distorted by large differences among teachers or classrooms. A Latin Square layout ensures each treatment is tested once per teacher and once per classroom.

title: Latin Square Design: Step-by-Step Worksheet
text:
2. Layout of a 4Ã—4 Latin Square
A 4Ã—4 Latin Square ensures:

Each row represents one teacher (T1, T2, T3, T4).
Each column represents one classroom (R1, R2, R3, R4).
Each of the four treatments (A, B, C, D) appears exactly once in every row and once in every column.

An example random assignment is shown in the table below. (In practice, the row and column labels themselvesâ€”and the letter labels for the treatmentsâ€”are also randomized.)




R1
R2
R3
R4




T1
A
B
C
D


T2
B
C
D
A


T3
C
D
A
B


T4
D
A
B
C




Randomization Note: - We randomly label the rows (teachers T1â€“T4). - We randomly label the columns (classrooms R1â€“R4). - We randomly assign the letters (A, B, C, D) to the four teaching methods. - Then we fill the 4Ã—4 grid so that each letter appears exactly once per row and once per column.

title: Latin Square Design: Step-by-Step Worksheet
text:
3. Example Data

From this table, each entry is â€œthe average test scoreâ€ for that Teacherâ€“Classroom combination under the assigned teaching method. We can gather the raw data into a single 16â€“observation list if we wish, but it is easiest to keep it in this 4Ã—4 grid.
Letâ€™s label these responses by \(Y_{ij}\), where \(i\) indicates the teacher (row) and \(j\) indicates the classroom (column). Our grand average \(\bar{Y}\) is the mean of all 16 scores.

title: Latin Square Design: Step-by-Step Worksheet
text:
4. Model Assumptions
A Latin Square experiment typically uses an additive model:
\[
Y_{ij} \;=\; \mu \;+\; \theta_i \;+\; \phi_j \;+\; \tau_{k(i,j)} \;+\; \varepsilon_{ij}
\]

\(\mu\) = overall mean
\(\theta_i\) = effect of row \(i\) (e.g., teacher \(i\))
\(\phi_j\) = effect of column \(j\) (e.g., classroom \(j\))
\(\tau_{k(i,j)}\) = effect of whichever treatment \(k\) is assigned in row \(i\), column \(j\)
\(\varepsilon_{ij}\) = residual (â€œnoiseâ€) term

The design ensures each treatment \(\tau_k\) is replicated four times overall (once in each row and once in each column).

Key assumption: There is no strong interaction among teacher, classroom, and the treatment. In other words, the teacher and classroom merely â€œaddâ€ or â€œsubtractâ€ some baseline amount from the outcome. If strong interactions are suspected, a Latin Square is not appropriate.

title: Latin Square Design: Step-by-Step Worksheet
text:
5. The Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)
We decompose total variation into three parts:

Differences among rows (teachers).
Differences among columns (classrooms).
Differences among treatments (the four methods).
Residual â€œerrorâ€ (everything left over).


5.1 Step-by-Step Sums of Squares

Compute Grand Average (\(\bar{Y}\)):

\[
\bar{Y} \;=\; \frac{\text{sum of all 16 observations}}{16}.
\]
From the table above, adding all 16 values:
\[
82 + 88 + 85 + 83 \;+\; 79 + 87 + 81 + 80 \;+\; 84 + 89 + 82 + 86 \;+\; 81 + 78 + 80 + 83 \;=\; 1278.
\]
Hence,
\[
\bar{Y} = \frac{1278}{16} = 79.875.
\]
(Rounded as needed; weâ€™ll carry decimals through for demonstration.)

Row (Teacher) Means: We already have row means from the table, e.g.Â for T1,

\[
\bar{Y}_{\text{row }1} \;=\; \frac{82 + 88 + 85 + 83}{4} = 84.5.
\]
Similarly for T2, T3, T4.

Column (Classroom) Means: We also have them from the table, e.g.Â for R1,

\[
\bar{Y}_{\text{col }1} = \frac{82 + 79 + 84 + 81}{4} = 81.5.
\]

Treatment Means: Gather the four observations corresponding to each treatment (A, B, C, D). For example, treatment A appears in (T1,R1), (T2,R4), (T3,R3), (T4,R2) in our table. Compute its mean from those 4 data points. Repeat for B, C, D.
Sums of Squares:

Total Sum of Squares (SST), relative to the grand mean:


\[
\text{SST} \;=\; \sum_{i=1}^4 \sum_{j=1}^4 \left(Y_{ij} - \bar{Y}\right)^2.
\]

Row (Teacher) Sum of Squares:

\[
\text{SS}_{\text{Rows}} \;=\; 4 \,\sum_{i=1}^4 \left(\bar{Y}_{\text{row } i} - \bar{Y}\right)^2.
\]
 (Multiply by 4 because each row mean is based on 4 observations.)

Column (Classroom) Sum of Squares:

\[
\text{SS}_{\text{Columns}} \;=\; 4 \,\sum_{j=1}^4 \left(\bar{Y}_{\text{col } j} - \bar{Y}\right)^2.
\]

Treatment Sum of Squares:

\[
\text{SS}_{\text{Treat}} \;=\; 4 \,\sum_{k=A,B,C,D} \left(\bar{Y}_{k} - \bar{Y}\right)^2.
\]
 (Again, each treatment mean is based on 4 observations in a 4Ã—4 square.)

Residual Sum of Squares:

\[
\text{SS}_{\text{Error}} \;=\; \text{SST} \;-\; \text{SS}_{\text{Rows}} \;-\; \text{SS}_{\text{Columns}} \;-\; \text{SS}_{\text{Treat}}.
\]


5.2 Degrees of Freedom

Total: \(16 - 1 = 15\).
Rows: \(4 - 1 = 3\).
Columns: \(4 - 1 = 3\).
Treatments: \(4 - 1 = 3\).
Residual: \(15 - (3+3+3) = 6\).



5.3 Mean Squares and the F-Ratios

Mean Square for Rows:

\[
\text{MS}_{\text{Rows}} = \frac{\text{SS}_{\text{Rows}}}{3}.
\]

Mean Square for Columns:

\[
\text{MS}_{\text{Columns}} = \frac{\text{SS}_{\text{Columns}}}{3}.
\]

Mean Square for Treatments:

\[
\text{MS}_{\text{Treat}} = \frac{\text{SS}_{\text{Treat}}}{3}.
\]

Residual Mean Square:

\[
\text{MS}_{\text{Error}} = \frac{\text{SS}_{\text{Error}}}{6}.
\]
We then test for significance:

Rows vs.Â Error: \(F_{\text{Rows}} = \frac{\text{MS}_{\text{Rows}}}{\text{MS}_{\text{Error}}}\).
Columns vs.Â Error: \(F_{\text{Columns}} = \frac{\text{MS}_{\text{Columns}}}{\text{MS}_{\text{Error}}}\).
Treatments vs.Â Error: \(F_{\text{Treat}} = \frac{\text{MS}_{\text{Treat}}}{\text{MS}_{\text{Error}}}\).

Each ratio follows (approximately) an \(F\)-distribution with appropriate degrees of freedom (numerator df = 3, denominator df = 6 in each case), so we can check standard \(F\) tables or software to see if the ratio is large enough to claim statistical significance.

We see that Treatments might be significant at around the 3% level, meaning there is evidence that at least one method (A, B, C, or D) differs from the others.
Rows (teachers) may also be significant at around 5%.
Columns (classrooms) are not as strongly significant but still borderline.
The conclusion might be that the teaching methods do affect student test scores, with teacher differences also playing a role.

title: Latin Square Design: Step-by-Step Worksheet
text:
7. Graphical ANOVA (Optional)
To complement the ANOVA table, we can create a Graphical ANOVA:

Plot the row effects (teacher means minus grand mean) on a dot chart scaled so that the â€œnoiseâ€ is visually comparable.
Plot the column effects (classroom means minus grand mean).
Plot the treatment effects (method means minus grand mean).
Plot the residuals.

If the spread of points for â€œTreatmentsâ€ is obviously bigger than the residual spread, that visually supports that treatments matter. Meanwhile, if row or column spreads are large, that tells us there really are teacher or classroom blocks that differ.

title: Latin Square Design: Step-by-Step Worksheet
text:
8. Practical Advice and Interpretation

Check Residuals: Make sure there are no severe outliers or strong patterns that hint at non-constant variance or a need for transformation (e.g.Â log-transform).
Check Interactions: A Latin Square works best when row and column factors do not strongly interact with the treatments. If you see suspicious patterns, consider alternative designs.
Replications: Often, people replicate the entire Latin Square more than once if they can afford extra runs. That increases residual degrees of freedom.
Conclusions: If the â€œTreatmentsâ€ \(F\)-ratio is large (small p-value), we conclude at least one of the methods differs significantly. Follow-up comparisons (like pairwise t-tests with error MS) can clarify which specific method is better.

title: Latin Square Design: Step-by-Step Worksheet
text:
9. Step-by-Step Summary for Students

Plan and Randomize

Assign each â€œrowâ€ factor (Teacher T1â€“T4) at random.
Assign each â€œcolumnâ€ factor (Classroom R1â€“R4) at random.
Randomly assign treatments (A, B, C, D) so each appears once per row/column.

Collect Data

Fill in the 4Ã—4 data grid with the response measured in each cell.

Compute Averages

Grand Mean = sum of all 16 responses / 16.
Row Means = average for each teacher.
Column Means = average for each classroom.
Treatment Means = average across the 4 cells that use that treatment.

ANOVA Calculations

Total SS: sum of squared deviations from grand mean.
Row SS: multiply 4 by the sum of squared deviations of row means from grand mean.
Column SS: multiply 4 by sum of squared deviations of column means from grand mean.
Treatment SS: multiply 4 by sum of squared deviations of treatment means from grand mean.
Residual SS: difference = Total SSâ€“(Row + Column + Treatment SS).

Degrees of Freedom

Total df = 16â€“1 = 15.
Each of the row, column, and treatment sources has 3 df.
Residual df = 15â€“(3+3+3) = 6.

Mean Squares and F-Tests

MS = SS / df.
\(F = \frac{\text{MS}_{\text{Factor}}}{\text{MS}_{\text{Error}}}\).
Compare each \(F\)-value to the \(F\)-distribution with (3,6) df to see if it is large enough to be significant.

Interpret Results

Identify whether row or column blocking was significant.
Check if treatments differ significantly.
Present a final conclusion and any potential next steps (e.g., further studies, transformations, or different design if strong interactions are suspected).

title: Latin Square Design: Step-by-Step Worksheet
text:
10. Final Remarks
A Latin Square design:

Blocks out two known sources of variation (rows and columns).
Tests a single primary factor of interest (the treatment).
Is valid under randomization (rows, columns, and treatments all randomized).
Is straightforward to analyze with a standard ANOVA and standard software.

This example helps students see:

How to construct a Latin Square.
Why it is effective at removing large, unwanted variability in two directions (rows & columns).
How to perform step-by-step calculations of the sums of squares, degrees of freedom, and F-ratios.



References and Further Reading

Box, G.E.P., Hunter, J.S., and Hunter, W.G. Statistics for Experimenters: Design, Innovation, and Discovery (2nd ed.).
Chapters on â€œComparing Several Treatments: Blocks and Latin Squares,â€ which illustrate the general analysis of variance principle for multi-way blocking designs.
